text: Got a to-go order on a very cold Sunday afternoon in March. I ordered a Hot N Sour Soup, a 4pc Crab Rangoon, and the House Special (Beef, Pork, Chicken, & Shrimp) Lo Mein. The Hot N Sour Soup and the Crab Rangoon were both adequate and typical of any strip mall carryout Chinese place. The Lo Mein was probably the worst I've ever had. The noodles were overcooked and tasteless. The beef was stringy. The pork appeared to be reddish in an alarmingly undercooked way. I took literally two bites of this and threw it away. I would never go back.

Travel Tip:  Find out about the best local eateries from your Lyft or Uber drivers.

One of the suggestions from our kind and "Uber" friendly driver (see how I did that? Lol) was Drago's.  He proclaimed they had the best charbroiled oysters, and he told no lies.  The piping hot oysters arrived at the table crusted with Parmesan cheese on top, and swimming in butter.  I grabbed a piece of French bread, gave my best somersault tuck, and dove in!  So rich and flavorful, just sublime.  The spinach dip was tasty as well, but the oysters are a must.

This has become the restaurant I most often frequent in Chinatown. Not fancy, but a good selection of authentic Taiwanese food (as visiting friends from Taiwan always note). It's nice to eat at the restaurant (staff very friendly and very child friendly) and also good for takeout. So far I've had nothing bad on the menu (3 cup chicken, scallion pancakes and fried rice very good). Looking forward to trying a whole fish next time I dine in.

Best Mexican food available on Purdue University! Burritos as big as your head! Burritos, tacos or tortas... You can't lose! Ask for their extra hot sauce behind the counter.  Yummy yummy! Came across this location by accident during a blizzard and it was a pleasant oasis of flavor.

We went right before Christmas and enjoyed many of the holiday flavors on "tap". The plain tart yogurt is still my fave, but the red velvet is pretty yummy too. Can't say that it tastes anything like the real thing, but who cares. I have been won over by its artificially colored and unidentified flavor.

I learned my lesson last time and didn't load up with toppings which seem to be what tips the scale in the price department, especially the fruit which makes sense. My husband being the "frugal" person he is likes to load up on the plain tart and take it to go... once at home he adds his own toppings. 

As an added bonus we took my mother-in-law on a Monday and she got a $1 off her order. They have other great specials for teachers and active duty military, police, etc. You gotta respect local businesses who take care of their locals!

Desided to come back here for the second time on Mother's Day. When first arriving. I noticed outside there are a lot of Hornets. please be careful you don't get  stung buy one. macaroni and Grill needs to get some kind of an exterminator out to get rid of them. 

When I walked in I had reservations. And was seated asap, but it was not that packed so I can only guess that maybe I really didn't need to make reservations. but it was Mother's Day so you would expect them to be packed. Better to be safe then sorry. 

After seated, was asked what we would like to drink. I got there peach iced tea. which is very good. And they brought the good bread and oil on a plate to dip the bread in for a little snack. So so good. 

 I wound up ordering the buffalo chicken parmesan with spaghetti with blue cheese and celery mixed in the spaghetti, yes and it was good. The sauce on the chicken parm had a little kick to it. just how I like it. And got a Caesar salad on the side for an extra $2.99. but the Caesar salad was small. Could have gave me a bigger salad, it's not your typical salad. most places that's much bigger and most of the lettuce in the salad Was chunks on the bottom. 

Overall everything was good. except the service could have been a little bit better. especially at the time I was there it was not that busy.
Crawfish duo was great, and the food here reminds why Cajun food is absolutely incredible. Wish we had this caliber in SF..

We had to try a philly cheesesteak before going back to NYC, so we headed on over to Sonny's. I ordered the loaded cheesesteak sandwich which comes with peppers and onions & cheez whiz as my choice of cheese. Hands down, one of the best cheesesteak sandwich I ever had. It's not oily greasy and it just simply hits the spot. Definitely give this place a try!

Great location right at the marina and steps from our hotel. We just had beer since they don't serve mixed drinks. Some weird Florida law reduces the number of full service bars. Also they wouldn't let us put tables together for our big group - what law covers that topic??

Anyway a typical waterfront joint with a good view. Nothing special but it was convenient.

Heard this place had great ice cream so we stopped by to taste. I tried the strawberry and the churro flavors. I have to give this place a thumbs up for forcing us to always buy 2 scoops and for making super creative flavors. The churro was excellent! Very strong cinnamon taste, kind of like horchata. The strawberry was pretty standard. The ice cream is just okay for me. The texture is not thick and creamy like cowabunga creamery or jp licks. The variety of flavors is nice but that's pretty much the novelty of this place.

OK - let me say I love El Vez, and have been a fan since they converted it over from Pasion years back. Unfortunately, this old lady is starting to show her grey hair and really needs some retooling. 

Blood Orange margaritas have been the sad draw here forever. Heck even Copa has like a dozen these days, how about rotating a few new flavors. Great on the new Guacamole selections, but it shouldn't have been at the expense of the salsa. Manchego still rules, but the cactus and crab is way too oily, and the citrus tuna one was unavailable last time I was in (seriously - unavailable? someone forgot to shop?) 

The other downturn is with the fajitas. The old presentation sent them out to the table steaming and sputtering. A lot of show? Of course, but that smell. I'd order them and in five minutes three others would too. These day's they're tasty, but the mystique of that lovely sizzli smoke is nowhere to be found. 

Yeah, they have lots of tequila. Yay. I'm a Negro Modela man myself, so I'm content there. Black bass taco's and Mahi-Mahi tacos shouldn't be missed - simply delicious. 

But not a lot to rave about. It's the same old concept with retreaded salsa, and not a whole bunch like they used to have, with a few new guacamole's. I agree if it's broke don't fix it, but come on guys - you're a Starr joint, run some seasonal offerings through or some new specials or something. You're food's good, we're just bored with the same old dishes! 

And telling us you can't get the sizzling grills is just absurd. I can google them up on the net in about 4.3 seconds - spend some cash and get the right ones back in!

In true foody fashion, after I went and grubbed out on a Village Whiskey foie gras burger, I had to come here and get ... another burger. Because why? Because I LOVE Shake Shack!

I didn't even know they had Shake Shack in Philly, so when I passed by it after dinner I had to go in. I dragged my entire entourage of now 8 people to come with me, and also convinced them to have burgers because they had never tried it before even though they live in Philly.

O.M.G.

Sorry but I love Shake Shack. I think it's way better than In n' Out (I might get massively flamed for this ... ) and I loved it here with no exceptions. Just talking about it makes me miss it :(!

"Where shopping is a pleasure!" Only do my main grocery shopping here! Cleanest, spacious, friendly, and they have everything you need, why would you shop anywhere else?! 

Produce is always fresh and they have a large organic section :) The guys at the seafood counter are always awesome, and the sushi is so good! 

Checkout is speedy and the variety of foods and brands is endless. The bakery always does a great job and I use them for several special occasions. I can't imagine shopping anywhere else.

Sonic is one of my favorites!!!! The chili cheese dog and their corn dogs. Yesssss please and thank you!  Oh my as I'm writing this I'm wanting it.  Ok I'm getting off track thinking of the yummy foot long hot dog with chili all over it..... raw onions.... mmmmm mustard and cheeseeeeee.....

Ok lemme stop . Get back on track girl. 

The food here is always good. Staff is nice.  Sometimes they are out of things like unsweetened tea when I order it. I mean how so?  How can you be out of unsweet tea. It's basically brown water lol I don't feel complete without my unsweet tea.  That's my only complaint. Don't run outta the tea! Geesh. 

But overall this is a good location so when in the area stop and get my favorite chili cheese hot dog and bring me one lol.

We sat at the outdoor seating close to the beach. The View was beautiful because it's the beach, what's not to like? However, the service was extremely slow... The server was somewhat attentive for our large party, but it took forever to get our dinner. 

Meanwhile, A storm was starting to come in with dark clouds and the winds picked up. The staff was very aware and were ready to move us if we needed it. Fortunately, we did not have to move. We finally got our dinner. Most of us were OK with what they ordered, but were so hungry by that time. We just ate. 

I ordered the Seafood Trio appetizer. The plate consisted of (3) blackened scallops with a reduction sauce, a scoop of fish bread, and two shrimp with cocktail sauce. First were the shrimp .... Just OK... Not hard to mess up (2) boiled shrimp, but the cocktail sauce was prepackaged. Second, the fish bread was OK, I've definitely had better. I asked to substitute cucumbers slices, instead of crackers. Lastly, were the scallops... They were supposed to be blackened with some type of reduction sauce. The seasoning was so salty, it was not good. By that point, we had waited so long, I knew it would take forever if I sent it back. I drank a ton of water because it was so salty. No one ever asked if the food was ok. Unfortunately, would not recommend.

The salad bar is something a girlfriend and I crave! Worth the money because it has everything you could want on it including but not limited to- pasta salad, granola, yogurt, muffins, crispy breads ect.  The soft serve is a delicious touch!

been here several times.. but today was my first time trying their signature braised beef noodle soup (红烧牛肉面) it was out of this world!  not only did it really hit the spot for me! but it was definitely my favorite beef noodle bowl so far!  i ordered it on a whim actually lol wanting to try something different.. and it was one of the items on top of the menu, so it must be good right? 

when they served it, i had no idea it was going to be spicy! all the red peppers in the bowl were pretty intimidating.. i started to sweat just from seeing the red peppers and red chili oil everywhere o-o.  luckily, the heat was very manageable! (thank god) i tend to look like i'm crying when the spice level is off the radar so i didn't want to make a scene at one of my regular lunch spots lol

but yes i do recommend trying this! the beef was yummy with the slow cooked radish.  there was plenty of noodles in my bowl.  it took quite the effort for me to finish my lunch today. i was holding my belly walking out nan zhou...  so all in all, lunch-- well served! can't wait to return for another round!
3 stars because this is the original and it is an OK place to stop for a beer. The food is pretty mediocre in my opinion. I just never liked anything on the menu.

So many choices! Right now our favorite Is the hot cider, and the cold brew with maple infused foam. Yummy!! 
As long as you wear a mask you can step right up to the window and order your goodies. 
Blueberry muffins is a must in the mornings but don't miss out on the many lunch opportunities as well. Very happy to have this convenient coffee place in the neighborhood.
They have also extended their outdoor seating in case you like to rest your feet with your coffee.

I have family who live close to Is-a-bella and so I'm no stranger to her ways. Never have been crazy about the pizza and the cheese steaks have been so wildly inconsistent in most recent memory that I have put a personal kibosh on making that move again anytime soon...

...but I'll tell you what's what...

 The "Bella Special Hoagie," is a real good sandwich. Every time. 

The Bella Special is delicious with all its sopressata, capicolla, prosciutto, roasted red peppers, and sharp provolone, topped with just some tomato slices and olive oil on sesame-seeded Italian roll. Get that if you're goin.

Bella Special Hoagie, ya never done me wrong. I ain't mad atcha.

Nothing really special here.
Gluten free options are handy for some.
Ok food.
Ok atmosphere...
Ok service.
If you've had your fill of BP's and the Olive Garden...it's on a comparable plain.

This place is ok in a pinch. Why only in a pinch? Well, with Trader Joes and Aldi springing up everywhere it's easy to see that even Hannaford store brand stuff isn't the right price, or any better quality than the cheap stuff. Why such a disconnect? Why is it so difficult to compete? Well one tip for this place, is that they hide large sale bins in the back near the restrooms if you need a brief escape from the small, $8.00 bags of trail mix. There are a few finds in there, sometimes utensils, sometimes soups, sometimes matzo ball mix. Is it worth having to shop in a bathroom hallway? Probably not.

Four words: Peking Style Pork Chops. Order this, and it doesn't even matter what else you get! #noregrets It is the perfect combo of sweet and salty, crispy and tender. One day, I ordered this as I was eating in the restaurant and I felt sad we didn't have enough for leftovers the next day, SO I WENT BACK and got another order the next day! Mind you, I live thirty minutes away. That alone should speak to the deliciousness of these Peking Style Pork Chops. 

Other things that I've ordered that are delicious: the house tofu, the seafood tofu claypot, the Singapore Chow Mein, the Walnut Shrimp, and the Blackened Steak. Almost all the veg options are great too- pretty standard sautéed Chinese vegetables. 

Dishes to pass on: anything with their duck, the noodle soups, and sautéed string beans. The sautéed string beans are sometimes are miss because the string beans are old, causing the dish to be less than ideal. I'm pretty sure they don't have a legit roaster because their duck is always lacking, no matter if it's in the duck noodle soup or the plain roasted duck. Hard pass. The noodle soups are fine, but rather lackluster. If you're seriously craving, go ahead, but I hope you won't be disappointed like I was! 

Note that this is a Mandarin-speaking Chinese establishment, meaning that a lot of the dishes like wonton noodle soup (HK most well-known for this) will not be as tasty. That said, I always leave Little Chinatown satisfied. It's absolutely worth the thirty minute drive!

Outrageously good beer, great food, and super friendly people.  I've been going here off and on for years, and even after moving to the West Coast and then coming back for just a quick visit, they still remember me, my beer, and my favorite sandwich.  I wish I could live in this place.

Now THIS is a 5 star lunch spot! Clean and freshly prepared mediterranean food in a clean and spacious dining area is heaven on earth for a ravenous law student who just emerged from a 5 hour exam. 

I dined in around 2 pm on a Saturday and tactfully avoided the insane lunch rush of the professionals on Market Street. Verts is a "build your own" set-up and I ordered a chicken over rice bowl adorned with an array of colorful vegetables. It was delicious and the portion size is massive; expect leftovers! 

I also ordered a side of fries, which an employee fried when I ordered it and he brought it to my table PIPING HOT and crispy. What a gentleman! The fries were lightly seasoned with red pepper powder (I'm not sure exactly what it was...) that had a unique and tangy flavor. A+.

The price is also very reasonable. For a massive rice bowl, it was $8.50 and the fries were $2.50. I will definitely be back to try the tasty looking chips and hummus side!

The food is so simple, but so tasty. In this chaotic world, that's really all we can ask for.

Excellent carry out experience during stage 2 of the pandemic.  Ordered on-line, which was quick and painless.  Order was ready in 30 minutes, as promised.  Pulled up out front, walked in the door just a few feet where I was greeted by two friendly, helpful staff members who immediately confirmed and retrieved my order.  After a quick 6  minute drive home, we were dining on some of the tastiest Thai food in town.  The Tom Kah soup was delicious, and spicy enough at "medium"  to make my eyes water.  The cashew chicken was perfect.  Loaded with chicken, veggies and cashews.  My date usually chooses pad see ew, but since SukhoThai doesn't offer that particular noodle dish, opted for the drunken noodles.  She gave them 3-stars.  All in all, a great meal on Covid date night!

I admit, I didn't participate in the ropes course.  However, the middle school kids loved it!  This was their second time here... first time was in the day, this time was in the dark on the lit up course.  No one had a negative thing to say.  We will definitely be back.  The staff was great.

While I'm in the loop for Thai Food, I'm usually pretty loyal to the one around the corner. But tonight - I wanted to try something different. I also really wanted drunken noodles - the wide flat noodles, in which the other establish does not have. 

Pros:
1) Interior is more traditional and surprisingly pretty nice inside.
2) Won like a best STL Thai award in 2014!!
3) Drunken noodles is spot on and not greasy

Cons:
1) Tom Yum Soup. It's good, but it's has a lot of fish sauce. If you are not use to heavy fish sauce and a red Tom Yum with a more sour than sweet. This won't be for you. I prefer my Tom Yum from around the corner.
2) Pricing is slightly (but only very slightly more expensive than the others)

However, I am a believer that there are other amazing thai options in the area. I will def. eat in here and take advantage of the full menu next time!

On a mission to indulge the cravings... 

I haven't seen a Twistee Treat in a long while.  I love their soft ice cream. 
This time I tried the Pistachio yogurt on a cake cone.
As expected - totally deeeelish!

My first ever Sonic experience...

A faux modern drive-in of sorts!? brilliant. Let us all forget the food is still dangerously unhealthy because someone brings it OUT to the car!

Happy hour without booze? Only if your slushies and shakes ROCK. And they do, so half off at Happy Hour. nice. 

My toaster, perfect. My companions ate a myriad of chili cheese dogs with random accompaniments. All eaten in our car, on a breezy evening in Louisiana...

Not bad. Not bad at all...

Absolutely wonderful! From the service to the fantastic view to the fabulous dinner, I was thrilled with my experience at Ocean Hai. Located in Clearwater Beach at the brand new Wyndham Hotel, the restaurant is a must for any special occasion, or if you are just in a mood for great food. We came on a Saturday evening, hoping that we wouldn't need to wait that long. To our surprise, there was no wait. We were greeted by our hostess who sat us down immediately . I have to mention that every seat in this restaurant had a great view so you won't be disappointed in where you sit.  Our waitress promptly greeted us and asked us for our drink orders, she also gave us the specials. What I enjoyed was that she actually gave the price of each individual dish. 
Now, to the food. We decided to order two sushi rolls and the Chinese meatballs. We got the Yamada and Hai Roll. The Yamada had yellowfin tuna on top and in the roll it had a stone crab. The roll had lemon zest in it and it was paired off with a lemon mayo. The Hai Roll was my favorite, it was a lobster salad roll and it was topped with beef carpaccio and truffles. Yes, I said truffles. The only thing that was disappointing was that I had to share it.  The meatballs were your basic pork meatballs, kicked up a notch with a hoisin sauce and Serrano peppers. Yum! 
Everything was wonderful and I can't wait to go back and try the thai mussels and the pork tenderloin.

Bright, clean & fairly new Save On.

Save On has a couple perks that keep me popping in like Daryl's Deal of the Week - think high end loss leader and often an excellent cut of meat from the butcher block.

Another lovely thing about Save On is that they will give kiddos a free piece of fruit in lieu of the standard bakery cookie - love this!

They have an Save On Rewards cats for deals and points accumulation that thankfully the cashier can lookup with your phone number once registered (one less card to carry around and lose).

You need to know your price points when shopping here - there are deals to be had but many, many items are $1, $2, or even $3 more than what you find at Superstore. 

The washrooms at this location are located up front next to customer service - and I had to chuckle because the ladies was long like a bowling lane & there was a change table for wee ones :-)

Two thumbs up :-)

PS If you're on the hut for Halo Top, you'll find it here.

Oops.  I don't know how I've let it come this long without reviewing this place.  I have been coming here since opening week and I've probably eaten here 10-12 times.  I would recommend this to anyone looking for a quick bite around the Carmel area.  The line tends to be long but they move people very quickly as they are very efficient in creating your meal.


Think Chipotle, Moe's or Qdoba but with Italian food.  


Piada - Think burrito
Noodle bowl - Think rice bowl
Salad Bowl - Think...umm salad bowl

They have a few side items you can order as well to accent your meal such as a Piada Stick which is basically a Piada wrap covered in oil and heated up with cheese on it until it melts.  It is as delicious and unhealthy as it sounds.  I think ONE of the sicks comes in at a whopping 500 calories.  Absurd.


You choose your meat which are delicious but very high in calories unfortunately.  (I believe they cook things in massive oil)

You follow that up with veggies. (Soooo many choices, make sure to get pancetta)

You follow that up with a sauce or dressing (depending on salad or piada/pasta)

You then pay at the other end of the counter and off you go.  Fast Casual as it is meant to be.

I can't give this place 5 stars as I reserve that for places that blow my socks off, and I am not quite happy with the calorie counts at this place but I fully like this place enough to work it into my lunch rotation.

I believe this place is newly opened.  I bought the hot stone massage on special with Groupon.  At this point, I won't try a spa service without a Groupon or LivingSocial deal because they are so hit or miss on spa treatments in Indy.

I liked my hot stone massage, but it was different than I have been used to.  That isn't bad...just different and the jury is still out on whether or not I really liked it.  

Kind of an odd set up.  The massage rooms were downstairs and you can hear people walking around upstairs...not entirely restul, but that wasn't a deal breaker.  The hot stones appeared to be out in the hallway because my massage therapist kept leaving the room to get more hot stones.  

At some points, I had to ask her to go a little easy with them since I didn't want 2nd and 3rd degree burns...I have no idea how she could hold onto them!  I usually like all things hot, but these were almost too hot.  But she was careful to listen to me and adjusted the amount of exposure to my skin.

The entire hour was spent face down...which was different and no massage at all of my arms...which was odd.  Again, the jury's out on whether or not this was a good massage for me.

I do plan on coming back for their one hour foot reflexology for $29...a good run for Foot Finesse's money since I refuse to go back to Foot Finesse because of their practice of ignoring appointments.

I like that Pastel Spa is walkable from my home...but after an hour of hedonism...I'm not sure I want to walk home :-)

I'll be back...and hope to upgrade them a star or two.

Stopped by after a rainy day at the beach for the chance to sample more of the places right on the beach. The name of the place didn't entice me, but the outdoor seating was something that I wanted to experience so we dropped in. 

I ordered the chicken quesadilla and it was actually HUGE and delicious. For 10, you really can't go wrong with this beach eat. My companions had the BLT salad and she-crab soup and an order of king crab legs. I tried the crab legs and they were excellent. 

The one snafu of our time at Cooter's was a visit from "Rufus" and a few of his friends (i.e., a large Florida roach). I get that it's outside, in Florida, after a rainstorm, but when one of these guys starts crawling up your leg it makes for a it of creepy crawly feeling for the rest of the evening. The wait staff was kind enough to help us shoo them away from our table so I am assuming that this experience is commonplace. 

After dinner we retreated to the sports bar area to have a happy hour drink. 3 drinks for under 7 dollars was perfect for us. Highly recommend the happy hour in what is surely the Pittsburgh Steelers bar of Clearwater, FL.

I tried Pho Quyen again after a disappointing first experience.  It has mostly redeemed itself.

The first time I went to Pho Quyen, I tried the Bun with pork and egg roll.  I found the sauce to be heavy on the fish sauce, and I did not enjoy the experience.

This time, I tried the combination Pho, and I found it very satisfying after doctoring it up with a little sriracha and a heavy amount of basil (and some lime).  The broth was beefy, and I enjoyed the quality of the tendon used.  The different cuts of beef were all quite good and not tough.  

The young coconut juice was very refreshing.

Service is only okay, but I don't expect much.

Prices were on the high side for pho.  I guess these are Temple Terrace prices.  I have a feeling that pho at any of the Vietnamese places on Waters would be much more reasonable.

There's a new sheriff, eh chef at West End Grill & Pub (WEGAP) and her name is Liz Shuster.  Name sounds familiar?  She was the brains behind Tenacious Eats.  I am so glad that she landed here because not only is she a great chef, she's also very innovative.  She already has plans for the Royal Wedding day starting at 5:00 a.m. at WEGAP.

We shared the fried cauliflower while we looked over the special board.  A soup, pasta, boil and tacos.  We actually wanted to try each one but we settled on the crawdad boil for him and the bucatini (pasta that looks like spaghetti but is thicker and has a hole running through it) and meatballs in a pomodoro sauce.  The crawfish boil was a true spicy crawdad boil along with sausage, corn and potatoes.  I got to try it and it was delicious.  My pasta was outstanding and I wish I could have eaten all of it.  I can't wait until it's on the menu again.  Don't forget to check out their trivia night and wine Wednesdays along with other special nights.

Would I come back here?  I can't wait.  And that's the way it is.

Wow, great sushi and they deliver! Wifey and I wanted sushi, but didn't want to walk in the cold to get it. I had been driving by Kansai for months since we moved to the area, but never got the opportunity to stop in. They have a well rounded menu of rolls, entrees, dinner boxes and appetizers. the prices are spot on with any other sushi place you'd go. We ordered the gyoza ($6), a Philly roll ($6), and two Godzilla rolls. ($11 each). The Godzilla roll was very good, it was filled with fresh tasting tuna, crab, avocado, deep fried, then covered in roe and spicy mayo. It came with 8 large pieces, very good rool. The Philly roll was done right, they didn't skimp on the fish which is nice. the gyoza were also good, albeit cold by the time they arrived. Next time, I may give one of tghe dinner boxes or an entree a try. Overall, solid spot for japanese/sushi in the area, and bonus they deliver!

Good eats for cheap! I'm definitely a fan of their hand-drawn noodle soup :9* It's a smaller hole-in-the-wall type of place, and you might end up sitting really close to your neighbors or sharing a table, but the noodles are so worth it. 

If you get a view of the kitchen you can see them stretching the noodles out by hand or shaving it into the woks/pots. The hand-drawn noodles seem never-ending and they're the right consistency. The pickled mustard greens in the broth add a nice touch. 

Simple and delicious. (And cash only.)

i'm gonna go out on a limb here and say that this is some of the most banal dim sum i've ever had. when you've had the opportunity to eat dim sum from some of the most authentic chinese restaurants all over the world, places like ocean harbor fall kinda flat. compared to its neighbors, though, your best bet is probably here.

in my opinion, there's a limited selection of dishes that come out on the carts. i feel like it's always the same shumai, shrimp dumplings, pork ribs, chicken feet, steamed buns etc. what about the fried taro cake or pineapple bun or shrimp ho fun? they have most of these things, but you have to specifically ask for it. doesn't that take away from the concept of dim sum on carts?

i will say, though, that when i'm suffering from socal withdrawal and missing the hustle and bustle of a cantonese restaurant, coming in here gives me that reassuring feeling of being in a B or C rated chinese restaurant (the best kind! A = bad in the world of authentic chinese dining). something about the cantonese/mandarin chattering all around me is very comforting.

in the grand scheme of dim sum restaurants, the prices here are kind of expensive. still cheap.. just.. more expensive than most. wait times during weekend lunch hours can take up to an hour, but that's pretty standard for any dim sum restaurant. if you wanna avoid the rush, go before 11am. 

service is so-so, but that's also standard of most chinese restaurants. in fact, it could be much worse. at the end of the meal, you have to take your stamp card up to the cashier desk yourself and pay. kind of atypical, but much faster than waiting for shoddy service to ring up your bill and bring it to your table.

Okay. I LOVE these guys. They are absolutely professional, friendly, and reliable. 

I was scramming to find a moving company for my move from Philly to DC and called every place around the area. Every company wanted to charge me an arm and a leg for the long distance move even though I did not have much to move with me. This company was the only moving company I trusted after talking to many. 

Nate, the owner of Smooth Moving Pros, was very prompt with answering any questions I had and even offered me a discount for my move since I did not have much stuff! 

They came on time and even brought along coverings for all my mattresses, mirrors, and paintings which they took the time to put on for me. Needless to say, this has been the quickest and most efficient move ever! Everything was packed into the van in less than an hour, they drove to DC quickly, and unloaded everything within less than an hour. I did not have to worry about gas, toll, etc. because everything was covered with a flat, reasonable rate for my long distance move. 

I paid less for my long distance move from Philly to DC than I did when I moved 5 blocks away in Philly with another moving company! Please use them, they are amazing and I HIGHLY would recommend Smooth Moving Pros to anyone looking to move. 

Thank you again guys!

I have only been here twice so far but I absolutely love this place. First time I came in I got a few tacos (wanted to try the steak, chicken, and chorizo) and all were perfectly delicious. This last time I went in I got another chorizo taco and I tried the carne asada torta which I was also very pleased with. It was about double the size of the torta's I have tried in the past, which I will admit has only been a couple, but I couldn't even finish it (which while I hate wasting food this is better than not getting enough). Everyone is always friendly and there are so many other items on their menu I would like to try and plan on making this is a regular place I eat at when visiting Reno.

With so many places to eat tacos on Nolensville, the tacos at Taqueria Express didn't stand out to me. They were fine (the lengua was a little gristly, and the carne asada was okay), but the wait for the tacos was longer than I typically expect for a taco truck. Definitely okay - not a bad meal. It just isn't a truck I'd go back to necessarily.

I believe this location is drive thru only and the line is always super long. I'm not sure if the service is slow or if people just have complicated orders lol. When I get to the window I feel like I'm serviced fast but when I'm in line it seems each car takes at least 5 minutes. The daiquiris are always amazing though so I'm going to wait every time!

It's still pricey, but yes you are paying for the convenience. Try your hardest not to shop here, but if you must it can be a pleasant experience. I once was dead set on having rhubarb preserves and lemon sorbet. I only like hagen daz lemon sorbet. I've tried every lemon sorbet, Hagen daz is seriously the best. I mean other than capogiro. Well they didn't have any in the case. The super sweet manager, went in the back and dug up a ton of them for me! He didn't have to do that for me. I might have received this sort of service at Whole Foods, but definitely not at super fresh! Super fresh where I have had to explain cream of mushroom soup to the manager. No joke. I have a witness!

Soho Juice has the best acai bowls I've ever had. I live in a bigger city than St. Pete and thought I'd find a better place there, but I haven't. So I make sure to stop by Soho Juice when I'm in St. Pete. 

I think the Cloud 9 bowl is particularly good and unique, although I have enjoyed all the ones I've tried. You may think the price is a little high for the large size, but it's a large serving, you can eat half and put the rest in the freezer for another time. 

I'm glad they also serve toast to provide a little variety. Also love that it's easy to get vegan food here!

I have a problem.

I have been thinking about the vegetable samosas from Desi Chaat House a lot.  It is causing a serious interruption in my daily functioning.

Sometimes I will be in the middle of a conversation and I will pretend to get a call so that I can go outside, hail a cab, and go to Desi Chaat house for the samosas.  I return, sometimes an hour later, and attempt to continue the conversation as if nothing had happened.  My friends think I'm on drugs and my girlfriend is accusing me of having an affair but they don't know how much I love these samosas.

But Brad, why not introduce these people to Desi Chaat house?  

The answer is simple, hypothetical question-asker...it is because I am a man who's mind is rife with delusional paranoia.  I fear that my friends and loved ones, knowing my weakness, will buy out the samosas before I am able to get to the restaurant and they will sell them to me at ridiculous markups.  Like a hopeless addict, I will be enslaved to the wills of those I once trusted. 

Illogical? yes.  Impossible?  Nope.

...ok back to reviewing.

When you order them, they will offer to pour chickpeas over them.  Let them do this.  

The best way I could describe the chaat is...wacky.  It is a peculiar mix of sweet, spicy, creamy, and aromatics.  I've had the vegetable samosa and mumbai chaat and both are good.

The chicken roll and lamb roll make an excellent lunch.  The meat is tender and seasoned extremely well.  I highly recommend these items.  For a very vegetarian-leaning culture, India sure makes some excellent meat dishes.

On top of it all, the staff is ridiculously friendly and always asking for feedback on how they can improve.  It is tasty, inexpensive, unique, and has the best veggie samosas in Philadelphia.

Note: I like veggie samosas a lot more than most people so bear that in mind when you consider this review.

Pros - cute place with a decent amount of tables, friendly service, interesting shake flavors 

Cons - expensive, the meat is tasteless, I'm not a huge fan of the fries 

I ended up getting a kids meal because I didn't want to spend 10 dollars on a burger meal. The kids meal consisted of a small version of their regular burger, fries, and a small drink. The meal was a nice size. I didn't get a shake but some of the flavors really intrigued me. I may go back for a shake but not for a burger.

I just went here because I had coupons, and it was convenient on my route.  Well, and I admit I'm a Yelp addict, so part of the reason was to Yelp about it, and get another cool-point for being the first to review this place.

Cleanliness is decent, cleaner than average.   But I did go right before the lunch rush.

My Whoppers (2-fer!) were pretty good for a Whopper.  The burgers are pre-cooked, but the sandwich is assembled to order, so all the ingredients are fresh, not wilted and squished (like McDonald's often is, if you get a standard pre-made/pre-assembled sandwich that sits around for up to 15 or 30 minutes.)

The men's room was decent.  I've seen better, but it meets my expectations for a Burger King franchise.

They have free Wi-fi.  You don't have to give them your email address, but you do have to click through an "I ACCEPT" (terms of use) screen.   Unfortunately, the Wi-fi Internet connection was so slow as to be useless.  It was like a dial-up in terms of speed.

Good food very near Bourbon Street and all of that fun, but there are concerns.

First, they don't take reservations...  Our group size was nine, and so they would not seat us until our whole group was together.  This is important to know since Bourbon Street does have some.... distractions.  Once we finally had our whole group together it was another 30 minutes as we waited to be seated, and this was a Wednesday in the middle of summer.  I can't imagine the wait during prime time.

Second, the food is good, but it is mostly fried.  If you are not into fried food, you may not want to go here.  I hadn't had a Po'Boy yet, and so I let the waiter choose one for me, and he chose the 'soft shelled crab'.  This was my first soft shelled crab and it arrived fried in a batter on the Po'Boy bun with all the fixins.  I liked it.

Third, it is air conditioned, and in July this is truly a blessing.  It was 98 outside and about 90% humidity.  It was a great relief to get inside.

Fourth, they do sell beer by the pitcher.  They had three on tap the night we were there, and we went with the Abita Amber.  It was good, cold, and short lived.

Fifth, they've got some signs that pay homage to those that have eaten 15 dozen oysters, and one guy who ate 51 dozen.  As I thought about this, I was struggled to imagine how this would go.  Do you start ordering them and then get into a rhythm and just continue?  What happens if you have seven and stop?  Can you take a break at about the 12th dozen?  Is there a time limit?  Is there a Monty Python film in the foreseeable future?

Good food, good location, get your group together and enjoy.  Be sure to know that you'll need to wait outside, there are no reservations, and most of the items are fried.   I'll be back.

Great service. Chargrilled oysters ALL DAY! The bread they use for their po'boys rule. I got the "Peace Maker" half oyster half shrimp.

Good beer selection here! Tight seating but really fun and makes you let loose a bit. Good for crowds! I like their checkered black and white table cloths. Dark lighting but no one seems to care because everyone is just having a good ole time. 

You can't go to NOLA without hitting up Acme Oyster House! There might be a line but well worth it.

Look, there's nothing wrong with Rita's. The water ice is generally good. The service is generally good. They try to come up with interesting flavors. And their presence overall has made water ice more popular in general.  I have no major problem with Rita's. 

But honestly, I can name two water ice places in short driving distance that are better quality and less corporate, also far cheaper.  That's just fact. On top of that, the last water ice I got at Rita's was just a little too slushy for my taste.  

But, if someone handed me a Rita's water ice, I certainly wouldn't say no.

Ditch yo' family, ditch yo' friends, grab one person and hit up those tasty oysters at Acme!

Long line out the door is the norm here. But if you have a small party of 1 or 2 you can sometimes get bumped to the front of the line (especially if it's just tourist groups of 3+ in front of you). 

Best oysters in my short time at NOLA. Don't waste your time with the raw, go for chargrilled. Outstanding seasoning and done to perfection. I'm sure the raw is good, but seriously - you won't regret just going all in with the chargrilled.

Minor demerit for the "sorry we can't make the mojito; the bartender says we're out of mint" (which per my bartender friends is a common lie when they don't want to make mojitos). Either take the mojitos out of your menu completely or make sure you stock enough mint. Given how established this place is, I find it hard to believe they can run out of mint so early in the evening (before 6:30 pm). But whatever. It's not like I would boycott them since they have me by their oysters and fantastic po'boys.

Wish I was staying in NOLA longer, would've gone here twice.

I came here yesterday with a group of 6 for one of our friend's birthday. We had a reservation so we had no problem getting seated. This is a new place, and the service was good! The restaurant itself is nice and roomy. I've been to other gyu-kaku locations, and this one has a lot more light and space as compared to the other one I've been to (in Cupertino, CA). We ordered the $180 combo meal for 6 people, which proved to be more than enough food for all of us. Ordered a pitcher of beer too! It came with a lot of items, but I'd say my favorites were the hot oil seared tuna, the sea bass, and the kobe beef items! the bibimbap to start off with was really good as well. Overall, this was a good dinner at a place that just recently opened. After a few tweaks here and there, this place could potentially be a really big hot spot in Philly considering there aren't many Japanese bbq places around.

Not a bad Mexican food joint in my opinion but I have had better closer to me. 
The restaurant is very cute, I like the big arm chairs that you sit in at the tables. Everyone is very friendly and the glass ceiling is rather unique so overall the atmosphere is quite pleasant.

We were brought chips and salsa almost immediately and like another review said before, I was a little sad when I noticed that the chips were not hot, I like having fresh and HOT tortilla chips at Mexican restaurants too. The salsa was good but I enjoy one that is more chunky with lots of "stuff" in it like tomatoes and onions. This one is very smooth and it has a good flavor and a nice spice to it but I just prefer one with more substance.
The margaritas on the other hand were very tasty and one pitcher definitely went a long way! They had a great flavor and just the right amount of booze, I would definitely recommend getting these if you are coming to Bertha Miranda's.

The food was very good, I chose to get the "Masterpiece" plate which had a little bit of everything. A shredded beef enchilada, a chicken taco and a cheese chile relleno were my choices and they were all very good. The taco was by far my favorite item of the three, the shell was a freshly fried corn tortilla but it was still a little chewy and the chicken was perfectly moist and tender, very tasty. I would have liked a little more meat in the enchilada and the relleno was good but nothing to write home about.  
The beans and rice were also good, but not great. The rice was a little overcooked and sort of lumpy but it still had a nice flavor. The beans on the other hand were perfectly cooked yet also disappointingly bland. 
My brother ordered a similar dish to mine but with a tamale instead of relleno. The tamale was very yummy and they say that they are handmade at the restaurant so I'm sure this is one of the better things on the menu. 
My mom ordered the chicken mole which I think was probably one of the BEST things that any one of us ordered. It had a nice, rich sauce with a smoky yet subtly sweet flavor. The chicken was nice and moist and I was definitely having a little food envy after I tasted her dish.  

Overall, I would definitely come back to this place if I was ever in the area and would recommend it to anyone that likes mole, it is very hard to find at most places and this restaurant really does a nice job with it. The tacos and tamales are also probably the best choices here, but everyone has their own tastes. 
Worth a try if you are in Reno. A very nice authentic Mexican restaurant in a rather small, unassuming building. Don't forget to check out the automotive museum right across the street too! Two great little finds that are just a stones throw from the more popular, touristy casino joints.

Big Lots is aces with me. I got two boxes of Chex cereal for 5 bucks. It's not expired or anything - as if cereal even expires?!?  Big Lots has all kinds of stuff I have zero use for but I'll buy it anyway because its such a great price. They have a lot of Le Sueur canned vegetables; mostly peas and green beans... what's the deal with that?

+/- THE FOOD
The food is just okay here and I have definitely been to better buffets in Reno. There wasn't any particular dish that stood out to me or left me wanting for more. They try to have a wide variety of foods of different cultures but it doesn't seem that legit to me. I saw in pictures that there would be a bunch of seafood but when I got there, there was only a big pile of shrimp for shrimp cocktails and small platter of crab legs (which were all empty.... no meat in them at all). The meats are okay but not impressive. I liked the bbq ribs the best and I was pretty disappointed with the prime rib. Their Asian section was a DIY noodle soup area which was not good. They have a lot of different bite-sized desserts but they all taste really weird. The only ok-tasting desserts was the sorbet. 

- THE WAIT
The wait is crazy here regardless of what day you come here. Be prepared to wait at least an hour even though this place isn't that good. They have a faster line for the members with higher reward cards.

Very good Steak!  It's cooked in a style midway between the "Charred" method of Morton's and the "Tenderness" method of Ruth's.  I prefer Ruth's among the three b/k I like the melted butter and tenderness, but I do like Flemings better than Morton's.  NOTE: Valet Parking in the front, and regular parking in the back.

DRINKS:
** Water(tap) = (4.5) Very Good!  Must be filtered:)
* Coffee = (3.5) good
* A-to-Z Pinot Noir = (3) ok...definitely not worth the price

FOOD
** Bread(free) = (4) very good
** Dry-aged Prime Ribeye = (4) very good flavor
* Fleming's Potatoes = (3.5) good
* Mashed Potatoes = (3.5) good
* Berries & Cream(dessert) = (3.25) pretty good, but needed more cream...

This location is back behind Marsh in a strip of businesses that are basically dying.  All of the DQ's in this east side vicinity are older and in need of upgrades, but this location has kept up with giving us quality product.  The staff has been friendly, and they have continued maintain their business in an area that has been hard hit by urban decay. We appreciate their longevity.

My first review update comes with good reason, and that's because they got rid of the terribad musical act! This makes Dunders far more tolerable than it was previously, and actually a great place to have a brew and a bite!

The advantage of the bierhaus-style tables means it's great for groups as well, and you can hear multiple conversations and jump back and forth between them. Plus they have every kind of mustard on the planet, so if that's your thing you'll be able to try all of them.

The crowd is everything from USF grad students to hipsters of both variety (ironic and non-ironic). But get there earlier if you want something more than a sandwich, as they shut a bunch of the kitchen down at 10pm, thus meaning you can't get your schnitzel fix after that hour. 

A pretty authentic kind of place that's beloved by it's loyal customers... and now I'm a much bigger fan than I was before!

It's IHOP. 

We came on Thanksgiving Day and were seated immediately. Our waitress was super kind and attentive. There were six at our table. We looked at the menu and quickly decided on the new holiday seasonal pancake combo. It is the best value for your money here. It is even cheaper than items on the senior menu. 

The special holiday seasonal pancakes were pumpkin spice pancakes that half the table had. Dark Chocolate Peppermint pancakes that my daughter had and the Eggnog Pancakes that i had. The pancakes come with your choice of egg, hash browns, and 2 pieces of bacon or 2 pieces of sausage or 1 bacon and 1 sausage all for under $7.00. 

The pumpkin spice pancakes were nice. My eggnog pancakes had a butter rum sauce that was outstanding. But my favorite were my daughters dark chocolate peppermint pancakes. I thought they were going to be really sweet. I was surprised at the fluidity and the balance of flavor. They had a nice chocolate taste not too sweet with just the right amount of peppermint. 

We were able to get in and out before the crowd hit. Our waitress was super attentive and made sure that everything was done right and to our liking. I wish I could remember her name. I know she was super busy.

I'm here for the records--specifically the Latin/Mexican records. As a tourist, I thought the selection was surprisingly smaller than expected but still happily left with a good 10 LPs I was excited about. Place overall looks to have a good selection of records. Even on a Monday morning, it was a busy place with plenty of staff (masked up!) ready to help. 

Record selection: 5/5
(Specific focus selection of Latin/Mexican music: 2.5/5)
Service: 5/5, the gal who rung me up was hella cool and gave me lots of record shop tips and list of cool places to eat in town
Cleanliness/Shop: 5/5, right kinda music shop dustiness but super well lit that you don't need your phone's flashlight to look through the bargain bin!

Called in a pizza order. Called to cancel minutes later because it was going to take an hour and they wouldn't. Screaming kids demanding food now we had to take them elsewhere and this place wouldn't cancel. Crazy. They hadn't even made it yet.

Even though we had been warned when we were making our reservation that a large holiday party would be wrapping up when we came in, we still were eager to try Fare. The manager was very attentive in making sure that we were not bothered by the noise and provided some complimentary menu items - it was a very nice gesture!

Looking to go light, I ordered the Grilled Octopus starter and the Fare Mixed Greens Salad. The starter was a very generous portion with a lot of octopus - it was also much more like a salad than I had expected. So when my actual salad came out, I was not able to finish it, but I appreciated the freshness and flavors. The miso dressing is tasty, but if you're not going to finish the salad, definitely ask to get it on the side so everything isn't wilted for tomorrow's lunch. I also sampled the Hand Cut Fries - with truffle oil and parmesan, this is a good choice.

Nada is one of my go to spots in Cincy and also now in Indy!  The food is super tasty as are the cocktails.  We recently stopped in for dinner before a concert since we knew it would be a solid pick.  
Our server was friendly and seemed to be enjoying her shift.  I find that to be such a nice thing when you're dining out...it can definitely make the mood of dinner more pleasant.  
The salsas are all great as is the guacamole too!  And of course the queso is a must if you love melted cheese like most cool people do!  The chips are thick but fresh and except for the fact that they fill you up quicker than you might want, are solid vehicles for the dips and salsas!  Grab a kale and mushroom taco too!  You will not be disappointed.  Oh, and the potatoes, beans & rice, and chicken enchiladas are also high points in my opinion.  
I wish this location had a better patio but due to the location it isn't feasible I guess.  None the less I am glad to see that Indianapolis now has a Nada to visit.

It's hard to review Whole Foods, because you kinda know what you're getting into, but every time feels different.

As with all other Whole Foods, you can find:
 - Great quality foods!
 - Ridiculous prices!
 - Insanely helpful staff!
 - Rich people / health nuts / hipsters!

So here are the things that stand out more about THIS particular whole foods.

 - The parking situation is insane.  I've always found a spot, but it's just a madhouse trying to get in here.  Since there's high traffic in and out, something should open up... but that doesn't mean you're gonna like the experience.

 - It's very busy, and a bit cramped compared to some of the other Whole Foods i've been to.

 - They don't have Prosciutto Di Parma, which is the most First World Problem one can have.

This restaurant is spacious, intimate and has a very chill atmosphere. They also have a huge selection of wine and let you walk around to choose which one you want:)

I came here on a Thursday night with 8 girls and Ron was our waiter. He was amazing! He was attentive, patient, and funny. This place is definitely good for a large party, but do rsvp ahead of time:) 

Linguine Triton (5/5) - It's light, flavorful and tasty
Mussels (4/5)
Marsala Pork Cheek (5/5) - Wow, this entree really impressed because it was so tender. 
Pama Royale drink (4/5)

Overall, I had a great time at Marcello and the food was delicious. It's one of those restaurant that I would come back when I visit Nola.

5 Stars for what it is, and 5 Stars for what it's going to be. Does that mean I can give 10?

For the longest time I followed that the owner of South Philly Tap Room was going to open up a cafe that hook up delectable coffee offerings from one of my favorites, Counter Culture (http://mealticket.blogs.citypaper.net/blogs/mu/2009/05/05/first-look-at-brewultimo-coffee/). and even better was the fact that it wasn't only going to offer one of my favorite vices, it was going to offer TWO of them by doubling over as a beer store as soon as it procured a liquor license (http://ultimocoffee.wordpress.com/2009/01/23/meal-ticket-round-two-keeping-tabs-on-brewultimo-coffee/). And while one of those goals is still a work in progress, the coffee shop is very much alive and might just be one of the best in the city.

as soon as I walked up one of the South Philly roads that is less traveled for me and saw my destination, I became enamored by it's outdoor seating and garage door that opened to combine the outside with the in. the incredible decor expanded with church pews and antique window fixtures hanging indoors. I also made note of the many refrigerator units that will one day hold mass quantities of delectable beer.

The iced chai that I initially order made for the perfect relaxed wake up call during a hot day. and the coffee that I ordered afterwards embodied a dark richness to it's body that was fully accentuated by the drip method that they utilize. and the lemon square that I ordered along with it was sheer perfection. 

Overall the staff were friendly and extremely accommodating, and the atmosphere made for the perfect environment to have our book club in. It looks like Ultimo is a place that I'll be visiting for a long while to come!

The absolute best pizza in NOLA. When I'm visiting my family we usually opt for delivery for convenience. But last night we decided to dine in and enjoy the $3 happy hour. Where can you get a $3 glass of wine in any major metropolitan city?! The inside is so cozy and quaint. Pretty romantic if you ask me. No more than 10 tables but if you go early enough, right after 5pm, there is no wait. Their pies are nothing less than divine. Perfect amount of sauce to cheese ratio, great topping options and crispy crust that is perfect for dipping in sauce. Vegans can delight as there is plenty for you to eat! We went on a Wednesday so you buy a large or extra large pizza and you get one for $1. Are you kidding me? A specialty pizza for a buck! And you can dine in or carry out with this deal. It's incredibly. We normally get the chicken/ bacon ranch and meathead but because I'm not eating meat for lent we also added a Cajun shrimp. And wow, I'll never look back. I really recommend checking out the specials before you go because they vary every day and have something unique every day. I can't rave enough about everything here. I did sit right under a speaker in the corner and that would be the only thing I would do differently, otherwise PERFECT and consistent pizza! And now my new favorite dive in NOLA to dine in. Can't wait to try the pastas and wings.

it's almost great.  
to start, it's a byo that lets you make reservations for the weekend.  and even for larger parties!  imagine!  and the menu continues to change and evolve, love it!

the apps were so good, i could have stopped there.  especially the arancini.  a fried rice ball stuffed with short rib ragu?  i mean, how could you go wrong?  
i like the fact that you can order a half order of pasta so you can get a main course as well.  but, really i think i could have been happy with just the pasta in itself.  the light pillowy ricotta gnocchi are divine.  my tagliatelle with artichokes and lemons and mushrooms were perfect for the warm summer day.

and really, i could have stopped there.  my main course (swordfish) was good, but not spectacular.  it was cooked perfectly, but the light dusting of cinnamon and burrata just threw off my tastebuds.

the dessert (almond milk panna cotta) was some of the best i've ever had.

points off for the loud noise, and the 3 (!!!) requests for filling up my water glass before it was done.  maybe they could use a bit more than the 2 servers that they had for a saturday night...

Place was clean, and service was friendly and prompt.  We did the All You Can Eat (AYCE) menu.  You checkmark what you want on an order slip and turn it in.  You can do this multiple times until you've had your fill.  But be wary, they'll charge 15% for anything you do not eat.  This is meant to discourage you from ordering the entire menu and leaving most of it to waste.  I want to go back and 1) get more crab rangoon; 2) not get the salad (little too big for me); 3) order 1 sushi piece per person (don't assume it's a pair); 4) try some different rolls than last time other than spicy tuna (definitely getting that one again).

Crab Rangoon (5/5) - Some of the better crab rangoon around; I would order more than one set of 2 pieces
Salad (4/5) - Pretty big portion with the delicious ginger dressing - very good but a bit too much of it
Gyoza (3/5) - Texture and taste seemed same as any potsticker from a Chinese restaurant
Shumai (3/5) - Their version is done with shrimp (remember it's not quite like the Chinese dim sum shumai; the Japanese version is much smaller)
Yaki Chicken (4/5) - The chicken skewers are worth ordering
Sushi (4/5) - This is the seafood piece across the pillow of rice.  These tasted just fine but note that they are single pieces; if you want a piece for you and your date, you will need to order two of them.  At other similar AYCE sushi, marking "1" here means a set of 2 pieces, so make sure to clarify.
Boston Roll (3/5) - Just OK, not outstanding in flavor but tasted fresh
Spicy Tuna Roll (4/5) - They do a solid spicy tuna roll here
American Dream Roll (3/5) - This comes in 5 large pieces; there is some eel sauce but not a lot
Honey Roll (3.5/5) - This is small and 6 pieces; it's ok, but I'd probably try something different next time
Very impressive store. Great customer service. Tons of healthy choices and pre cut food. Did I mention there's homemade peanut butter very impressed! Visit this store if you are in the area.

Rare Ethnic Food 52. Ethiopian cuisine 

It is close to 4.5 stars for my experience today. I kind agree some food need to tone up the spicy taste. However the spice and ingredients are there. With that said. Let me get into the experience. 

Mitmita is actually meaning one of the Ethiopian Spice. It can be mixed and make many dish. I like the restaurant reflecting their true calling. The culture of food is use a piece of injera to pick up a bit of entree by hand and eat it. That is how it done to enjoy the different cuisine. 

We have a group there can try different dishes. Injera is a crepe type sheet for pick up the food. The best dish is the Ye-doro Wat. This is a chicken dish with Ethiopian Ber-bere sauce. The sauce has so many ingredients. It is flavorful. We also order the  Kat Wat the chop beef with Ethiopian bbq sauce, Kitfo the lean beef is with the Mitmita sauce, Gored Gored the raw tenderloin beef with amaze sauce. Those are good dishes. 

Afterward we have Ethiopian coffee with ceremony incense to celebrate special occasions. It was a great celebration. On the appetizers, we have the chicken, veggies, and beef sambusa. Very tasty. We have good time there.

Great place to watch a game. First time we went we were upstairs for the LSU game. The drinks were pricey and the buffet they set up was expensive and the food was just okay. Nothing special. 

We sat downstairs the second time. The food was pretty good but not really up to par with the prices. We waited a good while for the food, however. 

I will definitely go back, but not my favorite place to sit at through an entire game

I eat here about once a month and like it but they really knocked it out of the park today. The spinach and garlic soup was fantastic and I got seconds. Same for the cauliflower and potato dish. Perfectly cooked and the cauliflower tasted like it was picked this morning. It was lightly seasoned with something, I'm not sure what. Saffron? And this was the buffet.
Most of the rest of the buffet was good today. As usual, the tandoori chicken was a let down. I guess it's not economical to do a quality tandoori chicken for the buffet.

We stopped in at Port Orleans about 45 minutes before they closed and had the huge huge space mostly to ourselves.  I couldn't believe how much room they had in there and outside -- I bet it makes for a fun space when it's a bit earlier and busier.  I ordered the Storyville IPA and liked it, though others in our group seemed less enthused so it's hard to say how good their selection is, but I'd be willing to go again and find out.

Amazing food and the tasting menu is a great value, but they seemed under staffed as service was poor. Our waitress was inattentive and just bad.
Lovely seating outside, but can be quite dark. We got seated and it took a while to get our menus. Slowly, we got a free appetizer bite (delicious fig on Rosemary shortbread), though no silverware or napkins. Eventually, after a long time we were able to order. 
We all did the tasting menu.
The sweet bread special was cooked very well and was tasty. Octopus was a salad, which I hadn't realized beforehand. It was just okay. Shrimp appetizer was okay (one shrimp).
The gnocchi was excellent- wow probably the best dish. Fluffy gnocchi with mint on top, which was a great layer. Squid ink with calamari was just okay. The lamb ragu special was good, but forgettable.
The ribeye was very heavy, but very delicious. Loved the egg on top. Cooked well. Buttery.
The salmon special was cooked well and was very delicate and flakey.
The magi stew was just okay.
Chocolate tort was thick and delicious. Panna cotta was well executed. Very smooth. The tiramisu was not my fav- they had a fruity take on it.
Overall, the food was great and we got tons of food. We were stuffed. Service was seriously off. Insanely slow start. We were there 2.5 with the first 45 minutes just ordering and getting our table set. They also accidentally threw out two of our leftovers!

Tony and I went to Publix Super Market to pick up a few groceries. We were in the area and decided to shop here. 
We absolutely love the fact that this is a VERY CLEAN store..and we both agreed that the CHAIN of Publix are always the most clean stores we have grocery shop in.

We noticed all the employees carry a cleaning cloth with them. We noticed that there is always so many employees to help out.  They are so helpful.  The groceries are so well stocked and I love the flow of the stores 

The prices are a little more expensive. A few pennies here and there, and some items about .30 to .50 more but they have a lot of Buy ONE GET ONE FREE items.
I love the Bakery section, The Deli section, well actually all the sections.

The store chain could give lessons to other chains on how to keep their stores this clean and they Rock on Customer Service...
Others like Kroger's ((( which I love by the way)) should learn from them..

Great store..!!!!

Located in a highly desirable spot, but in a very undesirable looking hotel, Bongos was a sharp contrast to it's surrounding, largely run down property. I am sure you've already looked at the pictures and know that you'll get a chance to seat on the beach while enjoying a meal. Although that's absolutely true, I'll write about an element that pictures won't describe.

Fun and friendly staff make the visit worthwhile. You'll get a piece of fish anywhere in St Pete, but finding such great people is hard. The bartender was managing a ridiculous influx of thirsty tourists and doing it in a friendly, efficient manner. All drinks are made from pre-made Walmart shelf mixers, so don't expect anything exquisite. Rum selection is as basic as it gets, Bacardi, Morgan or well. The place has a very typical, average American beach bar feel to it. Of course, that comes included with country music and southern middle class crowd. In other words, people who want to be country, but live in a city like Birmingham, Mobile, Augusta and the like.

Food is fine. Again, standard stuff. The much recommended artichoke dip was pretty good. Seafood selections aren't phenomenal, but there. Lots of fried items as you'd expect at an American beach bar.

The establishment shines of course in one area and that's its location. Right on the beach, it's a perfect spot to watch the sunset and have a beer.

I go to Fleming's about once a year.  I know that while it will be expensive, all the food will be good, the service will be friendly, and the atmosphere will be clean and comfortable.

My friend and I sat in the bar - first at the bar for cocktails, and then moving into a bar booth for dinner.  Our server was efficient, although a little slammed with all the tables she had going.  Great deals for happy hour from 5-7 - they offer 5-$6 drinks, and 5-$5 appetizers.  

Taking advantage of the discounts, we shared the pork belly and tenderloin carpaccio to start with.  The pork belly was just okay - the best part of that plate was actually the creamy goat cheese grits that accompanied it - yum!  The sweet onion chutney was just not enough of a contrast with the rest of the plate.

The carpaccio was excellent.   It was a generous portion, sliced extremely thin, with capers and a creole mustard sauce on top,  with cheesy crackers to put it on.  My one wish would have been more 'bite' to the sauce.

For dinner I had the French Onion soup and the small plate of New Bedford Scallops.  This was one of the best French Onion soups I have ever had.  It was baked with both gruyère and parmesan cheeses, with a nice crispness to the bread inside.  The cheese topping was incredible, and the broth was flavorful without being too salty.

I liked the scallops, but didn't love them.  The sauce had flavor, but the scallops didn't really seem to.  I  know, I know, only eat steak in a steakhouse, but I'm a seafood girl!

For dessert  we split the carrot cake.  Since I am a carrot cake connoisseur, I will rate this one 6/10.  Very moist which I love, it did not have even close to enough frosting on it/in it.  I guess that's why they serve it with a side of homemade whip cream - there needs to be some sweetness to contrast the non-sweet flavor of the cake part.  More than just a tiny drizzle of dark rum caramel on the side was needed, too.

Final thought - GET WIFI!  Sheesh - close to the airport, close to many businesses - enter this century and make the upgrade - thanks!

*Mobile Review*

Came here with NYU ADEA faculty and student doctors

Decor: 4/5
-indoor and outdoor seating (mostly outdoor)
-lovely weather but leaves may fall onto your food

Service: 2.5/5
-Service was average.
-Servers had missing or gold teeth
-overhyped, not impressed

Food Presentation: 4/5
Taste: 3/5
-BBQ Shrimp: did they put BP seasoning in this? the shrimp tasted rubbery
-Veal: not what I expected. small portions for the price ($30) and wasn't that great
-Banana Foster: the amount of brandy was too much. I have a sweet tooth so the banana and vanilla ice cream was yummy
-Pecan pie: warm and soft yet not too sweet. This was good

The average rating says it all. Don't expect much from this place. I wouldn't come back.

C'est fantastique!

My nicer half treated me here for my birthday dinner this year. 5 stars for ambiance and service! The rooftop patio is the bee's knees. I felt very carefree and happy just as a result of being up there. Our server, Charles, was very charismatic and fun. I like that he introduced himself and shook hands with everyone at all of his tables, and remembered mine and Devin's names throughout the meal. "Christine, my love, how are you doing?" Charming as hell. Loved it. The entire team of servers worked together seamlessly to clear plates in a timely manner and keep our water glasses full. Charles also put together a really adorable birthday card for me and had a bunch of staff members sign it. Awesome!

The food was pretty good. Not stellar, but definitely good. I liked the escargot but felt the puff pastry was kind of stale. The soup was not my style, but it was really my fault for ordering something when I didn't know what it was. Tip for the French cuisine-ignorant: vichyssoise is served cold. It would have been MUCH better hot. Like clam chowder, except smoked salmon. But I didn't really like it cold. The pork chop was good but didn't blow me out of the water. Devin got the monkfish special which was MUCH better. The star of my meal was the creme brulee! It was truly perfect.

I did the prix fixe menu which was reasonable at $38.99 for 4 courses, and they were full size - not tiny tasting plates - so it was a really great deal. 

I would be willing to try other things off the menu again, but I definitely want to come back to enjoy some of their delicious drinks (the cocktails were superb - I recommend the Summer Fashion - like an Old Fashioned with a peachy twist) and desserts on that lovely patio.

I like the atmosphere. One section has high top chairs, another section has booth seats and regular tables, which can be romantic for couples. I love the posters throughout the restaurant. The food was good. I especially like the calamari. The sauce has a nice spicy kick. I would get the sauce on the side though. It's not a lot of sauce so it's okay. I didn't understand the cooked carrots. There were a good amount of it in two of the dishes. It's interesting. Overall, a good experience and would come back again.

I've been a couple times, and the food was amazing each time. I haven't tried the pizza or the tapas...I'm more of an Italian fan, so I went for that. The calamari is AMAZING. Best in St. Louis if you ask me.

There's nothing better than raging in downtown Reno, drinking some tasty cocktails and brews with buddies and suddenly realizing it's 11PM or later. Why rejoice at the late hour you ask? Because it's the perfect time to for some preventative medicine at Golden Flower! 

Grab a table and get ready to fight off that hangover with a banging bowl of pho, some delicious imperial egg rolls, or one of their cold noodle dishes! On this last visit I'd had enough liquid courage to allow me to order the most daunting dish on the menu, Bun Bo Hue, a spicy noodle soup made with a rich, complex, and meaty broth, packed full of all the best animal tidbits like well-done flank, rare beef, tendon, and oh yes, blood cake! The version here does tendon right! It cooks for hours in the broth until extremely tender, all the while absorbing the rich flavors of the stock. Andrew Zimmern would describe it as meat jelly, and I'd concur. If it eats like that, you know it's good! The blood cake is harder to describe, but it turns out it was way more a textural thing than a flavor. Kind of thought it would be a little different, but eating it is worth the shock value! I'll be back for more of this soon! 

But slide a big bowl of that up right next to a big plate of the chicken wings they have on their late night menu, and that is a match made in heaven! My fiancee, who enjoyed her night just as much as I did ;), only ate a tiny bit of soup that night before we went home. The next morning, Bun Bo Hue #FTW! Hangover be gone for me, and well, lets just say she wasn't as happy!

The location, right on the sand on the beach, adds a star (and a bit) to a pretty decent beach bar. The food is pretty much what you would expect, but it's done very well.  The portions were generous, and very tasty. I ordered the shrimp tacos, with a side of fries.  I got two soft tacos, and they were filled to overflowing with grilled shrimp. The fries were crispy on the outside and soft, but not mushy, on the inside, just like I like them. The o5hers at the table ordered a variety of dishes witch looked similarly appetizing. 

As I said, the view was superb, and the live music was great too. Our server seemed a bit overloaded as he was not around very much. Not too terrible, but we were not in a rush, and just enjoyed sitting on the beach with a cold one while waiting.

This is my favorite store!! 

 Love the selection and choices of organics and health food items here.

The Deli is awesome. The choices for sandwiches and breads are varied.  I really like the meat department. I have placed orders for trout etc. and they call when my order is in. The butchers at the meat department are very knowledgeable and friendly. 

I love that there is a coffee shop inside this store. I also enjoy the famous quotes on the walls. The store has a nice feel to it. 

Raley's has eCart too now. I haven't used it yet but am dying to try it. eCart lets you order your food at home and a personal shopper inside the store does your shopping. Then you set up a time to go in and pick it up. You can even pre pay for your order. Your service fee may be waived if (A) this is one of the first five orders on this account, or (B) your final amount meets the requirements of a specific promotion. For more information https://www.raleys.com/www/promotions/promotions.jsp?contentid=4690570

Love the new location! So much more space and less congested. Still has the adorable fairytale atmosphere.

Make a reservation and appreciate how it's expected to enjoy your time and not feel rushed to turn tables. 

Lots of white (compared to the pink OG location). Out door seating and so many twinkling lights. 

Order to-go at the bakery. Like the bakery set up. Easier to navigate through.

Got the brownie cheesecake it was AMAZING. Must try, and totally worth $6.

Seeking a hole-in-the-wall - truly authentic- Mexican restaurant? Los Portales is the spot. I was meeting a friend for dinner and decided to go out on a whim and randomly pick a place. Random, I tell you. I saw that Los Portales had one review, but it was a good one. The restaurant itself is located in a not so attractive area, but try to look past that fact when pulling into the parking spot. I honestly debated whether or not we should stay, but we decided to give it a try.

The place, though small, was filled with lively folk.  There was a group of guys glued to the soccer game on tv while on the other side of the place sat a family chowing down on fresh chips and salsa.  While looking through the menu, we quickly noticed that everything was in Spanish. Everything. Really made me wish I would have paid more attention in my Spanish class in high school. I'm telling you, everything about this place was authentic. The food was delicious and incredibly affordable. I was able to eat two large tacos for less than $5. Our waitress, even though she had difficulty communicating with us, was very attentive and helpful. 

I want to reiterate that this place isn't in the most glamorous part of Indy. Please don't let this detour you away, though.  It's definitely worth the stop.
Cheap tickets for $5.50 matinee. Definitely an older theatre. iIt reminded me of a theater from back in the old days of black and white movies. I could of definitely been a fan of that.

I am  not sure I have the words to describe this experience... Some landmarks are hype of a long gone memory.. This place is a living and breathing icon. This place is a cathedral.... This place is a religion.

2.5 Stars

Decent Thai food with some good items, and some fails.

Fried tofu to start with was marginal - it was very bland with almost no flavor, and didn't have the silky interior that I love. However, the Larb Gai appetizer, chicken mixed with chili powder, scallions, mint leaves, Thai herbs and lime juice served with sliced cabbage, was outstanding, with a fabulous, fresh flavor.

For my entrée I had the Amazing, which was anything but.  Served cool, with a cloying, sweet brown sauce on top, it was almost inedible.  I sent it back to be warmed up, but that just made it even worse. My boyfriend had their special fried rice which he liked, but they must have gotten their 'heat level' confused, because his ordered medium was extra fiery.

Service was just okay. They had two waiters in the restaurant, and while they were attentive at first, that dropped off as more tables arrived.  It's been ten or so years since I tried this place, and it will probably be that long before I go back.

acme oyster house really really reallyyyy is as good as they all say. 
stellar reviews from thousands of yelpers means good stuff. 
i didn't even like oysters before this trip. i'm now an addict. 
damnit.
you will be too. try it. i dare ya.
the po'boys and hush puppies and gumbo aren't too shabby either. 

had the raw and the chargrilled oysters... i actually preferred the raw. 
whatever you do, don't leave NOLA without eating oysters here at least once.
 
yes, there's a line. yes, you're probably on vacation and don't feel like waiting around in line. DO IT ANYWAY. trust.

I had a very enjoyable visit to Yogurt Mountain. They had some very fun, tasty and interesting flavors. It certainly helped that I was with Boon, Grace, Fernelly and Rachel who are always entertaining..

Nate was friendly and helpful and I started off with a few samples.
