Didn't love the pomegranate (not pomegrantey enough) but the cookies and cream, coffee, yellow cake, and birthday cake were all good. The original tart wasn't the best I've had, maybe on the sweet side? but it was fine. The watermelon is SUPER interesting and fun. 

The toppings are also very playful. lots of sweets like gummies, chocolate covered gummies, licorice strands, sour strips as well as fruit. The price seemed quite reasonable for what I got. The place was pretty busy even late and it's nice that it was open late enough for us to enjoy. Seating was comfortable and the decor is nice. Well lit. People were friendly. 

If they had mochi and the blackberries were a lil better looking I would give it five stars. No WiFi also a lil disappointing. And I like fresh mango and kiwi toppings. Makes me believe I am being healthy.. But otherwise it's definitely a super fun place with a lot of variety, taste and fun. Definitely go with Boon, Rachel, Grace, and Fernelly if you can.

You walk into what can only be described as someone vomited up bright colors.  Wow.  Burns your eyes it's so tropical in there!

The thing that saves this place:  bowl o' chihuahua cheese.  They don't know how to make this stuff in Chicago.  We *almost* delayed the drive home to pick some up to-go as a road trip snack!

Taco salad though, not good.  I asked for no sour cream, but I think between the guacamole and the grease from the chicken, it ended up making taco salad gray soup in the bottom of my shell.  I picked at it but ultimately ended up making do with more cheese and chips!

The cheese is good, the Diet Coke is fountain and the chairs have different brightly colored animals and birds on them.  If we weren't on this side of town, I wouldn't make a special trip for it.

If you are more interested in portion sizes and getting the most food for your money, then this is your joint. If you want food that tastes good and has flavor, don't bother coming here. 

I ordered the Philly steak and cheese omelette and the meat was literally the same flavor and consistency as the eggs. I had to add salt, pepper and tobacco sauce to eat it. The hash browns also didn't have good potato flavor, it tasted almost watered down. 

The biscuit was doughy and heavy. I regret eating the calories. 

The wait staff was unfriendly too, seemed like they were too good to serve me breakfast, or take my money. Even when it came time to pay, they helped the customer ahead of me, and then just walked off when it was my turn. There was no "hold on, I'll be right back". I just stood there for ages looking at everyone's back. When someone finally took my payment, she asked me if I needed a receipt, I said no, and then she just walked away as I was writing in the tip. I wasn't sure if the transaction was done. Most ppl say, "thanks for coming, or have a nice day". After standing there for a few more seconds and realizing she was done with me, I left. 

I don't want to say they were racist, but, I was definitely the only non-white patron there, and everyone else was getting chatted up. 

Anyway, I won't be returning. Even if it only cost me $11.

This place could be THE go-to dinner spot on the fringe of Fishtown and Port Richmond.  Excellent burger (got to love a burger that comes with the option of pulled pork and/or a fried egg on top).  Fantastic onion rings.  Solid fries.  Cold beers and all the PWC favorites on draft.  I think everyone in my party of 4 was really was satisfied with the food.  The service was surprisingly helpful for a dive bar too.  

It's just everything else that's bringing the rating down....

No one wants to sit in the back of the room next to a cold drafty window with a giant neon Guinness sign 2 feet from their head.   Lose the neon beer signs and put up some Christmas lights and you really got something.  Get rid of the rickety tables and chairs and get something a little nicer and people will want to sit back there and eat.  Oh yeah, and let's try a little heat, it was freezing when we were in there.

Despite all that, it did have a really nice and well maintained bathroom.

I get it... it's a dive bar... but there are a few minor things they could do to make it more inviting.  

I will return for those onion rings.

A trip to Santa Barbara is incomplete without stopping by McConnell's for a sweet treat. It's very difficult to decide what flavors to order, so I suggest getting the flight of 3 scoops. Their ice cream is creamy, thick, and not too sweet (depending on the flavor). I tried the strawberry rhubarb, olive oil, and summer fruit cobbler, with the cobbler being my favorite (big chunks of fruit and pie pieces). Be sure to budget in some time to stand in line on the weekend!

I come here practically everyday! They have the nicest staff they are will to help you find anything you need.  If a line has a lot of people in it they open a another line so you don't have to wait forever!

Their Starbucks is one of the best since Torey works there she makes a good black and White mocha.  Their bakery is also so friendly to they always have HOT fresh bread and they will slice the bread for you with a smile on their faces!  This one of the best Safeway's in town!

For months I have been craving some Chinese food. I began to research the area and after reading reviews I had to try this place! 

I drove out to the location and noticed the area it was in was actually an area I was familiar with! I entered the restaurant and was immediately greeted by the cashier! She was friendly and helpful. My "go to" dish at any Chinese restaurant is the sweet and sour chicken with fried rice; and so I didn't have to think about what I wanted to order. What I really enjoyed about this place was that instead of the egg roll as the traditional side, I could choose crab rangoon instead! I LOVE crab rangoon and had actually thought about ordering a side of them; but since they were included in the meal I had to get them. They were to die for! Creamy and delicious! The sweet and sour chicken was phenomenal and just the way I love it! Some places use chicken that I find to be too chewy, but this was tender and juicy! Just thinking about it is making me hungry again. 

I will be making another visit and have another dish I plan to try! I will let you know how that goes!

I more or less stumbled upon Aldo Lamberti Trattoria in Philadelphia's international airport after a flight. During COVID-19 quite a few options are closed so I decided to get some food where I could before my next flight. I'm sure glad I did.

I was skeptical at the food at first, as it's airport food, however don't let that keep you away. The food is delicious and of really good quality. I have gotten some slices of pizza here, both cheese and veggie which were very good. I also have had a eggplant parm stack that was absolutely delicious. The eggplant is spot on. 

The line moves quickly and the people are nice. They have a sanitizing station as well as some condiments towards the end of the line. I absolutely will not hesitate to come here again.

Just the salad bar catapults it into the three-stars.  Not many places have those anymore and I'm a salad freak.  Then there was the meat.  My partner had a juicy steak cooked just as he asked, and I had the salmon, also as rare as I wanted it.  Excellent beer selection and good service.  Yes, it IS a chain for suburban sprawl malls, that takes it down a notch.  But for a decently priced, good dinner, you can't go wrong at this place.

Very yummy place.  Everything they do, they do with top notch ingredients. 
 I ate there 4 times during a week long visit....It's  'mother ship establishment' Cochon, right around the corner is also really worth a try...but get reservations well ahead.

Love love love this place!!! Customer service is number 1! We were offered random flavors to try without even asking! Super duper fun!

When you walk in...it like a childhood dream! The smell of fresh baked waffle cones fills the air.  The unique chalk board menu immediately caught my eyes.  I wish I thought of this!   Love it. 

The flavors are abundant and chances daily! I was able to try Soo many flavors and my favorite so far is the coffee pecan pralines! It's rich and creamy, with a pecan praline crunch for added texture! I was not brave enough to try lavender honey. 

If you feel adventurous, take the Tchoupitoulas Challenge. 8 scoops and 8 toppings and be on their Hall of Fame Plaque if you choose to finish! 

This is a must try local joint!

Very cute donut shop. They have a lot of variety but it's best to come early since they sell out. 
I had the salted caramel... it was a cronut style donut...salty and sweet. Also a cake donut with pistachos and tasted a bit more savory than sweet.

Quality of ice cream is superb and I was pleasantly surprised upon first lick.

I ordered their peanut butter crunch and Brazilian coffee ice cream.  PB crunch was mostly vanilla with chocolate covered peanuts mixed in the swirl which gave it that "crunch".  Brazilian was of a lighter coffee taste.  After the two scoops in a waffle, my friend decided to get a small frozen yogurt which really turned out to be a HUGE one.  The cookies and cream flavored yogurt was not so great, although the quality was rich and creamy, just like their ice cream.  It doesn't really taste like cookies and cream and after a few bites, you kind of get sick of it.  The half vanilla, half chocolate fro-yo seems to be a popular item.

-1 star for the impatient service.  I was pondering what flavors to try and the girl asked "Can I help another person while you're waiting?" No, bitch.  I want to try other flavors before I make a final decision =/

BTW, parking lot is EXTREMELY small.  You have been warned.

People less decent and honorable than I tell me affixing an extra X to a name is a popular branding technique of adult film stars. Coxx, Roxx, Boxx, people who lack my moral compass and Rick Santorum bumper sticker collection tell me, as examples, are popular choices. So with this purely academic knowledge, it was surprising when I saw it was indeed Quick Fixx, with that extra sexy (sexxy?) 'x.'

The Fixx flatbread ($8) with white sauce, bacon, caramelized onions and gruyere was rich and filling. However, the richness really covered up the salty pork flavor I was hoping would counter the inherent heaviness. The caramelized onions were done right and added great flavor, managing to stand out slightly. The dish is very good, I was just hoping for a little more balance, that extra level that makes it pop. Despite the Shaq-sized palmfuls of cheese the crust held up admirably and added a nice little crunch.

Gnocchi ($12) was the definition of A-OK: absolutely fine, the bolognese was very tasty on its own, but nothing that I can say a lot about, other than you wouldn't be in harm's way ordering it.

QF also has a snack/late night/late chance to ditch that ugo you met at closing time menu. It's an admirable step up from your typical late night eateries and includes Panzarotti poppers ($7), dubbed as mini fried dough balls filled with goat cheese, shallots and chives. They seem baked to me, though. Tagging along is an apple jam sauce that provides a kick of sweetness to the velvety goat cheese. Parmigiano-Reggiano dusted fries ($3, big enough to share) come with ketchup and toum--a Lebanese garlic sauce similar to aioli but with olive oil. Push the Heinz to the side and focus on this.

The service is top notch. Concern gushes from who I presumed to be the owner like blood from a gun shot wound. The sheer brute dedication to his business mirrors what Kenneth the Page has for 30 Rock. The prices, portions, and quality match up well. Very close to 4 stars. I'll be back.

Let me preface by saying I love a good tapas restaurant.  In fact, I think tapas should be the restaurant go-to for all women.  Let's face it ladies, you don't need the massive portions being served up at these BYO Italian joints.  Unless of course you like men who like their women thick. 

Anywho, on to the review...

Tinto is all-around fab.  Much needed in the Square, if you ask me.  I love the atmosphere/decor here, and they have some fantastic wines by the glass.  Oh, and service is impeccable.

As for tapas selections, coming here without ordering the bacon-wrapped figs, short-ribs, or the duck confit should be considered a cardinal sin.  De-lish.  

Perfect spot to catch up with old friends or flirt on a hot date.

I'm withholding the 5th star b/c I've been spoiled by too many visits to Cafe Iberico in Chicago and Alta in Manhattan.

I think the photos speak loudly. Never have I ever had Biryani with peas. This isn't even considered chicken fried rice, it's just flavorless rice with dry chicken and peas. 

The chicken vindaloo wasn't actually vindaloo, not sure what paste they used but they didn't cook the potatoes all the way through. Which is sad, because we were the only people there and our order took 40 mins to come our. 

The naan was a non issue. Didn't even try it. It was cold and I'm 99% sure this is the same stuff they sell in the frozen section at Wegmans. 

It's hilarious that this place is called "Indian Restaurant", it's anything but a Indian restaurant.

I ended up liking this place a lot more than I thought. I applaud a "quick service" /casual eatery to care about the quality of their food and they seem to put a lot of effort in making sure they are serving organic meats and veggies. It doesn't have a slew of options, but enough. I ordered the burrito in a bowl and everything tasted very fresh and flavorful. Large portions too, "This burrito is delicious, but it is filling"
Gad the linguini vongole.  Clams were good but some had sand in them (as someone else mentioned on yelp).  Pasta was too soft but we took the food to go. Sauce was good but nothing special.

Find a way to go here-- no matter what. The first few times I came to visit, I avoided it because of the line (and inadvertently found a new favorite next door, bourbon House) We finally got in by swinging by for an early lunch. Two words: chargrilled oysters. UNBELIEVABLE.

I can't even begin to describe the experience of eating one, salty, buttery, with a sprinkling of cheese and a piece of bread to mop it all up. We ordered a dozen. Then another. 
Then another.

Po-boys are also good. And no ifs, ands, or butts. It must all be washed down with an Abita.

It's Qdoba so you know what to expect - fairly consistent Mexican food that caters to the burrito, nachos, and tacos type of crowd. Sometimes you just need something fast though, you know?

I stopped by to get some easy takeout dinner for the GF and I. While I understand lunchtime is when the major rush is (and I hope they have the appropriate number of staff to accommodate it), around 5PM there were only 2 people serving the 7 people in line. It seemed to be the manager and one of the employees. This location could use a few more people to service its customers. 

Other than that - it's a Qdoba. You know what to do.

Hmmm hard to review both a bar and restaurant because the bar has an excellent selection of martini's. In fact I don't think I've ever been to a bar that has this many martini choices!? The menu is like 12 pages long...the only problem, the martini glasses are really small..as for the restaurant next door, the decor is cool and it feels, yes, swanky for sure....I've never really had stellare service or food here except for one thing...the souffle desert!! OMG you have to order it at the beginning of your dinner because it takes 30 mins to cook but it is SOOOOO good...the best one I've ever had, and I will always go back just for that!

Went for the free coupon and when I get there I was surprised how slim the line was although it's hard to compete with red beans and rice on a Monday in New Orleans. Well the service this day was abominable. They literally threw what I ordered in a bowl in such a way that half of what they threw landed on the assembly line bar and not in my bowl. It was as if none of the employees had been trained in how to make orders. What caused me fury the most was their was a line nearing the door and I had to wait 15 minutes for the cashier to come back to her station to pay, at that point I just walked out leaving my order on the line. This place is too far a drive for me to get this bad a service thus at that point the free coupon meant nothing because I will probably never come here again.

Royal Orchid is a very large restaurant with multiple seating areas and an open bar area in a Ramada Hotel in Westshore. They serve up some first rate Indian cuisine and also have other Asian and continental dishes in an extensive menu to meet all tastes. They are introducing a lunch buffet for 2015. They also have an extended happy hour and lunch specials.

The multiple seating areas at Royal Orchid can accommodate a very large gathering but the setup maintains intimacy and comfort and isn't overwhelming at all. The main space is a large open area with a bar area and dining space with high tables and comfy booths. There is also a patio area, more secluded side dining area and banquet rooms.

Royal Orchid serves various Asian dishes and offers a lunch buffet. The Tom Yam Goong, Thai shrimp coconut lemongrass soup, was tasty. The lamb korma was excellent with a rich subtle taste. The mango lassi was rich and delicious. The naan was excellent. They will spice to the heat desired and the food tends to have some zip.

Dishes are served in hammered silver bowls and rice (white, brown, jasmine) that are conducive yo family style and group dining. Have as much or as little of any one dish as you like! They also split a soup no problem so two of us could share it. Serving various dishes over a rice felt traditional and everything tasted very good. 

We met the chef who has more than two decades of experience internationally. Our server Kristina was super and sweet. It's a classy tasteful feeling space but also relaxed. There are even nooks with pool and Foosball for gamers.

Look forward to returning. Hope people find this great space with some very tasty dishes.

$2 per person for tea?! $8 for that (somewhat small-sized) plate of steamed Chinese broccoli?! Come ON!

I went on Sunday for lunch per the recommendation of a friend ("that's when they have more carts, and the dim sum is fresher") & upon sitting down we were immediately swarmed by 3 different carts.

The dim sum was fine, with some ups and some downs. I thought the shumai was pretty crappy; the bbq pork buns were good (if a little small) (I don't even usually like bbq pork buns); the shrimp-cilantro dim sum were tasty but I wish the bottoms wouldn't've stuck to the paper; the Chinese broccoli I mentioned was sooooooo good (but again, $8???)...

Overall I quite enjoyed it & will be back again... just probably not too soon.

With the Pho 75 in Chinatown closing and the bulk of the Ramen Boy reviews scaring me I found myself in serious need of finding a quick and easy noodle fix when I didn't feel like climbing aboard the Pho Train (http://www.yelp.com/biz/pho-xe-lua-viet-thai-philadelphia#hrid:TqIDfYjlnBN7MbrDfxqbEA/src:self). Fortunately I remembered Rachel's and Steven's reviews and was able to savor a bowl of the comforting pleasure that hand drawn noodles delivered.

if my pho addiction had taught me anything its that the perfect asian soups have to be filled with a revitalizing broth, a plentiful and oftentimes odd assortment of additional ingredients, and a helping of some of the best noodles that you've ever had; all while coming at a fairly inexpensive pricetag. And for just $6 the seafood soup with shrimp, scallops, clams, and fish balls had Nan Zhou delivering on all cylinders. But the main thing I wasn't expecting was the fact that the tantalizing consistency and interesting back story of the hand drawn noodle recipe may have me giving pho and ramen a stink eyed comparison for the forseeable future.

Be sure to bring cash to get your fill, but not a whole lot unless your table feels the need to split random delicacies like marinated duck, beef tendons, and spicy pig ears. And be sure to keep your vegetarian friends at a distance.

A kid, or an adult that is a kid at heart would love this whimsical dreamy dessert haven. These are the phrases that comes to mind when I envision Creole Creamery. The exterior and interior aesthetics scream antique candy/malt shop and it smells awesome once you step foot inside. When I walk inside, I immediately look at the giant chalkboard that list the current flavors. Note: Some flavors are subject to change. On my last visit I tried the Creole Strawberry Sundae-- Fresh strawberries served over a mound of our famous creole cream cheese ice cream topped with whipped cream, a cherry, and a wafer, which came in a huge sundae glass, topped with dips of creole cream cheese flavored ice cream, fresh strawberries and graham cracker. It looked too cute to bite into so I made sure to take a photo and upload it first. Then I took the first bite and seen rainbows. I am very dramatic but I like--well--love Creole Creamery and wish I lived down the street as a kid vs. Dairy Queen. I feel robbed. If you want, they offer samples to taste and try different unique flavors like Lavender Honey, which is also good. Next time, I am going to try either another sundae or Ice Cream Sampler--
--4 mini scoops or  6 mini scoops--so that I can try more awesome frozen goodness. 
Oh, and bring cash, this place is true to tradition, no fancy cards to swipe in this place.

Yiro Yiro, how many ways to say and spell that delicious pita sandwich with grilled meat, various sauces, tantalizing dips and veggies? Over the years I've had many different concoctions of this sandwich and Yiro Yiro's version was pretty darn good.
I DoorDashed them yesterday and delivery was extremely quick and I appreciated the care and the use of quality packaging they use. You would be surprised seeing how some spot use cheap containers for their food.
I ordered the beef/lamb combo with a rice pilaf, fresh salad of diced tomatoes, cucumbers, eggplant and spices, and a wonderful spicy feta dip. I finished the meal with a scrumptious baklava.
The meal came with triangular shaped grilled pita bread. The portions were abundant.  I grabbed a slice of the pita bread and crammed as much of the meat the bread could handle and smeared the spicy feta cheese dip over it. What a heavenly bite! The beef and lamb was tender and that spicy feta was the truth. The rice pilaf was fluffy and not dried out and I didn't know the name of the salad, but it was so fresh and crisp, a perfect accompanying item for the meal.
The baklava was magnificent, two large pieces encrusted with honey and pistachios with a thin layer of vanilla icing across the top of the philo dough. It was a sweet ending to a good meal. 
I would have awarded Yiro Yiro 5 stars if I would have received whole pieces of the grilled pita bread so I could make a whole gyro, the small pieces of pita ran out quickly. Next time I will ask for that in advance.

I do think Indiana Pizza Hut is the best Pizza Hut around, but this was decent. Everything went well: Ordering, picking up, eating, etc. Nothing really to note, except I don't think it's near as back as older reviews mention. Would I recommend, sure!  It's Pizza Hut! I wish Tennessee Pizza Huts did the side of cheese sauce you can order, that really just ties all the tastiness together with the perfect bow.
Meh. The K-Mart of discount stores. Not so organized. Decent prices. Cheap housewares. Okay if you don't want to fight the traffic and madness across the street at TJMaxx or Burlington.

Wow!

Someone had posted on Nextdoor app in my neighborhood..of course I had to try.

They are in S.Reno 10-2 ..South Meadows and Veterans at the end of the road..

Two miles from the house and so delicious.

Bigger and full of meat!

Three carne asada and three carnitas.. red and green hot sauce..

Sauces were kickin spicy, but good..

All for $12!

You know where I'll be during lunch..

[1032]
11/2019

This place was always on my bucket list so I was happy check it out when company came to visit.  

We parked in the visitor center garage 

We visited on a Saturday night in November.  It was cold out but we were able to warm up by the FirePit.  

There was a tent that looked like it served s'mores and hot chocolate but you can see the crazy long line so we did not go inside. 

The kids rode a train, carousel and played mini golf. The golf course was good as each hole was a different landmark in Philly.  

The place looks cool with the zillion holiday lights.   There was a music/light show each half hour that was pretty cool.  

Definitely a cute place to take the kids.    We stayed 2 hours in the 30 degree cold but definitely could have stayed more. 

I'll definitely be back

I can't see anyone complaining about this joint but there are apparently some jackasses that work there. I got lucky and went on a night where the staff was just unhappy to be working a shit job. I can accept that. It's the same any crappy bar you go to at 9pm on a weeknight. Those folks are going to have to clean up vomit later and they know it.

Upon arrival it is in fact a dirty dive. There are only a couple people working. You seat yourself and order at the bar. It will take a minute for your order to be taken and your draft to be poured. No one is going to come check on you. It's loud. People are going in and out smoking constantly. But it's a bar, you get what you asked for when you walked through the door.

Still trying to figure out why the pizza sauce is brown and spicy but I like it, and none of that provel BS thank you very much! Is it the best in STL? No way, Pi is much better and yet that's not saying much. STL pizza 2 out of 10. Chicago 9 out of 10.

My friends really, really wanted to do this tour on our last trip to New Orleans, so as the accommodating host I am, I signed us up. Now, little bit of a disclaimer... some of my girlfriends are really into the whole Twilight/Vampire Diaries thing. I am not. But I'm not opposed to vampire lore. I've read my fair share of Ann Rice books and seen plenty of old vamp horror flicks.

The tour I pictured was something completely different. Intimate and entertaining with just a little bit of kitsch. It was none of this. First of all, at the meeting place I was expected there to be maybe 10-15 people waiting. There were so many people (75-100?) that I was confused. Who were all these people? Were we all going on the same tour? They broke us into "smaller" groups and away we went. Our "small" group had maybe 20-25 people and seemed to keep picking up more as the tour went on. You couldn't hear anything the "host" was saying unless you were on his heels constantly. The stories were kind of boring and dragged on. 

Most of us ended up bailing half way through. I hate to say it but this was kind of a waste of money.

French Quarter Haunted Ghost Tour

Great tour with Clint! We had a better "haunted" experience this time with our tour guide, Clint (in reference to our first experience last year). We used our City Pass and booked an evening of the French Quarter Haunted Ghost Tour. We stopped by famous places like Lalaurie Mansion, Lafitte's Blacksmith Shop and the Omni Royal as Clint proceeded to tell us stories behind each landmark and, you know, ghostly sites and stuff where ghastly spirits have been documented. I found the stories fascinating.

Lafitte's Blacksmith Shop is actually a bar and it has a long haunted history. We were given a chance to go inside and check it out for a chance encounter with Jean Lafitte. Legend has it that he simply stands in the dark corners, staring at people until he is noticed, at which time his ghost disappears into the shadows. Not sure if his ghost would show up with all that people inside but supposedly he is always seen on the first floor, most of the time near the fireplace that's inside. Well, that was just one of his stories... there's many more where it came from. 

This non-theatrical, non-costumed tour guide shared events rooted in NOLA history and feature historically accurate storytelling. Clint was a great storyteller, no sugar coating anything. The tour was about two hours long. It is a walking tour so wear comfy shoes and probably bring a bottle of water to hydrate yourself. Normal Entry Price - Adult: $25.00  

Review #1500 updated

This so a pretty high energy spot. It has a Center City feel, but less stuffy. We sat at the bar, had a couple of salads (sorry, I forgot to take pics) they were good tho. I wasn't pleased with my shrimp, they were supposed to be grilled, but they weren't. I mentioned it to the bartender and she got me more shrimp (they weren't grilled either but she got an A+ for effort). The drinks were good and service was great. She even took the shrimps off the bill. I was impressed and pleased. Would def come back, I want to try the nachos (they looked delicious)!

It's like Meijer! Only they're not open 24 hours, which actually is kind of lame. BUT! I forgive them because their selection, prices, sales, and really everything that makes this store (this location especially) what it is is (are?) so fantastic that I am willing to make sure I'm in and out before 11pm.

Acme was recommended by so many friends for my New Orleans trip, so I made it a must-try. 

We came on my birthday (Friday night) in December and the wait actually wasn't too bad at 7PM. We waited maybe 20 minutes and got seated promptly. The inside is casual (no fancy) but I have no cares for ambiance if the food is on point. 

We ordered (from favorite to least favorite):

1. Raw oysters (5/5 stars): WOW. Have I ever tasted such plump, fresh, delicious oysters in my life? I think not. This was most definitely the best fresh tasting oysters I've had the luxury of trying. Amazing. (Raw here is better than Felix's)

2. Softshell crab (5/5 stars): !!! Holy crap. First time eating crab this way - fried but the meat is so soft, so good. The outer layer of fried crust is just perfect - flavorful but not too thick.

3. Chargrilled oysters (4/5 stars): Yum! The chargrilled oysters were flavored with butter, sea salt, cheese, lemon and who knows what else. I really enjoyed dipping the French bread in the sauce - perfect pairing. Still, I always prefer raw oysters to chargrilled because I like the original taste without being masked by so many other condiments. 

4. Boo fries (3/5 stars): Fries with roast beef gravy and cheese. Good side to have, but not the best fries in the world. I guess Acme can't be the best at everything haha.

5. Jambalaya (2/5 stars): Nooooo. The rice was rather bland and dry. Not much going on here. Jambalaya is MUCH better at Felix's. 

OVERALL
LOVED IT. For the price it's totally worth coming here, everyone ate to their heart's content and each person only came out to about $25 including tip. If I ever make another NOLA trip this is a must go-back-to :)

Redheaded Stranger is no longer a stranger to me and I am glad about that. The staff, the food, the ambiance and the concept are all great. I think over time it has the potential to be 5 stars but there are a couple of things I think could get it there.

My friend and I came for a late lunch but there was a line out the door. This is quickly becoming a popular spot! We waited in line for about 30 minutes before we were able to order at the front. The restaurant has a retro/Southwest kind of feel with cactus plants lined up along the window and the mod tables and chairs. They have an outdoor spacious patio that they had decked out with misters which in this August heat was a great idea (although umbrellas would be an even better one). They have a long bar area with seating and then an open kitchen and a place where you can see them making the flour tortillas, fresh. When we got up to order we were informed it would be a 40 minute wait for our food. Since we had already spent 30 minutes in line we were already invested so we stuck it out and waited although we were super hangry by the time the food actually came. Just a note that you will need to patient about the wait if you come here! 

My friend and I both got 2 tacos each since the size looked pretty substantial. The barbacoa taco had a lot of meat in it (yay) as well as black beans, red peppers and a hot sauce. This was super tasty. I also got a vegetarian taco which had poblano peppers, hot sauce and whipped feta. This was also really good so I was happy with these. My friend had ordered queso which was advertised as coming with tortillas. I had made a comment that this was interesting that it didn't say tortilla chips and she had responded that she was sure it was a fried tortilla like a tostada. It was not. The queso came with 2 flour tortillas. Although the queso is a smaller portion, 2 tortillas is not enough to eat with the queso. Conceptually I get it that maybe they want to show off their fresh, housemade tortillas but the practicality factor is just not there. They should reconsider this and serve with housemade tortilla chips!  

Personally I am a fan but for a pretty small menu it seemed like a really long wait. I understand that this is not a fast food joint but the things we ordered should have already pretty much been prepped and ready to go so I think they could be a bit more efficient there. Otherwise, all great!

This chain is one of my favorites. The food is consistently good. Not incredible, but definitely above average. Basically, regardless of the location you know what you're getting. I came in about 30 minutes before closing. All the staff was friendly and I didn't get the sense that they were trying to hurry me up so they could go home. They took my order and it came out pretty quick and it tasted just right. The server checked on me regularly and I had no issues. My only gripe is they got rid of my favorite burger. The 5 Alarm Burger! Bring it back! Puhleeeeeease! Ok, tantrum over. So in conclusion, this is a decent Red Robin...go there. And tell them to bring back the 5 Alarm Burger. Thanks.

They have declined so greatly since my last visit three years ago. Their new name should be Misdirection. 

Their seating is right on top of other tables. Hard to be comfortable sitting with your back in someone else's back. 

I was mostly disenchanted by the menu changes since my last visit of 2008. I remembered that I used to be able to order any variety of mac n cheese toppings for a reasonable value that improved with quantity of toppings. Now there are only three set "levels" of the appetizer, more expensive and lacking the creativity of the build your own variety style mac menu. I felt like the whole reason to return to this restaurant had been compromised, but ordered mac anyway because obviously I had been looking forward to the taste. Unfortunately, our waitress discouraged my custom order by saying that the menu had always been that way, at least as long as she knew. Not only that, but having worked there for three years, she nonetheless refused to acknowledge our longer term patronage in favor of her dwindling recollection of the time they must have streamlined the menu for faster prep, instead of made to order.

Another menu anomaly was the yogurt smothered lamb burger. My friend was perplexed when his came out of the kitchen. Our waitress merely indicated that the menu description was accurate (It still claim it WASN'T... see attached menu screenshot) and that we could try to absorb the unwanted yogurt sauce with napkins. However, the item had been so smothered in white cream and could hardly enough be salvaged.

All in all, I was very disappointed with my last time in Misdemeanor, Misdirection, whatever you want to call it.

New to Midtown but not new to Reno, Cafe de Thai will bring a traditional Thai cuisine to an underserved area! This restaurant will be located in the Sticks in the heart of Midtown. Alex, the owner, knows how to deliver an exceptional meal, dining experience and ambiance for his customers to enjoy! More to come once they announce their grand opening!!!

My favorite dish they have is the TODD MUN BPOO } Crab Cakes and PO PIA SOT } Fresh Spring Rolls at his current location. I do not think the high quality food options will change!
This is your average Walgreens. Had to come by and grab a few items.  Staff is friendly.  They had what I needed which was expected and I was in and out on my lunch break.

After visiting our eldest grandson and his new apartment on the west side, we decided to take him to lunch.  Mexican food was agreed upon by all of us and w decided to give La Hacienda a try.  It can be a little difficult to find since it stuck in an inner corner of a large building.  We ended up driving all the way around just to find it.  

Although the parking lot needed some cleaning and pot holes filled, Once we pulled up to the restaurant, we found the interior to be clean and lively.  we were given our choice of booth or table and we chose a section where the music was not too loud.

All three of us ordered something from the lunch menu which was fairly large serving for the price.  Our food came with chips and salsa.  The salsa was very thin with just a hint of heat to it.  The chips were light and crisp...good  enough to munch on even without salsa.  Our entrees came with beans and rice as well, so a full meal. Service was pretty good and the wait time on the kitchen was acceptable.  My wife decided to add a frozen strawberry margarita and thought it needed more mix (not enough berry flavor.)  The waiter brought us our bill and I paid at the front counter.  Overall, a pleasant meal and experience.

#Review 3966

Best in the city!  That's what the tour guide on the hop on, hop off bus said.

I've tried Genos and Pats and was caught up in the hype but not excited by the food.

Sonnys hits the mark!  Hand sliced meat right in front of you, delicious bread, tasty fried onions and my personal choice of mozzarella make for an amazingly tasty Philly Cheesesteak.

Until someone proves to me otherwise, I'm going best in the city!

Kind of a limited buffet, but for $5.20 (2007's price) (includes drink, but not tax) for lunch, it's a heck of a deal. No salad bar, but they did have jello, a couple different canned fruits (pineapple and fruit cocktail), and orange wedges. And the hot items that they had on the steam trays were more than acceptable; and I'd even say very good, considering the price.

I got there shortly after the lunch rush, and just had the buffet, but the food wasn't old. And people kept coming in for carry-out.

The limited buffet, with it's low-low price, makes it mainly a fill-up-cheap place. But, ordering off the menu gets you more variety and quality. Their extended hours are good if you are in the neighborhood, until 10pm weeknights, and 11pm Fri/Sat.

Their red and green colored menu has a lot more items than standard walk-up Chinese restaurants. Lots of Szechuan style stuff on the menu.

Monday through Thursday: 10:30 am to 10:00pm. Friday and Saturday: 10:30 am to 11:00pm. Sunday: 12:00 noon to 10:00pm.

This is a lovely spot to hit for brunch while in NOLA- the Jazz band could play more consistently, we were a large group and everyone came to that individual conclusion that the band was hardly playing the entire time we were there. 
The food is amazing and the chefs are friendly. The staff is welcoming and will help in any way they can. 
Definitely recommend to have the eggs benny and to try them every which way possible. The turtle soup was also fantastic! 
It's a great way to get your group gears up for a full day on the town, the location can't be beat!

A slow, boring, day afforded my friend the time to randomly search for Mexican establishments. When it came time to eat he recommended this place and off we went. 

Located just a few blocks from Broad and South Streets, Quetzally is nestled into a residential neighborhood. I cannot recall seeing another establishment in the immediate area. The dining area is not very large but capable of accommodating a decent amount of patrons. When we arrived we were the only people in the restaurant.  Within minutes the place was packed. 

We started our dining service with a plate of nachos. After all, that is what brought us to Quetzally. My friend chose this place because of the nachos. He is considered the nacho aficionado of the group and the nachos are what sold him on this place. While we may not agree on his nacho rankings, one cannot question his ability to seek out some of the greatest heaps of meat, cheese, salsa, and sour cream on a bed of tortilla chips and the nachos at Quetzally were just that, a heaping mound of goodness. 

Once we polished off the nachos I decided to go with the Chicken Tinga burrito. I was expecting a certain level of spice due to the chicken marinating in a chipotle sauce. I didn't quite find the level of spice I was seeking, but the flavor was  present. That had to be one of the best burritos I have had in Philadelphia. 

The service is cool. Even when things got a little busy for the one server she was still on top of her game. There is a $15 credit card minimum. We didn't know so when we asked to split the check the waitress tried to work with us but there was nothing she could do. The manager got a little testy. No worries

While living in Gainesville and learning about this Tampa location, I was ecstatic to be making the move knowing that I wouldn't have to experience a KFT void.

We know​ you're here for the drinks, so let it be known that they are great. My go-to's are the Winter Melon Milk Green Tea, Mango Slush, and Coffee Macchiato depending on the day. The menu is extensive so there's enough to suit everyone's taste. What made this location different was the fact that it offered an actual good food selection for a reasonable price. Surprisingly, the food is delicious. I did not expect that whatsoever considering it was coming from a coffee/boba shop.

As a recent college grad, this place is perfect for setting up camp to study all day. Apart from having food and drinks, they are open fairly late and there are plugs with almost every table aka a college student's DREAM.

The Kitchen is one of the dining establishments at the River Cree Resort & Casino, located just outside of Edmonton's city limits on the Enoch reserve.  It is a large, open space with tables and booths, excellent lighting, and unassuming decor. 

I won a gift certificate for the restaurant a while back, and decided to treat a couple of my friends to an evening out. We were all incredibly impressed with the buffet, which served a wide range of food with quality, style, and selection. I have never been to a buffet with such high class food. Starting with the salads, I enjoyed spring mix greens, wild rice with chicken, and an incredibly flavourful and unique turkey with pineapple salad, which was exactly as described: large chunks of turkey and pineapple brought together in a light, creamy dressing.

Next, was a selection of seafood such as crab legs, mussels, and smoked whitefish. The seafood was served ice cold, and looked very fresh. Due to dietary restrictions I only sampled the whitefish, which was delicious but would have been better had it been fully thawed before serving.

There was a bread service, roasted potatoes, vegetables, pasta dishes, and a chef's station serving up stir-fries. The final part of the buffet were the main courses, which on this evening included fried chicken in a sweet chili sauce, skirt steak in peppercorn sauce, a fish dish, and a jambalaya. The steak and chicken made the meal for me - both were excellent, with the sauces adding flavour without overwhelming.

Then came dessert. The desserts are in a separate area and include fresh fruit, cakes, and a hot dessert. You can accent your sweet treats with a variety of toppings such as whipped cream, chocolate sauce, and caramel. I sampled the black forest cake, brownies, strawberry shortcake, and pumpkin pie. Unlike the meager slivers served at most buffets, the pieces here were of substantial sizes. I did not care for the hot dessert, which was mincemeat, but someone else at my table enjoyed it.

A trip to The Kitchen is just a short drive and worth the trip. On a Saturday evening the buffet will cost you $19.95, and on most other nights it is only around $15. There is a lunch buffet available most days. Beverages cost extra.  The coffee is excellent.  I definitely hope to head here again.

Okay.  I really love this food here.  Food - 4.5 stars.  Service - 2.  

It takes forever to eat here.  I mean forever.  Plan on an hour and a half if you are doing deep dish.  Its a little ridiculous.

The wings here are awesome, but the last time, there was not nearly enough sauce and a little too much grease.  I am hoping it was a bad day, as I have been there before and had great wings.

I have had deep dish and the thin crust.  I actually prefer the thin here.  But, I find it hard to not like any pizza anywhere.  So, I am not very picky.

The cookies at the counter are huge and wonderful as well.

Go here for some good food, but expect service to take forever.

This is the best Starbucks in Reno, NV and maybe the good ol USA. The employees here go above and beyond and seem to be just better than other Starbucks around the states. I've been coming here for over 12 years on a weekly basis and am amazed at how polished their skills are to other Bucks stores.  This store staff go above and beyond for their customers.  My drinks are always made correctly.  When In Reno, NV check out this place at 7th and Keystone.

The line for this place was LONG but moved fairly quickly. The prices are honestly pretty good for someone who's used to ice cream costing more in the states. I tried the Moonshine brown brittle pecan and double cookies and cream in a cone. The Moonshine brown brittle pecan was delicious. The double cookies and cream was okay. Maybe it was the waffle but I did not enjoy the ice cream with the waffle (which is where the cookies and cream was). I was so sick it of it (waffle cone) I gave it to my husband and he was glad he didn't get one. Next time, I'm planning to get the ice cream in a cup instead. The girls were super friendly. Definitely planning to come back to try other flavors!

I really want to love this place because it's the only one of its kind in the area, where you can order food and drinks from the comfort of your recliner chair as you enjoy a movie. Sounds like something you'd enjoy right? You'd think it would be! BUT the inconsistencies and unqualified staff make for a less than pleasurable experience.

Granted they TRY to keep the menu fresh and exciting by switching SOME things around but it's always hit or miss. Never a guarantee even one thing will be the same, that goes for drinks and food. Call me bougie but when does a mule come in anything but a tin mug? 

As for the staff, sometimes they're good and sometimes they're just plain terrible. Forgetting things or just not showing up at all. Hellooooo does this lil blue light thingy workkk?!!! 

As recently as today, we had tix for a noon showing of Widows. We arrived to signs plastered on all the windows stating the theater was closed due to inclement weather. Uhhh excuse me but the streets were clear since late last night with no snow nor rain in the forecast today. Management should have advised their staff to be there, instead we were told only kitchen staff were there and they couldn't open without someone to work the box office. Major fail management! 

Honestly the one in collegeville isn't much better so I guess I'll just suck it up a little longer until something better comes along to replace this disappointment.

If I MUST say something nice it would be you can pretty much always find parking and that shopping center has some pretty decent stores lol

I had been wanting to try Sushi Bistro for a while, and when we finally made it by this week I was unfortunately not impressed. Let's start with the good. The place was gorgeous. The trendy and very up to date look created a great ambiance. The service was friendly and prompt, but we did get the early bird special dining at 5pm with only 2 other groups in the place.

The reason it gets 2 stars is what we really came for...the sushi. We ordered 6 rolls and all greatly lacked flavor. I usually never use soy sauce when I eat sushi and I definitely needed it that night as the sushi was so bland! I could tell it was very fresh and neatly prepared, but it just tasted boring. The best tasting roll was the sweet potato roll as many other reviewers mentioned, but I still wasn't that impressed by it. The rainbow roll, tuna king roll, and kirkwood roll all tasted very bland despite how expensive and how many ingredients go in to them. The spicy shrimp roll was not spicy at all, and the lobster tempura roll was way over cooked as it was rubbery when trying to chew it.

Sorry to say that Sushi Bistro did not impress. They did everything else but their signature items well, and sadly if you can't win me over with the food I definitely won't be a satisfied customer.

I have a few guilty pleasures that I really don't like sharing with anyone.

I would say guilty pleasure #1 is watching America's Funniest Videos.  

I don't get it.  

I can't stop laughing at little kids farting, dudes getting hit with balls in the, well, balls, and old ladies falling on their faces while trying to catch the bouquets at weddings.

It's so bad that I have all my recordings hidden in a folder on my TiVo.

And yet I keep the porn out in the open.  

Whatever.

Next guilty pleasure is consuming massive amounts of girlie drinks when I can.  

Holdrens makes a stellar pomegranate martini.  After downing two of those, I switched to the grapefruit martini.

Deliciously wussy if you ask me.

I am surprised that Holdren's has such low ratings.  Definately a good place to eat.

I got the top sirloin with the rosemary bluecheese dressing.  

Service was great and so was the atmosphere.

Whiffle.
Order the #41 - Fajita Quesadilla, trust me.

Otto by Polop offered  delicious food with atmosphere it was nice enough.  I had dinner there on Sunday night with two large tables of 10 each. The 
Servers handled the crowd very well. I've heard a lot of good things about this restaurant. I would say that all in all it almost lived up to the hype. The restaurant feels like an independent mom and pop shop. I was pleasantly surprised at the amount of space. The Decour was mostly updated but minimal. Everyone seems to enjoy their entrées and appetizers. My Caesar salad was good but very lightly dressed to the point where I had to ask for more dressing. I noticed that another guest ordered anchovies with their salad. I guess it's better to add more dressing and salt than have something overdressed. I should've done that but it wasn't offered to me. My friend had triangles of polenta that were topped with a mushroom sauce that needed a little bit of salt to make it pop.
    I enjoyed one of their special plates. The pasta was a little "purses" filled with Gorgonzola and was swimming in a  a light fresh marinara sauce. There was also shrimp that was good but nothing really to write home about. As I looked around the table, I noticed other people really liking their meals. The veal chop Milanese standed out to me and looked amazing. It was big, bold and delicious. (I had a bite) I might get something like that next time. I'm offering 4 perfectly solid shiny stars for this review. If you were looking for a refreshing 'ma and pop' Italian restaurant that serves a great consistent meal then give this place a try. It reminded me of the old Berwyn restaurant called Alfredo that, sadly, closed down during Covid. Otto by Poloa has a simular vibe. Don't forget that this is BYOB

I love how this strip of a park has developed over the years. It's now a lush green space with a fountain where you often find children playing and dogs frolicing. 

Since many of the people who live in the area do not have a ton of yardspace, many make this their defacto front yard which is fun to observe and not crash (unless invited of course). 

Love that the trees are lush and beautiful right now despite the cold winter...or maybe because of it. Now I just wish some neighbor with a green thumb would plant some flower beds to enhance the beauty.

SO and I were starving when we spotted Maggie O'Neill's, so we decided to make a detour for a late lunch. After having a round of Guinness and Harp and settling in front of the Astros playoff game vs. Red Sox, we ordered lunch. For an appetizer, I had a cup of the Potato Soup. It came out perfectly and was incredibly filling. I was worried I wouldn't be able to eat my entree! Luckily I ordered the Pub Sampler as my entree. It comes with the Sulley Shrimp (shrimp wrapped in Guinness braised bacon), Pretzel Bites, Buffalo Chicken, and Cheese Steak Egg Rolls. The Cheese Steak Egg Rolls were an interesting combination, but so good! The only item I didn't care for were the Pretzel Bites. The staff was very friendly and welcoming. I agree with another poster that the prices are a little steep, but overall everything came out tasting perfectly!

I was in STL for a work conference and this hotel bar became our nightly routine for the week.  The staff was very accommodating and friendly despite the large crowds, big orders, and split checks. 

We mostly drank here but stopped in for happy hour one night and ordered the chicken quesadilla.  They had some other good happy hour options but we only needed a small snack.  The food was fresh and came out quickly. 

If you're staying at the Hyatt I would check this place out as opposed to the other restaurants in the hotel.

"Dunder Box" is how most people say the name of this joint, not "Dunder Backs". Either way is fine, as long as you start by saying "Hey Ben, let's go to..." and finish with "...I'll buy you a beer."

Vegetarians can dine as cheaply as $3.99 for a meatless Reuben, which leaves money to spend on a hot pretzel (about $2) and a pint of draft beer (generally about $6, with some *liters* around $8).

Wooden chairs aching your Arsch? There are a few cushy armchairs in the "man cave" section.  Got a lot of friends? There's a room with a moderately sized long table, enough for a dozen people, maybe more. Just moved to town and haven't met anyone yet? There are two bars you can belly up to. If you've got a butt, it belongs somewhere in Dunderbak's.

Bonus for USF students: You can get off the Bull Runner C at Skipper Road, walk a block north to Bruce B. Downs, and across the Hess parking lot to Dunderbak's, then walk back the same way when you're going home. Check the shuttle hours, especially on weekends, but there's no need to worry about driving home safely when you can let the Bull Runner be the designated.

More rolled ice cream in South Tampa!

I've been watching this location for a while. My husband loves rolled ice crea m, but we don't love 35 Below, and North Tampa is a hike. 

This location is brand spanking new. Very clean, modern. The staff is very eager and friendly. I went during the day on a Monday and was the sole customer. 

They have preset flavors and toppings. We tried the strawberry cheesecake, and it was smooth and creamy. Very good. The strawberry themed toppings were quite good too. 

They also have popsicles that can be eaten as is or dipped in chocolate and toppings. I have a watermelon mint popsicle waiting for me in my freezer for as treat later. I can't wait to try it!

A friend and I dropped in for an impromptu foot massage on a Saturday night.  We were lucky not to have any wait.  The chairs are comfy and the towels are very clean.  No frills, but a relaxing ambiance and soothing music.  

Our massage therapists were both very accommodating and we had a fantastic massage.  The foot massage started with a dunk of our feet in warm water then reflexology for 40 minutes for $27.  They have a flyer with the reflexology points to review.  When signing in you select the pressure you prefer.  Complimentary water bottles are appreciated.  

Overall, it was clean, relaxing, and prompt service.  I'd return again!

I like this place's improbable nautical decor. It makes me want to hoist up the John B sails and find a wily whale to pursue, preferably in white. 

The beer list would be awesome in most cities but is kind of unremarkable for Philly. Your Bells and your Dogfishes can be had here. They seem to rotate the drafts frequently, so I can count on finding something good to drink here. The beer list and cocktails change with the season (hot boozy cider right now, for example) - I wish more places would do this.

If you're looking for diet-busting bar food on a budget, this is the place for you. Vegetarian options (and they abound) include a hearty house-made veggie burger, a grilled cheese livened up with pepper relish, and fontina mac n cheese to which you can add a number of things (arugula, red pepper and roasted garlic for me, please).

With lots of TV screens with sports on them, sometimes this place is packed to the gills with polo shirt types. I have yet to discern their migration patterns - sometimes I'll be sure this place will be a dudebro no go (Friday night at 8?) and it's merely humming and pleasant, and other times the flocks will descend unexpectedly. When it's quiet, though, this is a fine place to have a beer and a cheap dinner and dream of plying the wine-dark seas...

Our last visit, Oct 13, was below a one star. The experience was so horrible in the first five minutes that we had to walk out of there. Service wasn't there. Bathroom was nasty. Just a bad vibe all around. This ~was~ one of my favorite places. I'm going to give a three star for previous experience...

It took me years to finally find a spot I felt comfortable in. I loved the gumbo and the boils. We loved it so much one trip that we came twice in the same day. 

Maybe we had a bad day our last visit or maybe all my favorites are just not favorites anymore. You know it's so hard to pick and choose from the billion restaurants in the area. I'm really sad that I might just have to take this one off my list.
Food, GREAT!  Service, just okay....Cleanliness, needs work....overall, I think I would go back.

I live in the neighborhood but am hardly ever drawn to go here.  It is hit or miss from 2-star to 4-star depending on the night.  

My last visit involved a chewy as hell octopus salad, ridiculously slow service, and a flavorless steak.  I wish I knew what other people saw in this place as it is near my house and I wish it were better.

Los Gallo's had a space at the Italian Market festival and my Love and I could not resist the enticing smells coming from their booth so we ordered up some steak tacos and bam- flavor bomb in your mouth. 

That little taste brought us to their restaurant for lunch this week. 

We were not disappointed! 

Parking is a mess but that is par for the course in South Philly. The restaurant is small but clean and vibrant. Service is friendly and welcoming. The food lovingly prepared, served hot and in a reasonable amount of time considering all the ingredients are fresh and so flavorful. 

Let's talk about the salsas. Holy moly. So delish. Strong depths of flavor and spicy spicy yummm can't stop eating it, take my chips away - don't you dare.  

I had chicken enchiladas mole and could have licked the plate it was so good. The side rice and beans were jammed with flavor too. They are BYO too so bring some dranks and enjoy!

[Preface] 
Anyone who has been watching the whole Yelp photos conversation will appreciate the fact that I made the decision to go to Santa Fe this evening because it was the first business I found in the mobile app that didn't have a photo uploaded. John L will appreciate the fact that I uploaded two dark, blurry, almost useless photos. 

[Background]
Over the course of the last several years, the building that now exists as Santa Fe was a succession of different restaurants -- it was [insert name I'm forgetting], then Nonna Mia's (I think), then Santa Fe. My memory fails me with regard to the details (clearly), but the point is there were a bunch of different businesses in this location, and Santa Fe was the only one that stuck since I've been paying attention. 

[Rumors/Hearsay]
In any event, the first feedback I heard from other people who'd been to Santa Fe was entirely negative. (I won't repeat some of the more colorful statements, entertaining as they may have been; suffice it to say that the food was allegedly not good.) Therefore, I fully expected to see another restaurant take its place rather quickly, and was puzzled when this did not happen. Eventually, I came up with the theory that they *must* have kickass margaritas, because if the food is as bad as I'd heard it was, then people keep going back because they have an awesome time, love the margaritas, and drink so many they either don't care or can't remember whether or not the food was any good. 

[Personal Experience]
Well, I finally had a chance to experience Santa Fe firsthand, and here is what I have to report: 

-It's a bustling place, and can get kind of loud if you sit inside, because people clearly come here and have fun (again, I suspect it's the margaritas). 

-In all the times I've been to this building in its various incarnations, I've never seen it so crowded and noisy (in a good way). 

-There's an amazing, huge, gorgeous outdoor seating area with ceiling fans, tiki torches and (tonight, at least) live music. There was a wait to get a table outside. 

-The food is pretty standard Mexican fare. I had nachos, which were pretty much indistinguishable from nachos I've had elsewhere. Everyone I was with enjoyed their food, so whatever people were complaining about years ago is no longer valid (if, of course, it ever was).

-The service was very friendly and helpful, but a tad slow. (They were busy, though, and everybody was running around doing stuff. It's understandable.)

-We were greeted by a woman who, I suspect, is one of the owners. When we left, the man who I assume is her husband bid us farewell with a sincere thank you and enthusiastic handshake. It's a nice touch.

-They probably have excellent margaritas, but I can't say for sure because I (unfortunately) didn't have one. 

[Conclusion]
Overall, it's a great place, and the only reason I'm giving three stars instead of four is because I need to go back and confirm they do indeed have incredible margaritas, at which point I'll update my review accordingly. 

[Next Steps]
I'm going back soon for a pitcher (or two) of Margaritas.

[Recommendation]
My advice: Go. Soon. Before it gets too cold to enjoy eating and drinking outside. 

[Post-Script]
This place totally should've been included in the "Yelping Alfresco" edition of the New Orleans Weekly Yelp. It shall appear in round two, should there ever be a round two.

Wish I could come to PHL to eat here more often. Arctic char was so good, crispy skin, great seasoning, tender/flavorful green beans and I can't stop eating all the fingerling potatoes. So full. 

I've been thinking about the Char, and haven't had a similar experience since. I need to go back to PHL!

Man. It's been a LONG time since I have been to PM! So when my friend and I needed a stop for our Friday night Restaurant Week adventure, we decided to enjoy the 3 course meal for $20.13 offered here!

We were able to grab a table a little after 6pm and ordered the white and red sangria. YUM. Very tasty and a healthy portion for sure! Great start. We decided to have the shrimp spring rolls and moo shu quesadilla to start and wow, they did not disappoint! I loved the sauces on the side and we knew we were off to a solid start! 

For entrees we decided on the green curry with chicken and the salmon teriyaki with veggies. I ordered my green curry spicy, and it was even though the heat kinda floated to the bottom of the bowl. I have to admit I didn't love the broth, it seemed a bit watered down (maybe from all the restaurant week orders?) and I was let down. The salmon was good, and I definitely grabbed more than one bite from my friend's plate.

For dessert I ordered the tempura brownie bite with caramel and my friend the coconut sticky rice with mango. Both were good but not great.  Probably wouldn't order it off the menu again. 

I always say that your appetizers shouldn't outshine the main course. I feel it should be a delicious and amazing build up to the grand finale that is your main dish. In this case, I was wishing I could have done a re-do of the appetizers.  

What brought it down to 3 stars is that they rushed us out the door. I HATE when I'm still working on a course and the next one is brought out to me. Give me a minute or two please! And they weren't completely slammed or anything when we were here. 

Overall, not bad. I'd like to come back and have a refresher on the sushi!

You know you love frozen yogurt when you specifically ask for your own frozen yogurt machine so that you can make your own homemade frozen goodness. Of course, that doesn't stop me from going out to places like Yogorino and buying myself a cup; it just means that I don't go and buy it every night of the week.

Of all the froyo places in Philly (and there aren't that many of them), Yogorino has the best texture. Its smooth, creamy and really does taste just like frozen plain yogurt, with a little sweetness to it but only enough to remind you that this is technically a dessert. I would also argue that they therefore have the best plain flavor, but then again it is their only flavor. This is not a place to go to if you don't like the plain froyo craze, so don't complain if you walk in and question why there's only one flavor. 

They offer many of the toppings that most places have, such as fresh fruit (they had cranberries at one visit!), chocolate chips, sprinkles, but additionally they offer six different sauces in flavors like dark chocolate hazelnut (with WHOLE nuts!), walnut, white chocolate, dulce de leche, milk chocolate...its endless, and the list tends to fluctuate slightly each night it seems. I still haven't had the pistachio sauce that I desperately want to try because they never seem to have it when I go! The only issue I have is that the prices are somewhat high considering the amount of froyo you get and it only includes ONE topping; you have to pay an additional fee for more (and I'm too cheap to do THAT). 

However, the staff is very nice and jumps at the chance to explain things to you, which you might need to do since they seem to forget to label the toppings at times. That's a problem they should fix since it only holds up the line, and late at night it can get kind of long, especially on the weekends. The cups are a little weird too. I appreciate that they're supposedly biodegradable, but they really are just...weird. Worse, if you decide to walk outside with your treat and eat slowly like I do, the warm weather melts the froyo and the cups are insufficient at containing the overflow that occurs. 

They recently started a card system where you get a free small cup after purchasing several, which is an awesome thing Red Mango does (they should come to Philly!). I wish they also offered a take-away option so that I could bring some back for later, but those damn cups clearly aren't designed to accommodate that request.

So, if you're like me & being from Southern California, listening to all the hype in your own "backyard" about this 5 Guys Burgers & how much better it is than In-N-Out, is somewhat blasphemous. Right? 
From where we currently live (here in SoCal), there is a 5 Guys approx 25 miles to the North and another about 20 miles to the South.
Well, while visiting my brother in Palmyra N.J. for the Thanksgiving Holidays, I just so happened to discover there was one right around the way from his house. So, it was only necessary to find out what all the jibber-jabber was all about.
We had no plans for dinner that night after Thanksgiving, so we all decided to go. This would be me & my wife's first time at this establishment.
To my surprise I found that the 5 Guys' burger is quite tasty! 
I especially like their numbering system of the special ordered burgers. Loaded or unloaded, you make it your way with the fixins that are available.
There were 4 of us with 4 different burgers. Each wrapped burger is numbered which corresponds to the numbered burger on the receipt. On the receipt after each number is the description of each burger & its contents. Genius! One order of fries is definitely enough for two, maybe even 3 people. Very good fries by the way.
However, it is definitely hard to compare their burger to the left coast's In-N-Out burger. The freshness of the Double-Double's lettuce & tomato...and if you happen to get it with grilled onions, it's perfection. The special thousand island dressing that is dolluped upon the Double-Double is...well, special! But this isn't a review about In-N-Out & their burgers...
5 Guys is definitely a unique experience. You're getting a nibble of that side of the country. As you walk in [at this particular 5 guys] , you'll see the bags and bags of Idaho potatoes stacked waist high upon entering & there's a humongous container of peanuts right by the "pick-up" line for you to munch on while you wait. 
All in all a very good East Coast experience.

Now on to the 5 Guys Burgers here in Cali.

This is a deez® public announcement & me and a couple other peeps approve this review. Thanks. Eat & drink well.

My most memorable meal of my NOLA trip was brunch at Brennan's and that was after trying MANY places while visiting. The whole experience was perfect from the delicious food, to the amazing hospitality and atmosphere. If you are looking for a traditional New Orleans meal I definitely recommend it. We started off with their bloody Mary's which were made perfectly. I had the shrimp gumbo to start followed by one of their egg Benedicts called Eggs Sardou which came with sautéed spinach, and fried artichokes. I opted to get it topped with fried oysters as well (because at this point why not lol). We also ordered sides of bacon and grits and wow we were so full and happy after that. The table side prepared bananas foster looked incredible but we were way too full to order dessert. However, they knew it was my birthday and brought me some great surprises after the meal including a sash, a Brennan's cooking apron to take home, and a giant mound of cotton candy with a candle on top which we discovered had delicious ice cream underneath. They sure know how to make a girl feel special. If you find yourself in the FQ definitely come for brunch.

We love Wegmans! 

Cost: my husband always says Wegmans has the best eggs. They are usually three dozen for $3.80. That's better than costco! Personally, I find each individual item to be more than the average grocery store. That's why I'm not giving this establishment five stars. 

Ambiance: the Wegmans decor and interior design is standard and commiserate with the average Wegmans. This particular establishment is clean and the employees are courteous. It is quite crowded on weekends, so we prefer to do our shopping during the week. 

Quality: the fresh produce and perishables in general are what we shop for on a weekly basis. And Wegmans quality is consistent and that's what we like. 

Hours: I also love that it's open 24 hours!

Solid brewery. It not really near anything but because of that it is very large space. The upstairs is much larger with outdoor seating and some board games to play. 

They serve BBQ here too in case you get hungry. Nothing too stand out about their beer though they have an interesting selection. It all tasted pretty standard to me, but still good regardless.
The Grasshopper is life changing. I never liked so many things about a drink: green apple, green tea, little bits of lychee pieces. Wow.

Came home from a long time away from good indian. Planned to come here but took 7 months to drive to Taj. Friends who have really good taste for Indian love this place and I kept aching to make the trip. But still too busy. Finally made it there and of course kicked myself for not going sooner. We had buffet and ordered off menu. Vindaloo was amazing and was not on buffet. Bread wonderful not dry and plentiful. Tiki Marsala best I have had and the butter chicken was worth the longgggg years away from good Indian. I would be once a week if I could be closer.

SO GOOD! 

We got there fairly early Saturday, kind of a late lunch/early dinner basically something small while we start drinking kind of thing.  It was prob around 5pm so there were no more than 10 guests total but by the time we left it had filled up significantly.

I had the blackberry infused Jack Daniels drink and might have fallen in love, so good!  My friend and I shared the tomato basil soup, truffle mac and cheese and the BLT.  Our server was a doll and had the BLT made with the pig on the side so it wouldnt touch my half of the sandwich. It was honestly phenomenal.  I had heard so much about the mac n cheese but I thought the sandwich and my cocktail kicked its ass!

The decor, music and location of the place really make it great as well and there are seats outside (to bring your pooch) but I only saw two tables, so it was too risky to lure him there with promises of table scraps, only to not find outdoor seating!

I would highly recommend returning for happy hour, the drinks were too good not to sample a few and the size of the portions are perfect for sharing a few things with friends!  Also I noticed they take reservations, so thats probably a good idea for a larger group.

I def look forward to returning!

I've attended this event for the last 3 years but after this year, I probably won't be returning. Our visit was Monday, June 4th around 7:30pm to around 9pm.

My friend and I are in line and 2 straight couples are getting in line in front of us. When one of the males walked by me, you could smell the alcohol from him; like strong. As I watched him and his party purchase tickets and head into the event, the guys were drunk; blood shot eyes, the smell and having issues walking. I notified the staff in line (who were on their phones and only looked up when I said something) about the issue and I was told they were going to tell their manager. But I was in line for a while and never saw such action. 

The biggest issue I had with this year is that, it is not a Chinese Lantern Festival without Chinese Lanterns. This year was just illuminated cloth colored animals. I mean were they going for a deep sea theme? And what was with the Game of Thrones tree? And a tarantula? And a dung beetle? The large shark was dripping some brown water from it's tail, no joke and people were walking right underneath it. I'm sorry this is not some "light show" in your friends backyard and that is what if felt like compared to even just last year. Please stop gentrifying (white washing and diluting) everything. It is bad enough how Chinatown is changing with all of its boutique looking generic restaurants.

Second issue, they allowed drinking everywhere. When in years past they had a "beer garden" area where people could drink. But this was just an awful decision on the event coordinator's part. People were noticeably drunk and even saw a staff member with full cup of beer sneaking off to behind the bathrooms. I'm not anti-alcohol but people don't know their limits so allowing them more and more events to drink at, how is that helping the situation, especially in front of their children? Events want money so allowing booze is the cheap, easy way to get it. But how many kids are left in the hands of their "tipsy" parent driving them home? People cant see past their own wants to understand the bigger picture. There were several females who were noticeably drunk and I was walked into at one point.

There was very little staff working this event and the staff that were there, were either at the front on their phones, or around the gates to make sure people didn't sneak in, on their phone. And at one point my friend and I smelled cannabis and he said it was one of the guards. I didn't see it so I don't know but I smelled it near them and no one else was around them.

The last thing, was the bathrooms by the beer garden (like 20ft away) smelled like fecal matter. It made me want to vomit. As we left, I spoke with the manager Wayne, who was in the ticket booth, and I told him everything I am stating here. He wanted me to identify the staff member drinking but I told him I didn't want to get involved. I did my part several times to get these people to pay attention to what was happening under their watch and no one cared to do anything. What bothers me the most is the children that were there...what if some over intoxicated person hurt one of them? It is a dark park with lots of little areas to hide. This is not a family friendly event at all.

This was definitely not like any of the other festivals from previous years and for the price we paid to deal with all of this and the staff not even caring? Yeah, I can give my money to other cause that deserves financial support. I didn't feel comfortable taking pictures of people (I don't want to show their faces) but I have uploaded a picture of 3 staff members not doing their job to add a little more credibility to my review. I don't give 1 stars out lightly if you look at my profile.

Stumbled into this place without even yelping (gasp!) merely because I was wandering around in Chinatown, subconsciously looking for a place worth checking out since it was my first time there. The sign caught my attention and there was a long line as I peeked in, so I made a mental note to self to come back later. When I did, the length of wait line didn't diminish much, but I went in anyway and got myself an almond milk tea.

A few cultural shock points (compared to NYC bubble tea shops):
- I ordered in Mandarin and was met with a confused slash apologetic look, so I made an awkward switch to English - awkward because I've never had to order bubble tea in English, not because I'm not fluent. So yeah, it was my first time ever ordering bubble tea in English lol. Not a bad thing at all, just different.
- Prices were relatively cheap across the board. $3 for a medium is a pretty good deal to me as I'm used to paying at least a buck more.
- They accept credit card!!!!!!!!!!!!! 

I also liked the layout - it's got sort of an industrial decor with its hardwood flooring, but  also a laid-back lounge feel with the high tables and, check this out - JENGA. I was there by myself (touring Philly alone) but the thought of playing Jenga while sipping on a passion fruit bubble tea sounds so quirky and fun. Like an avant-garde way of bubble tea tasting.

Also offers a variety of snacks, including onigiri rice balls(?!!). This place overall offers a refreshing, creative and fun ambience as well as decent drinks. Will definitely return the next time I come to Philly.

Showed up to ACME around noon for our first meal in nola to be greeted with a line. Even though we were starving, we decided to stay and I'm glad we did. The line moved quickly and they were very efficient of getting people seated as soon as possible. 

My fiance ordered the shrimp and catfish platter which he liked, I had the crab cake and we both shared a dozen char-grilled oysters. I loooved the crab cake.
