It had so much flavor especially paired with their special corn salsa. It was our first time eating char-grilled oysters and loved that as well! I'm not sure we ate it the "right" way though- it came with lots and lots of bread that we just ended up discarding. Nevertheless, the oysters were cheesy, buttery and delicious. It was our mistake not ordering some raw oysters as well. We sat at the bar and could see them crack opening all the oysters in front of us- quite entertaining to watch while waiting for your meal!

I LOVE Angeline! I was just there last week and I can't wait to go back.

Because my friend L and I had happy hour elsewhere, we unfortunately did not get an appetizer. We did get a bottle of the Riesling and some great options for our main dish and were very happy with our experience.

L got the veal and I got the rabbit. I love rabbit and I love Angeline's rabbit. The greens that accompanied the rabbit were really good too, with a slight tanginess. I had a bite of the veal as well, and man, that thing just melts in your mouth.

Our server was great, and I ended up having a full-on conversation with him about Portland.

I am definitely going back and trying some hot appetizers (a good friend works in the kitchen) and other main dishes that I am sure are amazing.

PM was a definite regular spot for us years ago and always fit the bill when in the mood for sushi. We were in the hood for the evening and were on the lookout for something vegetarian and, of course, up pops PM on our yelpy radar. It was a pretty busy night but we were sat immediately inside at a table. There's no mistaking that most are looking for an al fresco dining experience in Nashville. It's gorgeous. 

I think we missed the boat a bit with our order, unfortunately. I do remember loving their sushi and especially going nuts over their veggie burger. We went a bit of a different route --

Veggie Fritters - These were a little bland on our end. Not sure if we just got a weird batch? They did have some visibly delicious veg within, but the flavors were a bit flat. The dipping sauce was interesting, too. A different take on honey mustard. Not my favorite. 

Veggie Mu Shu - Where the veggies were pretty good, the crepes, which are typically softer, chewier, and a bit more structured, were pretty bad. They fell apart and had a really bad texture altogether. I forewent them and just ate the veggies, which again, were fantastic. 

Veggie Lo Mein - Holy sesame oil, Batman! That's really all I can say. It was so overwhelmingly sesame-laden that it was a bit hard to eat bite after bite. My wife only ate about 1/3 of it. 

The setting of this place is just awesome, though. Killer place for a drink on the patio or even at the bar. I'd definitely recommend the sushi and veggie burger, but the items we had are a little less-than passable. Either way, still a huge fan of PM!

It's like every other Chipotle ever. But if you want to do Chipotle like a boss, order online or on your phone, walk in, pick up your food, and watch the 20 people in line stare at you with jealously in their eyes.

Beautiful, historic hotel just blocks from Bourbon Street, Jackson Square, and all that the French Quarter has to offer. The rooms were a decent size and this hotel has a beautiful courtyard where they do a Sunday Jazz Brunch and they have a decent sized pool. 

The staff was very friendly and helpful -providing some great recommendations and holding our bags after check-out. While a little pricey, the location and charm of this historic hotel could not be matched.

Just trying to grab something  after  dinner  to take  home.  I waited at least 15 minutes & kept asking for assistance & not receiving  any help.
The pasteries  were running  low and none had any prices on them. It is sometimes hard to decide if you are willing to pay the price, depending on the size & visual b of the pastry.
I got 2 cannoli s & 2 tiny finger eclairs. The canola crust was half pasty and wet, not desireable. I liked the cream filling, but it was a bit gritty, good flavor & personally  I  missed the chocolate. 
The very tiny eclairs were absolutely  delicious.  The cream was tender and luscious.  The minimal chocolate  was tasty and solid.
Overall, the prices for the minature sweets was way past the price of the individual  pieces.  Hey, come on post the prices! It looks bad on the restaurant  & makes  the customer  feel  uncomfortable, having to ask for prices. This is a no win situation.
Even though the sweets were quite good, considering the wait, with no one in front of me, no prices, curt service & lack of courtesy....I see no reason to return.
What's a girl to do? Look for pastries that are better  served, named & priced.

Wait they have malts!  What's a malt? I don't know. I know that I've always sucked the chocolate off of Whoppers candies so that I could enjoy the flavor of the crunchy center, so why not give this thing a try? Super excited to suck down a cool shake that could possibly taste like malt balls we went ahead and ordered. It certainly didn't disappoint. I want one all the time now.

Great service and food! The staff were extremely friendly. The seating area was very clean. Plenty of parking outside.

I ordered a burrito bowl with white rice, chicken, mild salsa, corn salsa, cheese, sour cream, and guacamole. All the ingredients were very fresh. The flavors were also amazing as usual! 

Only change I would make to the seating area is to have more low tables and chairs. Seems to mostly bar stools and high top tables.

When it grew cold outside on Tuesday I had a serious hunger that could only be quenched by a huge sandwich. So I braved the wind and a 5 block out of the way walk to Primo's only to find that they were closed. Rather than shed a tear I went with the next best option - a semi out of the way train ride and a long walk back home after hitting up Lee's. Good thing it was worth it!

I remember Lee's back when it used to be in Wynnewood and how it always hooked up a monster sized Hoagie. It was a sad day when that one closed and I was hoping for the West Philly one to at least provide sandwiches that were equal in size. So when I found out that they did and also hooked up all kinds of chicken wings, finger foods, and breakfast sandwiches - Needles to say happy days were here again. I picked up a monster sized turkey Hoagie and loaded it up with hot/sweet peppers, lettuce, tomato, and sharp provolone and t sent me to flavor country. It's good to get reacquainted with old places!

Pros: Large portions, freindly service.

Cons: Parking, cash only, not the freshest gyro... the meat was a tad dry.

What's up with the Egyptian pictures on the wall?

I am so glad we booked The Handlebar on our most recent trip to Indy!

The Handlebar is a trolley/pedal pub company. You can bring your own drinks aboard (no liquor) and then for two hours get to pedal around the city blasting music! The pedal pub will also stop at a few stops. 

On this specific occasion we were with a bachelorette group and another couple. Definitely a fun vibe. We stopped at the Circle for pictures and two pubs. 

What makes the Handlebar unique are the people working. Joel and Sawyer are such fantastic people and really care about the company, your experience, and Indy. My husband and I truly enjoyed getting to know both of them!

Please take our suggestion and book the Handlebar for something fun to do in Indy!

Why doesn't Yelp allow for half stars? They really should... With that said, this place is a 3.5 stars for me. 

I love me some good Thai and this place is absolutely legit! I always get the same two things: drunken noodles and papaya salad (Thai hot!) and I'm never disappointed. 

I've dined in twice but usually get take out. I like the layout of the restaurant - the tables are far enough apart that you don't feel like you're eavesdropping on anyone else's conversation or bumping into another chair when you need to get up. The decor is modern and clean. The staff has always been attentive and helpful. 

My only gripe with this place is the price. Vietnamese food is cheap. Chinese food is cheap. Indian food is non-existent in this city. Japanese food is pricy but sushi is an art and eating art ain't cheap. Anyhow... what I'm trying to say is Vietnamese/Chinese/Thai food can be very similar - especially when it's frying noodles with veggies in a sauce. I just don't understand why Thai food has to cost more? A lot more. What am I missing? 

So I like the food here but I wish it were student-budget-friendly. Oh and the portion size can be bigger. Coming from Seattle and San Francisco where Thai restaurants are as common as Popeyes, I'm accustomed to authentic, affordable Thai in fat-lazy-American-gluttonous portions and this place falls short of these expectations.  Guess I just can't have it all...

2013 is an awfully weird year to open up a video rental store given the current climate of Netflix, On Demand, and Redbox. But if anyone can pull it off its a ragtag bunch of TLA Video alum who are full blown cinephiles!

Rather than be an average rental store Viva really does strive to win its customer base over with a full blown cinematic experience, and you'll know that once you realize that each and every movie display they have laid out contains at least 5+ Criterion Collection DVDs. The owners worked at the TLA Video store in Bryn Mawr for several years before it became the final TLA to close down, and they have become experts in helping people find the rare movies they've never heard of that cater exactly to their preference in genre.

Whether your a sci-fi kung-fu fan who's looking for movies that feature ninjas battling cyborg samurais, a comedy drama fan who's looking for quirky romance stories, a documentary fan who's obsessed with scandal, someones who likes Hollywood legend debut films, or is someone who just likes to walk into a store and carry on a conversation about zombie movies; they are fully able to help you out. And you can even rejoice if you're just looking to catch up on an old standby of yours, because there's a good chance that they'll have the very rare special edition that you never knew existed.

Hold the phone! Union Trust is offering a $7.17 lunch menu!! While I had trouble choosing between the three options: Duck salad tossed with cranberries and candied walnuts, fish and chips, and the Kobe beef burger, I ultimately caved into my beef calling. Delicious brioche bun, perfectly seasoned meat topped with melted American cheese. Simple but awesome.

To think you can now experience UT without have to dive deep into your wallet. Wonder if Tommy Up's going to pull another receipt stunt.

Wow the portion size is huge, the food is fresh, and the price is cheap! Thankful that Hispanic food places are finally popping up along the Main Line. It took long enough! El Limon is a welcome addition and one of the first. (Now others, who shall remain nameless, have followed suit.) Their tacos, burritos, etc. are great and will leave you stuffed and with leftovers. They have Mexican Coca-Cola (real sugar used!) too, which is just like the Coca-Cola we had as kids before the high fructose corn ick was added to American Coca-Cola. The service is friendly, all round making for a nice meal.

This is on Lancaster Avenue near the Ardmore R5 Station. Check it out!

Attentive and kind staff.

Very well organized and well stocked.

Everything you need healthy (real cheddar cheese snack, greek yogurt, actually healthy protein bars) to not-so-much (candy, mac 'n' cheese, soda).  Seriously.  Where else can you get an umbrella, coffee, ice cream, shampoo AND Vicodin (ahem, they have a pharmacy, duh)?!

I'm so glad I found this place in Philly, it's going to be my go-to-stop if I'm in the city. It's a nice, new, clean shop right on the corner of Race and 10th. 

This is the place to get fruit tea or diced fruit teas with pulp in them. There's also smoothies and milk tea, though I would say the focus is mostly on the fruit drinks offered.

I tried a passion fruit green tea, it was good, with real seeds from passionfruit inside. I loved sucking in the seeds. At 60% sugar level and less ice, it was still pretty sweet, so I recommend trying 30% sugar.

The colorful fruit tea was also delicious, I could taste the fruit juice and there were finely diced  tiny cubes of apples, and some passion fruit seeds. It gave the drinks a fun texture. Drinks are around $3.50 for medium or $4.50 for large.

I like that this place uses real fruit, that you can taste! There's also toppings you can add to your fruit tea or drinks, like coconut jelly, boba balls, aiyu jelly, aloe, or chia seeds.

This is a pretty decent steak house, especially considering it's in a touristy beach town.  It's one of three restaurants by the same owner on St Pete Beach, the other two being Mad Fish and Snappers.  Like the other two, this one also does not have liquor, just beer and wine.

The restaurant does not take reservations and it is quite small, as is its parking lot, so chances are if you have trouble finding a parking spot, you're also going to have trouble getting a table; that's my method of determining if my wife and I will go there or not.  It's very cozy inside, perhaps 12 tables total, most being two or four tops.

This is not really a good place to bring kids, especially if they're still stroller-age, because it's nearly impossible to maneuver a stroller inside.  The only exception to that is if you're in a party of four to six.  In that case, there's a table in the front corner of the building that seats six and has room for a stroller on the end of it.  There is also no kids menu.

Food-wise, everything is quite good.  I've had the ribeye, filet, chicken saltlmbocca and chicken marsala and all were excellent.  Their wedge salad is crunchy and fresh as well.  They know how to cook the steaks the way you order them, even Pittsburgh-style.  They DO have Bearnaise sauce, which is surprisingly hard to find at steak houses, and theirs is great.

The staff are generally very attentive, however, they often forget to tell you about the specials, and the specials often include items that are not on the normal menu, so make sure you ask about them if it's not mentioned as you might be missing out on something unique and great.  I had a fantastic salmon entree a few weeks ago that was not on the regular menu and would not have known had I not asked.

They have outdoor seating, but I'd probably forgo that if you're in the months of June through September because it's pretty darn warm outside.

Yes it is absolutely worth the wait! The food was spectacular! The service was great and we had a great time! We started dinner off with some vodka oyster shooters to warm us up, then of course we had to try the sampler to get a good taste of New Orleans staples, followed by a combo of the fresh and chargrilled oysters. The oysters in New Orleans are amazing and at Acme, they are just incomparable! The Bloody Mary's are also specially made there and so delicious!

This review is on Rusty in Tampa 
The star is for the great atmosphere and views. Other than that the food is just bland and not worth the money. 
I have been here multiple times for work meetings and events and it is always terrible food from appetizers to main course to wine selection. I imagine the company keeps on going there every year because they have some kind of connection   I cant really see any other reason

Food
Stuffed mushrooms are dry and tasteless 
How do they manage to ruin mushrooms...?
Pastas are always drowned in sauce that lacks seasoning
Steak are always overcooked and flavorless
Service
I never got the opportunity to get a knowledgeable waiter 

Bartender do not know how to make a negroni nor an old fashioned!!! What!? Really? In a high end restaurant like this one says it is

On top of it, I have to agree with other reviewers, especially Pink, about the event planners. The older man does not really handle the event planning in a pleasant manner. Is almost like they are doing us a favor if you want to plan an event with them. The other ladies in the office are not attentive. First thing they said when we walked in was i hope you have an appointment. Im not sure how they do business but they are lucky they have an amazing location on the water which keeps people coming in to try it 

The only thing i havent try here is brunch... So maybe they do good with eggs and waffles. 

If you are looking to wow a date and have delicious food with great service you should try other Tampa places like Berns steakhoue. No panoramic views there but it is beautiful place inside and you can always take a walk on bayshore (by the bay)  after great dessert at their top floor

Love this place the atmosphere is very chill the drinks and food are awesome the staff is very friendly 

I've been here a few times and it never fails this place is awesome 

I love the view 

The prices are fair, this place is great to have drink an just chill. I come here a few times a month.

This place is awesome!! It is my birthday and  I made a special request! They went over and above to accommodate it! No hassle , no complications  the late night crew that worked 04-24 deserves the recognition!  

I'm a stickler about my Starbucks and if it wasn't so far from home it would be my regular! I will definitely stop by on my way to Tampa!!

You go Starbucks crew!! You have a new fan here

After reading many positive reviews on this Korean wonder, I knew hubby and I had to try it for ourselves!

We normally don't venture down to Temple Terrace, but were coming from an event that conveniently had us nearby!

Food: Whoa. Best Korean in Tampa! I've been to Sa Ri One in Tampa, and wasn't impressed. Coming from a family of Asian background, i've had authentic Korean food and Soul of Korea is authentic! We tried the kim chi dumplings, chicken wings, sweet and sour chicken, and a steak hot pot. We totally overordered, but didn't regret the leftovers! The wings were huge and full of Korean BBQ flavor! The dumplings had the great taste of kim chi and were fried just right. The sweet and sour chicken, came with honey sauce instead of it's red imposter. The hot pot was our favorite! the mixture of Korean vegetables, fresh egg, rice, and meat was scarfed down quickly!

Atmosphere: This is a little family-owned "dive" in Temple Terrace. Don't expect fine dining, this is more of a cafe feel type of place.  The food makes it totally worth it.

Service: the ladies who served our food were so friendly and sweet, they made recommendations (since we were so hungry we couldn't think straight) and they were spot-on!

We want to come back, like, yesterday. We wished it was closer to us - GO HERE if you want YUMMY Korean Food!
We had the bibimbob and the pajeon (korean pancake). Those 2 dishes for 2 people were just enough and the price for it all was awesome.

This place is FIRE, quite literally!

First of all, I love the pandas in the entryway, and I appreciate how clean the place is and how friendly the employees are. Oh, and the fact that there are photos of the food emblazoned on the menu in the front--I always find that useful, but especially at places where I'm not 100% familiar with the cuisine, like authentic Sichuan noms.

We've come here a few times, and can't wait to come back. We've been trying to try something new each time we eat here, and Chengdu never disappoints. The ignite noodles were, well, Sichuan-level spicy, and they certainly did ignite all sorts of feelings. Some included tears.But it was tasty. The spicy cold chicken noodles were just as delicious, and perhaps even more peanut-y and tasty, but less intensely spicy. Perfect for a hot summer's day.

The dumplings in chili oil were some of the prettiest dumplings I've ever seen, though a bit light on the filling. I can't wait to try the dragon wontons next! The eggplant, which I'm not sure was on the menu, is breaded and covered in sweet, spicy sauce, and I think is one of my favorite ways to eat eggplant now. Their Chengdu burgers are interesting, though not necessarily what I'd come here for... that I think belongs to all the chili oil and dry pot foods.

Overall, it's a great way to visit and eat through the capital of the former Shu Kingdom without a passport. I'd highly recommend for the adventurous, Scoville-loving eater in Philly!

I love my parents.  But if Marcie Turney and Valerie Safran offered to adopt me as their child if I never spoke to them again, I wouldn't even think twice.  Oh to be able to eat from their delicious restaurants all the time... sigh... and sorry mom and dad.
 
The atmosphere at Little Nonna's is a 10.  We ate out on the patio and what was probably my favorite thing was the hanging laundry on the side wall.  Great touch.
 
Don't even get me started on the meatballs... mmm mmm mmm.  B + V + P + Shauna = BFFs.  It was definitely the highlight of the meal.  And because I feel the need to always put my food in competition with each other and rank things and make lists, I will now list in order of taste preference the other things that I ate (from the Restaurant Week lunch menu):
 
     2. Orecchiette 
     3. Tiramisu
     4. Shaved Salad
     5. Chicken Parm Sandwich
     6. Pistachio Cannoli

Yum!  Well done on your new place, ladies!

I don't know what I was expecting. I guess "diner" by definition means average. Diners always tend to be a little too expensive for the quality of food you're getting. This one is no exception: pretty average diner with average food and average diner prices. Nothing was terrible, but nothing was outstanding either. Maybe I'm a diner snob, being from Jersey, but this one isn't particularly worth a trip out of your way. We should've saved our $25 for two people and gone to one of the Indonesian or Vietnamese places in South Philly. 

I will say, however, that this place is much better than the Philly diner in West Philly. That place is gross.

I'm not a huge fan of Dublin donuts over the past several years since I've consistently had water down coffees and a stale donut here and there when I do opt to get one. Since this DD is right around the corner and I've been here several times I thought it was only fitting to finally leave a review.

The hot chocolate I ordered from here was so water downed, as if they are trying to stretch the mix. I informed the worker how bland it was and he offered another one; that too tasted similar so I just didn't bother thereafter. The hash browns I ordered were soggy and soft. This place just did not leave a great impression.

We started at the bar with Georgeann, she was friendly and engaging, fabulous!  They have great happy hour prices on their 102+ martinis and your Yelp check-in BOGO, such a deal.  We had a mocha and a James Bond both were smooth.  I loved the mocha!  Also free smoked almonds at tables and bar.

We headed to our table, in the small circular brick room opening to the bar/kitchen.  The atmosphere was romantic and almost castle like.  Great candles!

Our waiter was Clark, he was  very friendly and informative about specials and items on the menu.  We settled on the scallops, wangu burger, and a side of truffle, mushroom macaroni and cheese.

While waiting for the food which was out in less than 10 minutes, a young lady with a basket draped in red delivered  us bacon, cheese bread. OMG, it was incredible!!  She made it back to our table just before the food hit, yes I will make room for the bread.

The scallops melted in our mouths, cooked perfectly.  They were accompanied by spinach, peas, fiddleheads, and gnocchi.  The burger was ordered medium rare and also cooked to perfection, served with thin crispy chip like fries.  The burger is out of this world.  The mac and cheese was creamy and good, but was very heavy handed with the garlic and proved to be too over powering to eat.  We did order two martinis from the bar inside a blue moon, yum like a hurricane, and a blue eyes, but it was like turpentine.  As we were leaving Clark brought another this time for Georgeann in the bar area, huge improvement.  He told us he just didn't want us to leave not enjoying ourselves. Such a class act!!

We will absolutely return.  Watch for a Groupon! Which we used in conjunction with our other Yelp check-in.

Only 2 visits under my belt but been more than impressed both occasions. I have made a vow to include them in my regular rotation for dinner. 

I have had shrimp pastas and chicken piccata and both were devine. Others have ordered fish and chips, fajitas, prime rib stroganoff, and the cippinnio. All have raved about their dishes. 

I highly recommend you check them out. Menu is smaller but still extensive, something for everyone.

ISC met June 29. Thanks, Sarah S., for your continual spot-on restaurant selection.

El Agave is in Watson Plaza, a large, C-shaped shopping center, with Kohl's at the top (facing west), Shop 'n Save facing Watson and El Agave at the bottom (facing east). Just turn in when you see Kohl's.

This may be the largest Mexican restaurant I've ever patronized. There's a lovely separate bar and numerous smallish dining areas.

Our server was pleasant and knowledgeable of the menu. I asked him for a recommendation, and that's what I got. But I don't know its name. The menu is sporting a picture of it. Nopales are involved.

And this massive, wonderful dish was served in a huge black "pottery" footed bowl lined with foil. Besides nopales, there was chicken, shrimp, pico, sour cream and vegetables . . . no doubt other things.

This was the first time in my life I've had a Mexican dish that didn't include tortillas. And that includes Mexico City, Puerto Vallarta, Cancun and all villages down the road from Cancun to Tulum and up the road from Mexico City to Taxco.

And I was more than ecstatic with that.

Dang-bang it, was that good and continued to be fabulous with the abundance in my to-go vessel.

It was a fun evening with fellow Yelpers. Service was just right. Water was replenished in a timely fashion. And it seemed like everyone was pleased with their selections.
Another Dunkin that take zero pride in their coffee. Just get your coffee and beat it. No professional workers, place is dirty and the coffee is inconsistent

I always enjoy myself at The Rum House. It was a nice day out so I was able to enjoy my dining experience outside, which makes me happy because I love Magazine Street. I tried out the scallop and fried oyster tacos which both were amazing! I love scallops and these were done right, I just wanted to over millions of them!

When you visit The Rum House, definitely try different tacos, you will be surprised how much you like them and I normally don't like tacos.

5 stars for cool beers, 1 star for German food.

Their beer selection and in-house brews just make ya want to drink more and try em' all! Most of the people there were drinking, not eating, and now I know why. 

Perhaps we ordered the wrong food or were there on a bad night, but we were not at all impressed with the food. I ordered the Jagerschnitzel with spaetzl - absolutely huge portion (size of entire large plate) of schnitzel (dry, bland, and a little tough) covered in a cream sauce with mushrooms (reminded me a Campbell's cream of mushroom soup with some wine added - blech). The spaetzl was nothing special and a little rubbery. BF ordered the homemade sausages (1 pork, 1 chicken) with hot German potato salad - sausages were soooooooo dry it was hard to eat and potato salad was like boiled potatoes in pickle juice - blech. Both entrees were pricy ($16 for schnitzel, $12 for 2 sausages). 

Server was super friendly and interior is inviting and pleasant.

I had no idea there was a Pizza King over here, and I'm pretty excited that it's a good one! It's kind of out in the country, in Cumberland, but it's convenient for us east-siders. The interior is wood booth seating, with Tiffany style lamps above each table and and lots of live plants and trees. You place your order on the Ding-a-Ling (red phone on each table) using your table #, and a server brings out your drinks and food. Our cheese bread arrived kinda lukewarm, but the pizza itself was great. I love that they put the toppings edge to edge on that wonderful thin crust. Pizza King uses crumbly sausage and thin frizzled ham rather than the bizarre "sausage balls" and "ham squares" that many large chains use. 

The jukebox selection is AWFUL, unless you're a fan of bad early 90s country music. I put my dollar in before I looked at the tunes available and actually had a hard time picking 4 songs to play.

This was my absolute favorite meal I ate in New Orleans, and trust me... I ate A LOT of meals. I love you, Gumbo Shop!

Our Lyft driver recommended this spot to us while we drove into New Orleans from the airport during our first afternoon in town. A few days later, we finally had some free time to stop in, and I was so satisfied with our experience. 

We arrived around 1:30pm, which I thought might be a good time to visit since it's a bit after the normal lunch rush, but there was still quite a long line in the foyer of the restaurant. Luckily, the line moved quickly and efficiently, and were seated in no less than 10 minutes. While we waited, I began to notice the gorgeous decor and colors inside, and that the shop features two all-gender restrooms.  There was also a specials board featuring some appetizers and a gumbo plate that wasn't on the printed menu.

Once we were seated, we had a chance to look at the menu, and our waiter reiterated the specials. Gumbo Shop offers plenty of gumbo options, of course, and at fair prices. I thought they might easily charge a good amount of money for a dish, since there are always long lines outside, but their low prices may be *why* the lines are so long. Who can resist a delicious deal? I am a big fan of seafood -- and since we're in New Orleans I trust the seafood will be amazing at most places -- so I ordered the seafood okra gumbo. My boyfriend decided on the creole combination platter. 

While we waited for our food, we each ordered a beer. Gumbo Shop features some rotating options, and on this particular day they were featuring two Abita brand pours: an amber and a blonde. My boyfriend ordered the amber, and I went with the blonde. Our waiter brought these out within a few minutes, along with some bread and butter. Who doesn't love some bread and butter to start off a hearty meal?! The answer is that everyone does. 

When our food was on its way out, I got so pumped, because this was my first time eating gumbo, EVER... and once I tasted this gumbo, I knew I'd been spoiled. I will never taste gumbo as good as the one I experienced here at Gumbo Shop. Please, please, if you visit New Orleans, you must eat here. I promise the wait is much shorter than you'll expect, because service is impressive and efficient here, and the prices are low. You'll absolutely love it. 

I can't wait to come back next time I'm in town!

I am really disappointed by how they are coping with COVID.  First of all you have to download the menu on the phone.  My phone wouldn't scan the  barcode, and they didn't seem to have back up menus. Our server was short and unfriendly and not helpful at all. Luckily my friend arrived and she was able to download a much slimmer menu. Then, our "server" who actually didn't serve us anything,  said we needed to go get our food and pay online.  To pay online you need to open an account (?) and give out personal information.  Neither of us was comfortable with that so the server rolled her eyes and said that if we insisted we could pay at the machine.  And it was a tap. No idea why you would make your customers open an account to pay via phone when you have a tap machine.  We asked for water which we got tiny glasses of with no refills. And after we got our food,  there was no asking if we needed anything else, and we had to clean up our own dishes.  I felt like I was paying for a friggin summer camp experience.  We were both super disappointed.  Why open your restaurant to the public when you have no intention of serving them. I have been to around 20 restaurants and I have never seen such mismanaged bad service and COVID protical. Both servers who really didn't do anything and  looked like they hated being there.  Both of us had the falafel bowl which was tasty but was completely ruined by the atmosphere.  I haven't had such a bad experience in many years. I probably won't ever go back even when COVID is over. If you want a nice enjoyable experience stay clear of here.

Drive thru is fast and the outdoor lounge area is so cool. It's a good place to meet a friend or something.  If I lived closer to this location, I would be here daily. Also, parking is pretty good. Lots of spaces.

I really struggled between 3 and 4 stars but I rounded up because both my boyfriend and I really enjoyed our breakfast and it was a fabulous price.

I dont normally get omelets but i ordered one because they had some really interesting sounding combinations - ESP the Irish omelette. It had all my favorite ingredients: spinach, cheese, mushrooms, onions & tomatoes.

The prices are suspiciously cheap here. Less than $6 for a three-egg omelette not drowning in grease?!? It was a solidly good omelette. Not the fluffy kind with the ingredients tucked in; it was the scrambled then folded type of omelette (takes less skill to do those). Still it was really very good - again, not greasy, not dried out. It had an adequate amount of veggies so I left happy and ready to return.

Ambulance has left a little something to be desired. It's just a plain 'ol mom n pop diner. Not much character or flare. I will say that they have kept the place up by accenting some walls with nice beige tile; so it's nicer looking than some other diners in St Pete.

Service was prompt and super friendly too.
This  New Mexico-based hamburger  joint is a must try. The  green chile cheeseburgers are so freaking good!
Tuesday night crawfish!! 2lbs of Crawfish for $30 for soup and a draft!! I really need to thank my buddy for introducing me to this place. If you like bread pudding...this is your spot.

I definitely saw Mother's on Man vs. Food many times and I'm a sucker for places that appear on TV.  So finally on my recent trip to New Orleans, I decided to stop by.  It happened to be a rainy Monday afternoon and we visited around 1 PM.  To my surprise, the line was only about 6 people deep.  Not too bad.  It went by pretty quickly.  So you get a menu and you order, pay, then seat yourself and one of the waitresses will come by to take your ticket.  Odd, but it works.  After hearing about how big the regular sizes of their po-boys were, my bf and I decided to share one, get a side of gumbo and a side of potato salad.  Gumbo was yummy and the sandwich was definitely enough to feed two.  We got the famous Ferdi Special and were satisfied.  All the waitresses there are so nice and I enjoyed being called "sweet pea." Too bad they don't accept tips.

Despite the name, Stella is not traditional New Orleans cuisine. It is more of a gourmet experience with New Orleans overtones. 

My wife and I had the risotto appetizer (extraordinary), fish and chips (deconstructed and put back together by a gourmet wizard), and lamb like no other I've ever had. For dessert we split a bananas foster French toast which was excellent. Our friends had some funky egg appetizer which my friend wasn't happy with, duck five ways and the fish and chips. They had another appetizer and dessert that I can't remember. 

The araucana egg appetizer had some other kind of egg, not the blue egg that was supposed to come with it. In response to my friend's email, the owner said they had goofed up and apologized but didn't offer any sort of accommodation. 

The ambience was nice but not overwhelming. The tables were far enough apart that we could talk. 

Yes, the service is pretentious. Veddy pretentious. But I'd get a big head too if I were serving food this good. And they advised me not to wear a coat and tie when I called to make the reservation. Nor did the officious waitress flinch when we ordered beer instead of wine.

Easy market and sandwich bar near the marinas and boat yards.  They carry a aood selection of beer, pop, waters, snacks and really good made to order sandwiches.  
We had turkey and Italian sammies and requested turkey to be warmed in the panini press (not a norm).  No issues and they were delish!  They use Boarshead spreads.  Sandwiches are under $10 each.  
Friendly and fast service!

Recommended by the Marriott, where my parents were staying... dad was looking for a good Italian restaurant.

The ambiance in Cibo was great, especially the live music with the rotating servers singing! The food was standard Italian, but I don't think it was really anything special. Our server was not helpful at all when asking suggestions about wines and dishes. It would've been helpful to note that any dish not listed as pasta does not come with pasta. Most Italian restaurants, you assume pasta is the side. Not a big deal, I loved the sides, but it would've been nice to know ahead of time. 

A few minutes into our meal, my dad found a hair in his side dish and immediately brought it to the attention of our server. All the server did was take it away and offer him something else, to which my dad told him he had lost his appetite. And that was it, no further conversation about it whatsoever... no apology from a manager, nothing else to make it better... it was either get another meal or you're SOL for having a hair in your food.

My food was great, as was my stepmom's. I know stuff happens and sometimes you get a hair. The whole thing just seemed awkward and handled incorrectly. The food was good enough, but I probably won't be back due to the whole experience.

Pumpkin came highly recommended by many of my colleagues and Yelp Eliters, so my husband and I decided to give it a try for Restaurant Week Fall 2020! 3 courses for $35 for dinner. The menu always seemed a bit lackluster to us with relatively simple ingredients but assumed it was a more elevated cuisine. We were correct that it's definitely elevated but possibly just not a great fit for us. We like bold and elegant flavors, which we got from the sweet potato confit which was our  favorite part of the night. Every other part of our dinner was subpar. For our other appetizer we got the chickpea soup (chilled) - good fragrant spices but not enough bold flavor for us. Entrees were monkfish and shrimp & grits which was disappointing because the Instagram post with the restaurant week menu listed duck breast on the menu, but it was never corrected on Instagram or the website and only told once we were seated. I heard raving reviews about the duck breast and was genuinely disappointed we drove out to Rittenhouse from the Main Line and weren't able to try it. Dessert we got mint panna cotta and chocolate cake. My husband liked the mint Panna cotta but the texture just doesn't do it for me; the chocolate cake was dry and sauces were confusing. It tasted like hoisin sauce and cranberry sauce on the plate with a dry chocolate cake that was hard to swallow. Overall, pretty disappointing. The ingredients were all fresh but it did not live up to the hype. I was looking forward to this dinner all week, I guess these menu items were just not a great fit for us.

This review is from my July 2021 visit.

It wasn't a fun experience. 

We went there on a whim ( we found a parking spot near by). 
Service was borderline rude and very slow. Chips, which are NOT gratis, were stale, ice cold and  "flat ". The salsa was tasteless there seemed to be absence of flavor in everything we ordered. I'd the beef el pastor burrito bowl. Meh, it was very rice centric! Pineapple Margaritas were too sweet - there was no pineapple flavor evident just sour mix. 

Here's the kicker our server added a 20% tip (for a party of 2)  but didn't tell us and there's no warning on the menu. When we asked him why he didn't tell us (after we left an additional 25% tip before realizing what he did) he said it was because of "dine and dashers". If someone is going to run out on the check they will also run out on the tip! So that's just not a cogent explanation! Frankly, i could see why you wouldnt want to tip there but dining and dashing is theft. Ironically we were the ones  left feeling ripped off for sure. Since it was my first meal out in 17 months I didn't want to deal with confronting the server but I'll never go back there again. 

The overall experience was unpleasant. I have a hard time leaving less than 3 stars on any review but I won't be recommending this location. Evidently there are several in the area. 

So, after all that we discovered it's a crappy chain joint to boot!

Affordable prices and great food and service!  We got there around 11:30am and it was easy to find a seat but as we left around noon, there was a line out the door!  We got the boiled crawfish which was about $10 a pound that day and it was delicious and fun to eat!

Thai Cafe is another of the 4 family-owned Thai establishments that populate the east end of the Loop.  Thai Cafe is located east of Skinker, across from The Pageant.

Their menu is similar to Thai Country and Thai Gai Yang, while the decor is more reminiscent of Thai Country.  The food is good, with huge portions and a good amount of spice delivered with the curries.

On a recent visit, it seemed as though they were short staffed because we only ever saw one waitress throughout the whole restaurant.  So while service was a little slow going, it was still good, as our drinks were refilled regularly, and our food didn't take forever to make it out of the kitchen.

While I enjoyed Thai Cafe, I can only hope that on my next trip to St. Louis, Thai Country Cafe will be done with the remodeling and I can get my real STL Thai fix.

I like this place. I've never had chaat and so the first time I asked the guy who works there what chaat is. He said it is Indian street food and he described chaat was being something that is sweet and sour and tangy and spicy and and salty and excitement for your mouth. 

That's pretty much correct. I've tried 3 different chaats. They were all called chaat, but they were all pretty different, so it's still not clear to me why all these things that are so different are all still called chaat, but that's the way it is. In any case, they were all very good. I especially like the Lamb Chaat. Another time I also tried the chicken biryani and that was pretty good (biryani is not chaat). And the samosas and lassi are also very good.

I've been here about 3 times in the last 3 weeks, and I definitely plan on going back, and through campus food it looks like you can have your food delivered. 

For those interested - here's a portion of what wikipedia says about chaat........ 

The word derives from Hindi c  (tasting, a delicacy), from cn  (to lick), from Prakrit caei  (to devour with relish, eat noisily).[1]

The chaat variants are all based on fried dough, with various other ingredients. The original chaat is a mixture of potato pieces, crispy fried bread Dahi vada or Dahi Bhalla ("Bhalla" in Hindi), gram or chickpeas and tangy-salty spices, with sour home-made Indian chilli and Saunth (dried ginger and tamarind sauce), fresh green coriander leaves and yogurt for garnish, but other popular variants included Aloo tikkis (garnished with onion, coriander, hot spices and a dash of curd), bhel puri, dahi puri, panipuri, dahi vada, papri chaat, and sev puri.

We came here with another couple who are vegetarian and I am pleased to say that I enjoyed a great vegetarian meal (they have meat options as well). The paneer pakora, veg biriyani, chili paneer and malai kofta were all delicious! If you have a craving for Indian food, this is the place to go.

I like this place a ton! It definitely has the atmosphere of a brewery with the beer brewing towers, wood tables, chalkboards with the beer list and several beer taps.

I came here for a date and we initially sat at the bar. He ordered an IPA and I ordered a blonde beer, both great choices! I wasn't really focusing on the names of the beer since I was on a date, sorry. :)

After about 10 minutes of chatting and sipping our beer we decided to head upstairs so we could hear each other better. I think on a regular, no music day, sitting at the bar would be fine but they had a great singer/songwriter playing some tunes. 

We moved upstairs where there were board games, a t.v with football playing, and, dun, dun, dun- A fooseball table! 

My date and I were the only people upstairs so we played solo foose and had a blast. Afterwards we sat and chatted and drank a few beers and enjoyed the ability to have a conversation while still listening to the live music!

I will go back more often now! The beertenders were very helpful, knowledgeable, and fun! 

Tip: go check out the bathroom sinks, they are pretty cool.

Enjoy!

First time in Gyu-kaku Philadelphia and it was a good time for us. They offer happy hour menu everyday before 6pm and weekdays after 10pm, which takes a few dollars off most of the items on the menu. And their app, being the most useful restaurant app ever, you get 100 points straight after you sign up and you can already redeem the points for some free food :-) 
We tried their shio ramen and beef sukiyaki bibimbap, tastes are ok but price is really cheap so no complaint. The bibimbap only has beef, no veggies at all, which is kind of weird... 
As for grill, we got duck breast, beef tongues, beef toro, horumon, pork belly, kalbi chunks, and mushroom medley. The duck breast and beef tongues are my favorites, the cuts of pork belly and horumon definitely need some improvements though... 
The experience to grill yourself was fun and the service was really nice. Also the price is much more friendlier than Korean bbqs, I hope they could open one in Baltimore!

a few friends and i were looking for a new byob to try and chose this place for its generally good reviews. so thanks yelpers, for yet another great experience! it's a bit out of our way, but was definitely worth the extra effort!

my friends went with the $25 three-course meal, but personally i have no use for appetizers and desserts. i go straight for the meat, and so i chose the mushakkil. according to their description: "a mix of chicken and lamb kabob, juicy lamb chops and spicy kofta all marinated in exotic spices, served with rice and tahina sauce." 

all the different types of meat appealed to me, especially the lamb! i love that gamey taste ;) even the chicken was good- a little dry, but more tender than most restaurants that serve chicken. what can i say? i'm a true carnivore.

even the rice was amazingly addictive! i had to finish every bite on my plate even though i was stuffed about three-quarters of the way through. i think having wine with dinner helps expand my stomach :)

the restaurant is long and narrow in shape, and for the most part was empty on a tuesday night. the seats and walls are decorated with curtains and pillows in what seems to be a mediterranean/middle eastern style, at least from movies that i've seen. the service was prompt and the waitress was really helpful with explaining what everything was. since this was only the second time i've ever had mediterranean in my life, you better bet i'll be back for more.

Hovering between 3 and 4*. TLDR: Flatbeads and bison burger were good; the fish tacos should be renamed slaw tacos (at least on this particular visit). 

------------------------------------

The sister stopped by to visit us in Philly, so we rounded up the troops to grab some grub in the Fairmount area. I was told that Fare had bacon Bloody Mary's round the clock, regardless of whether they were serving brunch. And sure enough that's true.

But alas, they were somehow out of them when we stopped by. Not sure how that happens, but they did have food at least! There's a modern farmhouse-vibe of a bar to the left and to the right, there's plenty of seating for dining. 

Farmhouse Flatbread [$12]
Bacon, sharp cheddar, Granny Smith 

We got the farmhouse flatbread to start. Sweet and savory elements were featured here. The crisp Granny Smith apples imparted some tart sweetness that was accented by the honey. This was balanced by the heft of the bacon and the sharpness of the cheddar. The crisp flatbread lent some nice texture to each bite. 

Short Rib Flatbread [$12]
Port reduction, fig gorgonzola 

Not to be outdone, the short rib flatbread came with a foundation of savory short ribs, with a nice port reduction. The sweet figs were balanced by the funk of the gorgonzola and the peppery arugula, which was nicely seasoned. 

Greek Salad [$11] with Chicken [+ $4]
Tomatoes, cucumbers, red onion, olives, feta, red wine vinegar, EVOO

While a bit of a small portion, all the standard flavors were there - the sharpness of the feta along with a melange of tomatoes, cucumbers, onions, and olives dressed in red wine vinegar and olive oil. The grilled chicken was moist and some lightly grilled bread accompanied the salad.

Fish Tacos [$13]
Citrus slaw, black beans, brown rice

The fish tacos should have been renamed slaw tacos because clearly, the fish was not the star here as it only made a small appearance. The slaw had a nice citrusy brightness, but again - where was the fish? The stewed beans were nicely seasoned and some rice was studded with bits of carrot. Definitely a lighter option. 
 
Bison Burger [$19]
Spinach & feta bison burger, opened faced, lemon herb yogurt  

I opted for the bison burger, which was served open faced. It was surprisingly moist and had traditional Greek flavors, with the herbs accented by the lemon-herb yogurt. The pickles were great and really shined - the slight sweetness balancing out the sour. The accompanying potatoes were nicely spiced and were creamy rather than crisp. The green beans had great snap, with a spritz of lemon providing some brightness.

Truffle Fries [$8]
Truffle oil, Parmesan cheese, chipotle aioli, salt

We also got a side of the truffle fries, which were perfectly crisp and had hints of truffle oil and salty Parmesan. It came with a pat of chipotle aioli.

Overall, Fare is a decent option in the Fairmount area. Do try the flatbread and while the fish tacos were lacking, there aren't many places in Philly that can cook or even offer a decent bison burger.

Really good. Now I know why they're famous. After waiting in line for about 15 mins, we got to cut in line because we sat at the bar. Otherwise most people waited about 30 mins. My friend and I came here for dinner on our first night in New Orleans & we had the chargrilled oysters, abita beer, fish and shrimp po boy sandwich w grilled mushrooms & bell peppers with tabasco mayo, cole slaw, & chicken corn chowder. Everything was delicious and set the standard for the rest of my meals in New Orleans. I would definitely come back to try more because their menu is so extensive & the food was all great.

I try to hit this place for lunch almost every time I'm in the area. The outside of the restaurant has fun "bus" decor and a walk up "to-go" window. The tacos with beef or carne asada are a solid choice. Two tacos are great for a lunch portion. I usually skip the side of rice and beans. Also, I usually add cheese and jalapeño on my tacos, which I think is about .60 cents extra per taco. I'm all about upgrading for things like cheese and jalapenos, but wish at least that cheese was included. 

Taco Bus has some house made beverages, I've had them before and they are mostly good. The watermelon aqua fresca was a bit heavy and thick this time, so I would probably stick with a soft drink or horchata drink. The green and red sauces taco sauces they serve with the tacos really add to the flavor. Without the sauces I find the tacos a little bland., so be sure to sample some sauce. This is a nice place for lunch and the service is usually pretty quick. Just stick to basic tacos and you can't go wrong.

Why did I listen to the concierge? ARRRGGGHHH!!!! I should have known better!!! This restaurant's not even listed in our Zagat book nor did I read about it on Chowhound. I obviously came prepared for our N'Awlins Food Fest but did not even heed my own well-laid out plans!!!

Anyhoo, this restaurant's in the French Quarter - very close to ACME Oyster (review coming shortly).

Our server highly recommended her fave dish - the stuffed shrimp with crabmeat filling. I ordered it broiled but she heard fried and it came prepared this way. It tasted like fried mush. Actually, it had very little seasoning. My husband had 1/2 dozen oysters and the crab au gratin. The oysters, according to him, were bland - despite the parmesan cheese topping. The crab au gratin was just a sea of cheese and sour cream? with bits of crab. Ewwwww...

I just don't understand why some restaurants think all they have to do is fry something and it'll be tasty. NOT!

Tinto was such a disappointment. We came in for dinner around 9:30 and we were seated near the kitchen. I was very excited about the view at first...but was later unhappy because my clothes and hair reeked of grill smoke when I left. The food was only okay...none of our food except for the mushrooms was particularly hot (maybe it wasn't supposed to be). The Kobe beef was my favorite, and the octopus was okay. The apple dessert was not good at all. And as we were finishing our meal around 10:30 there was a very distinct smell of bleach. Not sure if they were starting to clean, but it was not a pleasant scent during dessert. I definitely would not go back.

I enjoy this place. Me and My Son came here  yesterday on a Tuesday and he had so much fun! The ducks were out and squirrels so he was so amused while I was trying to exercise my sprained ankles.  I wanna say it's like 3miles but I'm not sure. I went around the track and baby by the hour and a half later I was soaked in sweat and tired. I went to bed at 8:30pm. My son dis not want to leave. There were trucks that rode by every hour to checl pn the park. The dog walkers  followed directions 
 And they put their dog poop in a bag in a trash.  I was so stunned. I felt safe. Everyone was friendly and me amd my son had a really good time overall. We will be back.

Sweet alley is so yummy! They don't have as many options as your typical froyo place, but the flavors they do have are never disappointing.

Some of my personal favorites are the honey Greek yogurt and the acai berry. The honey Greek is so smooth and creamy and not too sweet, and the acai is sweet with a little tartness that pairs well with the fruit toppings. I also tried the chocolate custard recently, yum!

They also have candy (Pop Rocks anyone?!) so if you just want a sweet treat you can get a piece of candy if you're not feelin froyo.

Come to find out Monday and Tuesday nights are very busy here. 

With my recent move I have been flooded with offered and coupons to local places. GSR offered me a free buffet for two and gambling up to a $100.  Angie B and I headed to GSR on a Tuesday night to play and eat.  The line at 6 seemed long30 minutes, so we gambled for 45 minutes and came back to an even longer line. Oh well.  While in line an elderly woman had a medical emergency- I felt bad that they never moved her for privacy the entire time we were in line. 

Now the food, if that's what we are calling it. It was free, but still so very disappointing. So many fried choices that had been out awhile, were now dry and over crispy. The rare steak could have been good but so tough to cut and chew. AYCE shrimp was watery and soggy with very little taste. I didn't want to carb out so I didn't try the create your own pasta area. After two disappointing passes thru the buffet, I settled on the salad bar area that was brightly lit and full of fresher looking food. I did save some room for dessert. The chocolate items weren't really rich enough for me. I settled on some gelato that was ok. 

Safe to say I won't be returning.

Now if you're feeling only slightly peckish or looking for a light meal this is not the place for you - however, if you're looking for a hearty meal made with care then Meat delivers. Tucked just off Whyte Ave the restaurant is adorable with great decor and lots of communal tables with lots of room for your platters of food. I highly recommend coming with someone that you like sharing with so you can try a variety of meats with a few different sides. The brisket and pulled pork are delicious, especially when paired with their house-made BBQ sauces, make sure you sample them all! The sides are great, brustle sprouts, mac and cheese and cornbread are my recommendations. You'll be absolutely stuffed when you leave but it's totally worth it. A great menu of local beers helps wash everything down and should you happen to leave some room for dessert there are tasty options like a banana parfait or pecan pie.

I was already in the drive through when I noticed that this Jimmy John's has been rated poorly by other yelpers.  I went ahead and ordered my usual #4.  The service was friendly and fast.  I couldn't have been in the drive through from ordering to receiving my sandwich for more than 2-3 minutes.

Now, for the sandwich.  It was a standard Jimmy John's sandwich.  Good crispness on the outside of the bread and softness on the inside.  The toppings were fresh and plentiful.  Overall positive experience.

What better way to spend an afternoon in St. Louis than with local brews and eats on The Hill?! 

It's a converted gas station in the corner of an intersection which makes for a quirky fun vibe. 

My husband and I went to J Smugs for lunch. From the moment we stepped in, interactions with staff were friendly and helpful. 

We had ribs with fries and brisket with the mac and cheese. Everything was fantastic! I loved the rub on the ribs. It had a slight kick. My favorite? The brisket! So tender. When I return, I'm going for a brisket sandwich and more Mac n cheese. 

The owners are down to earth and so friendly- the kind of people you want to sit down and have a meal with. 

I highly recommend having a meal here soon!

This place is pure perfection.  We stayed in room one, a queen studio, and it was spacious (a bedroom, a kitchen and dining nook that is stocked with all the essentials- tea pot, coffee maker, microwave, coffee, tea, sugar, plates, glasses, utensils, etc., and a comfortably sized bathroom).  The inn provides an amazing welcome basket (see mention of banana bread in nearly every review), a DVD library, and bikes that you can check out for the day, and it's literally a block from the ocean.  There's nothing that isnt absolutely perfect here.

This is just one of those Main Line staples that you have to go to, just to say you've been there.  The menu is comprised of the typical offerings at a diner, but the portions are huge.  Yes, the prices are a bit higher but you do get what you pay for.  It's clean and the service is fairly fast and amenable.  The wait can be extremely long on Sunday during brunch hours, so I would suggest another time.  Since they are open 24 hrs., you do have a lot of other options.  The sandwiches there are pretty good and can last you for both lunch and dinner, should you grab one during break.  Probably my favorite diner in the area, although I must say that I do miss the now dearly departed Villanova Diner (oh the high school memories...).

Kansai is a local sushi restaurant that is literally half a block from our apartment. So it's pretty sad that it's taken so long to check it out. Either way, it's good to know if I want some decent nigiri or rolls, they're just a few steps away.

First thing's first - Kansai is a Philly-friendly BYO! So the GF and I brought over a Junmai Nigori sake to start off our night right before seeing Aziz Ansari at Wells Fargo. This was a lusciously floral libation - easy drinking to be sure. So be warned, you'll find yourself knocking them back and stumble out the door. 

Salad
Ginger dressing

This came as part of the sushi regular appetizer and offered a fresh and crisp mix of lettuce, tomatoes, and cucumber with that ubiquitous, yet addictive ginger dressing. 

Spicy Tuna Tartare [$7.95]

I appreciated that the tartare wasn't obliterated beyond belief and that there were distinct pieces of tuna interspersed throughout this chili and ponzu-spiced melange. Accents of tobiko were a nice textural pop to each bite. Pretty standard, but well executed. 

Vegetable Tempura [$7.50]

The tempura were expertly fried - eggplant, sweet potatoes, broccoli, and squash were offered - each with a crisp, crunchy exterior that lent itself to tenderness within. 

Sushi Regular [$17.25]

The regular sushi appetizer brought forth a classic quartet of nigiri including 2 each of salmon, tuna, yellowtail, and striped bass. Decent - the sushi was fresh and the quality was on par with a non-omakase sushi experience. A California roll was included as well.

Sweet Potato Roll [$3.95]
Spicy Salmon Roll [$5.25]
Yellowtail Scallion Roll [$4.95]

The yellowtail scallion wasn't exactly revelatory, but I appreciated that the spicy salmon roll offered substantial pieces of salmon, instead of a pureed blend of spice and salmon leftovers. The sweet potato roll was also one of the better iterations I've had - huge chunks housed in a crisp shell. 

So if you're in the Fairmount area, you've certainly got a few options including the venerated Umai Umai and Doma Sushi. But if you're looking for a relaxed BYO environment with fresh, decent quality sushi, Kansai has got you covered. Better yet - while they take credit cards, cash is king and they offer discounts for those who bite.

I've never been to Buffalo Wild Wings and was surprised it's such an open space, like a warehouse. TV's are everywhere with every sporting event possible on the screens. When the place is packed I can understand why the volume needs to be loud, however, it was practically empty yet the TV volume was full blast. It made it hard to have a conversation. We asked our server to lower the volume and she did but, it didn't make a difference. 

Service was very good. They have a hot and ready policy. As soon as anything you order is ready, its brought to your table. Onion rings, wings, fries and chicken fingers were decent. Both their buffalo and garlic sauce were really just average. My brisket sandwich was not great. It was much spicier than expected and the meat was mostly gristle.  I did not enjoy it.

It's obvious this restaurant is best for people who want to eat wings, drink beer and watch football. They don't have much else to offer

Lots of Great Gluten Free. Thannnk you! Denny's. And today Brittany took care of us. And Ms Dena, assisted her. They are Fantastic. 
It's 8pm. Breakfast for Dinner why not? Many new choices on a simplified and best of all. For all wanting Variety on Gluten Free. I am very excited about the Gluten Free English Muffin. I personally do not mind the more Country Style Taste and Texture. Due to the Corn Bread like Texture ( You may want to Request the Butter or Margarine on the Side). The Chef/Cook may overdue how much he/she puts on it.
I ask for Soft Poached Eggs. Great pair.
Their Coffee is Sooo Goood. And I appreciate good Coffee. Since I frequent the place w/The Green Sign. We are very familiar with. 
Here, they very graciously offer me a Cup for the road. 
Now that is great service and Hospitality. 
Of course I'll be back. Will have to try That Grilled Chicken Avocado Salad. Hold the Onions, please:-)

Blaze pizza has opened from California bringing the Subway concept to New Orleans. You walk in pick what crust you want and then proceed to choose what toppings you want from an abundant selection of meat and vegetable toppings. Its almost the Kramer concept from Seinfeld where you build your own pie. Once you've created your 12" masterpiece it bakes for 7 minutes and boom you have a pizza. At $7.95 you can't beat the price and they are big enough for two people. The drinks are great too as they have a blood orange lemonade that is excellent. I highly recommend this place especially if your on a budget. Only drawback is that because the ingredients are so fresh your pizza will be a little wet as 7 minutes is not enough time to burn off the condensation so the pizza is a little sloppy depending on how many ingredients you put on it.

Great place off the main strip! Cool vibe, good service and very good food.  

Drinks
"Blue is the color of jazz"
Pimms #7.  

Pork belly $ crispy scallops. - very good.  4/5
Beef tartare -awesome!   5/5
Gulf fish- dry and overcooked 3/5

Popped in here after a spa day and a bit of Christmas shopping and could smell the bread baking, so you know it's fresh.
Young staff is warm and friendly, cut the sandwich on the diagonal as requested.
Don't miss the vinegar Jimmy chips -- probably the best potato chip you'll ever get. I always get an extra bag (or two) for the cupboard.
Suggestion: add a nice garlic-y pickle spear for that authentic deli touch.

Chipotle was sort of cool when it first came out. It's still cool to many people. But to me, it's always been average and still is.

Yes, they make a tasty burrito. And, they do it quick. And the guac and chips they overcharge you for are pretty darn good.

But as a boy for Cali, this is not a real Mexican burrito. It's so American wannabe Mexican. And, it's priced that way as well, which means you pay more for something not quite is good.

Don't mistake me. It's not bad. When convenient, like on this recent occasion, it does the trick.

But, there is a lot better out there. And, not just authentic restaurant places. There are plenty of fast food Mexican joints that are much better.

I'm stumped. Why do folks love this absolutely average burger? I had a grilled cheese here once as well, and felt awful afterwards, I mean how much peanut oil soaked toast can a person shove? To be sure I'm not watching my weight, but this burger isn't worth the liverfront property to me. How could I be so lucky to have this location within spitting distance?

made it on a friday to see glen david andrews. i'd say he is a must see. got there at 730, he went on at 9. snagged a seat at the bar. bar was much better than a cramped table. good service. 

lamb sliders may have been up there with the best items we had the entire trip. bulgogi bowl was good but i woulnd't need to order that again. quail egg was nice to see on top of the bowl. fries were good but i should have ordered something more interesting. 

i could take down probably 9 of those sliders.

Seriously the best ice cream ever. Bring someone to help you eat it because one scoop is like FOUR. You get your money's worth here, for sure. Love, love, love the Broad Ripple Blackberry flavor - tart and berry-licious! Always a friendly atmosphere, with an upgrade in style to something as traditional as an ice cream shop. Wish they had some Italian sodas or something like that to give it that "ice cream and soda shop" vibe. One of my favorite things to do is to walk down the Monon Trail to get a treat with my guy and take a stroll around town. Just lovely!

Blah.  Just another sports bar and an unimpressive one at that.  I am not going to waste too much of my time telling you why you shouldn't bother when you can read the countless others.  I will mention just a couple things that bothered me in particular.  I went to see a certain team play on Sunday and there must have been 30 screens.  My team was only playing on 2 of them and neither of them were at the bar.  There was an hour wait for a table and I wouldn't have necessarily seen either screen from the table I might have received.  The same game was playing on both of the jumbo screens..... stupid.  You can't see more than one screen at any one bar seat.  The screens should have been bigger so if you were lucky to get a seat you probably couldn't have seen the game you wanted anyway.  I hope Archie fired all of the people who advised him and helped him put this together because they did a really poor job of making this place special.

I was assured that all of their beans were vegetarian, which was great. They had three types: black, pinto, and refried. I hope that the bartender was being honest.

The house margaritas are great. I tried the Murrietta's Margarita for $10, and even though it was a better tequilla, I thought the house margarita for $6.99 was better. I went ahead and had 3.

My dining partner lives within walking distance, so he is a regular and proclaims that it is the best Mexican food in Reno. He loves the chicken chimi.

I had the veggie fajitas and they were really good. There were a ton of vegetables (not just onions and peppers like you normally get) and the corn tortillas were fantastic. I was also told the rice was vegetarian. 

The chips and salsa they serve was pretty good too, but I like a lighter chip. The hot sauce is very hot and the pico has no spice.

PREFACE: I started the draft of this review back in January, the first time I went to Mannings.  SInce then I have been back twice, so I will note in the review.

1st visit-Have never been here before, because most sports bars are over-rated (think BWW).  But I was downtown on a staycation and wanted to try it out.  I sat myself at the bar and ordered a glass of wine and some wings.  It was around lunch time, but surprisingly quiet in there.  The bartender was friendly and attentive.  Lots of screens, I could see why this place would be a hit during sports events.  

2nd visit (KENTUCKY DERBY) there was an event going on in Fulton Alley for Kentucky Derby, so hubs and I wandered in to watch the race.  It was packed (which I have come to learn is the norm more than the exception).  The only thing we had was a shot, and it was a drink.  The thing I like is that even though the patrons seem to mainly be tourist/visitors, they are always really friendly.  I love a bar where everyone is interacting, talking smack, and looking like they are having a good time.

3rd visit (FOOTBALL SEASON/STEELERS GAME)-We were so foolish.  I knew there would be a wait to get a table, so we decided to arrive 1 hour before kickoff.  WRONG.  There was a 2 hour wait for an inside table.  We were actually able to quickly locate seating outside but the game we wanted to see wasn't on so we left.  It was crowded.  

Overall, I will continue to return to Mannings in hopes we can get a table and order several items so I can give a follow up review.  It's big and clean and has a good atmosphere so I hope to be able to write a follow up with pictures and feedback on the service.

I have to say......because of my first incredibly positive experience with Bareburger....I am disappointed to have to reduce the stars. However, the last 3 deliveries I've gotten from here have either been crazy late and cold or wrong and the fries are ALWAYS soggy. 
Not ok. Not good enough. 
Food is good, but what use is that when it's cold, wrong or delivered at LEAST a half hour late. 

I work for a delivery service. I can bike food to Northern Liberties twice in the time it took this restaurant to get my food 4 blocks.

I had a sore throat and all I could think about was soup. Dan Dan's wonton soup was EVERYTHING, (including extremely overpriced, but it really did the trick). Since I didn't want to place a delivery order just for soup, I also got the spicy cucumbers. Fantastic, but similarly overpriced for the amount you get.

That has always been my beef with Dan Dan. I've ordered from them before and between my husband and myself, there are almost never any leftovers, even with several dishes ordered. And did I mention it's expensive? 

Alas, Dan Dan is a once-in-a-while delivery option as opposed to once-a-week.

My friend and I came in for lunch on a Sunday Thursday afternoon. I made reservations for outdoor patio dining and we were brought to our table right away. 
Love the vibes on the patio! We came here because of the good reviews and the many options for my vegan friend. I got the ketfa wrap with fries she got the falafel wrap with fries. We also ordered crispy grape leaves and a bunch of different cocktails.
Cocktails were fantastic. On the pricey side but worth it. My wrap looked small but was surprisingly filling. Love the different flavors from the kefta and veggies. Fries could have been alittle crispier but that's just my preference. Service was great and accommodating and they took our temps prior to sitting down so I felt safe from their Covid precautions. Love this place! Would highly recommend. Can't wait to to come back one day :)

I can only go by my experience which was excellent . Came here for dinner and ordered a nice o wings , fries and beers with a colleague . Everything was great and the service was quite good . Will visit again !

It really depends on what you order.
Beef and Broccoli?  Great.
Beef with String Beans (special)?  Great.

Shrimp and Snow peas?  Gelatinous goo.
Shrimp toast?  Burnt.

I am going back to beef & broc. Every time I try something else I regret it.

Also - no ice, no water unless you BUY a bottle.
I try, try, try to remember to bring my water with me.  This is SUCH a take out place.  A lady came here to dine in with 2 little kids and asked for a cup of tea and they served it to her in a tupperware soup container.

Decent Chinese food, take out is the best way.
NOT a fine dining experience, or even a mediocre one.

The concept of this restaurant is spot-on... but the selection wasn't particularly exciting. The antipasti was a true Italian antipasti -- an array of meats and cheeses. But I think there was only one kind of cheese, definitely an array of meats, but no introduction upon delivery. While sitting at the chef's counter, the IDEA is to have a conversation about your food/wine with. The most I got out of our guy was that he didn't like Italian wine (hi, you work at an Italian restaurant...what do you mean you don't like Barolos?) I will say though, the lamb was really well prepared. It had a honey walnut sauce, which was delicious paired with the lamb and its tangy goat cheese. The bisteca, not as exciting -- but hey, now you know.

Maybe with a few FOB Italians behind the counter this place could be amazing, but for now it's just okay.

Kuma's Corner is truly a little gem on the corner in Fountain Square. With the endless amount of burgers and great atmosphere, Kuma's Corner is the perfect spot to eat with friends and family. 

It was hard for me to choose which burger to get because they had such a variety of great options with a lot of fun ingredients. I decided on the "Led Zeppelin" burger, which had bacon, BBQ pulled pork, pickles, and sharp cheddar, with a side of fries. Every bite was incredible. I was glad that I was too full to finish it because that meant that I could take it home and enjoy it the next day!

If the weather is nice, sit outside on their patio. Since it is located on the corner of Fountain Square, it is a fun atmosphere to eat and chat with friends and do some people watching ;)

2 cool things about Kuma: I found on their website that they have a charity of the month. If you ask the server what the charity is, you can help donate to the cause. Also, they only support purveyors that are local and homegrown, which means that they don't carry any Miller High Life or Budweiser. Yay local!

I will definitely be coming back here with new friends! Everyone needs to try this great place on the corner!

I came here with my boyfriend for a date night out and it did not disappoint! We waited almost an hour which is to be expected on a Saturday night. We sat outside in a perfect little corner for us and it was so great! We ordered the bacon wrapped stuffed shrimp and we almost had a heart attack. Those little suckers are so damn delicious! The sweet chili sauce paired so well with them and the shrimps were huge and stuffed with warm feta cheese. I could have eaten 5 of those by myself! We then ordered two salads to go with our steak and scallop dishes. I had the rib-eye and my boyfriend had the scallops and we shared both of our dishes for a great surf and turf meal. They were both top-notch! The scallops were not anything like we had before -- thick and meaty with bacon and covered in a tangy sauce that was divine. My steak was off the charts and I had it come with the rosemary blue cheese sauce and it almost knocked my boyfriend out of his seat. SO GOOD! The steak was cooked perfectly and the sauce was a great compliment to it. For dessert we shared an adult hot chocolate with the peanut butter pie. It was so sweet and decadent but it was worth getting stuffed over. All in all, the food and service was very good. They did not rush us out which we GREATLY appreciated. We were one of the last 3 couples having dinner and just taking our time. We were originally going to have dinner at either Oku or Bluewater but we are so happy that we came across Holdren's and happy we spent such a great evening here!

The kimchi here is 10 stars out of 5 stars. Sooooo soooo gooooodd!!! Haven't had kimchi that good other than at 1-2 places in the PalPark/Ft.Lee/Leonia area of Bergen County, NJ lol.

Came here on a Saturday afternoon for lunch. That H-Mart next door is always packed so don't even bother parking in the H-Mart lot. Actually this complex has their own parking lot separate from the H-Mart parking lot but you have to exit first. 

It wasn't all that busy and we got seated right away. The first thing I noticed was the children playroom. Super adorable and this is definitely a good place to come with kids. 

Ordered the extra spicy curry sundubu because I was a little adventurous. I have to say not again, I'd rather stick with my favorite red-broths sundubus. Other than the typical sundubu options, they also have the budae jiggae sundubu. I was like whattt, that's like a dream come true lol. Typically you either have budae jiggae OR sundubu but not both in one bowl haha. Also ordered the spicy gejang which was pretty good. The banchans were standard, but the kimchi made all the difference. We had 2nd and 3rd on the kimchi lol.

Service is very quick and friendly. Definitely one of the sundubu places I'll come back too.

It's game night so I didn't expect fast service. Just what I expected. It was her first day serving she said. Therefore, she wasn't knowledgeable about the menu but she did tried to give good service. The wings are always on point with Buffalo Wild Wings. This specific location is smaller than the other bww that I've been to but I really like how there's still a lot of television screen giving the small restaurant feel as though you're at a big arena. Thumbs up for that.

Your standard Chinese bakery shop. Get your variety of breads and treats here - yes they do have the egg tarts and the sesame balls. Yes, they also have durian cakes. Yes, you can get the standard cream buns or variations on buo luo mian bao. Their bubble tea is decent as well. Good Chinatown prices.

I've been meaning to check this place out for a while - Philly's been stepping up its ramen game, yay!

However... Cheu is not a ramen shop. They serve a variety of noodle dishes - only one of which is actually ramen. The miso ramen was good, but I probably wouldn't come back to Cheu for it. I'd definitely return to explore some of the other items on the menu, like the black garlic wings and the coconut curry noodles.
