I also had the pork belly bun, which was really... crispy. I'm really partial to the traditional soft white buns and the buns at Cheu taste more like a fried biscuit. I thought the filling could have more flavor too - the pickles were a bit bland and the sauce felt like an afterthought.

Back again, why, because there is no other Indian restaurant like Guru. (Not even back in Secaucus NJ where we used to dine on really good Indian food from different regions of India.)

The passion of this husband and wife team are incredible, they both share a passion for creating great flavors and for making their guests happy. Per their bio, "we aim to cater to the sophisticated palates of our friends and neighbors in Bucks county" and that they do.

We are still newbies here but have dined at least 6 times in such a short period.  Simply because they make us feel as though we are family.  Best part for us is that we've connected with Preya (Ashni's spouse) and she totally understands us and our palates.  No more opening of menus for us, she just brings us what she thinks we'd love based on how we feel and our spirits.

We were so lucky to again be able to sample a few more new summer  items before they hit the menu.  Ashni Kumar Guru is indeed a master chef. I was feeling blase today so to help give me Preya surprised me with their version of chicken soup; not just any chicken soup.  Was incredible, just the right touch of spice and magic flavor that I felt so lifted afterwards.

For our second course, we were served a new shrimp appetizer with a sauce mixture featuring mangoes (we Iove mangoes), this is based on their garlic shrimp, I think even better. 

Next, my wife had wanted their lamb chops where were cooked to perfection without us even asking---- medium raw, was able to cut it with just a fork.... so tender and accented by the dipping sauce.

Next we shared chicken methi  (chicken cubes cooked with fresh fenugreek leaves flavored with herbs and spices); a home run flavor.

Lastly, I gave in to trying paneer with their delicious Palak Paneer disk (Homemade Indian cheese cooked with spinach, mild spices and herbs.)  Loved it.

To finish off the meal, Kheer , a traditional firm rice and milk pudding with aromatic spices. a nice slightly sweet finish to an excellent meal.

BTW, there was plenty for a second meal.  Just nice to taste a range of flavors.

It seems like so many of us yelpers were at this location. Why not?! The food is delicious. The quantity is filling. And, the price is affordable. 

So a bunch of us Elites got together to try another new Chinese place in town but it seems like they ran out of steam and could not be open for normal operating hours. Their loss because we landed at Meet Noodles. It was an ideal day for Noodle Soup. 

We got the Zhou's beef noodles. We were recommended regular and they gave the extra chili sauce on the side if we wanted to make the soup spicier. The broth was delicious, the beef slices were generous and the noodles were plenty. The noodles were el dante. I know el dante applies to pasta, but I don't know how else to describe it. It was chewy, which is a great texture as it didn't get soft and mushy while soaking in the broth. Although, next time I am getting medium. I think I can handle the heat. 

The basil fried chicken is plenty and amazing. It's actually tasted like karaage, japanese fried chicken,  and was very enjoyable. Highly recommend it for sharing. 

We also ordered the Takoyaki! Order this. It's so good! It explodes in your mouth with rich creamy texture and is made of a mix of fish. 

We also got the honey lemon tea and the cheese milk foam, peach oolong. I found the former too sweet but the latter was such a new and pleasant drink. It may not be a crowd pleaser like the boba tea but it's worth trying. Looks like beer but once you drink it the foam is a salty and creamy followed by the sweetness of peach oolong ice tea. I actually really enjoyed this and recommend. Don't let the unknown deter you! 

So we all sat for four hours post lunch and chatted away in our booth and I really appreciate that they did not rush us out. They let us be. In fact, they also got us pumpkin cakes to write reviews, they were so nice and kind about it. 

They had a new staff on training and that's where I knocked off the star. We got lemonade at first instead of water, but they were really nice about it and got us our waters later and didn't charge us thankfully. And, then while someone was there to explain us what to get as we sought recommendations, our friend didn't get the same advice so ended up with a spicy bowl of soup. When I asked if there was anything we could do about it, the lady said I like to talk so I mentioned that to you. Granted they were busy and it was what was ordered but a consideration would have been appreciated, I guess? 

They are new and gaining popularity so will need to iron those kinks out. We are glad there is such an affordable and delicious place in town and they are very nice people so will certainly be back. I hope the quality continues to deliver and the service gets better with time.

Wow!  This place is legit.  It reminds me of Germany at Epcot, with a Willy Wonka flair.  This place really has it all.  They have a deli, grocery, wine / beer store and restaurant!  We came in for lunch and it was pretty packed.

It is a seat yourself place, and you get to sit with other folks on picnic table benches.  Pretty cool if you like to chat with people, not so much for introverts.

We wound up getting the schnitzel and Rueben.  The portions were huge and delicious.  I went with the extra meat on the Rueben, which probably was not necessary.  The craft beer selection is phenomenal.  The list is huge for both draught and bottle and they focus a lot on local breweries.  They also just started to brew their own beer in house.  I can't wait to go back.

For my first Indian food experience, I have no complaints! I even burned the crap out of my mouth due to the spice but was still smiling because everything was so delicious.  

The restaurant was great and in a convenient location. Staff was enormously helpful as we had no idea what to order. Luckily we went with some friends who took over for us! 

They bring out a large rice cracker type app that goes with the 3 drippings already at our table. We ordered the garlic naan to pair with the 4 entrees we chose. A tiki masala, excuti, and a curry chicken one. Then the spicy rice and chicken mix which I can't remember. Unfortunately I went for that first and it was the spiciest so I was screwed from then on out. But everything was so delicious! You can choose your spice level and my dining companions all like spice so next time I'm picking my own!

I want to like this place but it is really just OK. I got some scallop and salmon chowder soup and it was creamy but kind of plain. The waiter was friendly but didn't seem to know the menu very well or at least didn't care to be. 

He told us we could substitute the cold slaws with french fries but he forgot to mention there was a $3 surcharge. Then he didn't even intend to remove it out of courtesy. Lame service and mediocre food.

booked this place for me and my man for a weekend getaway during all this covid madness. upon arrival, we parked in the free stalls in front of the rooms and checked in at the host desk. I interacted with 2 property managers during my time here and they were SO friendly and I had a great experience with them. they were VERY knowledgeable and even let us know about the rentals they had.

once we got into the room, it was smaller than some of the pictures I had saw on hotwire, but still very nice clean and cozy. at this inn they have half smaller rooms and half BIG almost apartment like rooms. we stayed in the smaller ones, but it was still great. during covid I took things very seriously and they made me feel the room to be very clean and even checking in and out I saw the efforts they made to sanitize keys, pens, etc.

PROS:
-free snacks in the main office
-free rentals!!!!!!!! omg even after we checked out they let us borrow and we used it to bike to lunch and return after
-variety of free rentals - bikes, stuff for the beach, etc. highly recommend using this since its part of what you're paying for
-location!!!!!! walkable to restaurants, the beach, etc. recommend going to dinner at brophy bros which we walked for maybe 10 min
-shower pressure was nice
-everything felt very clean
-bed was comfy!
-tv
-coffee corner in your room with all you could need
-fridge

CONS:
-none!

OVERALL:
highly recommend you stay here!

Going to IHOP for breakfast has become thing for my brothers and I. We used to frequent IHOP in Philly and always enjoyed the ambiance and coffee. Their coffee is pretty good. 

This Sunday, my brothers and I decided to hit up our nearest IHOP location. We drove down to Fowler Avenue in North Tampa. The highway was quiet but as soon as we neared the restaurant, it was like grand central. The line of cars pulling in and the people out the door was crazy. 

My brothers spotted a parking space in the corner and we got it pretty easily. We hopped out and hurried in to be beat anyone else that drove in at the same time as us. 

The waiting area was packed. People standing, people sitting. People walking out because of the wait time. We put our name on the list and was told it would only be about 10-15 minutes for a party of 3. We waited. 

As we sat and waited, we realized that all the people in the lobby were one group! A party of 22!

What I can say about the staff in this location was that they were patient and professional. They had a party of 22, that didn't speak English too well, and everything seemed smooth. 

Our waitress was nice and took our drink and food order right away knowing we would want to get it in as quick as possible. She did let us know the kitchen was a little backed up but it wasn't so bad. 

Our food was excellent. I ordered the smokehouse combo. Scrambled eggs, delicious smoked sausage, shredded potatoes and a side of pancakes, which I order in their special Dulce de Leche flavor. Everything was tasty and filling. The Dulce de Leche pancakes were spot on. 

Despite the busy Sunday morning, my brothers and I had a great meal here. It was clean, well run and friendly.

I came to Walnut Street Theatre for the first time about a week ago to see "In the Heights". The show was excellent and I loved every minute. But I'm not here to review the production.

The theatre is in a great location, so close to the PATCO speedline for us Jersey folks! The theatre itself is nice. The seats are very close to one another and there is not much leg room but luckily I'm short and it doesn't bother me too much. Downstairs the theatre was selling "In the Heights" swag along with jewelry (I know, a little odd). Upstairs there are tons of old pictures lining the hallways of former stars who have performed at the Walnut. 

The service was okay.. I didn't order any food or drinks because I had just eaten dinner nearby. When I walked into the theatre itself, there was no one handing out the playbill..I had to retrieve it myself. I miss seeing a beautiful chandelier like the one displayed at the Forrest Theatre. 

Will I return to the Walnut? Sure! But I have to say nothing beats seeing a show on Broadway.. I have seen some good productions in Philly but to me Broadway is just magical experience.

I came here tonight with my girlfriend! It was SUPER busy for a Thursday but we were fine sitting at the bar. The food came out really quickly which I liked! We were hungry as hell so that was a plus. The people working behind the bar smiled at us and we were happy.

We tried the salad rolls, beef tataki, spicy tuna roll, Udon Aglio Olio E Peperoncino, Aburi Saba and the spicy tuna sashimi (yep all of it). It was all really yummy! The food comes out really quickly! I think my favourite dish was the beef tataki! It was delicious. The tuna rolls were also good - you can add salmon on the top to them, yummy!

The ambiance of this place was really quite beautiful. It had nice lighting and the chairs were comfy. Our server was really nice and attentive! The prices are good! I think for all that stuff it was like $75.

Those who lie in South Jersey will know, Olga's Diner used to be one of the most famous and popular diners in the area. It closed in 2008 and before I moved here. 

A year ago, a new family decided to recreate Olga's Diner right up the road on route 73. It wasn't the original family or original building, but the name Olgas.  When it finally opened in November of 2019, I was excited to go!

I met up around lunchtime on a weekday. It was packed! You would think we were going on a busy Sunday morning.

Olga's Diner Atmosphere: 
Olga's Diner stands out on route 73. It's hard to miss the big, shiny, modern building. The inside of Olga's Diner is large. Each booth and table is spread out, so you don't feel like you're sitting on top of anyone.

Coffee: 
The coffee at Olga's Diner is good. Olga's Diner uses the local company, Lacas. I could have used a few more refills.

Olga's Diner Food: 
Olga's Diner menu has everything you want and need in a diner.  There are plenty of breakfast, lunch, and dinner options. If you are looking for healthy options, Olga's Diner has that too. Plus an entire page menu dedicated to vegan options. Yes, vegan!  I thought about getting a vegan option just because Olga's Diner had it but ultimately decided for the beet salad with rotisserie chicken. If beets are on any restaurant menu, I usually order them.

The beets tasted good and the greens were fresh. There was plenty of chicken too. I couldn't taste a difference in the rotisserie-style chicken versus grilled.

Olga's Diner Dessert: 
Cyd mentioned the original Olga's Diner was known for their Boston Cream Pie, so we both decided to order that. The Boston Cream Pie was good, but the cake portion of it was a little dry.

Olga's Diner Service: 
The waitress said it was her first day, but you would not have guessed. She was friendly and seemed like she was working there for a long time. The food came out quickly. We were sat and eating our food within 15 minutes of arriving.

Cost: $$
For my coffee, salad, and pie, it was $25. The salad alone was nearly $19, which I found a bit pricey for the size.

Overall Thoughts/Would I Come Back?
I liked Olga's Diner, and I'll be back. The food was excellent, and Olga's Diner has a lot of menu options I want to try.

My friend and I went to Wild Wing before going to a football game (wings and football seems like an appropriate combo). While there are other items on the menu we went for the wings. My friend doesn't like wet (sauced) wings, so we learned that the chip flavours and the favours in the naked category were the dry (spice rub) wings. There's a lot of flavours of wings (heard 101, but I didn't count), so like another reviewer I saw mentioned don't just come and get the standard hot sauce or BBQ. Even my friend regularly goes for dill pickle wings, but I convinced her to try something new. I got the thai and raspberry flavour in the boneless (aka chicken nugget) wings, and it was good combo of spicy and sweet. The wings (least the boneless ones) were delicious - juicy, but not greasy. 

The price is a bit high - $10.95 for one flavour of wings. You could pay like $21 for 2 flavours, but I didn't see any sort of wing deals (although I didn't really check the rest of the menu). Still the wings are good, and I didn't leave the restaurant hungry. Our server was really friendly and helpful answer questions about the menu. Oh and you get this giant wet nap with the wings instead of a bunch of little ones. Wild Wing is a bit out of the way from me, but I'd certainly come back and try it again. The hot chocolate flavour sounded kind of interesting.

Service is slow outside on Sundays, but fantastic food. 

I have a feeling that TBBC is going to become one of the spots we go to on the reg. It's close, the food is great, and outdoor seating is perfect to bring fussy babies when the weather is nice. Ok, fussy baby, singular, my friend's baby was a perfect angel laying in his stroller for most of the meal. Mine had to be walked around the outdoor area by one parent for almost the entire time. So, five stars for that outside seating area. 

I got the Ahi Tuna Salad and my husband got the BeerBQ pizza. Both were amazing. When we got home I was dropping the food in the fridge before going out and I ate one of his pieces before returning to the car. It is that good. The cheese is baked to a crisp on the crust and the sauce is deliciously sweet. The Ahi Tuna Salad is delicious as well. It probably isn't the healthiest salad in the world with the heaping of fried won ton strips, but you only live once and I still felt healthy(ish) eating it. 

Service was definitely slow. When my baby was losing It because of nap time I would have appreciated if our server had a little more pep to her step, but I bet everyone else was here for a lazy meal. Just don't expect to get in and out if you sit outside on a Sunday. I also think most people come here to watch a game, so they aren't looking for efficient service.

The South's answer to a lack of In-n-Out, Five Guys excels in its simplicity.  It sells burgers, with toppings of your choice, cooked to order when you order, and cooked fast.  No, its not In-n-Out, for those who have experiences it, but they aren't bad burgers at all, and are inexpensive and taste so much better than anything at other fast food restaurants.  You can find them sprinkled all over town, and they offer the same fast and friendly service.  You can decide what you want or don't want on your burger and BOOM its done.  Have it your way but a whole lot less gross.  A clean, almost clinical eating space but this isn't the kind of place where you linger.  However, if you want a fast burger, I would recommend this over a McDonalds or Wendy's anyday.

I try to go to Biscuit Love close by at 11 pm on a Saturday in August when all bachelorettes are in town.   The line is in sane and way to long. So I found this lady title gem instead I mean little octopus is swimming by next to many big & famous fish in the restaurants ocean. 

I ordered "Shrimp & Grits"  with pan-fried country ham XO & bell pepper.  It's delicious, but it a bit too salty for me. You can see a pile of oil floating on top of grits. Maybe chef can reduce the sauce by 1/3 or add more grits, then the dish will be more balanced. The country ham perfectly cooked to reduction with all the favor and crunchiness. It's definitely a new approach to the traditional Shrimp & Grits. 

Cachapas~ this is the best dish among all dishes on the menu IMO. I said oh wow Ike three times when I'm eating this. It's fresh corn pancake with quest fresco in between pancake and top with fried egg. It has great savory flavor and the tastes of corn meal. Perfect meal for a weekend brunch. 

Pot de cream~ it's has a great coconut lightness taste with strong ginger & chocolate flavor and top with pistachio. Not very sweet. It was just an above average desert for me. 

This restaurant just open 7 months, but it gives Nashville local food an interesting approach. The Caribbean influence is a welcome change from many of the restaurants here.  The chef is creative and experimenting with new ingredients. Definitely a fun try after all the greasy & fried food I had in the past couple days. 

Although it has a fine dining decor into it, but the atmosphere is causal. Most people has shorts/sandals/slippers on them, probably are all tourists like me. I love the golden hues in the mirrors and the bright light from the skylights.   When I come back I will try and score a seat at the display kitchen so I can watch the chefs work.

This is not the IHOP of my choosing in the area.  It is very run down and the servers barely have room to get down the aisles.  We had a high chair and had to keep pulling our little one as close to the table as possible.  The food is not the best for IHOP, i frequent IHOP but would rather go to the new one in Fairview Heights, much cleaner.  This IHOP makes it seem like something may jump into your food with how dirty and old the inside is.

Good neighborhood diner.  Service was good. Food is good.  The day I was there it was a little warm in there but can't go by me I guess because I like things really cold. 

It has a quiet atmosphere which I like in a diner it's
Comfortable and not too loud.  Just right !

Brennan's updates their happy hour food and drink frequently. So if you find a great bottle of bubbles (which are offered at amazing prices on HH), it may not be on the menu the next time you visit. However, I've never been disappointed by any of their bubbles.
Currently, they are offering duck wings, baked Brie, fries, and a veal debris poboy on the bar menu. My friend and I tried the first three.  The duck wings were crispy and had a great flavor, although there was very little meat on them, and it was $12 for 3 wings. The fries were good. The baked Brie was great and a nice portion with some blueberries (candied?) on the side. Service was friendly.

We were starving & looking for anything that was open & came across this place, glad they were open late till 12am. 
we came in & were seated right away, once seated we started with some drinks, I had the Tennessee brew works beer this was good, nice & cold. my company had the Yazoo beer good as well. 
On the food we kept it simple got an order of 15 wings, The Garlic Parm & Samurai Teriyaki we got the naked wings. 
Garlic Parm I've had before & it's usually a go to option, nice taste good flavor to the sauce, The Samurai teriyaki never had this flavor they were not bad a bit of a sweet taste, decent overall.  
The naked wings totally hit the spot, only complain is that they were kind of small. 
One common complain here is about the food, now I get it but the reality is that u don't go to a place like this for "real food" I find that if u stick with the basics u tend to have a better experience.
Service was good & prices are decent, this place saved the night when nothing else was available.

These hotdogs right here!!!! The best in Tucson I dare to say! Get them with everything and please try the Chile on the side it is not hot I promise, it is just tangy,sour heaven.
The guys that serve you are really nice and attentive too. Really crave worthy dogs!!

I'm hesitant to write good reviews lately since everything I love tends to get super insanely crowded and then you can't get a reservation like every single restaurant in this town! At any rate, I am doing an injustice if I don't report how lovely this restaurant is. It's one of my new favorites...Shhhhhhh!!!!!
Beautiful decor, they've done an excellent job with the old Rusan's footprint. 
The Pussers rum painkiller is the bomb. Love it! They have excellent drinks all around. 
Now this is a tapas type place perfect for sharing. Some things were so good we ordered two, like the hamachi. DAYUM this stuff is good.
Avocado. So simple and SO FRIKKIN good. They rotate the menu so I pray they don't change those two things. Cornbread was a tad sweet, but perfect golden crust in a cast iron skillet. Empanadas were my least favorite, at the time it was filled with chicken curry, but they change all the time. We had something with sweet potato that has since been changed, along with potatoes that were tasty. Nothing was bad, it's all so great. We had phenomenal service, too. I can't wait to go back, but I pray it doesn't start getting impossible to catch a reservation.

I had a wonderful experience with NLT. This tour group company runs tours from the city our to the plantations and to the swamp. I chose a plantation tour. I picked this tour group because they run small business (15 ppl max). My tour guide, Dionne, arrived right on time at my hotel for pick up. She had other guests to pick up from 3-4 other hotels and we were on our way within 30 minutes. With everyone onboard Dionne started the tour. She pointed out interesting locations and facts about New Orleans that I would not have known. She was funny and factual -- making for an excellent tour. The trip to the plantations is about an hour. Dionne talked for about 30 minutes, a healthy mix. She pointed on the house where D'jango Unchained was filmed and stopped so that we could take pictures. NLT provides access to three plantations-- The Whitney, The Laura, and Oak Alley -- listed in order of drop off. From there guests pick up a guided tour of the plantation. I liked NLT because they allowed some downtime at the plantations for shopping and browsing-- but not too much time. A great tour company.

best of 4

the first stop in our great steak journey.  wit onions & whiz. 
the steak wasn't dry. it was quite good.
i thought it was kinda salty because of the whiz.
the fries were good with whiz.
good hot sauce that goes with the cheesesteak.  discovered it during my last few bites.

This is my second trip to Tastee this week LOL. I stopped in this morning for a little breakfast. I picked up a bacon and egg sandwich along with a chocolate doughnut, which by the way is awesome. Love going to those convenient location am always in there for about five minutes and I'm good to go ladies there are super helpful very friendly. Definitely a good spot for quality fast breakfast.

So I went here for dinner with a group of coworkers. I ordered the Wiz Wit Cheesesteak sandwich with a side salad. 
I also ordered a couple cocktails to enjoy with my meal. 
While the homemade cheese wiz was outstanding and the flavor of the beef in the cheesesteak was delicious there was very little filling for all of the bread. What's the point of eating a philly while in Philly if the portion size reminds you of war time rations rather than restaurant portions? 
Our waitress was good. We didn't have to ask for anything. I'll keep trying to find a great cheesesteak in this area though. 
Music playing in the joint was good selection but kind of loud for conversation. Some of my coworkers tried their brews and seemed very happy so maybe you should come here more for the drinks and beer as opposed to the dinner menu.

(4) ~ Overall Food & Service

* If you're looking for a Healthy Lunch, Snack &/or Smoothie this is as HEALTHY as you can get;-)  They've got Raw, Organic, Gluten-free, Vegan etc.  My Fav is the Coconut Curry Kale Chips:-)  They're addictive:-)

* Notes: Open from 10AM - 5PM (M-F); 11:30 - 3:30(Sat); & Closed Sun.  
Yes they take Credit Cards & you can CALL ahead your order.

So I have to say the staff in the aisles are much friendlier than the cashiers. This is the SECOND time I get home and the bagged my overpriced bread under my other groceries and half of it is flattened! It's annoying. I'm a DIE HARD Kroger, Meijer and Aldi fan and don't have much choice but to shop at this overpriced store and no one mentions the app with digital coupons when I even mention I just moved here from out of state and miss the rewards program they had.

Another Friday, another lunch out with my friend and coworker. Decided to try a new cheesesteak place for us, but Sonny's has been around for some time.

Oh, Boy! This was one of the best cheesesteaks I've ever had and would be probably #2 on my list next to Joe's Steak (formerly Chink's and see my review!). Right amount of meat, cheese, and onions and shrooms. A little too much on the sweet peppers for me, but the roll kicked major butt. What a great combo to make an awesome sandwich. Had some fries and they got a little soggy back to the office, but still quite tasty.

Sonny's has plain, loaded (which is what I had and took a picture), bacon, hoagie with lettuce/tomato/red onion/mayo, pizza steak, and pepperoni cheesesteak. They also sell the right sides like fries of all sorts, onion rings, and mozzarella sticks. But, there's more! You can get burgers and, get this, grilled cheese in multiple styles!

In these COVID-19 times, they are limiting the numbers in the store, everyone wears masks, and you have to go outside to wait for your order until they call your number. There's also about four metal tables to sit at to eat if you wish outside. 

Overall, definitely five stars for this awesome cheesesteak. No peppers next time for me.

$12 for the ultimate cheesesteak, $10 for the plain, and $3 for fries. Not bad at all.

SO cute and absolutely a wonderful respite from all the trashy dives in nola!

If you're from out of town and had enough with dirty venues filled with drunkards covered in beads - this is a nice, classy alternative.  I'd been here years ago for a couple glasses of wine with my boyfriend and father, sat outside and it was lovely, right by the cathedral. 

This trip it was disgusting tropical storm weather (same week as our NYC hurricane, so we got to do both in one week, super!), so we sat inside at the bar.  Probably a bit more expensive than other options, but worth it.  The dinner menu looked pretty good as well, and our bartender was awesome.  I got the prosecco, and my boyfriend got a rum and coke, so can't really speak that much of the quality, since both are typically pretty predictable.

Will definitely be back, and bring friends!  I only wish they didn't have the AC pumping so high near the bar area..
Best doughnuts in Indy...hands down.  If you have any doubt...just check out the line that forms every morning.  Forget all other bakeries (other than Taylor's on the Northside).

Great selection of fresh cookies and ice creams - especially considering you can mix and match the top/bottom cookies with a different type of cookie or a brownie or a donut!

Smells so yummy when you walk in!  And the 2 guys working tonight were so friendly and helpful. We will definitely be back here - ALOT!

Over-priced and over-salted. Just a bad idea from the get-go. My beef was waaay too thick cut. Please see to teaching your cook how to cut their meats.
The only flavor I really got our of the broth was salt. None of those many levels of tastes and richness you get at the better Pho places....and even at the mediocre ones.

The Bahn mi was mostly bun and a hard crusty one at that.

Truly one of the worst pho experiences I've had. Blah.

Ocean Harbor is one of the dim sum places that I frequent with friends and family. They seem to have the biggest variety of dim sum. The only downside is that this place is packed on the weekends.  Prepare to wait for your number to be called. 

Service is chaotic with the amount of inflow and outflow of people.  It definitely helps if you speak Chinese.  Dinner service is better since it is less crowded.  One of the servers was really sweet and let my dad pick out his own fish (or maybe she was flirting with him!!).  Food doesn't really stand out though and pretty much taste like any other place.

There's not a lot left to say about Long's that hasn't already been said, but it's my top stop in Indy for a sweet pastry so I'll go ahead and put in my 2 cents anyway. 

Long's is a little out of the way, definitely more old school, and certainly without the unusually high number of hipsters as the new "craft donut" stores that have popped up around Indy the past few years. They are also cheaper. While the options aren't quite as adventurous, they have what they do perfected and you aren't going to get something that will disappoint. 

This location, as mentioned earlier, is out of the way from most things in town. It's not somewhere I ever find myself going for a walk or bike ride, or even passing on my way somewhere, but it is worth the short detour from downtown. Their building is a little older and what might have been and old residence. As far as I can tell, there is no actual parking lot, but the street it is on has parking on both sides and you can usually find something without too much difficulty.

If you go during any of the busier hours, the line will certainly be out the door and down the sidewalk. That being said, they do a pretty good job of keeping things moving quickly so it isn't as long a wait as it might appear. They have an old menu inside on the wall that has the prices of their different options. You can call ahead and put in an order if you have a bigger one, and then cut to the pickup window to get in and out quickly.

Although it's commonly referred to Long's donuts, it's actually Long's Bakery and they do have a wide variety of items. While donuts are certainly what they are most known for, they also have cakes, pies, muffins, brownies, cookies, and a wide variety of other baked sweets. Along with that, I know that they also have milk and OJ to round out the morning refreshments. I know it's fairly hard to mess up something that is full of sugar and fried, but everything I have had has been delicious. 

CASH ONLY!!

Only stopped in for a drink since we couldn't get a table for over an hour and fourty-five minutes.

Had a margarita on the rocks and wow-wee was it a drink! The ambiance was great and a smart stop for happy hour.  I wish we were able to have dinner but I guess next time we will go prepared to wait.

**SO-SO HH DRINKS ON MAGAZINE**

Went straight to the bar and skipped the tables.

NOTE: HH (3-6:30PM).

Our bartender wasn't exactly friendly, but she wasn't exactly bitchy either. She seemed neutral about making our following drinks:

*RUM HOUSE PUNCH ($7) - Pre mixed drink, so it was so-so. Had a nice sweet and refreshing taste.

*PINA COLADA ($7) - I like them strong, so it was a bit on the weaker side. I also like a coconut  and pineapple POW, which it lacked.

The menu looked interesting, but we didn't order any food items.

Next time, I will need to check out the much referenced $3 mojitos instead.

Not the best place on Magazine for drinks, but it got the job done at 4PM on a weekday.

i like the name of this place and the names they give their drink.. 
but i have to admit. its not soo great..
i got something dragon? 
it was red bean and pearl with MILK. not even milk tea..
make sure you read the description CLEARLY before ordering!

(4) ~ very good overall food & service

OUR MENU:
** Onion/Paneer Kulcha = (4) very good...they actually allowed us to combine the two;)
** Lamb Vindaloo = (4) very good & spicy!;)
** Kheer(dessert) = (4) very good
** Masala Tea = (4) very good
** Mango Lassi = (4) very good
** Onion Chili Utappam = (4) very good...comes with (3) dipping sauces
* Raita = (3.5) good
* Garlic Naan = (3.5) good
* Water(tap) =  (3.5) good
* Lentil Chips w. two Dips = (3.5) good

Last night was girls night out. Monday through Wednesday 20 oz margaritas for $3.99 Heck yeah It never takes long after you sit down for chips and salsa to appear White cheese is extra but worth it My friend had a the veggie fajitas The smell and sizzle was just as good as the food I had the nachos Great drinks and dinner Must go place for girls night out Bonus I spent less than $20

I think this is officially my favorite taco shop in Reno. Every type of meat we've had here is always good. Carne asada, lengua, chicken, carnitas, and el pastor... it's all consistently delicious. My husband and I typically order a mixture of different tacos and then share them between the two of us; this is a great way to try a little bit of everything and not fill up on one thing. We've had other things here too, but the tacos are just so dang delicious that I go back to ordering them time and time again. 

This restaurant is always packed and it's not uncommon for the line to be almost out the door around lunch hour or when downtown Reno has street activities going on. If you're not planning to sit down and eat in the restaurant they typically have a takeout line to the side that you can order from. Regardless, it's worth the wait if you have the time. I only wish they had additional locations.

I love this place!! Golden Flower is definitely one of those hole in the wall places that is 100% worth the $7-8 dollars that you spend on a very delicious bowl of pho. The service is usually very quick (they are usually trying to get people in and out because it does get extremely busy at times) but the flavor of the pho is so delicious. When I come I usually get the rare steak pho bowl in a large. The portions are pretty big so if you don't finish - which I usually don't - this is enough food for you to be able to take home with you for a second meal!

I have had their potstickers and spring rolls before as well, which I didn't really like as much. However I have tried some of their fried rice and entree dishes as well which are really good! 

There's no doubt that I will continue to come to Golden Flower whenever I am craving pho!

It is still pretty fabulous. Terrific service lots of staff members. Very cheerful and helpful staff. The buffet had so many items , goat curry , chicken Tika masala, tandoori chicken for example. Four different kinds of desserts. I liked it and I would come back

This place was recommended to me and I saw the yelp reviews as well.  As you enter the place, it looks nice and it smells good too, it smells like Pappadeaux's.  But that's where the similarities end.  

The hostesses are very friendly and make you feel welcome.  They had a sign pointing to a room that said casino.  It had 3 old slot machines which I thought was kinda funny. 

Our waitress Valena was very nice, but also disappeared for awhile.  

The food was just ok, it was priced accordingly.  The seafood salad was a bit much but had a amount of lump crab.

But all in all I would not return.  It was not a good representation of this great city of New Orleans.

I decided to try the thai coconut smoothie with coconut jelly and it is just fantastic with a perfectly sweet, creamy drink base and plenty of coconut jelly.  Definitely better than your typical bubble tea drink, and it's a nice change from the rather trite offerings at just about every other bakery/cafe.  Plus, I love Thai tea and coconut so it was the perfect combination for me.  Will update once I muster the courage to get the pop bubbles.

I was warned that the person I'm traveling with this week has an unholy love for Steak'n'Shake. I've eaten at the chain before and thought that the burgers were pretty decent. Breakfast on the other hand...not so much.

First, there is literally not one healthy thing on the breakfast menu. Sure, you can get yogurt - the full sugar kind topped with gloopy pie filling "fruit". And you could get oatmeal - but it's the presweetened instant varety that tastes like fake maple & shame. I know, I know...what can a person expect when everything on the menu is $6 or less? If you want all the pancakes you can cram into your pancake hole, its just $3 so there is that.

I can take marginally bad food because SNS is what it is, but the service here was bad, bad, bad. There was one table in the place and we had to wait 5 minutes at the desk to be acknowledged and another 10 minutes before our server actually stopped by. Appears we interrupted "co-worker story time".

One further note - the restaurant was very, very dirty when we visited. Our table was greasy, the menus were sticky and the bathrooms are...gross. I'm going to leave it at that because to describe what I saw in there goes beyond the boundaries of good taste. All I can say is that there are some seriously dirty bitches in St. Louis.

The fresh cut fries were super hot & fresh almost made to order it seemed. The hot dog I opted for was nothing special. I don't quite understand the hot greasy fries into a brown paper bag thing but then I do like the fact that an extra scoop of said fries were shoveled in. I will need to go back & try their burgers at some point.

in case you haven't noticed, i make it my personal business to visit every chipotle in my region of the grand ol USA. while in south jersey, i took a trip here with a chipotle virgin. i let her order first and as i gently poked fun at her for being mildly confused at the ordering process, we were overheard by the girl at the register. she decided to pay for one of the burritos we ordered in honor of her first time! how adorable.

Muy Bueno!!!

La Hacienda has delicioso food and great staff!  The decor had an authentic Mexican vibe all the way down to the really colorful tables and chairs.  

They give you chips and homemade salsa to start, which were really good!  We had to ask for 2 chip refills.  We also ordered a pitcher of the Texas Margarita, and let's just say they were generous with the tequila...

I ordered the Texas Fajita, which included beef, chicken and shrimp.  OMG!  It was so good!  And really filling!  I was almost able to finish it (almost).  And the prices were VERY reasonable.  My dish was only $10.95!

So if you're ever heading South on I-69, keep following the freeway to the end and take a left on Graham and head into La Hacienda.
I've been back a few times since my last review, and I think the food has gotten so much better. Sweet potato fries are amazing.

Only way to describe this place is mediocre at best.. I came here for dinner tonight and for $13 I got hamachi, unagi, and masago nigiri.. Everything ran for about $3.75-4.00 for nigiri sushi and the quality of the ones that I ordered were not very good.. The hamachi color looked a bit off like it was old or something and they give you the thinnest slice of fish ever! The unagi and masago were okay but nothing special.. My friend ordered the teriyaki dinner and it was the saddest thing I've ever seen.. They basically give you salad, white rice, and chopped up bits of chicken on a plate.. The pieces were cut up so small it looked like baby food and you could tell that they didn't just grill up a piece of chicken, dice it, and sauce it.. They literally cooked it in bits.. Ick! From previous experience my friend told me they used to serve it as strips of chicken breast and the taste this time was just alright compared to before they changed ownership.. I will definitely not be returning here and I still stand behind my number one spot for sushi in Tucson, Sushi Garden! It should've been a dead give away when there was only one other group in the restaurant during the dinner rush..

We were lured in by the Yelp reviews and the smell as we passed by. The menu seem reasonably priced and straightforward. However, we were underwhelmed by the food. There was little to no Shrimp in my crepe and Fiance just thought his was too chewy. LOL The presentation of the food was also just not very appetizing.  The service was not very attentive either. Maybe we just went on an off night.

Finally a place in Tampa that serves really good gelato!! Variety of flavors, freshly made, and the customer service is PERFECT. They make you feel welcomed and urge you to try a few flavors as you browse. They also sell pastries and such which I definitely will try next time.

100% recommend !!!

Arigato Sushi is a very good local sushi restaurant in downtown Santa Barbara. The fish is very fresh and the preparation is good as well. Service is very friendly and accommodating. Nothing particularly amazing or creative, but all and all a very good sushi dining experience. It is walk in only, but they turn the tables relatively quickly so waits are not too long. Unless you want to head to LA, Arigato Sushi is a good choice for sushi.

As far as airport restaurants go this has to be one of the best.  It is clean, pleasant, well designed, and a good varied menu of sushi, noodles and other Japanese inspired dishes.

We sat at the counter and I had a dry Udon with chicken.  It came in a nice bowl shaped dish and all of the ingredients tasted fresh and well prepared.

The sushi in the counter looked quite fresh and one wonders how long it can stay that way at an airport installation (?)

I also had a some hot green tea that came in a stylish cup.

The service was overly accommodating and the entire experience was quite good.

I'm in love with Publix, but this location is subpar to the high standard I've come to expect from the chain :-(. 

Produce on the verge of going rotten, limited beer supply, less than friendly employees is pretty disappointing. This is supposed to be our neighborhood grocery as it's within walking distance to our home, and I'm afraid my fiancé and I may have to drive to a different location. 

Also not impressed with their seafood selection. Every time I walk by that department I feel nauseous because it smells so rotten. Definitely not something you'd expect from a location literally across from the beach. 

Get it together Publix!

Came here to see Moonlight last week.  It's a small, charming theater.  A little busted up, some of the seats seemed to be on their way to being broken, leaning quite a bit in one direction or another.  However, this place focuses on independent films that you can't find anywhere else.  This was the only place in 50 miles that was showing Moonlight.  The Ritz East gets an extra star or two just for that.

Tickets are still a bit more than I think movies should cost.  Snacks are still ridiculously priced.  But neither of these budgetary concerns are any different than any other theater.  Staff was pleasant, even if a lot of them seemed to be a little clueless about what was going on around them.

I order a lot of food because i am nocturnal.  

Sometimes, because perhaps of the tender evening hours i am ordering from, i get second rate fish.  Bad cuts.

If you cannot tell the difference, it doesn't matter.  I can.

And here's  the biggest problem i have with this restaurant:  Racism.

"Mei dan mei dan!"  They just don't like black people.

that said, the salads are all delicious.

I made reservations for 4 of us the day before we went. Being that we went on a Saturday morning, it was a bit crowded, especially in the patio where we sat. The jazz band was good and added a nice detail to the place.

The food was.. well, it's a buffet. The food was decent. The egg benedict was pretty good as were the hash browns. Our servers were right on top of making sure our plates were cleared and getting us more coffee and tea. Everything was just okay. But frankly, you come here for the lovely patio and the atmosphere, not the okay food.

Thanks again to the Yelp International Supper Club, I experienced a new restaurant. I'm always open to enjoying some new Greek cuisine. Tonight I wasn't that hungry, so I ordered a Gyro Salad. It was a large and I do mean large Greek Salad. It was a hearty portion of lettuce, cucumber, tomato, red onion, green pepper, kalamatra olives, crumbled feta cheese, tossed in their house made dressing and topped with gyro meat. It was a low-carb friendly meal in a bowl. It was served with toasted pita bread, for those who are not eating low-carb. The meat was tender and tossed in the perfect amount of dressing. This was one of the better Greek Salads I've had with Gyro meat. 

Apollonia has a great location, it is just half a block from the intersection of Gravois & Loughborough. If you do not nab one of the prime parking spots on Gravois in front, don't worry there is a prime parking lot behind the restaurant with a walkway directly to the front entrance.

The service was a little slow, I think our server was overwhelmed with a party of twelve. Even with the help of a co-worker our orders came out of the kitchen at a slow pace. However, they were extremely friendly and hospitable making Apollina worthy of a future visit.
Gorgeous pizzas. Mushroom slice very tasty. Some of the slices may be five star worthy but I didn't get to taste everything.

We went to Tiffin for Happy Hour after work and it was well worth the trek from CC.  We basically had the place to ourselves and the food came out quickly.  

They have half off apps and drinks - so nice cocktails were just $4.50 and $3 beer.  
Between the three of us we had four apps which was more than enough.  We were very full and happy with the food.  The price was fab - only $12 per person with tax and tip.  Can't beat that.

We tried the vegetarian samosas - they serve only two, so if you have a bigger group you might want to order more than one set.  They had a nice crispy shell, and the traditional potato and pea filling was really soft, smooth and flavorful.  The samosas themselves were really big and filling.  However, they weren't anything special in my opinion.  

We also had the cauliflower covered in some sort of dough, which was my favorite.  I'm kicking myself for not taking pictures, but once we started eating there was no stopping for photos!  Soft, cooked to perfection and not too much dough.  

We sampled the Aloo Papri Chaat, which was lentil wafers on the bottom, covered with potatoes, chick peas and yogurt.  SO good!  My favorite app by far.  It had all the right spices, and was a fresh dish I had never tried before.  Highly recommend it!

We also tried the lamb and chicken kabob.  It was definitely interesting.  It was lamb on the inside with chicken around it, kind of in the form of a sausage.  It was a lot of meat, so I'm glad we paired it with veggies.  I thought this was the least exciting app, but I'm glad we tried it.  

Overall, good service, good food, and a good price.  However, in my opinion nothing special.  I wasn't really thinking about the food afterwards, but I'd return for a happy hour for sure.

This place feels so... Genuine! I really liked it even tough we did not have a super food experience.
The service is truly fast, without making you feel stressed and I will be back for sure, probably for the pizza.

We love calamari, probably tried it in every place served in Nashville by now, unfortunately it was really way to blend... And the Marinara sauce was too. I tried to make it somewhat tasty by putting salt on it but it still did not really taste like anything. This is one of the first times we actually left it on the plate.

Some music (Italian maybe) inside would be great, they had a guitar player outside which was really good, could have stayed just to listen to him. If I was the decorator I would do the easy thing and put som string lights up, would make it look much better

We had a pizza which was truly fantastic and the chicken Parmesan was really good as well. We ended the dinner with a Cheesecake served without silverware, we got spoons after asking... The Cheescake was kind of sweaty and like the calamari just blend, I would not order that again. I wanted some coffee too but the Espresso machine was not warmed up for some reason, so that did not happen.

Our server Matt was working his third day and he was super, I hope he is still there. He was really trying hard and made our visit better with his great attitude.

When you enter into Bareburger, you feel as though Brooklyn came up and spat into Philly. And lo and behold, BareBurger began in a now-defunct bar from your favorite hipster borough in NY. Since then, it's expanded beyond the Tri-State region, with 23 franchises and counting.

Bareburger is all about being as organic, lean, and as pasture-raised as can be. Regular readers know I'm all about 80/20 cuts, if not fattier. But sometimes you just need to branch out and see what else is out there in the burger world. And much to the joy of the GF, we stopped by one weekend afternoon.

The Standard [$9.85]
Beef Sweet and wild rice, stout onions, dill pickles, special sauce, brioche bun

The GF went with the standard, but subbed the beef for the vegan sweet and wild rice patty. This features a nicely crisp exterior, with a hearty melange within. The stout onions imparted some savory heft, with the dill pickles providing some acidic crunch. The bun to "meat" ratio was on point.

Blue Elk [$12.15]
Elk, Amish Blue cheese, country bacon, stout onions, tomato fig jam, sprout bun

I love that Bareburger offers your not-so-typical protein options. I went with the elk, which is all-natural, pasture-raised, hormone-free, antibiotic-free, and 90% lean. All the stuff I frankly care less about than taste. But the taste was tantalizing indeed! Definitely not gamey, and featuring a slightly sweeter flavor than beef, the elk patty was well-seasoned and moist. The country bacon was crisp, but substantial and provided some salty savoriness to each bite. The Amish blue cheese provided creamy funk, with the stout onions providing depth. The balance with the fig jam was really nice as well. Delicious.
 
Large Rings & Fries [$8.95]
Smoke sauce, special sauce, habanero mayo, curry ginger ketchup  

We obviously had to try their rings and fries combo. The onion rings were well-seasoned, with great crunch. The fries were disappointing though, limp and almost to the point of being wet. Getting the large portion of this side nets you 4 dippers. The special sauce is what gets standardly dressed on most of the burgers here. The curry ginger had nice depth to it, while the habanero mayo had a light kick. The smoke sauce was essentially a smoky BBQ sauce. Definitely a filling side for less than $9.

With the exception of the limp fries, BareBurger hit it out of the park for me, especially considering its focus on the leaner cuts and the organic lifestyle. And while Bareburger Philly is casual, do note that if you're dining in, you don't order at the counter as servers are there to take your order at the table. Somewhat surprising for a burger joint. The menu extends far beyond just burgers, with shakes and cocktails on offer as well. Be sure to stop in for brunch which features everyone's favorite - chicken and waffles.

Conveniently located less than a block from my office, so in case I need an emergency box of Kleenex, here I am. The day I popped in, it was a bit of a mess in the middle of the day, which surprised me, so the narrow aisles were hard to navigate as there were half opened boxes that blocked the way. Signs were missing from the shelves. Just looked messy and that doesn't appeal to my OCD ways, LOL.

The aesthetic alone is worth a visit. But then when you see the prices for such s beautiful, new and hip space you are astonished. Wine and cocktails under $10. Whoa! We went on a beautiful Sunday and truly enjoyed ourselves. Nothing Like sitting in a courtyard that was once a rectory, drinking champagne and apperol spritz. I can't speak on the food but the menu looked fabulous and seasonal. Great and appealing sharable bar bites. I most definitely will be back for dinner next trip.

Booked the Grill Room for a Thanksgiving meal, prefixed menu, which looked great.  Food was pretty good but not exceptional.  Service was lacking as was the holiday atmosphere.  Kind of felt like a regular meal at the Grill Room, only the service wasn't any good.

First the food.  The crab au gratin was awesome.  Butter based sauce with lots of jumbo lump crabmeat.  Next I had the grilled sweet potato soup.  Bacon and parmesan was mixed in.  Kind of dull base flavor although it did taste like sweet potato.  The bacon provided the needed savoriness.  I'd say it was a 3/5.  I had the beef tenderloin and my girlfriend got the turkey.  Both were ok.  Turkey was about a 3/5 as was the tenderloin.  Tenderloin seasoning was just a few flakes of sea salt.  Dessert was a bust for me.  The chocolate mousse was a 2/5.  Great presentation but uninspired taste.  Tasted like chocolate soft serve.

The Windsor Court was decorated for Christmas with their lobby looking very plush.  The Grill Room didn't do a lot to participate in the festivities.  Not sure what I expected, but it was more than what I got.  

The service was subpar.  We were seated right away, but it was 10 minutes before our waiter came over for the brief intro and water.  Then it was another 20 before we ordered dinner.  When Jason (who was actually a nice dude) did take our order, I asked that he get some bread over quick, or I was about to start eating the food off our neighbors plates.  It was prefixed, so the food rolled out in a timely fashion. The server bringing out the plates continually mixed me and my girlfriend's dishes up.  A trivial nuisance but made the meal feel like amateur hour.  

I usually don't complain about price in my reviews.  Meals cost what the menu says and are usually available for review.  I knew the prefix menu ahead of time and was ok with it.  It was the 22% gratuity which I found irritating given the poor service.  However, I understand it's tough finding someone to wait tables on Thanksgiving.

In summary, the food was around a 3/5.  Service brought the overall experience down to a 2/5.  I doubt I will repeat.

This park definitely fails short next to City Park, while it is beautiful it boasted many less free amenities such as swings, fountains, or gardens. It's also definitely less lush and more dry than City and seems to be a favorite of local photographers to bring the families for pictures.

We ended up walking around, realizing the Tree of Life wasn't a free attraction (it's located within the zoo) then headed back to City Park later in the day.

Audubon Park was cute but definitely less comfortable than City Park, which I'd choose any day of the week over Audubon.

Appetizers at this trendy spot did not disappoint. 2 words: foie beignets.

Food: 4.5, atmosphere: 3.5, service: 2.5
Cost to worth it rating: 3 (beignets or chicken $12)
Return worthiness: yes 
Eve award: best topping for a beignet 

Highlights:
- Foie gras sweet potato beignets: refined decadence. Foie sauce along with the chickory coffee ganache was smooth and sweet atop these warm and just soft and donuty enough gems. 
- Chicken: big puffy almost round tender meaty crispy drumsticks with a slightly hot and sweet soy glaze 
- Shrimp sticks: tall with pineapple and spicy ghost pepper jelly 
- Spicy nuts: Cajun sweet and spicy pea and the trick

Midlights:
- Cocktails: was expecting a bit more but they were just ok

Lowlights
- Busy: hard to get spot at bar or waitress' attention. Likes the liveliness but the crowds detracted from it a bit 
- Didn't get to try the dessert: had my eye on the chocolate covered cracklin and peanut butter 

Enjoyed the food and would like to return when it's a bit less chaotic or I get a table for a full meal.

I left Cheu with a bad taste in my mouth, though I can't say it's the fault of the ramen. Dealing with an unexpectedly warm October evening, our initial plans of "warming up with some yummy broth" were not necessary, but we had a craving, and the only thing that could sate my buddy and I was ca-noodling at Cheu. We strolled in around 7:20 and the place was nowhere close to full. There were about 3 people at the bar and two sitting down, so we were immediately seated at the window. The inside of Cheu is warm and welcoming, the chalkboard showing off the daily specials (tea, beers, food, etc). A carafe of ice water was brought to our table, menus placed in front of us, and we were excited for a night out.

Cue when things took a turn for the questionable. I'm not sure if this is standard fare for Cheu, or just due to being a little bare bones, but we had two servers visiting our table periodically. I initially thought maybe one would just be to refresh our water, but they (a man and a woman) would follow after the other often less than a minute behind, asking the same questions. 

"Have you decided on a drink?" ..... "Can I get you ladies some drinks?"

Wait. Didn't I just tell that guy we weren't ready yet?

"Can I get that plate off the table for you yet?" (Oh, no, we're still working on it, thanks.) .... "Hey, want me to clear that plate for you, girls?"

No, we haven't even taken another bite since that lady stopped by... what is happening?

If they looked even moderately similar, I'd have felt insane deja vu that would've suggested that I, too, was insane.

As far as food goes, we enjoyed the shaved kale with dates, pepitas, and cheese curds, coconut curry (for my vegetarian pal) and classic miso ramen with pork shoulder. The curry was spicy and delicious, heavy on the broth and the heat. The more classic-style ramen was definitely jonesing for a little kick, added with chili oil and sriracha. Our duo of servers were attentive, almost to a fault. Like... interrupting us to check in, desiring seemingly bite to bite updates. That being said, the bites were quite tasty. The pork shoulder was a little tough, but otherwise all quite good. We enjoyed our cans of beer and our food, which was swept away immediately the second we finished our food. Our male server came over to let us know that, despite receiving our check, "No hurry though, take your time."

Five minutes later, the moment after we placed our card down for the check, the female server came over and, despite our earlier server letting us know "no hurry" she  told us, in no uncertain terms, that "because we have a waiting list, we need you to leave the table."

Ex-SQUEEZE ME? WHAT IS HAPPENING?!

Shocked by the sudden change in what we were supposed to do, we left, my friend just barely finishing the last of her drink.  I felt like this behavior totally ruined the experience for me, which was not going too poorly up to the point. But now, whenever I think of Cheu, I won't remember the ramen slipping through my chopsticks or the curdy kale. I will remember a rude, confusing waitress hustling me out the door as soon as we put down our tip. 

If I had the ability to take the tip back and reduce it, I would.

After 4 years, I'm still a fan of the consistent quality of fish, service and smiles. While it's not 5 star, giving it a 4 says allot.

The recent addition of master sushi chef Sam from Piranha is a huge plus the reason I bumped this strip mall eatery in Goleta to a 4. What used to be good is now great. Sure you can order off the menu but if you're at the bar, take a moment to get to know Sam (both in Japan, owned a restaurant in Hawaii) and ask him to make something special for you.

Always great service with a smile even when it's standing room only for payday lunch. While it's not a date place, it's perfect lunch fare that won't break the bank.

I've been to different Chipotles a combined six or seven times and my most recent visit to the Sparks Chipotle was the best. I liked the tacos better than Chipotle burritos. I had a coupon. I got three steak tacos and got the steak salad for free. I added the corn salsa to the salad and that was tasty. The ingredients overall are fresh. One problem was that my steak, both in the tacos and salad, was tough to chew. And their ordinary salsa is bland.
The staff was friendly. The restaurant was clean.

So we loved Cochon so much decided to try Butcher for lunch.

The place was packed on a Saturday afternoon. I had my girlfriend try to find us a table while I waited to order. We got the pork belly sandwich, muffaletta and head cheese.

The head cheese platter was good but having never tried head cheese I was expecting it to be a bit more flavorful. With the mustard and other stuff on the platter it was pretty tasty though.

The muffaletta was very good. Strong flavors that got better the more I ate, probably my favorite item. Also enjoyed the pork belly sandwich. Honestly it was an odd flavor combination when I read it on the menu but it worked very well.

I dropped one star because one of the servers kicked my girlfriend out of the table she got us because I was still ordering.

Went to American Sardine Bar last night with a group of friends and it (mostly) lived up to the hype. 

- Beer list: extensive
- Onion rings: overrated.  Tasty, but nothing special. 
- Falafel: falafel itself was a bit dry, messy/saucy but delicious
- Salt & Pepper fries: the perfect french fry
- Walt Witt Braised Pork Sandwich: sooo freakin good - tender juicy pork + creamy boursin cheese
- Location: a little sketchy but it's easy to find parking

Unfortunately they were out of brussels sprouts, so I didn't get to try those. I ate a ton of food & had a beer for a grand total of $25 including tax & tip.  Friendly service, awesome beer list, delicious reasonably priced bar snacks - if this place were in my neighborhood I'd be there all the time.  It's worth the trek out from other parts of the city to check it out!

Sofra is a Turkish café on Bristol Pike in Levittown, Pa.  It doesn't look like much from the outside, with small stature in a rather unattractive part of Bucks County, but grab some courage and go inside.  Within, you will find a small dining room, with open floor space for entertainment.  Most important, the chef knows a thing or two about Istanbul cuisine.  

Our Saturday jaunt to a commercial area nearby resulted in us stopping in to check out what was going on here.  We were greeted by a gentlemen I took to be an owner, owing to his general lack of social grace. Why else would he be handling guests?  Still, we sat to one side and were brought menus and cold water.  I am no maven when it comes to Turkish kitchens, but Middle Eastern chow I know something about from time spent in the eastern Mediterranean.  

I was looking for lamb gyro as an introduction to the skill here, but it was not available for lunch.  So, I looked further and found Shepherd's Salad, Falafel and Grilled Lamb in Pita Sandwich as attractive alternatives.  All arrived about ten minutes later in the hands of our erstwhile host.  The Salad was a plentiful pile of Tomato, Cucumber, Black Olive, Red Onion and a nice Olive Oil based herbed dressing.  Very refreshing. The Falafel Plate was 5 nice sized balls of ground chickpea and herbs, deep fried to a medium brown finish, with a stainless bowl of Tahini Sauce in the middle.  Wedge Tomato and Lettuce garnish.  Liked it!  Finally, the Grilled Lamb wrapped tightly in pita and again in paper, was excellent, with a rich BBQ-like flavor and more lettuce, onion and a wonderful savory taste.  Star of the show. 

We weren't asked if we wanted dessert or Turkish coffee (we did), but were handed the check as soon as we finished eating our mains.  I guess we weren't on the guest list, even being the only customers in the house.  

Too bad, because Sofra has potential.

I really wish they had a drive-through, as this is the closest CVS location to my house. I've found the service to be a bit slow (I recently got a text that a prescription was ready, only to have to wait 40 minutes for it when I arrived in the store). Atmosphere is a little dark and dingy compared to other CVS locations in the area. I think it could use some modern updates, but other than that, it has all the basics, meets my needs, and is in a convenient location.

érase una vez, estábamos borrachos a El Vez!  And then I woke up with a tattoo... true story.  This place was phenomenal.  We really wanted to Sunday Funday out in the city for the first time as a married couple... We had brunch here and we were on South Street like 3 hours later and ordering pizzas like 5 hours later and asleep probably 8 hours later... by 9pm... It was perfect.  El Vez had the best margaritas I have ever had.  We had guacamole that was so amazing and big that I didn't even touch the salad I had ordered.  We also had a margarita with Mezcal and it was SO perfect.  Our server was awesome- we warned him ahead of time of our intentions and he even brought us churros as a celebration of our wedding!  It was a very expensive day but I can't imagine it getting any better than El Vez.  The decor, the food, the drinks, the service- all of them are 5 star quality!

Since it came a wee bit of a snowstorm on my birthday, I had to cancel my birthday dinner at Blind Pig. But this Sunday the skies were clear, I was buzzed, and my dad and I finally got to celebrate our birthdays by eating delicious pig! 

I had no idea what to expect but I have been excited about this place after seeing the smoker out back every time I come to get my hair done at Trim next door. When you go in, the atmosphere is more BBQ joint than fancy restaurant, but perhaps a touch more classy. There's a full bar back there behind the bar which is an anomaly at a BBQ place. I did like the Christmas pig decorations - light up pig in Santa suit and pig Christmas stockings. Hello, that's just cute. 

So we had a seat in a booth and the waitress came over to take our orders. I got the pulled pork plate with the sweet corn and mac and cheese. Sadly the sweet potatoes were sold out so I will have to come back and try that. The pork was smoky and had a good flavor. I liked the traditional sauce on it. I didn't like the watery Carolina sauce or the mustard based sauce. The Memphis sweet sauce was ok but I really wish there had been a more fiery option! The corn was delicious and the mac and cheese was good. The parents didn't like the green bean casserole so much but then, they are used to green beans being cooked with ham hocks until pretty much mushy. I tried my brother's rib and although it didn't fall off the bone, it was SO SMOKY and flavorful! I am not usually a rib girl but I could definitely devour a rack of those ribs. The little dinner rolls they served were soft and a perfect complement to the pork. Sadly we were all too stuffed from dinner to even think about dessert but I saw some Red Velvet Cake and some bread pudding options that sounded pretty fab! Service was quick and friendly despite the fact that the waitress was the only one there. 

I liked this BBQ but I am not sure it is to-die-for-best-BBQ-ever. But a solid 4 stars and a place in my mental Rolodex as a BBQ place that is open on Sunday!!

Boil Seafood presents a style of boiling that is popular outside of New Orleans. Plainly boiled seafoods with sauce and spice added to the outside. We shared a couple of platters between 4 of us and an appetizer. It wasn't my thing. I missed the flavorful spice of the crawfish meat. The crabs were ok and shrimp are hard to mess us but I didn't think the seasonings complimented the seafood. 
In the flip size, we had a free dessert offer and the desserts were great! 
I would be willing to try them again but the prices are very high for what you get. I'm sure this style is for someone, just not me.

Oh, YEP!!!  I am always on the lookout for a stellar sandwich and this place delivers for sure. So much so that I'm going back tomorrow to try more of the menu.  The bacon melt was just perfect. Thinly sliced, not too crispy bacon with spicy collard greens and melty swiss on the most expertly toasted white bread. It was everything! Great spot for an afternoon sammy and brew (or vino, which I had. Bacon and wine, it's all good!).

I was really excited to try this restaurant because I love french food. I probably had too high of expectations... but the food was just okay.

I ordered the beef bourguignon because it's classic french and its hard to mess up.  It was a good portion, but lacked flavor.  I had a lot of fat on my beef which was a turn off. I think it would help if they seasoned the plain boiled potatoes that they served with the beef. I wasn't wowed by this dish but it wasn't bad, just average.

The red Rhone wine was great though! Our waitress was great, service was wonderful. My friend ordered the sea bass and they deboned it for her tableside.

We all shared a creme brulee for desert and it was good, I like that they didn't put a super thick layer of sugar on the top.

The ambiance is a bit odd, while the inside was decorated very nicely, on the outside, you have a very "nice" view of the gas station. lol. It's just strange because you feel like you are in a really nice place, but looking at the gas station while you are having dinner is a bit odd. Maybe, that's just me.

I would give this place another try, but I will definitely order something else.

Came here for brunch after barre3 class.  We had signed up for barre3 and brunch. What a great experience to try two new things: barre3 & deacons. 
Deacons is so stinking cute! The decor and open feel is great. I was kind of weary to try brunch because there weren't that many options. I saw the bonuts and knew I had to get an order. We got an order to split and I ordered the omelet. 
Oh my gosh. Both dishes were DELICIOUS. The omelet was good and the donuts were AMAZING. 
Strawberry and chocolate. Oh, did I mention the mimosas were great too?!  
I would love to come back and try some more dishes and drinks.

I hate to write bad reviews, especially for Desi establishments, but....

I got 2 orders takeout from them and was very disappointed with both.

First I ordered Tandoori Chicken. I was told it was 1/2 a chicken;it was really 2 tiny pieces, with a whole onion and tomato cut to fill out the container.  What a rip off.

Second time, I just wanted 2 Garlic Naans. It took 20 minutes! The girl behind the counter apologized, but it didn't make me feel any better. good thing I didnt order any actual food.Naan was good and hot at least.

While the food is just ok, it's places like this that give Indian food a bad name. 
Honestly, you would be better off saving money for a trip to Devon street in Chicago or some other Desi food mecca than waste money here.
10 dollars at Khan BBQ is 100x worth it.

A-OK in my book!

They have a cute spot near the Belle Meade campus which really puts them in a primo spot of town. Parking wasn't difficult with plenty of street parking available in this residential district. We missed breakfast (bummer) but they still had plenty of doughnuts​ and plenty of coffee. After snagging a doughnut for ourselves and a few for some friends back in BHAM we were on our way. We, of course,​ purchased their ever famous 100 layers doughnuts or "cronuts" as they call them. A little on the pricey side but it's a 100 layers​ of croissant dough so I get it. I had a taste of a Vanilla Cream doughnut and really enjoyed my nice midday snack on my drive home.

All in all, a pretty solid choice. I would love to go back and actually sit down and enjoy their doughnuts rather than being in such a hurry.

One of the best quesadillas ever. Grilled over the fire, which definitely helps.

I order the cheese quesadilla, the spicy salsa and guacamole. I am never disappointed. 

Husband swears by the chicken. I don't like chicken but tasted it and it wasn't too bad. For chicken. 

Son loved his tri-tip quesadilla and daughter liked her "cheese taco" because she says she hates quesadillas. (She actually loves them, eye roll)

Anyway, if you are in the area, it's worth coming here. We made a trip to Santa Barbara just to come here, so there's that.

This is about as nice a setting as you can imagine. Recommend you sit on the patio.  We went there three times (it was part of a package). 

The service was always expedient and very professional. 

The appetizers were sublime. After the success of the appetizers, I have to admit the entrees were a little bit of a letdown. Just good, not great. The dessert rallied well and always finished us off on a positive note. 

While it was not a top 10 in the U.S. type place (as billed), it was by far and away the best restaurant in Santa Barbara.

This is right off the corner of a busy street, a spot you can't miss, but may find difficult to park at. They offer several gluten-free ice cream which is feature. 

The only problem I had was with the young girl behind the counter. Doesn't have the greatest service on how to speak to customers.

Five Guys has the best fries in the whole world. I'm not big on burgers but I actually go here just for the family fry soggy with malt vinegar and delicious to the end. This is 1 of my favorite locations out of all the 5 guys in all the cities I've visited. I recommend it. very fast and friendly; good parking and a good place just to grab a burger and fries.

The food here is awesome but this is the second Chipotle I've had to change a baby on the floor. 

Why you have no changing tables?

We stopped in for a drink at the bar. The band and singers were good. It's definitely a place to go to if you want to focus on the music, not on conversation. I wasn't too into the music, but the experience was nice. The Earl Grey Gardens was my kind of drink, tasty and a little sweet.

Not bad for live music and $10 cocktails.

The Stonehouse Restaurant at San Ysidro Ranch is truly as ygood as it ygets. Talk about romantic . . . my honey's yeyes started melting the ymoment we walked in, and things just kept yimproving from there.

Started the meal off with about the best foie gras I've ever tasted. As good as Keller's at TFL. Moved on to a classic Steak Diane served with green beans (tickled with pancetta) so fresh and flavorful they exploded in your mouth. Dessert was a trio of excellent choices, but the one that stood out was the Meyer Lemon Tart made from lemons grown on the property.

Perhaps it was that we kept buying over-priced glasses (at $20 a pop) of Nicolas Feuillatte  Brut Rosé Champagne, NV (along with a delicious glass of ice wine served with the foie gras), but they didn't charge us a corkage fee when we showed up with a 2005 Ampelos Pinot Noir (92 pts from WS). That was very nice of them: As was the server whose name I forget, but who's been there for 17 years and was a total sweetie, along with being a complete professional.

All-in-all, one of the finer meals we've had the pleasure to enjoy, with great service in a magically wonderful setting. Make it the spot for a special occasion diner and you'll remember it fondly for a long time.

Sometimes you just really need ice cream. You've got cookies, cake, candy. Whipped cream and juju babies. But you NEED ice cream. The magic of the texture...soft...smooth...full and cool, dissolving across your palate into liquid velvet. The taste almost seems to change and it makes it's way into...in through you. Yeah. It's ice cream. This review isn't about sorbet, gelato, sherbet, or frozen yogurt. This review is about 2 scoops of the original treat, served from a sweet smelling shop in Mid-City. 

I probably eat ice cream 4 times a year, and rarely do I leave home with the sole intent of buying ice cream to eat right there. But I saw that there was a Baskin Robbins right in the heart of the Mid-city shopping complex and I couldn't resist. Parking was super easy. 

The shop:  I should call it a 'shoppe'. It's cute, small, well lit, and CLEAN! And you know exactly what sugar cones and waffle cones and happiness smell like when you walk in. The guy behind the counter was fast and courteous and let me try a few samples (I know, I know...we all owe it to ourselves to try new flavors) but I ended up with a double dip...chocolate and cookies'n'cream. Both had perfect mouthfeel. I ordered it in a waffle cone, and it was okay BUT seemed to have way to much cinnamon. I'm hoping it was just a mistake in the measurements for that batch. 

Anyway, it felt good. I felt like a kid again. I will definitely visit again and recommend anyone in the area do so.

Summary: A large menu provides plenty of options for dine-in or take-out meals. 

China Hing covers the Chinese standards of fried rice, lo mein, chow mein, egg foo yung, and combo meals of beef, pork, chicken, and shrimp. 

I stopped for a St. Paul sandwich but on impulse ordered chicken and onion curry. I was glad I did. However, it would more accurately be called onion with chicken curry as I worked through a lot of the vegetable to find the chicken and bamboo strips. It was a bit spicy but the pepper burn didn't last long. 

The dish lacked something, though. When I got home I added cooked cabbage to the leftovers and "presto"--that was the missing ingredient.

Honestly. I'm a bit disappointed here and not with the food...
My husband and I used to use our GSR Platinum card to get the buy one get one free coupon to the Elements Buffet every single week.
