Then the buffet closed and re-opened downstairs...which we all know wasn't the best.

Now it's reopened again!! And after the renovations as The Grand Buffet I couldn't wait to try it!!!! 
I'll start with the positives...
I do love the look and the new lay out is very nice compared to what it used to be. The waitress, or the one we got, was on top of everything. She apologized saying "they were alone" so I am guessing either they didn't have enough people working after the opening or people called out sick? Either way I didn't notice because of how well she did. 
I enjoyed the many new stations. Mediterranean station is my favorite...there was a chicken shawarma with Tzatziki in little cast iron things.. Those and the brisket Mac N cheese in the same holder... Amazing. Reallllly good. Also, kettle cooked chips in the soup area is genius. The new ravioli sauté station... WOW. So..Soooo...good. We discovered you can bring items from the salad bar to be put in our pastas...peas and bacon anyone? This is all better than it used to be at least.

Now to the cons though...
While I really enjoyed all the new mini casseroles... The cast iron they had it in was actually pretty heavy to carry with one hand. My left hand had a massive surgery and has pins in it now which makes it very weak. Anyone with wrist/hand problems in their left (or plate carrying hand) will find trouble here... And they're hot too... So heavy and hot cast iron means I'm carrying ONE at a time... And at a buffet, I want to be able to carry more...
The coupons. As I said before, we used the 'buy one get one' buffet coupons very regularly. It was a good place for the family to go and get to eat whatever they wanted (not arguing over what to eat that night) the buffet has it all! 
Well, now it's too expensive without our 'buy one get one'...and the hostesses at the buffet said they're trying to get rid of all locals coupons completely for the buffet!? There is only a 5$ off now which at 20.99$ a person on the weekdays still puts us out 45$. What used to cost 25$.

It's because of this that we decided we will try to find a new 'locals' buffet offering better deals. Maybe the Atlantis or Nugget offers deals to locals still that are better than this and when they're the same price, well.
Atlantis is better and kinda always has been so if they offer good locals deals too... We will just switch to a whole new Hotel/Casino to frequent...we are looking into players cards and the deals that come with them around town because if I'm truly being honest here...one of the reasons we came to GSR so often was the buffet.

All in all...it was four stars for me before... And because they're getting rid of the players card locals deals to the buffet, we may actually not come back.

The decor left me confused. There's what appears to be a... boat dock in the middle of the restaurant. One wall has some flowers and leaves or something, another wall has what I think were sugar canes, or bamboos or... something. And then there was a little vineyard sort of doohickie in the corner through which the employees on break were totally spying on us. Confusing (albeit totally interesting) decor aside, the food was pretty good. The restaurant recommendation came from fellow Yelpers when I mentioned that I was looking for a Thai restaurant near Center City. I don't know how a Malaysian restaurant counts as Thai, but I wasn't going to complain because I was looking for an excuse to try Banana Leaf anyway.

The food:
- Banana Leaf Satay Chicken: chicken was uber-bland, but the peanut sauce was pretty good. 
- Indian Mee Goreng: Indian style stir-fried noodles with various ingredients thrown in. I'm assuming the "Indian" part of the dish was the curry flavor; where it lacked in creativity, it made up in deliciousness. 
- Sizzling Beef with Black Pepper: meh. The title says it all. Not sure why I expected it to be anything other than beef that was sizzling... with pepper on it.
- Shrimp fried rice: standard fare that was done well.
- Malaysian Iced Tea: "Does it taste sort of like Thai iced tea?" "Oh yeah, like Thai iced tea." Lies. But still pretty good. 
- Fried ice cream: is a misnomer; it was fried batter with the most miniscule amount of ice cream. And the awkwardly placed fried banana pieces with the giant battered balls just made me kind of uncomfortable because I was sitting next to my girlfriend across from her parents.
- There was something else but I can't remember it now. 

I'm a huge (HUGE) fan of Penang, and I think if I had gotten what I normally get there at Banana Leaf, I would have been equally impressed. But for now, I liked it but didn't love it. Will definitely be back to try some of my favorite dishes though; really hoping to bump the rating up to a four or five because from what I've heard, Banana Leaf doesn't have stupid limits on how much you have to spend to use your credit card like Penang.

We are super local to The Pub (can kayak there) and have visited a number of times, but the most recent visit for lunch yesterday was a disappointment food-wise compared to previous visits. Not only did it take almost 20 minutes to place our order, but the meal took an additional 45-50 minutes to come out after that. Really a lengthy wait for simple food. My mom's grilled grouper sandwich was fresh and delicious and a nice portion size, but my bf's fried grouper sandwich was little more than half the size compared to previous visits and woefully under-seasoned. 

The fries served with my chicken tenders were tasty but over-cooked, many were fried a little too hard and I received the tail end of a batch with quite a few burnt small pieces.  

Since the new ownership has taken over, we have noticed several negative changes, would strongly recommend checking the seasoning and improving the fried grouper sandwich to more closely match the phenomenal one served here in the past. 


One nice touch: 10% discount when you put your cellphones in a basket on the table and not touch them for the duration of the meal and the service was friendly.

My theory on certain Chinese food items is they spread in droves across America, with the following key characteristics:  simple, cheap, and authentic.  This happened with scallion pancakes a few years ago and soup dumplings a little more recently, but maybe hand pulled noodles is the new craze in various parts of the country.  Nanzhou is probably Philly's most famous rep for la mian (handpulled noodles), and it has many local accolades to prove it.

Nanzhou does the city of brother love well, giving a chance for tourists (the main clientele here) a chance to sample some cheap Chinese eats.  The place is divey for Philly standards and true to it's Chinatown form:  it's cramped and difficult for group dining, a bit dodgy at night, and not exactly the cleanest place on the block.  Yet it's still among the "places to go" in most Philly tour guide books and luckily for many non-Chinese literate patrons, the menu is in English.

For roughly $6 a bowl, one can have various versions of handpulled noodles (or "handshaved" noodles in the menu) in a simple yet tasty vegetable, meat, or seafood broth.  The noodles themselves aren't too starchy, semi-thin like spaghetti, and perfectly smooth for the inevitable "noodle slurp."  In terms of toppings / meats, the beef can be a tad tough, but the seafood and fish balls are dynamite almost every time.  I always recommend a tea egg with the soup, and take advantage of the vinegar, hot chili condiments at the table for that extra kick.  If the regular menu of meats are a bore, definitely go for the atypical choices like tripe, pig ears, or oxtail for a savory alternative.

Service isn't going to be the nicest but they'll always be efficient.  They fill glasses of water / tea up quickly and are quick to clean the table for people waiting in line during their rushed dinner service.  I do wish they opened later than 9PM each night and if they're going to service tourists, I'm surprised they've stuck to cash only.  Perhaps this is the only way to prevent the prices from spiking.  Here's hoping they stay afloat by continuing to offer their noodle soups on the cheap.

Our first time here, no reservations, got lucky. Went on a Thursday at 7:30 and got 2 seats at the sushi bar which I preferred. Place is small, loud and packed. Kevin was our Sushi Chef, all the Chef behind the bar were very entertaining.

We ordered Sake as we reviewed the menu. One thing I noticed is how extensive, maybe overwhelming the menu options were. We are pretty straight forward pure Sushi/Sashimi lovers. We ordered: Sweet Shrimp, Smelt Egg w/Quail Egg Sushi, Edamame (garlic soy flavor), Spicy Thruster (3 spicy handrolls of tuna, yellowtail, scallop), Jalapeno Yellowtail (red jalapeno. habanero sauce), Su-Miso Albacore (mustard su-miso, jalapeno, cilantro).

The sushi was OK, though they did not have Uni to our disappointment. The Spicy Thrusters, very OK. The Special Yellowtail and Albacore dishes were OK. Fish quality did not have a lot of taste, though presentation of everything and service was very good. 

With competition being so high in Santa Barbara, we will try a different place next visit.

You're kidding?
Based on grungy digs alone my family (of 3) walked in and out.

This is clearly a take-out only place (a few card tables and zero atmosphere for dining in.)

The sushi case was empty.
Empty.

There is no way I would get sushi here.
I am reticent to even try the Chinese food.

Maybe it is, "all that".
But I was scared to even go there.
Who knew, Hardees has Mexican food? Purchased a taco salad which is on par with what I'd get at Taco Bell. Tasted a friend of mine's crispy hot regular fries which were delish as well!
This is the best ice cream that you can get after parking in a poorly lit gas station at 9:45PM.
Our bartender Chat was such an amazing bartender. He made great cocktails and was patient when we were selecting wines.
The pizza looked good.  The cheesesteak not so much.  Soft roll.  I got the cheesesteak special.  The meat got a little lost.  Peppers needed more time on the grill.

I ordered chargrilled oysters (so buttery, salty, and sooo good. the bread that comes with is very ok.), corn soup (pretty good - nothing special), and the soft shelled crab platter (fries were ok, the crab was good but very oily).

The best part (besides the chargrilled oysters) was the excited & happy service that they provided! they were chatting with us and even though they were packed with customers, they managed to smile and still be excited to meet each new group.

Make sure your whole party is there! no matter how long you've been waiting, and how cold it is, they won't let you be seated early :c

OMG, their breakfast gyro is amazing! As a true lush, I ordered a double vodka & cranberry from Ulele while waiting on my gyro, and only had time for a photo of my giant gyro before we had to get in line at the gate. Nonetheless, I nibbled on my breakfast during the flight, and the next day from hotel suite's fridge, and thoroughly enjoyed the deliciousness of this gyro. Look at all that lamb! Look at all that egg! Unfortunately, I don't see this on their menu for non-airport locations, so I guess I'm going to have to fly Southwest (or maybe Frontier?) from Terminal C to enjoy this huge, yummy breakfast gyro again.

Divey cafeteria place... we were lucky we didn't have to wait much. There's a single file line to place your orders and then someone yells your name to pick your food up after you pay.

The girls/guys behind the counter are definitely entertaining. They yell and talk as if customers aren't present. One lady's gold grill was just screaming, "Pay attention to me".

The debris po'boy was good but just didn't have enough meat. The debris is the roast beef that falls off and into the gravy. Yumm....

My husband had the jambalaya - good but not the best we've had and the sweet potato pie - same thing, good but better found elsewhere - even in LA!

As soon as you open the door you are greeted by aromas of fresh baked pastry, coffee and caramelized sugar.  Heaven!!

The display is beautiful.

Choose from an array of Macarons, the pastries are art pieces, frozen delights and coffee.

If you want a break from the hustle and bustle of Nola walk into this place.

I brought my mom here on Mother's Day. She was so enraptured by her experience that she began talking about how creamy and delicious this frozen yogurt is.  This forced her away from subjects such as the health hazards of living in an urban environment, how I don't get enough exercise, how I don't get enough sleep, how I look tired, how I should get more sleep, how sleep is good for me, the benefits of getting more exercise, etc.

All of these concerns faded, for a brief minute, so she could focus on frozen yogurt, strawberry, and dark chocolate sauce.

Thanks Yogorino! Love you, Mom!

The seafood part of the Buffet especially the Sushi (what was to resemble sushi) had a weird taste & texture. Yuck
The sausages and those fixins were pretty good
No ice cream machine, the night I went with friends there was chocolate mint, which was surprisely great.
Cheap

Bre is an outstanding guide!

We booked their "The Infamous City of the Dead Cemetery Tour" & had a blast!  It is a 2 hour tour.  Not only did we get to tour the cemetery, but Bre gave us the 411 on the history of NOLA, slavery, architecture, what VooDoo truly is (not what is portrayed in the media), Hurricane Katrina, music, lively culture that is New Orleans, & more!  It was great learning all of this from Bre because she is a native & we got to learn about the traditions she was brought up with.

Make sure to wear sunscreen, sun gear, etc.  because even though it was just warm, the sun beats down on you.  In addition, it is like 100 degrees in the cemetery so bring water!  (In case you forget, there is a friendly man that sells water for cheaper outside).

First off, let me say, this review is only based on the beer and service, I see many reviews for the poor food (which I can't comment on since I didn't order food), but I thought the service was great! 

I went to SB with a group of 12 others to celebrate a friend's birthday. The birthday boy suggested we hit up IV Loop because that was the thing back when he was at UCSB (oh yeah...we were a group of about 12 26-27 year olds, but we're all Asian so we looked like all the other barely 21 college students in the area LOL). We bought 3 pitchers and the owner asked if we wanted chilled glasses or plastic cups (it's like he knew we were planning on playing flip cup). We asked for plastic cups so we can play flip cup on the tables outside. The owner was so nice about it! He even came out with a pint of beer for the birthday boy on the house, made him down it, then stayed for a minute to cheer us on while we played flip cup! 

Great beer selection, various size choices, and super cool owner!

We had such a fun time here it's hard to seperate the food from the place.  But this actually was a good spot and we had a great meal here.

We came during brunch time and were easily sat on the beautiful patio.
Lot's of fun drink selections if you want something with a kick.
I just had a Diet Coke ha.

I ordered the chilaquiles.  Wow.
It's always surprising to me how many ways people can make the same dish.  This was just as good as some others I've had but equally different in its flavors.  Really enjoyed it (even if I couldn't finish it).

The table had some fun jams and things on it that were very delicious, including honey!

The food is expensive but everything around here is.

Can't wait to come back and try something else.

The service was fantastic, really good.

I know ramen and noodle places have been all the rage lately so I wanted to check out Cheu Noodle Bar.  I was curious about the different interpretation by others.  I was excited by all the good comments about the pork belly.  

The place itself is pretty small and cozy.  I love the lamps over the bar!  My party of three were seated at the bar (and YES, there are coat hooks under the bar).

I ordered a pork belly bun to start off with.  It is really tiny, like the size of a two bite brownie.  I wasn't really expecting such a fried and greasy "bun" or like some flat fried  dough.  There was a sauce inside along with cilantro and pickles with the pork belly.  Honestly, I couldn't taste the pork belly with all of that greasiness.  It was pretty disappointing.  

We also order the black wings.  While it was nicely crisp, the sauce was super potent while the actual chicken had no flavor.  We also ordered the brisket ramen and the pork ramen.  I didn't like the super super soft poached egg, borderline gross.  The broth had a nice kick but the noodles were chewy.  Brisket was tender but matzo ball was weird and unappetizing..like a wet sock.  Nothing special about the pork ramen broth.

While the servers were really nice and the place is still a BYOB (for now), the food wasn't my cup of tea.  It was pretty pricey for an unsatisfying meal.  Definitely not a place I'd go to for a ramen craving.

Wow this store has it all. Swimwear,sandals,suntan lotions,and more.Some of the best saltwater taffy ever.
This store has it all for your day at the beach, highly recommend you stop here for all your beach day needs

friday afternoon meal and finding brunch priced at $18.99 for adult...$20.56 after tax....empty and seated quickly....drink order and off to explore...the set-up is quite nice...everything looking picture worthy....grab a plate and starting with chinese...broccoli beef and sweet & sour chicken tasted freshly made, but comparable to panda express....moving on to american...finding some fried battered shrimp and fried chicken....both fried hard and dry....salad bar was fresh and colorful...breakfast eggs and omelette also bit dry....pho was a nice touch, but not very authentic...good if wanting some soup...the smoke house is where you should go....the smoked brisket was wonderfully melting in your mouth...slight hint of smoke and seasoned perfectly (not too salty)..same for the smoked pastrami...full blast of beef in your mouth....very good...the smoke house made the meal great...

We stopped in to The Gumbo Shop on a cloudy, chilly afternoon. A quick hot cup of chicken and andouille gumbo hit the spot well nuff. I liked that chicken, sausage, and okra gumbo just fine with added some hot sauce shaking. 

We enjoyed the chicken andouille rendition better than the seafood one, and to the grilled boudin appetizer I must give the "Ehhh, comme ci, comme ça," hand gesture of apathy. If we were to return maybe we'd try the alligator sausage instead?

Seating was tight with tables placed closely together; the large space was packed. Service was fast- hot bread for the table showed up with the quickness with our gumbos soon to follow. If were back in the area on such a damp, dreary day I might just get me some gumbo again 'fore the cold gets in the ole gals bones!

I had a terrible experience here and believe that this is the last place anyone should go in the French Quarter.

I wanted the best crawfish in town and went here to get them... after all, a fancy place like this is bound to have great boiled crawfish, right?   Wrong.

They started us off with potatoes which had been boiled with the crawfish... they were amazing.  Super spicy and delicious... perhaps if we didn't start with something THAT good, the review would have been higher...

We ordered 2 lbs of crawfish, because we were going to go on a tour of the food of New Orleans and figured we'd be eating a ton...

The server kindof heckled/hustled us for that decision.  "You're gonna want more than that...I'd order 6-8 lbs."  What???  At $10.99 a pound, over double what most places charge for crawfish in New Orleans, that's a no.  We said we'd try the first couple and if we wanted more, we'd obviously order them.  She huffed and put the order in.

Our crawfish were served room temperature and tasted nothing like the potatoes.  When we asked about them, we were told that, "every crawfish boil is different, so you never know what you're going to get."  WHAT WE GOT SUCKED.  The potatoes had better flavoring.  These tasted bland and lame... we stuck with those 2 lbs... reluctantly paid and left. 

Deanie's is supposed to be one of the standard bearers in New Orleans... this was a complete failure... from the food to the attitude of the server.  

Terrible.

We stopped in for dinner after a day of drinking on our first day in town, and this was easily my favorite meal of the trip. The food counter is located in the back area of a bar. You order at the counter and sit in the bar area, and they bring your food out to you when it is ready. I would describe the food as very upscale bar food.

I ordered the Fried Chicken Sandwich with Fries, and we also ordered the Macaroni and Cheese Bites to share. Everything was perfectly cooked, hot, and delicious! I highly recommend stopping here for some food! The bar is also spacious and has a good selection of alcohol.

This was a great find here. I had never been in Morrisville  before and had no clue on what or where to eat. So I decided to play it safe and find some pizza. I found La Villa with my Yelp app. It's located in a shopping center with a hod dog business and a liquor store. Didn't look too promising from the outside. But once you step in, you'll see that this is a quality restaurant. For lunch, you can order 4 entrees from a serving station behind the counter that has quite a few items to choose from. Very large servings of each, all for $8.95... Their pizza here is the grandmother style of pizza. Square and with plenty of garlic and olive oil to go with the cheese and other toppings. The dining room was very nice, and so were the waitresses. 
For a man starving to have anything for lunch, it was just by luck that I found this place....

Dinner at The Italian Barrel did not disappoint! How on Earth have I never been here before? 

A friend of mine has been taking up this place for years so I finally made the decision to get over there.

They're located on the fringe of the Quarter and street parking wasn't too hard to find.  We were welcomed and seated by a very friendly host right away. We had a reservation, which I definitely recommend as the place is small and very popular.  Once seated we were given all menus and our drink orders were taken. I went with a Bellini martini to start and it really hit the spot. 

We chose a bruschetta appetizer, my hubs ordered the veal porcini and I requested the penne alla vodka. The bruschetta was just plain "wow".  Warm, lightly toasted ciabatta loaded with super fresh, sweet, cherry tomatoes, and the portion size was very generous. My husband's veal was so tender. It was a huge hit.  My pasta was delicious! There was a good amount of lump crabmeat and the sauce was surprisingly lighter than I had expected, but without a sacrifice in taste. 

To close things out we shared their tiramisu, and I had a cappuccino. What a satisfying end to an excellent meal.

Two thumbs up!

Great Raw Oysters!  The sauce they serve it with is really good too!  I had fried oysters and shrimp with french fries so I think it would be pretty hard to mess that up.  The gumbo and the jambalaya were both pretty good!  I also enjoyed the pitcher of Blue Moon that my friends and I shared.  Our waitress kept our waters full, which apparently is hard to find.  Why is that I wonder?

 If I go back it will be to sit at the oyster bar and order quite a few raw oysters.  The restaurant was packed and we had to wait for about 10-15 minutes for a table.  It was good.  I will return!

I have to give Uncle Bill's 4 stars, based on nostalgia alone. 

I can't tell you how many nights me and my friends hit up Uncle Bill's after a night of late night partying at SLU. Oh, college...I miss you so. Now that I'm older (and wiser?), my partying days are far behind me, so there will be no Uncle Bill's trips in my future. However, I can still reminisce, right? 

I can tell you a few tips to make your Uncle Bill's trip a pleasant one:

1. NEVER come here sober. Just don't do it. Things that would normally bother sober!Stephanie (dirty carpets, smoky interior, sticky chairs) don't bother drunk!Stephanie. 

2. Order the pancakes, bacon, and hash browns. When you're hammered, nothing tastes better than buttermilk pancakes drowning in butter and syrup. NOTHING. 

I wish I could speak on the service and/or prices, but every time I've visited here, details like that seem like a blur. Really, the only proof that I ever visited Uncle Bills lies in the inevitable stomachache I have the next morning from all of the grease. 

And I kinda like it that way.

If you love socks, you are heaven. They have socks ranging from crew cut to knee highs. I'm a sucker for knee highs. The designs range from superheroes to animals to sports, etc. Believe me, I could have spent a lot of money in there. They also sell shoes too. If you need a gift idea, socks are the way to go...

This was my second time at Fond. My first time was in 2013. Six years later, this little restaurant still puts out excellent food. The paté du jour, duck paté, was awesome. So flavorful and hearty, it was accompanied with a sweetened mustard, green scallions, and grilled white pancake bread similar to the kind they would give you at a Chinese restaurant with your Peking duck. My salmon with lemon asparagus risotto was a heavenly dish. The thick slab of salmon was light and flaky, cooked just enough to preserve a medium rare like texture inside. The outer skin was a wonderful contrast of crispy to the tender, succulent inside. The risotto was a perfect complement. A fine French-style dish. If I could find a way to come and eat here by myself without looking like a crazy, single old bat, I would. I would come here quite often.

Sadly, my date this time didn't have the same hearty appetite as my date the first time. I got the feeling he wasn't very adventurous with his food as he ordered the "green circle" chicken, which was actually quite remarkable as far as chicken dishes go. The chicken was cooked perfectly. I will definitely be eyeing this place again as a dining destination now that one of my other favorite French restaurants has bumped up their prices to astronomical proportions.

It's very strange to me that I had never been to 717 South because I've pretty much been to all of the other restaurants on South Howard already. In fact, I used to run by this place all the time and thought, "Oh, there's 717 South," and pretty much didn't think anything else. 

So when I decided to come here, I was stepping a little bit outside my normal realm of restaurants. It seemed like a nice place, so I figured I would give it a shot. 

We came in and had reservations so we were seated immediately. The atmosphere of the restaurant is pretty trendy but does not cater to the younger Soho crowd which congregates a little bit further up the street. 

We started with the baked brie, which was VERY good. It was topped with a cranberry mixture which provided a wonderful tart and sweet taste with the richness of the brie. Really a great appetizer.

Afterwards, we were brought this pesto bread which came with a tomato and cheese mixture. This was REALLY good and was an excellent bread choice. I don't even like bread but that tomato and cheese sauce mixture was awesome and very unique. 

For dinner I opted for the macadamia nut chicken with broccoli and the chef's vegetable, which was asparagus. The broccoli was average. The asparagus was pretty good. The chicken itself was tasty, but it felt super fried and greasy. The cream sauce that came with the chicken was very delicious though, and provided a good diversity to the chicken. 

My boyfriend got the stuffed chicken which he said was very good BUT then he found out midway through that the middle of the chicken was undercooked. I felt bad because it was basically raw. That is sort of scary to me and caused him quite a bit of worry that he would get sick. Never good! 

We told our waiter and he sent it back and brought out a new, fully cooked stuffed chicken. It was taken off of our check which was very much appreciated. 

The service was pretty good and it was quick. The servers were very accommodating and understanding when we had to send food back, and taking the undercooked meal off of the check was very nice of them. I like when restaurants acknowledge their customers and go out of their way to make up mistakes for them. 

Overall I would give this a high three-star rating, but for Yelp's sake, I'm going to round up.

Highly disappointed. Got a cup of gumbo which lacked flavor, not sausage, okra, hardly and shrimp, and was rather slimy. I barely ate it.  

The space is jam packed, with tables everywhere. That said, I guess it's necessary because they are busy (seemingly with tourist like myself).  

One of the gals I was with got a po' boy with fried shrimp; she said it was good. It looked as if they gave a good amount of shrimp.  The other gal, got the seafood boil with just crab legs, and sausage, potatoes, and corn. There was no sauce provided, when she inquired what they had... it was only butter (I'm going to assume melted).  Honestly, it didnt look very appetizing, just plain and boring.  

Not sure if getting something else would have made the experience better, but for this visit.... it was a flop.
solid experience. nice staff and the alaskan roll was delishhh. this was a cute date spot (if you actually like your date, or you want to talk to them, not terribly loud like so many restaurants!).

Wow, Clyde's is an absolute blast! I organized a big group to come in for my birthday over the weekend and it did not disappoint. Our waiter Morgan was fantastic and somehow managed to get our huge group's drinks and food consistently throughout the entire day. The food was elevated bar fare, but very tasty and difficult to decide on what I wanted to sample! I tried the munchies and whatever is in their homemade cheese whiz is pure heaven! I also had the pork rinds and smoked wings. I don't even like pork rinds that much, but I couldn't stop eating them. They were fresh and incredible! They have a nice cocktail menu, but a few of the drinks were a bit sweet for me, so I stuck to greyhounds most of the evening. 
I can't recommend Clyde's highly enough. They brought it this weekend, and I am going to be a loyal customer from now on!

YUMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM!

I'm staying at a hotel a few blocks away, and was ecstatic to find out that this gem was within a 5 minute walk!

I had read about hand shaved noodles in "Serve the People: A Stir Fried Journey Through China" and my mouth was totally watering while reading about it... and was thinking I would never get to taste such wonders unless I actually got myself to China. And then... don don dooooooon! Yelp showed me HAND SHAVED NOODLES!

Shared a table with a couple on a first date (it was entertaining to listen in on the both of them selling themselves), but was completely distracted by the bowl of steaming noodle soup when it showed up within 5 minutes! And I have to say, so absolutely delicious! Soulful beef broth (I ordered the Oxtail Noodle Soup), crunchy greens, and yum yum yum thickly cut noodles. 

I think I'm coming back here for lunch tomorrow... I need to try more!

During our latest sojourn in the heart of the Southside, we found two yogurt gems. Literally right next to each other. We walked into this amazing coincidence unknowingly and just had to try both of them, to our mock dismay.

The flavors available are varied and imaginative (twinkies, for example). They have a nicely appointed board on the wall with a visually pleasing examples of flavors that are, flavors that were and flavors to be. Just about everything is represented. Except a staple for my froyo cravings. That staple being a hot fudge pump. Didn't see one, but I didn't ask. Maybe I just missed it.

The service is just how I like it these days: Stiflingly great. Well, they don't quite smother you with kindness, but close. I mean this in the nicest way. Keep it up. I was pleased to the gills at the true pride every employee I encountered took in this place.

Ever have a moment take you by surprise?  That's just what happened to me on the very busy Friday of Valentine's day as I was rushing into this Save Mart to pick up some last minute gifts for my kiddos.  I was speed walking from my car to the entrance when an employee was gathering carts and politely and quite charismatically asked me if I needed a cart.  I was in such a hurry, I didn't even stop to take notice of who was speaking to me, though I did cordially respond with a gentle "no thank you", to which he added, "my pleasure, you have a nice day."  He seemed so genuine and sincere, that it stuck with me the rest of the day.

In all my years of shopping at various grocery stores, I have never encountered that kind of hospitality, particularly in a parking lot.  And yet, that is the kind of customer service I would like to experience.  Most times, I'm even happy when the cart collector or other clerks make eye contact with me and smiles or nods in passing. 

While this moment doesn't make me want to drive out of my way to shop here, it was enough that I felt I had to share my story.  And if you do shop here, I'm sorry I don't know exactly who he was, but I hope he's there making your day, too.

Mexican food just isn't the same for me since spending a couple of weeks in Cozumel eating that the places where you don't see other gringos.  As Mexican food goes (outside of the local taquerias) this place is in the top 20% of the offerings in STL that aren't located on Cherokee Street.  

Things I liked:

Enchilada combo offered a nice variety and their red enchilada sauce is pretty good.  I've had their mole sauce in a couple of their other locations as well and found it to be pretty complex for a restaurant that primarily serves gringos.

Chips arrived warm (as always) and lightly salted.  The salsa was fresh tasting and had a good consistency - not too chunky yet not blended all the way to smooth.  Just about right.

Service is quick and accurate - always a big plus!

Came here to see The Green Lantern with the bf last weekend.  Some gripes about this place.  They didn't turn off the lights during the entire movie (I'm talking about those wall sconces)!  There was no bouncer at all!  There was one kid that kept talking throughout the entire movie!  Hearing "Is he dreaming?" from a little kid whose grandfather wouldn't tell the kid to shut up about killed the movie for me.  Oh yeah, one final gripe is the lack of maintenance.  The bf & I moved to a different aisle after we couldn't stomach the constant talking by the aforementioned kid.  I couldn't put my drink in the cup holder since the cup holder was really loose (as in it could fall off & is hanging by a screw).  The only good thing is the cheap prices ($4 for an evening show) as mentioned in the previous reviews.  It's a tiny movie theatre.  I might come back here but only at later in night shows (9 PM) so that I can avoid the "Is he dreaming?" nonsense.

This was the first stop in our "Oyster crawl 2016!" 

We got in line and the line was a quick...10 minute wait and discussed Street Fighter 5 with the waiter making sure people are in line correctly.  

After a little bit we got our table - right in the middle - next to a giant red light that set the mood for this place.  We ordered the fried crawfish tails, a set of raw oysters, and an oyster shooter for each of us.  

Fried crawfish tails - awesome!  Amazingly fried golden tails of crawfish with some buttered bread and a sauce on the side - pure deliciousness.  

Oysters here were pretty good - and for the oysters they were fresh - very mildy brine-y and didn't really have much flavor, but the size was enormous!  the first one i grabbed was as big as my palm and that was the actual oyster, not just the shell!  

The oyster shooter though - was a slight miss.  Mostly b/c the lack of salt in said oysters didn't have the right combination of vodka, oyster and cocktail sauce.  Overall though it was a good first stop for our Oyster Crawl

Enjoyed weekday lunch on patio. First time at coffee exchange camino principle at light Nw into tucson country club . Halloween afternoon al Pacino our host & server was very friendly and accommodating ( in costume ) . All food on large most  healthy menu items told is fresh .  The spicy guacamole burger ( angus or black bean I had ) was fresh tasty & spicy w jalapeños on a great pretzel bun. The salmon sandwich on brioche bun also fresh & tasty very large half was to return home. Please note the cole slaw was very good also thank you. Many salads & breakfast items. Busy at 2pm weekday afternoon. Drive thru available. I was impressed and will return .

How this place ever got 5-star ratings is a mystery to me.  I'm not often fooled by Yelpers, but y'all got me this time!

The pros:  Decent beer selection, but they were out of a few.  I enjoyed my Czech Pilsner.  Solid vodka selection.  Good burger (albeit, a bit overcooked) & fries, but not the best in town.  Good beet salad. The server did a great job, too.  

The cons:  Atmosphere, or lack thereof.  Dark & uncomfortable.  Horrendous rap/hip hop music playing.  (I don't remember all the lyrics, but "f#ck this sh*t", was the main chorus).  Beef stroganoff wasn't good.  Tough beef in a reddish gravy served next to some egg noodles, with a roll.  

I'd maybe go back for vodka shots, but not likely.

Okay, wow. So we were passing by and the line was LONG. However, they don't open until 5:30 and it was 5:25 so it makes sense.
 
Couple of my girlies and I went to Claret for HH and decided hey, why not go eat dinner there after happy hour. Our waitress gave us a good tip to call and let them know to put us on the list so we didn't have to sit and wait. Wait was about an hour.

We get there and it is a small cozy place filled with great smells. We decided to go for it all. We order three egg rolls, pan fried shrimp and pork dumplings, dan dan noodles (WARNING: these are super spicy), stir fry broccoli, dry rub chicken, and the special pork belly cooked twice. 
I will say the pork belly was my least fave because of how much fat was on each piece. I know pork belly has fat but this was like the each piece. 

Honestly, its good and the service was amazing but I will say I would come back once it isn't too busy and try them again.

This is where New Orleans hides their best french fries! Seriously the best damn french fries I've had ever.

We happened into what we thought was going to be a traditional bistro, but turned out to be anything but.

This hole in the wall amazing place is located inside and at the rear of the 700 club bar.  Initially when I saw 700 club on the outside of the darkened building, it reminded me of the religious group that used to be on TV Sunday mornings when I was a kid. A channel quickly flipped by

This little hidden gem has three high top tables, a few chairs, and seriously the best fries that you will find anywhere in the French quarter. Grab a menu from the wall, and head over to the window to place your order. Once your order is placed and paid for they will give you her number and bring the food to your table.

We ordered a plain cheeseburger... Meat, cheese, and the barn. Let me just say for a very plain cheeseburger it was delicious! Have I mentioned how good those damn fries were?! Seriously, I even asked the kitchen what they put on them or how they make them. All I know is that I was told numerous spices, and that was about all they were going to share.  

We also ordered what was called a cheesy burger. The concept in theory sounded divine.  Big chunks of meat slathered in cheesy sauce, horseradish sauce, and topped with shoestring fried onions. Who would not want that goodness?!

The pictures say 1000 words, and yes, the sandwich was absolutely huge. Did I mention that the price points were pretty reasonable for local food? A couple of sandwiches and order of fries, and a drink for under $30. That's considered reasonable in the area.  The sandwich was almost impossible to eat because as you can see in the pictures the cheesy sauce was everywhere LOL unfortunately, the meat was heavily salted to the point that it was practically inedible. In a regular restaurant I would've sent the food back.  This whole in the wall is pretty much a make to order place, which is part of it's charm.  I was able to pick around it but it something that I definitely would not order again, and less I had assurances that the meat wasn't going to be overly salted

Music from the bar spills into the area and definitely warms the atmosphere.  Here is where good food and cool vibes come together. With the tunes blasting, and the people drinking, they are sure to be random dancing and fun to be had.

Great place for a quality burger, and if you are in the area and don't try the french fries, you seriously are missing out on good eats. The guy that was sitting behind us was there just for the fries.  I now know why!! Seriously, this is one of the best hidden gems in the quarter

My husband and I have been wanting to try this place for quite sometime. We had no idea that it was one of the restaurants profiled on diners drive through's and dives. Not sure why because it it's not really any of those things. This place is in Centro Ybor below the movie theater. I had a seasonal port that was Gingerbread. It was quite different and a bit bitter so I wasn't able to finish it. I was really excited to try the beer cheese soup. While it was quite tasty, it was thicker than I expected and a tad too salty. I dipped my friends pretzel in it and wondered if this was the same cheese they served on the side of her pretzel. I ordered the crab/shrimp cakes from the appetizer side and it was ok. I felt it could have been cooked longer. My hubby had the shepards pie and it was also just ok. I tasted a cider wing that was profiled on DDD and it was really good. Too much heat for me personally but a great flavor. We sat outside which we really enjoyed since the cold air was filtering in.

I've been here a few times, always getting something off the standard menu i.e. red coconut curry, which is great, but I can be picky with ingredients. This past time I did the create your own, and I must say, I really enjoyed the whole experience from ordering to the dish itself! I love the Wawa-style touchscreen ordering system for customizing the order, and the dish came out fast!

My order this time was tofu (double order), rice noodles, broccoli, carrots, kale, green beans, bell pepper, chili flakes, shallots and a regular order of sesame garlic sauce. Totally delicious and served hot, and I like how they had sriracha available in the condiments section.

This pint of stir fry came to $11.99, which is a few dollars more than I expected from a fast-casual place, but I understand the premium is due to the local/organic/farm-to-table factor (not important to me - I'd be happy with non-local/conventional ingredients for $8.99 - but I realize this is their branding/selling point.) Very satisfying food but I can see it being more of an occasional treat than being a regular, due to pricing.

They use the "Fresh Tofu" brand from Allentown - I've been a huge fan for a long time, probably around 20 years. I wish they would go a little easier on their frying method because sadly I found the tofu to be very chewy and almost inedible. Sautéed would be much better than deep frying. I also don't know what their single order of tofu looks like but my order didn't seem like it had a substantial amount. Will have to try a single order next time to compare.

Looking forward to my next visit!

Ordered the jambalaya, gator sausage, and bread pudding to go because we were on a schedule. Call in and pick up at the bar! 

This was our first jambalaya and at first when I opened the box, I thought my order was incomplete. No! The Jambalaya is just two scoops of what looked like fried rice and no sauce. I was looking through the pics when I was ordering and completely thought wrong. Thank god I ordered the sausage because it was so amazing! It was salty so it complemented the jambalaya nicely.

I would not order the bread pudding again. It was so  sweet and drenched in sauce. Extremely overwhelming for my tongue. Very small cup of dessert. I don't recommend this.

I like to visit Burlington for their great sport clothing sets. I can pick up really cute Nike jumpsuits for under $20.  Most retailers sell for $25-$35 easy.  Seems they have some decent deals. Don't expect any customer service and much organization.  I don't shop for myself here but like the kids section.

This downtown DQ location is very small, but it serves all the ice cream treats we know and love. I came in during their Free Cone promotion and it was a hot Tucson day. Free Chocolate or Vanilla cone - who could say "no" to that? There was a 75 cent upcharge for dipped flavors, so I chose a free vanilla cone. Fast service and yummy ice cream - what more can be said?

What can you say about Big Al's.  What a cool place.  Gorgeous architecture and design, bowling, games, massive TV's and really fun place in which I can easy spend an entire afternoon there.  I was there the other day doing just that.  I spent most of the afternoon just watching the Olympics and having a smorgasbord of a variety of things on their menu over the course of my day.  Unknowingly, happy hour was from 2-6pm so I was able to try a lot of appetizers at half price.

Some were good, some were average but all in all, I had a great time watching sports on their big screens and chatting with a friend.  The restaurant has really nice tables and chairs.  Even though the restaurant is really big, my waiter checked back with us constantly giving us personal attention.  Food always came out fast and hot.  Prices are a bit steep but if you come during certain times, you can enjoy a quiet atmosphere and some decent food with really good service.  When they first opened, they were working out some kinks with their staff but I would say in the last couple years, if not more, the staff has really been much better and I have been really pleased with the level of customer service I have received.  I wish them the best and it is a beautiful addition to the Village area.

My past few trips down to the great US of A, I've always been intrigued by Pinkberry but I've never tried it.

Deciding to take a much needed break from wandering around WEM, we figured a mid-afternoon snack. The friendly fro-yo artisté greeted us and asked if we wanted to try some samples . . . UMMM YES!!! Their selection for the day were: original, pomegranate, coconut, mango, peanut butter and chocolate. I sampled mango and coconut - not sure why I chose the latter because I always think artificial coconut tastes like sunscreen.

I went with a mini sized mango with no thrills or frills, and my girlfriend got a mini mango as well but with some toppings and a waffle cookie. Presentation-wise they looked tasty and they were pretty delicious!

If I'm ever back at WEM, I'll come by again for sure!

Came here on a Monday evening and it was beautiful.  The reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because the parking here is horrendous! The restaurant is very nice and our server was very polite. We started out with a glass of white wine which was reasonably priced. For our entrees we had the salmon and  that steak and shrimp. All the food is served with a side salad. Their house salad dressing was very good and so was their homemade ranch. For dessert we had the white chocolate and raspberry cheesecake, absolutely delicious! 
You are paying for the beautiful views but the food is also priced very fairly. Very pleased with our experience here, I would go back for special occasions. 

Make reservations if you want a table next to the window also make sure you make your reservations for around sunset time if you want to have the best sunset view in town.

My friend and I had dinner here during Spring Break. I had seen on Yelp that it was chosen as a Top 100 Places to Eat so of course we had to give it a try! The service was great and it was so unique getting to watch them cook everything. I started with the recommended cauliflower appetizer and it was absolutely delicious! For my entree, I had the scallops. They were perfectly cooked and it was fun trying to guess if it was your food being cooked. We ended with a cinnamon creme brulee. I love creme brulee and it was right on par. It's not a big place, very cozy and quaint. The perfect place to explore when visiting or if you want a unique dining experience.

The Morris Burner Hotel is a little slice of what Burning Man is and has to offer.  It's a place to go and mix/mingle with like minded people.  They have drum circles on Monday nights, Tuesday Talks, with educational and informative topics.  They have pot lucks, DJ's, bands, art cars, art pieces.  I've never stayed the night here, but I have looked at quite a few of the rooms.  They're all decorated differently, and give off an amazing vibe.
The bar has recently been updated with a sort of Steam Punk feel to it.  It's absolutely beautiful.   If you ever want to get an idea of what Burning Man is like, or what/who Burners are, pop on down to the Morris.  You'll be welcomed with open arms by everyone that's there.  You'll probably get a warming hug as you walk in.  )'(

Monsu has been on my "must try" list for over a year, and I finally made it in with my husband and another couple on a snowy Friday evening.  While I wasn't as blown away by the food as I expected from other reviews, the ease of getting a reservation and extremely good service solidified a fourth star - and also guaranteed a return visit.

The atmosphere in the restaurant is nice - more cozy/homey than fancy.  The tables are less cramped than many similar BYOB spots.  There were many more tables open than I would have expected for a Friday evening, but the weather reports of an impending major snow (that never materialized) may have been responsible.  The noise level was lively, but not overpowering even though there was music playing and a large group dining.  The hostess was pleasant, and our waitress was a knowledgeable, super-effective sweetheart.

Our entire party took advantage of the 4-course "Turista" menu (though, this was not obligatory), which was a great way to sample many different offerings at a reasonable price.  Everything that came to the table was, at a minimum, good food; unfortunately, many of the dishes were very rich and/or salty without those characteristics being balanced out.  The escargots and duck-gorgonzola ravioli suffered the most from this; though both were quite tasty and I would consider ordering either again, but to share with a friend and enjoy with a salad.  The mussels, snapper and a deceptively humble-sounding roasted chicken were the stars of the table.  I was also hoping for a little more wow from the desserts.  The two cannolis that came to the table were fine, a chocolate cake was a little dry, and the fourth dessert escapes memory.

The manager (I think?) was making rounds later in the evening pouring complimentary shots of an after-dinner aperitif, which helped fortify us all for the walk home.  I'm not sure if this is standard practice, but it definitely made sure we walked out of there feeling well taken care of in addition to being well fed.  It was the little things like this that changed my take-home message from "Yeah - that was good" to "We should go back to that place!"

11/19/19
I'd never had a cheesesteak until I came to Sonny's. I always wanted my first time to be in Philly. I was driving from New Jersey to Virginia and saw that I could easily stop in Philly. I googled "best cheese steak in Philadelphia". Sonny's was high on the list. I easily found parking on Market Street and made it to the shop before the lunch crowd. The woman behind the counter helped me place my order (glad she was patient since I had never ordered this before). I got the cheesesteak with Velveeta, sautéed onions, french fries, and a drink. The sautéed onions took the flavor to a whole other level. Every bite was bliss. I am glad I came to Sonny's when I did because as I was leaving the lunch crowd was lining up all the way to the door. I can understand why. Highly recommend.

A great place to get breakfast! It gets busy fast! 

Luckily, I came in at a good time (9AM) and was seated with my party of 9 right away. There were quite a few people waiting at 10AM for a table to open up. 

The service was very friendly. 

I had a cheese omelet which was basic but good. Their hash browns are large chunks of potatoes with onions. If you don't like onions, don't worry because they don't overload them. Most of my family enjoyed their food, my mom really liked her mediterranean omelet. The only issue with the food was that my step father was served practically a burnt waffle, very visually obvious, and he won't send things back so he basically dealt with it, but it should never have been served in the first place like that. Dark brown=burnt. 

The pricing is very fair! I would definitely come back for breakfast!

Wish pollo chicken was closer to my home. The service at this location is great.  Seriously.. I forget it's fast food. Today, I came in for a quick lunch and ordered some tostones and roasted chicken. When I asked what sauce goes with them.  The sweet lady pointed towards the sauce counter and said, " pick which ever you like." Although most may not get excited for things like this.  The fat cherub in my mind was smiling.  All of their sauces are great and having to choose just one would put unneeded stress to my day. 

 Choices make me happy since I'm a serious dipper.  I love variety and they had 5 different sauces to dip my chicken and tostones. 

Overall, I love this fast food concept. It's quick, clean and delicious. 

To all the people that have to see me eating chicken. I apologize in advance. I am that girl that leaves nothing on a bone.

Modest place with good food. 

Now I haven't been in here for a while but we order delivery quite often as they have a very large assortment to please everyone'scraving o'the night.

We started with broccoli bacon cheese bites, obviously premade but darn good! Also split a bowl of chili, Their chili is very good, not spicey , almost sweet. a nice change of pace.

Hubby got the open face roast beef sandwich with double mashed and it was good. Also enough to feed a trucker as he had an entire meal leftover for the next day.

I had a lightly blackened chicken sandwich with fries and onion rings (I actually ordered fried and mashed potatos with gravy to save for the next day but I got onion rings) Fries are always well done here , the rings were ok, not very cripsy, but the batter was delicious.

So for $33 with tip we had a huge dinner and a lunch the next day.

We can always count on consistent food here. Now, I would NOT order fish or salad from here, but keep it simple and you'll be happy.

I enjoyed that the burger cooked to order was made according to the actual order, unlike some burger chains that overcook everything the same.  However the burger was too greasy and caused the pretzel bun to delapidate itself before I was halfway done eating it. The fries, by contrast were cold and hard. I asked the waitress if they were reheated, and she said definitely not but offered to remake them for me.  I didn't think they would appeal to me either way, so I dropped it. 

The salad bar was somewhat redeeming. Although it was the end of the day and the spinach appear to be wilting, the majority of the salad bar was well stocked enough, and fresh, and the serving area was sufficiently clean.

The kids have loved this place for years, and now that they're in college, the parents keep going back for dinner. This location offers consistently good Garden Bar, Beef, and Ribs. There's a limited selection of craft beers, and an even better selection of wines by the bottle at reasonable prices. I've never seen a restaurant with a more comprehensive menu for diners with specific food sensitivities.  The website offers not only current gluten-free choices, but also suggestions for diners with allergies related to eggs, fish, milk, msg, nuts, shellfish, and soy.

Another neighborhood place that's not bad by any means but nothing really stands out.

Four of us went in for dinner. The vegetarian had cheese fries...can't mess that up. Another did ayce fried tilapia and fries. It was better then I expected. Not to say it was so good I'd actually order  but it was better then I expected.

The man and I shared broccoli cheese bites and hot wings. I do like their broccoli cheese.bites but since they're shipped to them frozen and all they do is fry them they don't get much credit for that but I do like them.

The wings are always good here and I like that they come out crispy and hot. Can't go wrong with them. 

As for the service. .ugh. the service. Same lady working behind the bar that had apparently for 50 years and it shows. She argues..complains and bitches about everything. Mumbles under her breath if u ask for something extra. Really I don't need a grouchy old lady who never had a decent job getting snarky with me. I will avoid the bar area if she is working there again as the other younger servers seemed much nicer and willing to help.

We go for the bloody Mary bar on the weekends and the guys sure enjoy that with all the fixings. They seemed to have stepped up their breakfast as well as its been quite good and everyone in our gang of 8 jas been pwrfectly.pleased with it every time.

Of.course..the bloody Mary's might help that! : )

Stopped in here the other day to grab some lunch. Amazing! Small, clean, attractive inside. Lots of organic items. As someone else said, like a little Whole Foods.

I had their caesar salad, which was amazing. The sauce was very spicy - just the way I like it.

Definitely recommend this little spot. Use it to avoid expensive hotel food.

Where can you find a man that is tall, dark, handsome, charming, and willing to cater to your every whim? 

I don't know.

But what I do know is his name is probably Franklin Mortgage and that he is, in fact, not a man at all, but a speakeasy.

To meet Franklin is to descend into a world of sultry turn of the century style. Franklin is a classy minimalist: a man who wears a Brooks Brothers' Regent while soberly sipping a concoction of gin, whiskey and rye. 

The ambiance exudes pure seduction. Franklin's chairs are reminiscent of taut vintage leather: supportive yet comfortable. Tiny tea candles dance over tables giving enough light so you can just discern your associate's face lest too much information be revealed. 

There's a drink for everyone. (For flirty flappers, the Blonde Redhead is sure to please.)  

So, good people of 2011, descend into the underground to enjoy old tyme cocktails with grace, and loose yourself in 1920s fantasies below the streets of the city of Brotherly Love.

Try their secret menu fraps?!  why not. I go here only for hot & cold drinks all the time. Andrew is my favorite guy to make drinks. Drive thru sometimes is packed otherwise perfect 5 star. I never have any problem here. Service is fast for me.

My hubby and I love all difference kinds of food. We found the Clay Oven on the south side before we found Shalimar, but we've quickly become regulars here. The Lunch buffet is excellent. It gives you an opportunity to try everything without committing to something you end up not liking. The price is great. It's really affordable. For what you'll pay at Pei Wei down the street, you'll get way more food. 

The space is quaint, very small and intimate and usually tidy and clean. The staff is pleasant no problems there. They don't really bother you (during buffet hours). They just let you do your thing and clear out your plates as needed.

I love trying new foods, especially those from different cultures and ethnicities. I would definitely recommend Shalmiar to anyone looking for something different for a really good price

As far as fast food goes, this place isn't too shabby. I had eaten at the other location up in New Port Richey near Ridge Road and walked away a little bit unsatisfied. One of my friends, however, advised me that I order wrong so I decided to give the chain a mulligan.
 
 I got the bacon double cheeseburger and subbed out my French fries for fried cheese curds. Winner move! The burger is very reminiscent of Steak and Shake, but slightly better and the cheese curds were amazing. They could use a dipping sauce though. It just didn't feel right having ketchup is my only option for the cheese curds.
 
 The staff here is very friendly, the food came out hot and fresh in a timely manner and the bathrooms are cleaner than the Board of Health.

a buffet is a buffet & quite frankly they all taste the same.

I dined in on a Saturday night when they served prime rib. the prime rib was huge & looked absolutely delicious but when I sliced it up, it was really bland. it didn't even taste like they put salt or pepper on it. it was really tender though. the mash potatoes were smooth and the green beans were tender but overcooked. 

they also had a great variety of desserts, which was nice considering thats my favorite part of the meal. lol, unfortunately all the options were overly sweet, dry or looked old. 

we were able to use our points to get a buy one get one free, which was great but even with that, I think I'll dine else where during my stay at the Grand Sierra.

We were there during their happy hour time. After reading the menu, I found out that happy hour price just only a little bit cheaper than the regular price. We ordered a Tampa roll, Mexican roll, spider roll also  one spicy crawfish roll that we saw written on their blackboard.  The service was average and the sushi tasted good. The crawfish sauce was spicy. All the rolls we got were all cooked tempura shrimp or soft shell crab. we didn't get a chance to try any of their Thai dish or raw fish sashimi. The pricing was fair and the ambience was fine. The  overall experience was okay.

My first visit here was a weekday lunch, and overall, it was just ok.  

Food was a mixed experience, and service was...interesting. We were greeted by who we thought was our server, but then someone else took our order. Server #1 explained the menu and offered suggestions, and Server #2 who eventually took our order explained the spice level as we were trying to figure out what to order. (More on that later). After reviewing the many options for lunch (we were brought a drink menu, lunch menu, AND a dinner menu since that had the appetizer section), friend and I decided to share the Dan Dan noodles, wontons in chili oil, and the pork dry pot dish with white rice. Since the dry pot had a spice level of 5 which was the highest, I was hesitant in ordering it, but Server #2 recommended the dish, and indicated that it wasn't too spicy. Isn't that confusing? So is the dry pot more of a 4, then? 

Anyways, I didn't even enjoy the dry pot dish. While it wasn't too spicy as Server #2 suggested, it was heavy on the salt. Despite that disappointment, I enjoyed the Dan Dan noodles (very flavorful!) and the wontons. Wontons had a very nice kick to them. I'm not sure why the menu doesn't label the wontons as a soup since all of the dumplings were drowning in chili oil. Another fail were the plates! They were way too small and narrow. It was like eating off a kids' plate!  And being a messy eater that I am, the table was just a hot mess. Literally and figuratively. Server #1 was kind enough to bring fresh, clean plates, but we were looking for bigger plates to easily maneuver the food from the shared dish onto our plates.

Service was friendly, but it was strange to have two servers. Besides the great Dan Dan noodles, the tea was a hit! 

I'd like to give this place a second chance because it does have potential, but not until they work out a few things first!

Ok. Real talk. Am I at an airport?? Aside from the suitcases and vocal travelers, this is quite a nice Florida seafood restaurant. The Grouper sandwich was just as fabulous as the one I got last night, on the beach, while looking at the Gulf of Mexico. The view is different today, but the fish is just as fresh tasting! This is a very nice addition to the extensive terminal remodel.
Ijji 4 just celebrated a 1 year anniversary! I ate there last night and it was AWESOME! =)

We hit this place on a weeknight with a local friend and our kids in tow.  We got there around 6pm & there was a line down the sidewalk, with a doorman.  It didn't take long to be seated, however, and we scored a table next to the bar.  Since it's located in the Quarter, even waiting on line was a little interesting, due to the people watching.

My husband & his local friend ordered the chargrilled oysters & by their enjoyment, made them seem like the best they'd ever eaten.  I ordered the seafood gumbo & it also was delicious.  The kids each had a po-boy & were pleased enough to eat it all (which is saying a lot for kids eating unfamiliar food in an unfamiliar place).

The prices seem a bit high (probably due to the demand) and the service was pretty rushed (definitely due to the crowd), but this was my favorite restaurant we visited over our three-day stay.

I'm definitely a fan but I have to deduct a star since my last visit. 

The service is still great but I wish they would be more careful about making sure the toppings bar was fresher. Bottles of Hersey Syrup were empty when my brother reached for it. The cookie toppings were stale. There was a lack of care when it came to the presentation of the toppings. 

The fro-yo itself is still delicious and I love that they make it clear the nutritional value on each flavor. The toppings bar needs some attention nonetheless.

Lighting in the store needs some work because at night it's pretty dark and dim.
Very good "diner food" on the Mainline.  NOTE: They won't let your group sit until everyone is inside the diner.

The food is good but definitely not your typical New Orleans flair. I would say if anyone from the West Coast was visiting- this restaurant will remind you of home.

Ambiance is super cool- love how this place is decorated. You will definitely open your mouth in awe at the decor. Moving along to actual dinner- the food is really good and definitely has a healthy twist.

We started with the sweet potato beignets, shrimp & tasso pinchos, and the boudin balls. I cannot speak on behalf of the boudin balls, and half of the pinchos- but it does not matter because my favorite of the appetizers was the beignets. Absolutely delicious- wish I had the whole plate to myself. Would definitely recommend getting these if you make a stop at SoBou.

For the main course, we just shared the whole gulf fish. Probably one of the tastiest fish I have ever had in my life. It was a lot of work eating it because of the bones and what not- but worth. If you come with friends or family that love fish, I would highly recommend getting the fish because it was absolutely delicious and definitely one of my favorite items from New Orleans.

Service is slow- typical of the South. Our waitress tried her best to accommodate to our impatience but it is what it is.

Come to SoBou if you needed a healthier, modern take on NOLA cuisine. I will admit- I probably would not make this my first stop if I had realized how similar it was to places like home. But it was still really delicious and deserves some attention.

Located in the Grand Sierra Casino, I had hoped that the food would be better than most.  It is average casino food and the only reason I eat here is because it is free.

I like the cocktail shrimp. You can't do much to ruin that.  I also like their Pho options though the broth is bland and has no taste.

Place is always packed with a long line waiting to get in.

The chocolate ice cream is really good - dark chocolate.

Best bet for food - eat at the salad bar, eat the shrimp, try the Pho and take a gamble with the beef brisket - it's hit or miss.

We stopped here before going to a comedy show on a Saturday night. It was early so it was pretty quiet. Good for us because our server didn't have a lot of tables to wait on. 

Service was good and the food came out pretty quickly. My husband and I each ordered wings and we shared some fries. I ordered the smallest order you can get (4 or 5) and I had the jerk sauce. It was really good. It didn't beat the best jerk wings ever (Longdoggers in Cocoa Beach) but they were the next best jerk wings I have had. That alone earned them a 4th star from me because I love good jerk.

My husband ordered the medium. His forehead was sweating so they had some heat to them and he enjoyed them.

I also tried the cucumber cooler. It didn't taste like there was any liquor in it but it was refreshing. I was thinking about having a beer but planned to have a cocktail later at the comedy club and you know the saying, "beer before liquor, never sicker" which is why I went with the cocktail here.

Not bad for a quick dinner.
Stephen Starr--as usual, the interior decor does not disappoint.  This is a seen and be seen type of place, so I wouldn't be coming for the food necessarily, which are expensive small portions.

If you like it when things are out of the ordinary, you need to come here.

If you don't, there are plenty of Comfort Inns, etc, around Tampa.

We stayed here just one night, and didn't really get to experience what Gram's is all about. This is probably because I'm awkward and stuff, but hey -- I know an awesome hostel when I see one.

The space is amazing, for a place you can sit around and enjoy all day, for only $25 or so, it's unbeatable. You are sleeping in a work of art. Hopefully more than sleeping there... the people seem to be really cool as well, and this sort of place attracts interesting folk. 

I really think Justin F. needs to delete or rethink his review. Yeah, if you get a really bad feeling about a place after driving by once, don't go, but also don't give it one star because you saw "some guy" sitting outside.

On that note, you will probably be a little puzzled when you drive up. Gram's doesn't look like a hotel at all, and barely looks like a hostel. Keep calm and carry on... you'll have a great time.

FAIL.

So I heard this place was great-- a real treat. The cocktails are expensive, yes, but supposedly you are treated with the utmost class and importance. You have to have a table, you can't just stand at the bar, and on Friday night my group of five waited about twenty minutes for that table. Fine.

The waiter was polite and knowledgeable. I ordered a "Stormy Monday," which was served tall with rum and absinthe. Fancy ice cubes. It took another twenty minutes for our bow-tied waiter to bring the drinks. Fine.

But then another two girls (friends of a friend I was with) finally joined us from the line outside. We had already received our check, but every single glass at the table was still half full. We had waited a total of forty minutes and paid $12 each for these drinks. We were sipping for about ten.

The manager, "Anthony," came to our table and asked us if we were all going to order another round. The original party said no, but the two new girls nodded eagerly, as they had been waiting outside to get in for awhile. Anthony told us that he was anticipating that a party of six would sitting down in a few minutes, as we had already gotten the check. 

He essentially told us he'd like us to leave unless we were ordering another round. But I still had $6 worth of a drink left! My friend told him that the two additions to the table would be ordering. He told her that she was slurring her words (she was not) and it was time for us to go. We were shocked.

I'm not proud to admit it, but as we left disgruntled, my boyfriend called out "Thanks a lot douchebag," to which Anthony, the MANAGER OF THIS ESTABLISHMENT, replied, "You're a f*ckstick!" in front of the entire bar.

Halfway down the block I realized I had left my scarf stuck in the corner of the booth. Luckily the nice bouncer got it back for me.

I wanted to give this Gyu-Kaku five star because I have been to three Gyu-kakus and with the same food quality, this is the only one which has Horumons(Beef large intestine), but I only give it four star because my "fresh washed" plates have leftover dry rice in it.

After reading some online reviews, I was eager to try their pizza and falafel. Unfortunately, it was a bit of a disappointment. 

The place was packed on a weekday night but we were able to find one of the last tables and ordered a pizza, falafel and manicotti. The falafel as a bit on the dry side and not as fresh as I would have liked. The pizza...eh...just average. The pizza at Roccos in Collegeville seems to be much better.

I give them a pat on their back for carrying some Middle Eastern items on their menu and still want to try the baba ganoush.

Conveniently located in a little shopping center where you can get gas, coffee, groceries and cash - why not add ice cream?  It's definitely a splurge - if you do the math, don't cringe because you're basically paying for the equivalent of a pint of ice cream for just one scoop.  But you are really just paying for convenience.

One funny story - my friend from Ireland was visiting and wanted some ice cream. We walked in and saw there were dozens of different flavors, which I thought would boggle his wee Irish brain.  So what flavor does he want?  FREAKING VANILLA.

He said it was the best vanilla ice cream he's ever had.

Sigh.

A couple of buddies and I stopped off at this Five Guys for a quick bite to eat. 

Generally, I don't mind Five Guys, but I just was not a fan of this location. 

I came in and was greeted by a long line, but it moved very fast. Eventually, Joe the cashier took my order. I decided to go with a burger and a fountain drink. Joe was pretty nice and kept the line moving. 

Other than the friendly staff, there were really no positives. 

My burger had a soggy bun and the patty was oily, somewhat hard and bland. My fountain drink was not too good either. Even though I just got a Powerade, it seemed to have an odd after taste. 

The restaurant itself, was not too clean. The floors were greasy and the area around the soda-fountain was covered with spilled drinks and lids. 

I did like how they had some outdoor seating. 

Altogether, this is not one of Five Guys best locations.

My rating: 3.5 stars.
The staff is really friendly, restaurant looks nice and clean, lots of options in a menu: Curries, noodles, soups, sushi, etc. (Still trying to get used to the fact that Thai restaurants in United States sell sushi! In Canada it never happens. Thai is Thai, Japanese is Japanese.)
We ordered:
- Tom Kha soup with chicken (good, I strongly recommend if you like Coconut based soups),
- Tom Yum soup with vegetables (very good. Loved the fact that it was full of veggies and tofu, not just few pieces swimming in a broth. This soup was very flavorful and little bit spicy),
- Eel sushi (delicious. It's great when you can actually taste the eel not just rice - as in other restaurants. Would order again. And for $7 it's great deal),
- Red Curry with chicken (here is my disappointment: it was bland, missing salt maybe? Not sure but in my opinion curry is the signature dish in Thai cuisine! It has to be good! My husband actually said: "This is first time when I'm eating so bland curry!" I added salt but it was still missing some spices.

Excellent. We ate breakfast here every morning, and dinner here twice during our conference. It was that good. The service is impeccable, and the food is great. Breakfast would have been expensive (but not super expensive) except that i am elite with Marriott and so had a breakfast credit to use in the restaurant ... still, if it had been horrible, we would have gone somewhere else. The coffee is really good ... nice, strong ... flavorful. I like the real cream they served with it and the the real sugar. The fruit was fresh, and sweet, and not left over frozen stuff you get in a lot of places. The cheese was awesome, and the grits were perfectly cooked. I loved the chicken and waffles as well. All in all, it was a pleasant way to start the day.

Antojitos was rather disappointing. We tried to order delivery via Yelp/Grubhub, but after placing the order, it looked like it was for pickup only.  It would have been nice if this were made clear at the time of ordering, but it wasn't a huge problem because we live nearby. 

When we went to pick up our order, the restaurant was packed at lunchtime, with what appeared to be no social distancing. I really didn't feel safe walking in, and it would have been more convenient to have a delivery or curbside pickup option.

We'd ordered a variety of dishes, including tacos, enchiladas, a quesadilla, burrito, and a few other things.  As others have mentioned, their tortilla chips are absolutely shameful and seem to come from a bag.  The food was pretty forgettable, and they left out two of our entrees, while charging us for them.  I had to spend 15 minutes or so on the phone with Grubhub to get a refund on the items we didn't receive, which was extremely annoying.

I won't be back.

Great char-grilled oysters! We came for the oysters but also got a soft shell crab platter and a side of red beans and rice. The beans were very good, a little smoky, and our toddler devoured most of the bowl!

The oysters: wow! They had cheese and a spiced butter sauce all over them, and were so tasty! The dish comes with several pieces of bread which were perfect for mopping up the extra sauce. 

The crab platter came with fries and a choice of coleslaw, hush puppies, or potato salad. We chose the hush puppies, and they were probably the best I've had. The fries, on the other hand were not great, maybe just ok. The crab was very good, Battered and fried. It was honestly a little strange to just eat the whole thing. That's not something I normally order, but it was good. 

There is ketchup, three flavors of Tabasco, and plenty of saltine crackers on the table.

I dig it.  Went for lunch one day during work.  

The service was great.  Though we did wait a couple minutes for the check.  But everything else was good.

I ordered the Carne Asada and Shrimp tacos.  Both were very good and had good flavor.  The chips and salsa were also very tasty.

The friend had a combo of enchiladas.  I tried a little of each.  The best part, is that even though they were all covered in sauce and cheese, when you cut into each, you could tell what it was without trying.  I hate when I go to a restaurant and can't tell what type of enchilada I am eating.  There was tons of meat in the chicken and beef ones and the cheese one was good as well. 

All in all, a good solid Mexican food joint.  I will definitely be back.

(4) ~ very good overall food & service. Notes: You have to ask for Fried Onions, as they aren't listed on the menu.  And if you ask to put on ketchup, be sure to get extra packets at the end as they don't put much on;)

MENU:
** Cheese Steak(w. Fried onions, Ketch-up, Whiz & Provolone) = (4] very good
** French Fries = (4) very good, best described as McDonald's Fries with the skin still on them;)
