Thanks to Everyone Yelps reviews this place deserved a 5 Star. Maggiano's was amazing. Mandy our waitress was wonderful. We started of with the tomato & mozzarella which had a drizzle of vinaigrette & so good. Veal Piccata was one of the best. Fresh Fettuccine Pasta with pesto sauce & chicken meatballs was a WOW factor. 
You must try Maggianos

Yum! Came here for happy hour snacks and man were they delicious. I love places that offer exotic flavored french fries and man did they deliver, and also the goat nuggets are little nuggets sent down from the Gods ;) The seasoning on both dishes was yummy and they were so big that it ended up being my dinner despite sharing it with people. 

The atmosphere is romantic yet fun and the servers were all super knowledgable, friendly, and attentive.

This will definitely be a go-to spot for me and I'll continue to update as I try more things here!

Cheap, delicious food that comes out quickly, even when I'm hangry? Sign me up. Came after the gym to negate everything we just did and were seated immediately. The food came very quickly after ordering, and everything was great. You can tell the noodles were super fresh because they were sticking to each other. My shrimp stir fried noodles came with lots of sizable shrimp, and I took a lot home.
Clean well stocked location and I can find everything I ever need here. Service is good and cashiers friendly.  Everything is fresh and stocked like you expect at a Publix, best grocery chain ever.

God, I really need to start writing reviews for some gyms, because I ate a six ounce meatball last night. I had one of the best meals of my life yesterday at Randolfi's, and certainly one of my favorite meals in St. Louis. After being born and raised in the STL, it's so nice to be able to still have these mind-blowing culinary experiences after all this time.

We had an 8:15 reservation (though it appeared we didn't need it - it wasn't crowded at all), but decided to sit at the bar so we could sit next to each other instead of across a table (all together now: awwwww!) The bartender was absolutely amazing and I should have caught his name, but he really made our night with his recommendations. I will say, too, that the bar is the perfect place to sit to see all of the cocktail action as well as what's going on in the kitchen.

I started with an *amazing* cocktail crafted with Four Roses bourbon, Big O Ginger Liqueur, sibona camomilla, rhubarb tea liqueur, house-made BBQ bitters, and a multitude of other things I couldn't remember if I tried. It truly blew my mind and was one of the best drinks I've had in years. I later moved on to a red wine that was also five-star worthy and perfect alongside pasta.

We started with the Crudo Del Giorno, wish was yellowtail prepared in a beautiful sauce, and also the Formaggio, which, lucky for us again, was a triple-cream brie. From there, our minds were blown by the meatball. You guys. You have to go try it as soon as you can. It's a combination of pork and lamb, and sits on top of the most glorious house-made pasta you could imagine, with hints of garlic, chili, and chive. Because we just couldn't help ourselves, we also had the asparagus risotto, which somehow was as good as the meatball. It was so rich and perfectly made, and had hints of parmesan and lemon.

We finished with two americanos and the chocolate torte, and I'm not sure we'll ever be able to eat again. This meal was so beautiful, the place was stunning, and I'm pretty much in awe of the food scene in our city right now. Thanks for an amazing date night, Randolfi's!

Was here for a private wedding event at the restaurant. In fact it was a 10 course Chinese meal wedding which I find kickass great and crazy amounts of food. However there are times in which I'm a fat kid on a cupcake, and a 10 course Chinese menu is no time to be on weight watchers, counting calories or on a diet honey!  Seriously. Here is a rundown of the pig out: 

1) Pork and Jellyfish - very solid. Lol actually I though I was eating duck it was rich and tasty! 

2) Fried crab claw appetizers. Chewy, crab-eriffic and piping hot

3)  Scallop and gai lan- I'm spoiled as I'm used to fresh scallops. These were definitely frozen. Overall okay but not amazing. 

4) Shark fin- crab maw soup- Not sure if it was real shark fin. People are in uproars over SFS these days but I grew up with this on my Chinese side. I respect people's opinions but it's tradition for me. I'm fine if they outlaw it just don't get all preachy on me. 

5) Lobster- Cantonese style- absolutely delicious. If bugs of the sea are your thing they do a great job! 

6) Sea cucumber, mushrooms and fish- another great delicacy. Google sea cucumbers if you have a strong stomach. Definitely not a cucumber but definitely delish! 

7) Crispy chicken- a tad dry for my liking but flavour was spot on. 

8) Fish, Chinese ham, mushroom w broccoli. - okay my stomach was read to explode but this was quite good also. 

9) Fried rice- like I needed carbs at the end of a huge meal but it was moderately good. 

10) Noodles- had a very small serving. Stomach too full.

The brought out the traditional red bean soup to close the night off but I'm clearly not a fan of this. Also were some sesame buns and other treats. 

Service at the restaurant was excellent and the meal although had some flat spots was overall very good!

Hello again Chipotle. 

Yes, yes, I'm back. I know, I said that last time was the end, that I can't afford to eat here anymore. But I just can't get over you. I think about you all the time - on SEPTA, at work, alone at night staring at the ceiling. Sure, I've had others - Qdoba is nice, reliable, and treats me well, but it's just so safe and boring. And Taco Bell is good for a cheap thrill every once in a while, but when I wake up in the morning I'm always filled with regret from the night before. Food truck burritos too, but they're always on the move and I want some commitment.

I know, I've made mistakes...that I've hurt you. But you've hurt me - your deceiving calorie totals when you've told me again and again you are a healthy alternative to fast food. Your ingredients are sometimes not as locally grown as your advertising indicates. You sometimes break federal immigration laws. There's that whole Salmonella and E. Coli outbreaks at several at your sibling locations. And, worst of all, the bump in the cost of guacamole, which you know I'll pay for because only terrible people who kick puppies and talk during movies don't order guacamole. 

But you've also got good qualities too - I can order online. There is plenty of seating available at this location. And, I'm not ashamed to admit it any longer...you make a tasty burrito. Sometimes you send me coupons or even, with a knowing wink and nod, you "forget" to charge me for the guacamole, which makes me feel special in a way a Qdoba or Taco Bell can't. 

So I'm asking for you to take me back. We can start over. Perhaps at a different location, such the Havertown or Wayne locations. I can cut back on other things, like overly-expensive brunch or frozen yogurt. Sure, you're not as popular as you once were, no longer the millennial golden fast food place of choice, but I don't care about that. What I'm saying is...we can make this work. I know we can make this work. I just need you to give me another chance.

And you know what would make me forget you're trying poison me with Salmonella and E. Coli? Free burrito coupons. Come on, for old times sake.

But seriously this location sucks.

The views, beach vibe and food is amazing !! 
Them mushroom garlic noodles - I can eat 3 orders to myself ! And the sushi is just so delicious !! 
Everything we ordered in the menu was great, I will def be coming back.

I had very high expectations for this place. I was expecting some bomb ass oysters. I ordered a half dozen raw and a half dozen charbroiled oysters. Both had one similarity, they had me spitting out huge pieces of debris or chewing on grit. I honestly think you could pass on the raw and would recommend you go to Lüke for their oysters instead. Hello, for Happy Hour Lüke serves $0.75 raw oysters and they are way better. Charbroiled Oysters at ACME offered a better flavor profile. The delicious herb-butter sauce was heaven. Make sure you dribble some of the sauce on these lightly cheesy oysters before eating. I couldn't stop drenching bread into the buttery pool of all things wonderful and shoving it in my mouth. Ambrosia!

If you do come here and when, that's right I said when, I come back, I'd get their fried dishes. I also ordered one of their fried seafood platter, fish and shrimp. The tilapia was flakey and soft and perfectly lightly breaded and crispy. The same went for their fried shrimp but you need to ask them for lots of tartar sauce. They have the best tartar sauce! The fries were normal fries. I opted for their cole slaw side which was also yummy. Not overly tart.

This Walgreens it's just Walgreens drop off your prescription pick it up you're in and out the staff is a little older and very friendly and talkative.

From the outside it looks open because the lights are on inside and out but the hours are 8 AM to 9 PM Monday through Friday Saturday they close at nine and Sunday they close.

Very pretty park.

Came here for the bourbon, beer, bbq fest so view was limited but you could tell without the mob of people it would be a nice place to hang on a Sunday afternoon, 

The restrooms were clean and air conditioned as well. 

Nice view

Every single staff person here is friendly in this well stocked and well lit store, but the pharmacy staff are rock stars of customer service even when the drive through is super busy and the inside lines for prescriptions and flu shots are long.  It is unfortunate for me to have been in enough times in the last thirteen weeks to have enough experience to marvel at all of this and before I shared that observation here on Yelp I told both the pharmacist who 'shot me' with flu vax yesterday and always cheer filled and efficient Austin at the pharmacy service window how impressed I was for my observations of the last many weeks of regular visits.

Old enough to remember how my gradeschool teacher announced President Kennedy had been killed and with onset of a progressive central nervous system disease as a college student in the second Nixon term, one might think age and that diagnosis would make me a person well versed in pharmacy service for umpteen meds.   But not so as thanks to good luck and also hard work to stay in good general health, I need not a single 'regular rotation' medication even at the age where it makes docs say "Really! Not one?" in surprise when looking at a new patient's med chart during office visit.  Well, up until the last 3+ months when there have been a couple of meds and refilled regularly to treat a stubborn issue.

So it goes in these last thirteen weeks I have been a regular customer in this Walgreens to observe how many people need all kinds of meds filled here and how well the pharmacy staff manages all.  (Even events like a customer having meltdown to learn their insurance will not cover much of the cost of the med their doctor prescribed, a problem the pharmacy staff did not create nor can they fix it for insurance policy but the angry customer sure expected them to do that.)   And the pharmacists are helpful answering questions or giving instructions about the meds one has been prescribed and I've observed how well they do that for all ages of people at all levels of understanding.  

Kudos all around.

Notes:
LUNCH BREAK:  The pharmacy is closed daily from 1:30 - 2:00 when staff takes a well earned lunch break.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Ample accessible (aka ADA) parking in front of store, level in the door, lots of clear floor space in aisles.

LOO:  Some stores have locked theirs during covid19, this one (ADA accessible) is open and sparkling clean. 

COVID19 MANAGEMENT:  Masks worn by all staff, masks required by all customer over the age of two, 6' spacing distances marked on floor at pharmacy and check out.

ICE CREAM!:  I didn't know Walgreens had a few grocery items in their stores but so they do.  Including a freezer with ice cream.  When I was a kid in Portland and went to the doctor for vaccines my mom and I would stop for cherry ice cream sodas on the way home.  Going in for a flu shot here seemed like a pretty good reason to go home with a carton of Ben and Jerry's Cherry Garcia from the freezer case.

This lounge is located in the JW Marriott Hotel in downtown Tampa. It's the first area you see when you walk in from the S. Florida Ave. entrance. It's a lobby bar with plenty of bar and couch seating throughout this portion of the hotel lobby. It also has a restaurant in the next room over. I haven't seen anyone occupying it (Restaurant) on my visits here though. I'm guessing this restaurant is more of a weekend spot, but not sure.  

Due to labor shortage, they did have only one guy serving that whole area. The service was as efficient as they possibly could make it. We didn't have to wait for too long. Their salsaccia pizza was delicious! Also, the architects and interior designers did a great job here.

Even if you're not staying in the hotel, it's a good place for a reasonable size group of people or a date.

Outstanding restaurant inside the Sand Pearl Resort.  So good I ate here 2 nights in a row.  1st night I had the Black Grouper, Beet Salad, and Seasonal vegetables, was outstanding.  2nd night I had the Filet, and it melted in my mouth.  I had a ceasar to start and then it had a really great soufflé potatoes type casserole with it.  To end the perfect meal I had a Trio of Creme Brûlée that was outstanding.  Would highly recommend eatting at this upscale restaurant if you get the chance.  The service and atmosphere were outstanding as well!

OK, Five Guys, I've given you four chances. What got me back were your peanuts and your fries. Your burgers didn't. Today was the last time before we part company.

I think their burgers are the most overrated of any in town. They are bland. No flavor. If it weren't for all the toppings I put on it, the only flavor that I would get would be the bun. As a matter of fact, the predominant flavor is the bun.

The last 1/4 of the burger, I decided to dissect it and just eat the patty. Yep. No flavor. Nothing there that excites my taste buds. By gum, if I'm going to spend $7.00 on a burger, it had better be at least decent! 

There are better burgers in town for the same or lower price. You'll find me there.
Had the spaghetti and meatballs with spicy marinara sauce: lots of spice, not much fresh tomato taste, but noodles cooked perfectly. The pucks of meat included were ok I guess.

It's always good to have another lunch option near work. Yeah, it's a chain, but it's still a step up from the McD's and Taco Bell across the street from Chipotle. 

Besides, I'll admit it, I did have quite the Chipotle love affair when I used to live in Indiana. It was a craving that had to be satisfied, since I hadn't eaten Chipotle in about 4 years. And yes, it was very satisfying. At least, the food was satisfying. Chicken burrito w/ fajita veggies, black beans, cheese, lettuce, and a little bit of each salsa. 

So big... so filling. It's a good thing that I built up quite the appetite in the 45 minutes that I waited in line. Oh, right, the wait. That would be the reason for 3 stars.

Yes, I get that they just opened. However, when Panera Bread opened a couple of months ago, they were just as overwhelmed. In fact, I think the lines were longer. The difference is, even with Panera's more diverse menu, the line moved quickly. There are some major kinks that need to be worked on at Chipotle, from the chefs to the order takers, and probably worst of all, the wrappers. That seemed to be the major hold up. I'm no burrito-wrapping expert, but I think they need some additional training.

This is a spirited and fun place to watch football, it is not however a good place for food. 

I went to watch the last quarter of the LSU game and the Ohio State game, so I was here for dinner. 

My Chicken quesadilla was just okay. The top inch or so of the tortilla was rawish, not crisp and lacked filling. I added some of the lettuce and pico from the plate inside the quesidilla , but they must not have washed the lettuce because I tasted dirt. 

Okay let's try wings. I got bone in because their boneless were crunchy and dry the last time I had them. I will say the garlic parmesan bone in wings were pretty good. They had a nice flavor and the chicken was still moist. 

I had watched the bartender make my Mai Tai about 10 minutes prior,  so I went to the bar from my table and asked for it. Not really our servers fault, he seemed to have a very large section of tables to care for. (management). My drink was not tropical, fruity or good. It was bitter and they must have been out of pineapple juice or it was old and sour because my drink had an odd aftertaste. 

Water for me the rest of the night .

On a positive note, everyone was having fun watching football and cheering for their teams.

New fast food place in Port Richey, I decided to give it a try on my way home from Atlanta. 

The drive through was quick, I placed my order and though it was later on a Sunday evening, the girl at the menu box was both professional and polite. I special ordered my burger with no condiments but pickles and knew if they got that right (most don't) it would be good. 

Once I paid, I was given a number to put on my mirror and pulled up just past the trashbin to wait.  The wait wasn't that long, and my food came out. Yes, it was right. The only reason they're not getting a 5 is that the fries were old and hard. Not really that tasty. But the burger was good.

I have to admit I am a HUGE fan of this spot,it may be small but it surely is a "Gem" located in South Philly. Myself, Vinny P. and Jim H. met up here to grab a few to many libations, share some laughs, and stories, with some bangin ass food. Yes I said "bangin ass" , because  kiddies this is the kinda joint you want to enjoy your night at. Besides the horrific parking situation you'd encounter this corner tap room is nothing short of amazing. 

A constant good vibe with bartenders who are very knowledgeable in the craft scene. We had the pleasure of dealing with Bill and he was on point with everything in which he was pretty solid with his recommendations . From the great crafts on tap that is in constant rotation, and the bottled selections even down to the nice liquor selections Taproom on 19th is on point. You'll surely find something to accommodate your thirst.  

Tap Room has some pretty good appetizers and bar snacks menu that you can look over. This is what we rocked out: 
Wings~ Korean Style ! Dude, I mean DUUUDE these wings had me licking my fingers to the point I was about to gnaw on them thinking I had another wing. A nice subtle kick to them with cashews and sesames sprinkled over top adding more flavor to it. Order it!

For my main course I went with their:
Better Burger Project~  Truly a  carnivores dream burger in which I added  bacon , well their "Insanity Garlic Bacon" to this work of art.  BRRUUHH, Uhh-Maze-ING! This is a  Lamb burger with fresh mozzarella from DiBruno Bros. Oh it gets better, they also went and concocted a cucumber and tomato salsa,  with a rosemary and mint aioli. This master piece was held together on an Italian potato roll that was made in Conshy. That is Conshohocken for those who don't know what "Conshy" means. I am telling you this thing, this beast I had cooked at a medium rare was juicy and flavorful. I along with my partner in crime were making moaning sounds with every bite. It escalated from a "PG" scene to an "R" rated moment while devouring this . Literally this is a must .. A MUST order if you're a burger fanatic like myself.

Great bar, great crew, plenty of TVs for the sporting fan, with an amazing menu. I'm sold,I know I'll be back even if the parking could be a bish.

What a fabulous find in New Orleans! We ate here on a Friday night during Memorial Day weekend. We chose to eat here because we could smell the amazing crawfish a block away. They also have an adorable balcony. We waited about 45 minutes for a balcony table but the timing was perfect because we got to see the fireworks at Jackson square and we had the best seat in the house. The hostess was sweet, the bartender was kinda friendly more like a fake friendly lol but whatever. Our server was a sweetheart she even cracked some jokes with us. The crawfish was amazing. I loved the way they seasoned it really spicy and flavorful. The oysters are great too! Swamp sampler was yummy the alligator was the best. I'd recommend this place. It wasn't amazing like omg but definitely not a bad choice!!!

Pretty impressed. The buffet was surprisingly good and a great value at $11. 

They had a nice assortment of dishes, perhaps 6 or 7 mains with a bunch of sides/apps and heaps of rice.  Everything I tried was fresh and flavorful. I sampled the chicken curry, paneer makhani, vegetable korma, and a super spicy okra, tomato and green pepper dish which was the best of the bunch. 

I was expecting mediocrity since it was a buffet, but everything turned out to be much better than expected. Dessert too was great. I typically never get dessert, but they had some fabulous milk cake and carrot cake which looked (and were) too good to pass up. I could eat those milk cake bars all day long. 

I look forward to checking out their regular menu rather than the buffet next time around. They had a really extensive selection with alot of my favorites. Four star Indian joint.

We came to Root after a zillion people raved about the scallops in the cigar box.  I easily made a res via OpenTable and we were quickly seated once we got to the restaurant.

We had two people helping us - a guy and a girl.  The guy asked what the occasion was since our guys had on jackets (no ties) and we had on dresses.  I told him, "Y'all are the occasion..."  Does no one dress up for dinner anymore?  Anyway, that kind of started the meal off on an odd foot.  That, and our waitress not showing up for about 20 minutes after we were seated.  Luckily, we had drinks to keep us company, but it seemed odd to wait so long when the restaurant wasn't full.

Our amuse bouche was a watermelon and cucumber soup (two things that make my throat itch).  I tasted it and it was fine; everyone else raved.  It was an unexpected delight.  

We ordered three of the sausages to start - the lamb, the mexican sausage, and the chorizo.  The chorizo and mexican sausage were delicious spicy and paired amazingly well with the pickled peaches.  I also liked the lamb sausage - it was much milder in comparison and delicious.

I had ordered the menage foie, but it got lost in translation and never came - which ended up being a good thing because I really got full off the appetizers.

For mains, I settled on the aloo gobi appetizer and they graciously prepared me some naan to go with it.  Hubs got the scallops, which were delightful (but weren't the best I've ever ever had...).  Another friend got the chicken and biscuits, which was an odd choice after we ate at Willie Mae's Scotch House that morning - it just didn't measure up, even though it was really good with that sauce.

Coffee was delicious, as was my lime ice cream that they brought me out.  Yummy.

Overall, I really liked Root and would recommend it - but I would recommend a few other places in NOLA first.  I think the tricky thing is that it didn't have that NOLA vibe to me - I felt like it could have easily been transplanted into Atlanta, and since I was in NOLA, I wanted the NOLA vibe... so if you're wanting to escape that, Root is a great option!

This place has been opened for nearly 2 years & I've never ate here. When they first opened, they brought food over to my work. I tried some of it then & wasn't too impressed. Everything tasted from a can. Not much flavor. Today I decided to try them again. 

I used the drive thru, it took no time at to order. I ordered the chicken quesadilla combo, & did waffle fries as my side. It came with a drink too, & was $5.79 before tax. I pulled up to the window & paid. It took about 45 seconds to get my food. It takes longer at Taco Bell. It was at 2:15pm so I was worried the food had been sitting under a heat lamp. 

I took the food back to work and tried it. I love a waffle fry. These look like they'd be somewhat Cajun & peppery. They are not. My fries tasted like they'd been sitting a little in a heat lamp. They were warm, but kind of dried out & very chewy. I put some ketchup & salt on them & it made them okay. 

Onto the chicken quesadilla. I don't know what it is about quesadillas, but I LOVE EM. Tortilla, cheese, sauce, & chicken, how can you not love it?! There chicken quesadilla wasn't as good as I've had before. The tortilla wrap used is kind of thick, this one I think too had been sitting out & it was hard on the edges. Inside, chicken, cheese, some kind of sauce & tomatoes. It was okay, but it needed more flavor. More flavor from the chicken, more flavor from the sauce, more flavor from the cheese. It was just bland. The whole meal was bland. I wouldn't mind waiting 5 minutes for the food to be prepared to order, as opposed to eating something that had been sitting around for a while.

It blows my mind that Seoul Garden has 4 stars on Yelp.

So, let's get the technical stuff out of the way first: most people come for the all-you-can-eat BBQ, which is really poorly explained by the menu and servers. Basically, $20/person gets you unlimited BBQ meat and there are 6 types: pork belly, spicy pork, beef brisket, bulgogi beef, beef sirloin, and bulgogi chicken. You order 2 of these at a time. Regardless of how many people you have in your party, the $20 all-you-can eat BBQ also comes with a choice of 2 soups, banchan (Korean appetizers), 2 bowls of steamed eggs, and rice.

I get that $20 is a pretty good deal for AYCE meat. The problem is that the meat is poor in quality - it has a mushy, too-soft texture. The spicy pork is especially terrifying; it actually took us awhile to realize it was pork and not chicken. You're safest going with the beef sirloin, which actually has the toothy feel of meat. That still doesn't fix the rampant over-seasoning, though - every dish (especially the bulgogi) was overpowered with salt/MSG and even after chugging liters of water I swear I was thirsty for the next 24 hours. Finally, I don't understand why 2 individuals get the same amount of appetizers as 6 - we had a party of 6 and each person was only able to get a nibble of kimchi. I suppose most people getting the AYCE aren't going for the appetizers to begin with, but that's all the more evidence for how unappealing the meat was - I found that the most tolerable items were actually the egg custard and rice.

But wait - the problems don't stop there! I don't think it would be an exaggeration to call service a catastrophe. Now, I know Asian restaurants are not known for their etiquette but there was no excuse for the absurdity we experienced. Our kimchi soup order was messed up (unfortunately for the non-pork eater in our party), we had to chase down a server for chopsticks/silverware, and even though the servers explicitly say they'll come back and take care of the BBQ-ing for you they remain mysteriously absent - I suggest you turn the meat yourself otherwise you will end up with burnt BBQ. But I'm saving the best (or worst?) for last: after paying and getting in our car, the owner of the restaurant ran outside, flagged us down as we were preparing to drive away, and insisted that we come back in and re-pay because he had screwed up the bill. Excuse me? Since when was the patron responsible for the business's mishaps?? And when is it ever appropriate to flag down customers who are driving away???

Here are the conclusions I drew after my experience at Seoul Garden: this restaurant does not understand the basic components of cooking, service, or fundamental human politeness. We got in our car and drove away without looking back.

So glad we tried 1200 Chophouse and thrilled we finally found a go-to steakhouse. Can't wait to be back! 

It's a super small beach bungalow of steakhouse.  They had a solid local craft beer and wine selection as well as full bar.  The menu was nice and small and certainly steak focused, all of which seemed to sport a nicely seared outer crust.  

We started with the bruschetta appetizer which was awesome. The bread was thinner than most bruschettas and probably the best part. The house salad and dressing was great and was nice size portion. Based on our steak preferences our server, Jeremy (who was fantastic!!) recommended a 2lb porterhouse for 2 where she'd have the filet side and i'd get the strip portion. This worked out perfectly and was just what we wanted. The steak was absolutely delicious, we looooved the crusty edge pieces and the medium rare cook was perfect. Our only complaint would pertain to the onion straws side. Being the end of the night and we clearly received what was left in the fryer basket. Essentially all over-crisped small pieces and crumbs. Pretty shotty attempt.

Wow! All the other Yelpers were correct that the non-fat custard here is Great!! It is not overly sweet and tastes fresh (not sure that's a word you describe custard), but comparing it to other places (like Rita's or McDonalds), you can tell the taste is not more generic.. ahh, I give up on trying to describe it, you just have to try it!! 

There were also many cars in the parking lot that I was able to grab one of the last remaining open "dedicated" parking spaces left. There were a lot of people sitting in their cars enjoying their ice cream. While there seems to always look like a lot of people in front, the lines move quick.

I got a SMALL twist cone with rainbow jimmies and it was just the perfect portion. I did not expect the Small to actually be so large, and I can't imagine how the Medium and Large sizes would be on the wafer cone or how they would stay up. One caveat with custard is that it will begin melting in seconds so you have to quickly eat it or it'll melt all over your hands! 

The prices are VERY reasonable with my twist cone being $2.75 (50 cents was for the jimmies) especially for the amount you get just for a Small! I look forward to trying their flurries or sundaes, it all looks so delicious! I'm glad it is open all year round, but also glad it is not right around the corner or otherwise I would be in big trouble.. but hey, it's non-fat right? 

As others have noted, Cash Only, which is okay by me.. gotta support your small businesses!

Located inside the gorgeous Renaissance Vinoy in downtown St. Petersburg, Marchand's Bar & Grill is a restaurant that has captivated my taste buds since my first visit almost two years ago. I have been longing to return, and had the opportunity this past week. I went with friends to taste their new Farm to Fork menu which showcases seasonal dishes made with the freshest produce, naturally raised meats and fish produced from local farms. 

We started off with a savory duo of Mangalitsa "Croque Madame" (with Georgia Red, Fried Quail Egg) and a Silk Onion Soup Shooter. Served on a butcher block, it was a delicious way to begin our six-course meal. Deriving from a "croque-monsieur" (grilled ham and cheese sandwich originating from French cafès) a "croque madame" is a croque-monsieur served with a poached or fried egg on top. "Mangalista" is a curly-hair hog descended directly from wild boar populations. Thus, our ham came from Pasture Prime Family Farm in Summerfield, Florida. This was my first time tasting Georgia Red Cheese which is a semi-soft cow's milk cheese with a creamy, earthy flavor. The Silk Onion Shooter (made with Florida sweet onions) was just divine. I simply could not get enough of the Croque Madame. The ham and cheese melted together in perfect harmony on the toasted brioche and as I bit into it, the yolk from the egg blended with the ham and cheese and yielded pure yumminess. This would make a fantastic brunch item.  With this, we enjoyed a glass of Acrobat Pinot Noir. 

Our second course was Golden Tilefish with Romanesco Cauliflower, Sunchoke Hush Puppies and Rock Shrimp Nage. I discovered tilefish when I first moved to Tampa while working at Bonefish Grill. Love at first bite, this fish won me over with its delicate texture and flavor similar to lobster. Our dish tonight was elegantly prepared with some items that were new to me, such as romanesco cauliflower (Worden Farm) which is a visually striking Italian vegetable. Almost a cross between broccoli and cauliflower, it yields a nuttier taste. Sunchoke was the other item I was unfamiliar with and it is also known as Jerusalem artichoke. Similar to a potato, it has a slightly sweeter taste and I really enjoyed it in the form of a hush puppy. Nestled underneath the tilefish were a few rockfish which were caught off the coast of Florida. This course was paired with Hahn SLH Estate Chardonnay.

Next up was Pork Cheek with Murcott Tangerine BBQ, Fried Mac & Cheese and Smoked Bacon Collard Greens. As of lately, I have been obsessed with Southern cooking and this was an excellent combination of some of my favorite flavors. The gorgeous pork cheek rested atop a glorious ball of fried mac & cheese and as I dug into the fried piece of heaven, the smoked bacon collar greens (Hunsader Farm) were snuggled underneath. The plate was drizzled with a tangy tangerine BBQ sauce and I enjoyed dipping a fork full of everything into the succulent sauce. This would end up being my favorite course of the night and it was paired with Trivento Amado Sur, a Malbec Blend. This wine was fantastic!

I was thoroughly impressed with everything so far and ready for the next course, which was Key West Yellow Tail Snapper atop a Chorizo Black Bean Cake with Warm Yellow Tomato Vinaigrette. This was a nice contrast of flavors, as I found the yellow tail to be mild and the chorizo black bean cake a tad spicy. The tomato vinaigrette beautifully blended the two flavors. This was served with the Trivento Amado Sur, Torrontes, which is a unique blend of Chardonnay and Viognier and perfect pair with seafood.

We had one course left before dessert which was Braised Rabbit (Seelys Ark), Savoy Cabbage and Gold Creamer Potato Puree with a Pinot Noir Reduction. While rabbit is often gamey, I found this to be mild and with a hint of sweetness. I LOVED the potato puree (Jones Potato Farm) and the savoy cabbage. Paired with Four Vines Old Vine Cuvee Zinfandel, this was a great way to end our tasting menu before dessert.

For the grand finale, we enjoyed a dessert trio of S'mores Hazelnut Ganache torte, Caramel Oatmeal Pie and Tiramisu. Since it was my birthday eve, they brought my dessert out with candles.  The trio was fantastic and it was paired with what would be my favorite wine of the night, Santa Margarita Brut Rose. Hands down, this was the best birthday dinner I have had in years. Service was impeccable and I had a fabulous time. I am anxious to go back and explore more of this gorgeous establishment.
Wowwwwwwwwww!  The bartender just hit me off with a fresh ginger beer which is PHENOMENAL!  Also had another "soda" which is delicious, along with chips and dip.  MY GOD!

Delicious po' boys here at Mother's.  I am particularly fond of the debris po' boy, but the Ferdi special (roast beef, ham, and debris) is great also.  Be prepared to roll up your sleeves and use a lot of napkins as the luscious juice makes a mess of you.

This is very casual dining - you're going to see a good mix of locals and tourists here.  Also, the food is just slapped down on your plate.  As Diane D. said - it's almost like a cafeteria of sorts. Don't worry,  you'll be so focused on your po' boy that you won't notice anything else after your first bite!

I ate here for lunch today.  We were the only people in the place and the decor made for a great first impression.  Sat in the bar area with an awesome view of a courtyard outside the restaurant.  Nice comfortable chairs, a fully stocked gorgeous bars with 2 large yet unobtrusive televisions.  The bartender was our waiter and he was great.  Brought extra ice for our iced teas, stopped by to check on us often but not enough to be annoying.

I had the special of the day, a 5 ounce "filet" with scallops and shrimp, my friend had the 10oz flatiron steak.  She loved hers, it was served with smashed potatoes and a corn salsa.  Mine was just ok.  I loved the sauces it came with and the vegetable of the day on the side, the green beans with roasted peppers and onions.  The steak, however, was a poor excuse for a filet.  It did NOT make me want to come and try their more expensive steaks for dinner, which was my original intention.  Overall though, for the price there are better options downtown including Mike Shannon's.

To top off our meal, when we went to pay we were told our "Dining out Downtown" gift cards weren't good.. "Sorry".  WTF.. that's why we came here!!  We'd already used part of one at another restaurant earlier in the week so the problem was not the card itself.  So instead of a $30 meal I was stuck with a $75 lunch tab.  Thanks a lot Shula's.  Good luck downtown .. I won't be back!

ETA: I did check with Dining out Downtown (DoD) and the problem was not with our card but with Shula's system.  I then called to let them know and the manager I spoke to had never even heard of the DoD program (uhhhh.. nice.. way to go training your people!) and took my name and number to "look into it".  Yeah, right.  Never heard back.  I made sure to fill out a comment form on their website and I sent an email to the director of the DoD program.  This is just ridiculous.

ETA2: After two phone calls and a complaint form filled out online, Shula's got back to me.  They offered to give me a refund if I'd give them my credit card number again over the phone (um.. no.. ).  Instead they pretty much insulted me by sending a $50 gift card.  Ok, so lunch there cost me $75 last time.. you want me to spend my time and money driving downtown.. to spend MORE money at your restaurant?  The managers here need some serious training on their customer service.  Before all this I might have been tempted to try them again to make sure I hadn't gone on an off day?  After this.. FORGET ABOUT IT!!!!

I only went there because I tend to follow people and Kris said it was good.  She has good taste!  I had the shrimp tacos on a corn tortilla. Excellent.   When I drove by one night and saw about 500 people there I said "I gotta check that place out"  The waitress asked "if there was anything else she could do for me..."

If we were in Mexico, absolutely!

But for right now the check will be all....

Now if anybody knows where to get REAL fish tacos please let me know.  The closest I can find is in a restaurant in san Antonio on the riverwalk.

This Panera brings great value to travelers using Nashville Airport. It's a mere three minute drive to the terminal and the only non-fast food, or greasy chain in the area where folks can grab something quick to bring with them on the plane rather than paying for poor-quality and overpriced items available in the terminal. While it might seem far fetched to some to come here with good service and better value it's a 10-minute side trip that's attractive to others. 

As with all Panera's it's clean, prices are fair and there's free wifi, too. It's a great place to come kill a bit of time before a flight if you have it. Also, consider there's no risk of traffic between this location and the airport. No time on the interstate is required. Consider this next time you're coming to the airport and need a quick bite or a sandwich to bring along for the air time.

If you are a bandwagon fan, don't come here.  Only seriously hardcore Pacers and Colts fans are allowed here.  How serious is this place? They will give you a two hour wait if you are NOT wearing home town gear.  Why?  Because you might get a beatdown.  Try to root for Miami or New England here.  The last thing you will remember is the fact that everyone next to you got up all of a sudden.  I swear one my "friends" almost got his tail kicked.  Luckily for him, he is a pretty good size.  If only they knew he was a pussycat.

The Pacers regularly hold events here, like viewing parties and draft parties, because the crowd is so loyal and boisterous.  It's good that we have hometown support so strong in my little neck of the woods.

We always have a great time when we go to The Empire Diner. Their staff are so great, remember what you like in great detail. Must mention that we always request to be seated with our favorite waiters....we.never request a female as the only bad experience we had here was with female wait staff. Our favorites....Edgar, Carlos, Tony, Lu.  Soup here is always delicious. They recently updated their menu and now includes color photos to boot!  My hubby loves their steak and egg breakfast.....on the new menu, now is $8.99 and an 8 oz steak. They have a senior menu that is certainly a deal and they easily and happily make substitutions for you. Great prices on good food are assured. Do check their daily specials that change weekly. They also have a hugely popular steak and shrimp special as well as a Prime Rob special.

Just visiting... Not okay that the staff can be exceptionally rude to its patrons. Your food does not make up for that, ok?!  

Sat down with my friends. Because there was plenty of seating... After about two minutes, a man comes up to us and says "I'm gonna need y'all to get up.".... Dufuq?! Ok so we did. We understood that we needed to order and then sit. But still, be polite... Lady at the counter was twice as rude. Smacking her gum, rolling her eyes. "What do you want"... 

So ok, my Gumbo was booooomb! But this service is trash. Wtf.

I used to love Boston Market when I was little. I have not been back in years. Their chicken has definitely gone down hill. But the staff here was really friendly. They were out of friend apples and had to make some extra and bring them to us. They were super hot when the arrive and I was not warned. It burned my mouth pretty good (BAD!!!) but I think I have recovered on my own and won't make an issue out of it. They brought all our food to us at our table. I do not remember that being the case when I came here back in the day. I also do not remember having plates, nor the cool cups they have for soda.

Everyone was pretty happy with their food. I did the quarter white meat, loaded mashed potatoes, and fried apples. Trying to save a bit a money before seeing a movie, my fiancee and I decided to share. That is what I would always get back in the day. Well actually I would get regular mashed with gravy, I think the loaded mashed are newer. They were pretty darn good. And besides being too hot, and a couple minutes behind the rest of my food, they were also good. The chicken, while not completely terrible, definitely tasted worse than I remember. I also think the coke was a little low on syrup. 

One of our friends got the chicken mashed potato bowl (or something like what they offer at KFC). She really liked it, but did not love it, and did not even finish it. She is very small and it was a big portion.

Our other friend get chicken noodle soup and a sandwich. That was also something new since the last time I had been to Boston Market. He was pretty happy with his.

Overall, this location is A-OK. They have friendly staff and a clean establishment. The chicken has gone down hill over the past few years, but for a quick cafeteria style corporate chain, Boston Market is just fine.

What a great place in Treasure island area for fresh ice cream, shakes and sundaes. They have 48 different flavors. The guy working there was great and let us try as many flavors as we wanted. The store is nice and clean as well. I had the Dulce de Leche which was delicious with just the right amount of caramel. My daughter had the red velvet cake which was also amazing and fresh. 
They advertise using the best locally sourced ingredients that Florida has to offer, and that's apparent when eating  the ice cream.

This was my first Shake Shack experience and it was great considering the current circumstances (COVID). I'm not a huge fan of burgers but I don't have a SS from where I'm from and I've heard great things about their shroom burger. 

Ordering & pickup was easy and safe! I wasn't sure what I expected the shroom burger to look like, but I was pleasantly surprised to see that it was fried and full of gooey cheese. It's meatless but certainly not a as healthy as I was expecting, lmfao! But it sure was delicious! Every single bite was amazing! The gooey cheese coming out of my burger was tasty and the crunchiness of the fried mushroom was phenomenal! My mom was so happy with her burger and she said it reminded her of homemade burgers from when she was growing up. Simple but full of flavor! Also, make sure you get some of the crinkled fries! You won't regret it!

I have to update my review and give Shake Shack another star for my last visit.  Don't worry about finding a table.  People seem to eat their food and don't linger over the table for conversation.  

We both ordered double hamburgers because the last time they were very thin and not very filling.  This time they seemed as if they were a little bigger.  We also ordered the cheese fries with extra cheese.  This time it wasn't necessary to order the extra cheese (although I'm glad I did) because the fries had much more cheese on them than the last time.  The double hamburger was very filling and the cheese fries were great.

Would I come back here?  Yes, and the next time I'm going to get a shake to go with my meal.  And that's the way it is.

The wife and I had dinner there simply because we wanted to get out of rut and try some new places, not just our usual favs. The service was very attentive. The charbroiled oysters were outstanding. I got crab au gratin and there was a very generous portion of crab. However, overall the dish lacked flavor and it was simply too rich. I left about 1/3 because the consistency got to be too much. The wife got an appetizer size portion of the BBQ shrimp. They were ok, but the sauce was simply spicy and not complex. Overall, it was a perfectly adequate experience. The prices are reasonable. Just nothing outstanding or so special to make us want to return.

We came to Ocean Harbor for dim sum on July 4th. Being Chinatown, this place was open and quite packed (perhaps because other spots were closed - our first choice wasn't available). Despite having a lot of people waiting and a large party (seven), we probably didn't wait more than 15 minutes before getting a full table to ourselves. The decor is what you would expect of a dim sum spot in Chinatown - crowded, not a lot of space, loud - but you really aren't here for anything besides getting the food. With the typical shuttling around of carts carrying different items, it wasn't too long of a wait between passes to grab food for ourselves.

That said, if you are looking for dim sum that goes above and beyond, this isn't going to be the spot. The food is solidly average, with the shu mai and the lotus rice being the bites I enjoyed the most - but they were pretty standard. The general lack of dumplings were disappointing, and some options were a bit puzzling (there were only vegetarian egg rolls on the cart, for example). The beef was flavored alright but overcooked, and the pastry with gelatinous rice flour on the outside and a crisped pastry on the inside was passable. As per the usual, you get served tea and would need to ask for water separately.

I wouldn't say that the food here was bad - completely edible and fine - but it doesn't stand out, and there's nothing to distinguish it from the many other dim sum restaurants that look, feel, smell and sound exactly like this one. If you absolutely need a dim sum spot, this will do, but there are a lot of other options in Chinatown as well (such as Dim Sum Garden across the street) that might be more appetizing.

I had a couple hours to kill before flying to Glasgow so I was happily surprised to see a Legal Seafoods at PHL! 

Line looked long but moved quickly. I was able to score a seat at the bar within minutes and order their classic crab cake sandwich that comes with a boatload of fries and a little scoop of coleslaw ($16.95).  Crab cake was all delicious lump crab, none of the filler, served on a buttered bun. Coleslaw had more mayonnaise than I cared for but also had the touch of sweetness that I enjoy.

No time for a sit down meal? No worries. You can place a carry out order.

Awesome place to get a bowl of noodles for around 6 or 7 bucks. The food comes out extremely fast too. My only complaint about this place is that the waitress was nowhere to be seen when I wanted a glass of water, but other than that, the noodles were delicious.

My wife and I were in the area wandering around and picked up a hotdog bun and mixed fruit bun to munch on while walking. The price for both was $2, and they were good. The mixed fruit was mostly raisins (I am not sure what the other fruit was, as I didn't taste any) and the hotdog was not very salty. However, both were worth the price paid. The guy working was friendly and they had a nice selection of things including some I hadn't seen before.

A pretty average Chinese restaurant with dozens of standard menu items to choose from. 
Several lunch specials offer a good value: an entree and side with fried rice for under $6.50. 
Beef and broccoli were satisfactory with generous meat mixed in with the veggies and rice. Chicken fried rice and crab Rangoon were included. The Rangoon were wonderfully light pastries stuffed with cream filling and served hot.
Accommodating staff: They worked with us on a special request. 
Clean, bright dining room.

It's the airport - and it's a bar & grille. :)

Yes, overpriced due to its physical location, but they served Coppertail Free Dive on tap so I was sold.  Great local brewery in Tampa.

Short and sweet menu that includes fish options (they looked delicious) to your standard burger.

3 stars for price - would've been 4 if value was there.

Came here after the Pretty Lights concert last weekend, everyone was a little buzzed and starving at 12:30am. I was not in the mood for Felipes or any fast food options so it was pretty incredible that this place is open for late night eats.  
 
We ordered several things but I only remember these dishes and they were delish! 
Grilled Compressed Watermelon Salad
"KFC" Korean Fried Chicken Wings
Chicharrones "2 Ways"

I will definitely return to dine here sober so I can better assess the food, but the sheer fact that they're open until 2 makes it a 5-star joint for me!

When you think of a "diamond in the rough" or "special spot" what do you think of? Me, I think of a place like this. It's quaint, classy and so much FUN! They even have alcoholic alternatives for the adult in us all!

I sat outside on a beautiful day, ate my alcohol infused ice cream and had a bottle of root beer soda. It was simply the best. People watching in the area is top notch and there were so many cute dogs to watch!

I say try it. It's a perfect first date touch down, breezy day treat, or...just because!

Thanks to the owner, she was totally sweet and wonderfully quirky, like me!!

Happy eating!

There was a line getting into Acme Oyster House like it was a club. The hostess was super nice and pleasant. She made the wait easier.

So, Acme Oyster House has a 15 dozen raw oyster challenge and initially, I got sick of the thought of 15 dozen oysters.. It's too many, I thought. And after I went, I got tough like I coulda woulda shoulda. I wished I had tried. If you don't finish it in the allotted time, you pay. If you do, you get your name on the wall and that 15 dozen is free.

If the challenge interests you at all--- DO IT!

Now in the restaurant, there's table seating or the oyster bar.. With a long line outside, you get what's available and we got a table. Our server pointed out a few things on the menu and that they're famous for their Chargrilled Oysters. Yeah, the Chargrilled Oysters are sooooo fantastic. Boo Fries and Bread Pudding with Ice Cream are also recommendable..

Worth the wait.

Mr wizards is a great yogurt/custard shop in my neighborhood.  Service is through a window like at Ted Drew's and there are tables out front to use.  Parking can be limited but there is usually something around. 

I like their concretes and snow cones. All their specialty concretes I've had from them have been stellar.  I don't think one can go wrong with any of them.  They offer their custard in chocolate and vanilla. 

Mr wizards usually sells Christmas trees during the winter holiday season.

It's snowing outside I know. BUT it's March! It should be spring! and that's why I decided to treat myself with a Yogorino so that I could pretend it's spring, even though I was freezing. 

I always get the mini yogurt (a plain tart yogurt) with the pistachio syrup (to die for!), but today I decided to try something new and got the milk chocolate topping that hardens (like a turtle shell) on the yogurt. It was tasty, but I think I still like the pistachio best!

If you come on Tuesdays, its double stamp day. 8 stamps = 1 small yogorino with 2 toppings! (Usually only comes with 1, each additional topping is 50 cents more).

This location also offers gelato. I've also been to the Yogorino on 20th street, and think the two are pretty comparable.

This place was highly rated by other yelpers so I figured I'd give it a shot.  A 40 minute foot reflexology massage was 50 bucks which I think was fairly priced.  My wife and I were the only ones in the place so the service was great.  If you want a massage that is better for you in the long run but not that enjoyable while it's happening, come here.  They definitely get in there and break down the scar tissue in your feet so the long term benefits outweigh the 40 minutes of mild pain while you are sitting there.

Oh, small town coffee houses, how you tug at my heartstrings. As much as I adore Starbucks, sometimes I just want to kick back on a Sunday morning in a place where no one knows me or my order...especially when they offer me a free piece of Bissinger's chocolate with my order. Sold.

I met up with a friend here several days ago and while waiting for her to arrive, I was offered a free sample of their homemade beignets. Whoa. Beignets this far north? How gourmet! They were utterly delightful.

I ordered a doppio con panna and curled up on their couch with a copy of Sauce magazine and waited patiently for my order. As it was handed to me, the owner offered me my free piece of chocolate. Feeling a little frisky, I decided on their olive oil truffle and was not let down. Amazingly creamy and garnished with sea salt, it was the perfect pairing for my doppio. 

I loved the ambiance of this new cafe and am eager to return to try their savory food offerings.

This buffet is pretty good. A friend of mine invited me to join her for brunch. So I did and we smashed away.

It's definitely a very nice buffet. There's all sorts of different things you can get, but I did the omelette station which was very good. Then I went into the lunch items. The brisket was really nice and tender. I can taste smoke as well, so it's definitely a plus whenever my taste buds become aroused like that.

The service was very good too. Our drinks were refilled and our plates were cleared when it needed to be. I would totally eat here again if given the chance.

Thank you so much for reading my review. I hope this helps with your decision making experience. Enjoy your awesome yelptastic day!!

Ocean Harbor has the best dim sum in Philly's Chinatown.  Don't be alarmed by the massive amount of people waiting on the steps when you walk in, the line usually moves pretty fast. 
They have all the popular items like the steamed shrimp dumplings called "Har-Gau" in Cantonese, pork/veggie/shrimp wrapped in wonton shells- "Siew Mai", pork ribs in blackbean sauce-"Pie-Gawt", fried turnip cake-"Lo-Bah-Gong" and the beef in a long white noodle called "Nu-Tsong". Ok, ok I mixed up canto with mandarin plus my "pinyin" needs a lot of help but if you sound it out, you'll be on the right track! If you're not chinese and make an effort to pronounce these items your effort would be appreciated and applauded (if not, I applaud you in spirit)! They even have some entrees from the menu that they portion out and serve as dim sum. It's a good way to get a flavor of the restaurant food after dimsum hours.  What I like most about their dim sum is that I find it less oily (is that possible?) than most of the neighboring restaurants.  Another thing people forget is that the tea is such a great compliment to the food during Dimsum! I usually go for a red tea called "Bo-Lay" and my dining companion enjoys Chrysanthemum (I think he just enjoys saying it), this tea usually comes with sugar cubes/rocks. 
Service here can be sub-par when you're in a party of two because most of the tables for 2 are hidden in corners or behind other tables so the chance of a cart of yummy foodies coming by is none. Dimsum is most enjoyable in a group, anyway. So why not grab your friends, head down to Ocean Harbor and show off some of the Chinese you just learned? (I promise none of those dishes are wacky.)

I have tried several things on the menu and by far my favorite is the Crispy Sesame Beef.  I love consistency.  Every time I order something, it tastes exactly as I remembered it. 

It is conveniently located in a strip mall near Majestic Movie Theatre on Overland between Eagle and Locust Grove.  I am always in the area and like to stop for a quick lunch.  Service is always excellent.  I love their Hot and Sour soup that comes with their lunch special.  I haven't tried their sushi yet but I have tried more than a half a dozen items on their menu and I enjoyed them all.

We ordered the Indian Red Lopez to start which includes spicy crab, cilantro, salsa roja with a side of chips. It was perfectly balanced and yummy. Definitely a must order. 
We ordered the mahi mahi and steak tacos. Out of the two the steak tacos were made well and very tender. The mahi mahi tacos fell short for flavor and quantity.

I finally got around to trying MEAT over the weekend. The place certainly lives up to its name as the menu features a variety of meat from brisket to chicken to ribs, and even fried chicken and sausage. I went for the brisket sandwich. The fresh baguette was piled high with pulled brisket which was smoked to perfection. It was literally melting in my mouth. However, I did not particularly care for the horseradish dressing and would have much preferred one of the four barbecue sauces made in-house. The sandwich came with a side of garlic fries, and next time I would definitely ask for them plain. They are VERY strong. Or, I would try one of the many other sides such as beans, coleslaw, or yam mash. I love the rustic wood that dominates the decor and there is a nice bar area (where I sat). I even tried bourbon for the first time. The bartender was very helpful in my choice and I found that bourbon goes very well with brisket. I will definitely return, but I think next time I will go for one of the orders of meat with a side, rather than a sandwich.

On a soft food diet and was out shopping on my lunch break so decided to stop here and order the veggie platter w/mashed potatoes, Mac & cheese and creamed spinach.  Boston has gotten expensive when I looked at the receipt and saw that I paid over $11 for 3 veggies!  The Mac & cheese was the only veggie that I didn't really like, it had an odd taste but the mashed potatoes and spinach were really good and hit the spot.

WOW! Love this hidden jewel! Although at first, you'll get confused of the location, but it's located in the back of the bar. So walk through the bar (must be 21+) into the back and it's a little space with about 4 tables. The menu is located on to your right on the wall a few feet away from the ordering area. 

Although was sister was slightly under the permitted age, however, the bartender said it was alright as long she was at least 18 to enter. I believe it's because there's a little tiny gaming machine so they didn't want anyone under the age to play and also the nature of the bar, but it's okay for her to be eating in the back. 

We ordered two items: Firecracker Cauliflower and the Fried Catfish. Both sandwiches were absolutely phenomenal! The cauliflower had a nice tasty combo of mayo, sriracha, jalapeños, melted cheese and vinegar slaw! The catfish was crispy and seasoned well with a great combo of sriracha slaw, mayo, pickled peppers and cilantro. Love the different flavors and something very unique that you don't normally taste in a daily basis. 

Highly recommend this place to friends, families and also other visitors :)

"OMG... Ok, before you get too comfortable, you HAVE to go to the washroom."

*raised eyebrow*

"No, seriously. Go now. And you're not going to want to come out for a looooonnnng time."

The meal hadn't even started... and already I need the bathroom? Well that's not a good start to the visit. At least, not until I got to the washroom and figured out what Jennie M was talking about.  

HEATED TOILET SEAT!! I really didn't want to leave.

Izakaya Tomo is Alberta's only Izakaya. Some sushi joints have it in their name, but they don't count. I've never been to an Izakaya, I'm told that back in Japan they generally have more bar seating. Izakaya Tomo comes with a small bar and more tables and benches. But the space is cool, there's plenty of sake, shochu, beer, cocktails and wine to choose from and the food raw-ks my yelpy socks off!

We let those who had been to Japan and knew what the food was order for us. Here's what showed up at the table:
Daikon salad (a type of radish)
Kinpira (burdock root and carrot stir fried up together)
Deep fried tofu
Aburi saba (sashimi)
Simmered pork belly
Chicken Nanban (think sweet and sour)
Beef tataki
Oyster ponzu (deep fried)
Tuna tataki
Tonpei Yaki (pork and cabbage fried under an egg... if you order nothing else, get this one! It was my fave.)

Order a lot. Share it amongst yourselves. Wait... it gets better. It's also not that expensive. Could this get any better? I dunno... but I'm going back the next time I'm up in E-town!

Visited this location while on a recent weekend get-away to Tucson and I felt like I was right back home in California.

Really, I think Safeway (and their sister child Vons here in SoCal) are taking the Lifestyle concept stores too far. They must have had a big gigantic sale on earth brown paint to cover the ceilings.

Is every Safeway/Vons going to look like this in the future?

Service was decent, not overly friendly. Store was well-stocked and clean with convenient parking.

Overall, a solid 4 * performer "serving Tucson since 1950" according to the wall over the exit.

This was our second visit to Party Fowl and yes, I am a fan.  We stopped by about 9:30 on a Friday night and were seated right away.  The restaurant was still hopping with people, which is always a good sign.

There were four of us and we all tried something different.  Our table got the Hot Chicken and Cheddar sandwich, the Hot Chicken B&B, and the Hot Chicken entrée.  I got the Beer Butt Chicken--even though I could not eat a quarter of it, I got the whole chicken because that was the best presentation.

All of our food was outstanding.  My Beer Butt Chicken was so delicious--smoked chicken but still moist.  I got a side of collard greens and they were amazing as well.  

For those at the table who got the anything that said "hot chicken" on the menu, our waitress warned us that if you like "Hot" chicken wings, you should order mild.  We went with medium.  It was definitely hot.  One person at the table said that while the medium was good, he would go mild next time so he could really enjoy the chicken.

The beignets that were served with the Hot Chicken B&B were really good too.  The sweetness of the beignets mixed with the salty, spicy chicken were really good.

Party Fowl also has a good craft beer selection.

I will definitely be back!

Well I knew nothing about anything related to CBD products. On a hot day while vising I walked past it & then decided to go in to check it out & get a break from the heat. Well let me just say I am glad I did. The person working there, Gary was super helpful. I mean the place was wall to wall products & I was clueless. He took the time to explain things & all the different products they had. People would come in & know what's up so it would be easy & quick for Gary to help them while I was looking at the products they had. I may have been overwhelmed by all these things in the store,  but once I was able to go through what they all did & how they worked it gave me a better understanding. I basically had Gary go from one side of the store to the other to give me a better idea of what the products were for. It helped me so much so I could determine what I would end up buying. Since I was traveling it was easy enough since so many things come in small packages. I probably spent way too much money but got a few things for a friend & think it was worth it. So yeah come here & ask for Gary to help you so you can get the lowdown.

So, I ended up going to Five Guys on Saturday May 11th for lunch since I was in the area. Before, I went to Five Guys on Saturday I haven't been there in a very long time. I ended up ordering a single cheeseburger with cheese and ketchup only. Along, with a delicious oreo shake with extra, extra, extra, and extra Oreos. Luckily, there wasn't no charge for the extra Oreos, and the person that fixed my shake did a marvelous job on how I actually want it. In, case you didn't realize I LOVE Oreos a lot. The burger was good, fulfilling,  and I was glad I bought a single instead of the double I would normally buy. Also, during my time there it was very calm, and it wasn't busy.

Went to the Bao with my Daughter and her roommates a d I have to say that I am thrilled with the Bao.  The food was outstanding.  We started either pizza gyoza.  Looked like a pizza but instead of cheese cabbage on top with a delicious sweet and spicy sauce.  Let's just say it didn't last long.  Then came the crispy fries which preceded the main event the Bao.  I got the spicy lobster Bao which was so light and refreshing.  It was like a lobster roll on a Bao.  Loved it!  Then I had the Wagyu beef Bao which was surprisingly like a cheeseburger slider Bao.  It was good but not what I expected.  Then I had the Char Sui BBQ pork Bao which was fantastic and so delicate.  My Daughter tried the shrimp Bao which she devoured.  Her roomies also tried the fried chicken Bao which was enormous.  Great place with cool ambiance.  They dimmed the lights and it was cool.  I'd come back here again often if I lived here.  Service was excellent and friendly.  I highly recommend and look forward to returning to visit again.

This is probably my family's favorite Korean restaurant in St Louis, and we've been going here for years. When we arrived I was pretty surprised at how full it was. The past few times my family came the restaurant was basically empty besides us and maybe 1 or 2 other parties. I might be imagining it but I think they might have recently gone under some renovations, which might contribute to the reinvigorated clientele.

With a party of five, we were able to successfully destroy 2 orders of appetizers along with each individual entree. For the appetizers we got the Haemul Pajeon and Goon Mandu. They're both really good, especially cause I think they make it better than my mom's. (Shhh... Don't tell her I said that.) This time around I got the Pork Bulgogi, which was also pretty good. Best thing about this place is that they give you tons of banchan (side dishes). I was smart and sat in the middle, so everything was within grasp.

I'm really glad that the restaurant is doing better than before, but I will say that the service has gone downhill as a result. I'm pretty sure they forgot about one of our appetizers because we had to ask about it 10 minutes after the first one was served. They also forgot about my order because everyone else was served and I was left to picking at the banchan for at least 20 minutes. I didn't even take a picture of my food cause I immediately dug in once it got to me. With all this going on, it didn't help that the huge TV we were seated next to was showing a Korean food show. Needless to say I was drooling and hangry af. Still a great place to checkout if you're looking to fulfill your Korean food cravings.

This is one of those heavenly places where you are hungry, craving something unhealthy, yet want to support local places instead of those fast food chains.

GATHERING PLACE
It may not be the shiniest building around, but after passing this outdoor-only building and always seeing a mini line, I knew I had stumbled onto a community establishment. There's always families and couples eating at the surrounding picnic tables. Sometimes I'm worried because of all the very young faces serving--but the adults are cooking in the background and the young staff has always been friendly.

COMFORT FOOD
The Chili Bacon Cheeseburger was fatty and gooey and looked visually unappealing but dang that bacon taste was strong. Aw--for that price there was no Fries? The much advertised Beignets were very soft and light inside, but the outside was too chewy as if it had been left out after frying. Since my teeth had to tear through, the entire thing deflated once I took a bite. There's LOTS of ice cream related goods and the workers are happy to mix together items not on the menu. My Espresso Chocolate Milkshake came in a very plain Styrofoam cup, but tasted creamy, thick and mildly chunky. It's not soft serve icy quality, but not insanely fatty either. Just right.

I'LL BE BACK
I'll admit, the burgers and desserts are not gourmet, top-notch, best-in-the-world... but I'm still going to return many times. They don't have many great combos (prepare to buy all the good stuff individually).

Definitely a tasty treat, so many interesting (and healthy) toppings.  Only problem is that there is only one flavor - vanilla, but its still quite good.  The set up is also rather disorganized, although thats mostly due to customers wanting to try every type of topping beforehand, making those who do know what they want quite confused on how to order without being rude.  
However, its a great addition to the area, and a great price to boot!

I have been here twice, though I've been slacking and its been a few weeks since my last visit. 

I gave 3 stars for the same reasons I read about after coming my first time. I came with 3 other people, of which two got the fajita's and the other two, fish tacos or something like that. The main complaint was that everything was bland. The rice was like boiled white rice and that was it. And the fish wasn't very memorable. Also the margariita's seemed weak as well.

As for the fajita's though, there was a ton and the flavors I enjoyed. I know that this is the only dish I will order when I go there. 

The second time I went, I stuck with the fajitas and again I was pleased. As a personal preference I need to remember to ask for softer peppers and onions. 

I wont not go here, as it is a relatively nice mexican food place that is not too far from home. The drink specials if I remember right were of good value and they also have a coupon in the Neighborhood News thing in the mail.

Fine dining experience here is amazing.  From reservation, seating arrangements, ambience is wonderful, Menu selections, exceptional service and amazing flavorful entrees........this is  worth our time & effort for the amount of money spent.  We are coming back for sure.

Today we tried the Seared Salmon, Rack of Lamb, Lobster with asparagus special, and Ribeye steak with onion rings, lobster bisque, and the tart pear with caramelized nut ice cream.  Every bite is very yummy.  Must try the Martinis.  We tried their Martini with Vodka and Lemon drop Martinis.  It went really well with our entrees.  Can't wait to try the pomegranate flavor next time.

Definitely a complete satisfaction and I highly recommend it. See my pictures.

"Wishboners." That's what I was hoping to see when I crossed Penn's campus and the Wishbone sign came into view. Two hastily postscripted letters from a couple of enterprising college students knocked up on Natty Lights and youthful vigor, that's all it would've taken to achieve comedy gold. But no, you goody do-rights passed on sticking it to the man and probably stuck your nose in a book. Nerds.

So the undefaced (...faced?) signage didn't satisfy my sophomoric demands, but Wishbone mostly did. Chicken fingers are boilerplate material for kid's menus and that makes it easy to dismiss them as child's play now that we're super serious Yelpers. You shouldn't.

Maybe the exclusive benefit chicken tenders hold over their classically fried brothers is the meat to breading ratio. Federal Donuts is great, for example, but there are some bites where I'm only scarfing down a naked chicken bite so I can get to breaded crunch. There's a reason no one tells you about the grilled chicken place you have to check out. 

The buttermilk batter and pretzel crust here demonstrate why. Tenders ($9/lb) come in white and dark. There's a healthy amount of fat and gristle in the dark meat so it's best those strips go stag without any condiments. But when you dress up the white, the pommery honey mustard is the cock of the walk. It's thick, and full of deep honey flavor. Interneting tells me this is typical of French honey mustards, in which honey is not simply a sweetener but the source of distinctive flavor. Bet you weren't expecting a French cuisine lesson amidst a chicken tender review, huh?

But a return visit will be due mostly to the mascarpone-cheddar mac & cheese. It was creamy and rich, which isn't difficult to pull off, but it also blended in a sharp edge that made it interesting. Bacon and herbs punched it up from good to great.
 
I'll be back, and with an "r" and "s" in tow.

This was the best game in town for me tonight. A short layover at the dreaded "airport hotel!"
I decided to order to go so I could ferry my fare back to my room and dine in comfort..
I hadn't enjoyed a Po Boy in a few years so I splurged for a fully dressed shrimp Po Boy sandwich with a side of fries.
The host was very friendly and took my order promptly. In only a few minutes my much anticipated Po Boy arrived in a handy clear plastic container that was steamed inside from the heat of my gastronomical treat! I hurriedly paid for my "airport hotel dinner" and tipped the host. 
Quickly returning to my room, settled in and opened my clear plastic container to expose the object of my desire. There it was, atop a bed of French fries, my shrimp Po Boy mocked me! Daring me to summon the courage to add the spicy Cajun mustard and take a bite!
I cased my Po Boy with desiring eyes before lifting one edge of the famously "baked just right" French bread and lavished it with the Cajun delight. I then with nervous hands carefully lifted my Po Boy and took a small sample bite. It did not disappoint! Being careful to avoid biting my fingers, I took a larger bite, which was filled with shrimp, tomato, and lettuce with the tasty Cajun mustard providing the balance to bread, shrimp, and fries!
My sandwich was large and satisfying, the fries more than I could dream of finishing. This "airport hotel restaurant" adventure was one that I'd recommend. The only reason for not rating the experience a 4 was because the server that brought my meal to me seems to have been trying to perform a quick drive by drop off to avoid any interaction with me. Maybe it was because I was salivating? Perhaps the old Pavlovian response applies to people too!

If you're ever there, go ahead, order the Po Boy!!
I'm just saying..,

We sat at the bar and the service was great.  The big negative is every appetizer arrived room temperature. Ugh. Obviously it all was sitting back in the kitchen and no one brought anything out to us until the entree was ready, I guess?

Terribly disappointed

Everything did taste good tho and I'm sure it would be amazing if it arrived hot 

Bbq shrimp
Grilled oysters
Seafood gumbo
Bacon wrapped scallops

Ahi tuna entree

Why my family loves this place: 

My grandma is hard of hearing and there's an amazing back room where our whole, large family can meet for a peaceful, Christmas meal together. It's large, so people can move around/switch seats to talk and the babies can run around without disturbing anyone. The lighting is dim and peaceful, and the service is always attentive.

You can choose menu options for everyone ahead of time (which is what my grandma always does) and then we pick between those. My favorites include the filet, salmon, mashed potatoes, chopped salad, and apple crisp.

I've been to Koreana a handful of times over the years. I used to love the Koreana wings but after my most recent visit, I can't help but to think that the chicken has dropped in quality. The flavor is still on point; however, there was more gristle and overall poorer quality meat than I previously remember. I'll note that I haven't ever tried anything else on the menu. For that reason, I'd be willing to give Koreana another shot but next time I'll be sure to order something other than the wings.

Came by with fellow yelpers and tried a plethora of dishes. Chicken wings in what appeared to be a salt pepper type garnish, fish maw soup, dungeness crab, snow pea leaves, seafood chow fun, sizzling ribeye and other items I am failing to remember.

The service was very prompt and the lady explained the dishes to us and was able to recommend us items that were more authentic than others.

Overall a great experience. Good chinese option relatively close to us.

Reminds me of Whole foods in the US.  It's a good place for any form of a healthy option one might be looking for.  Organic fresh food is available for purchase.  A small, but decent collection of cheese, fresh cream cheese, hummus and other such dips dress the counters in the food section.  The hummus is by far the best I've had in Edmonton!  They have a good collection of organic coffees from around the world, if it interests one.  The frozeon and preserved foods available are also quite tasty and healthy (lower in sodium content) compared to other store bought preserved foods.  From a variety of fresh produce, tasty and healthy cereals, nuts and grains, teas from all over the world, to protein shakes and much more, the store is complete for all your shopping needs.  It's well located for families with young ones or in the family way.  There's an expecting mother's clothing store right next door and a children's bookstore close by.  

They also have baking/cooking classes.  You can sign up online for their newsletter with updates coming in your inbox on weekly activites, discount coupons and more.
