The only downside - I don't think it has warmed up to the average Edmontonian yet.  Of course, if you have a family of four and you'd exclusively come here for groceries, it could be too expensive. Hope they get more busy in the years to come - might drive down the costs!

Every time I go to Clearwater or St Pete Beach I stop in Freaky Tiki to take a look at their new t-shirts. I particularly like that the designs are made locally. The drawings that are classic and show the young mermaid are my favorite t-shirts. And I also like the men's shirt with the old diver and tentacles drawing. I like the fabrics because they are so soft and last and don't stretch or shrink so that makes me want to get another shirt every time.

Food here is great- this used to be the place of that Israeli restaurant that always looked dingy and shady. 

The food Is here is amazing- I got the chicken sharwarma and it was plentiful and juicy. The shakshuka is AMAZING. I wish I got 2 orders of that. If you plan to get dessert- get the kanafa but I would say no syrup- They overdid it with the sweetness. 

Also, it's a 15-20 min wait for the dessert so order in advance

I've been here a few times for lunch, and every time I go, I've been impressed with the staff. They are the happiest bunch of employees I've ever seen at a Cosi, and they alone make it worth coming in for food. I got my salad in record time and chatted with my cashier about how hot it was. When I grabbed the salad, the man behind the counter gave me the biggest smile.

My only complaint is that the egg in my Cosi Club salad looked perfect, but something about it was off--almost sour. Otherwise, the salad was as good as any I've ever had from Cosi. Will definitely come back for lunch another day.

Great dog park but even better people. I've not meet too many poorly behaved dogs, or if there is an anxious one then the owners are usually attentive and accountable.

The pet owners here are amazing. I often see them sweeping the side walks and leveling any loose gravel. 

Generally no more than 10 dogs so it's usually a small to medium crowd.  They also provide tennis balls, poop scoopers and poop bags. Separate play areas for small vs large dogs.

I'll have to try it again during the off season, but my first visit here was just so so on nearly every aspect, albeit during the height of tourist season, so perhaps that explains some of the issues.

Where this place really stands out is the huge amount of dockage for boats.  Locals love to come by boat, so if you're visiting during the day, there may be a lot of boat traffic which can be fun to watch.

My experience was that service was simply mediocre, both at the bar and once our party of six was seated.  Not to knock teenagers, but a lot of the wait staff seemed to be very young, so probably extra bodies they picked up for tourist season who are not that experienced with the job yet.  Getting our initial waters took a while, refills were slow to come, food didn't come out at the same time, etc.

Drinks were mostly tourist focused; all the typical frozen ones, souvenir cups, etc.  Liquor drinks were not particularly strong or cheap.  Beer selection seems to be the average selection that the local beer distributor thinks every restaurant should have.

Food-wise, the house salad nothing to write home about.  The Jalapeno Snapper is fairly tasty, but don't expect it to be spicy.  You can taste the jalapeno but I was a little let down in the end; I was expecting more 'kick'.  The scallops were quite good, but, you can get the exact same quality and size for half the price down on St Pete Beach at Willys Burgers & Booze, albeit, not with a waterfront view.  

Overall, The Pub just isn't anything to write home about, literally if you're a tourist.  If you're a boater, it's perfect, otherwise, there's better options.

My parents brought me a kids bean and cheese burrito from this restaurant one afternoon when I wasn't feeling well. I'm telling you... I don't know what was so magical about this burrito but it was one of the most delicious things I have ever eaten. The tortilla was so good and the balance of bean and cheese was spot on. It was sheer perfection. My dad's burrito was also very good, as was my mother's nachos. I can't speak to the service or the cleanliness of the establishment. It's the taste of the food that matters anyway and this place does it up right. Totally recommend.

Publix is the best supermarket ever! I love the smell of it. I love the setup. I love the workers. 

This Publix is always clean and organized. I cannot remember a time when I have gone in and noticed something out of place. I swear they must have elves running around straightening items on shelves all the time. It is so easy to go in for an item and I know I will find it right where it should be. 

What I really really love about Publix in general are their sandwiches! That's right. They have an awesome deli area where they will make you your own personal sandwich! This particular visit that is the main reason I went; for a Publix turkey sandwich. I began by selecting my bread, meat, and cheese. Then, since I was splitting the sandwich with my sister I asked if they would make half with the toppings for me and half with the toppings for my sister; and she did! Perfection. 

I got just what I was looking for and it tasted great! Thank you Publix. I heart you.

When someone says "Hey, do you want five guys?" 
They are basically asking me "Do you want a stomach ache and a possible side of diarrhea?" 

Sorry, but lets keep it real.

It's not that I don't like five guys, its just that every time I come here and order something its dripping in grease. Don't get me wrong, the food is good but every time I have ate here.... its followed by stomach pains and possible... well, you know this part.

I like that the toppings are free. I like that the food is made to order. I like that the staff is friendly but I have to rate this place 2 stars because both times I've came here my food was super greasy, hands were covered in grease (enough to make KFC jealous), burger wrapper was soaked in greased and of course, the stomach-to-grease issue.

My second time here to the Starbucks location not much to say about this location it has the same like other Starbuck locations such as  WIFI, Coffee, cups, indoor/outdoor seating with umbrellas.  The service is great when not busy and when in busy expect wait times in the drive thru in mid afternoon time due to being next to the shopping centers, mall and restaurants.  Never had any type of my order when ordering for myself or a family member.

I've only experienced this Hard Rock location through the eyes of a corporate event.  I have been a guest a several events in their private room upstairs and I have to admit, it's the best private event experience in the Broadway/stereotypical-Nashville area.

The space has exposed brick, a private stage and an amazing outdoor deck overlooking Titans Stadium, Broadway and SoBro.  The food for catering is really strong and filling.  I love the spicy shrimp and Thai beef skewers.  If you're a party/corporate planner, make this location your top choice for your company outing!

We had a great lunch with a Groupon.  The flavors and presentations were nice.  The portions were generous, and the scallops were perfectly cooked.  Can't say anything negative.  AND!  They were dog-friendly!
yummm. just another good mexican food joint notin the bad part of downtown. lol

In the battle between Zaxby's and Chi-Fil-A it's hard to say who would come out the winner. I do hope to keep trying to figure it out, with lots and lots of testing.

Zaxby's really does have some great Chicken, with lots of nice chicken related meal items.  You can get your chicken on bread, or your chicken with bread, or your chicken with chicken.. and Zalads I guess.

There are only three shake choices (Vanilla, Strawberry and Chocolate), but they are quite good.

If you are looking for a fast food Chicken option, check it out.

I was disappointed, I can't lie.

I love the atmosphere, I love the feel of the place, but the Po Boy was really pretty average. The meat was dry, the sandwich wasn't great overall. I had Po Boys at Jazz fest that were 10x better. There was no messiness to them. The slaw was incredibly flavorless. I just really wasn't impressed. Seems to be more of a tourist trap these days than much else.

I'm glad I tried it, but don't have any need to go back the next time I'm in New Orleans.

This restaurant is offers a great menu ( see photos, different from that on Yelp)but is extremely overpriced given the fact that it is one of the 2-3 dining options in the Westin La Paloma Resort and Spa.

Having arrived in the resort on a hot Arizona summer evening, I chose to have a light salad (Tomato and Watermelon) and indulge in dessert for dinner but when my salad arrived I was quite shocked seeing the portion! Though the plate looked quite pretty, it was nowhere near worth $12!!! I had requested for walnuts to be added to my salad, and it was brought without any. When I requested it a second time, a small bowl of walnuts were given on the side...

The Triple chocolate mousse dessert was the saving grace, but I do wish there were better dining options for resort guests!

What an surprise find, and I used local yelpers to help me find and make the proper reservations.  I really enjoyed everything about this place and I'm sure fellow yelpers will also. Food and drinks were on point for enjoying great live entertainment.

Tacos for cheap, and a tasty margarita

Don't take the four star rating too literally, just know that I truly like this spot but can't just give it five stars because of my infatuation; it's not that kind of place... think of your general corner bar layout and you'll know what Loco looks like.

Located in a pleasant little section of fishtown, the bar has a warm and saucy vibe: they were professional and friendly, but I got the feeling if I started popping off at the mouth they wouldn't be afraid to pop me in the mouth. 

Basically got one of every taco, and my favorites were no surprise for me since I am such a meat fan, but I'd bet chorizo was my top. I was filled when I finished eating, but honestly I could eat those little Mexican salads on a shell all day if  had the time (and it wouldn't have hurt my wallet too much to boot). 

I would definetly come back for a quick lunch or a long night with no second thoughts.

Pucchino's doesn't offer many options for coffee but it will get you done in a pinch. When I was younger I enjoyed this little ice cream frozen treat (I don't even want to know how many calories were in that thing), but on my most recent trip I got a latte with almond and it was decent.

This location has a small parking lot, some delicious looking desserts, and a $5 minimum on credit cards.

We discovered Catahoula's after being turned away from The Village Belle on a Sunday around 3pm and almost passed right by. It doesn't come across as a restaurant because of the Catahoula sign with the dog logo on it and maybe that's why it's so special- it's def. a neighborhood gem and this little Southern Belle was more than pleased to discover the New Orleans menu, which btw, since we arrived at 3, we could choose anything from the brunch or dinner menu- an extra bonus! We've since been here several different times and have tried a majority of the menu.

Hushpuppies (the best- spicy and larger than usual). Ghouda Grits (um, ghouda in my grits- yes, please!). Bacon-braised Collard Greens (they don't make them w/out bacon down south!). The hubby gets a "my burger" all the time and loves it.  

We were there for Valentine's Day because 1) they don't change the menu to some lame V-day menu and 2) they don't take reservations. We started with the hushpuppies (delicious again!) and fried green tomatoes (cut a little too thick, but tasty and spicy with the green onion aioli) I got the blackened snapper, truffled mushroom grits, ragout of crab, leeks, fennel & creole tomatoes and the hubby got the duck jambalaya (he loved it). 

Our favorite thing to do here is to order the peel-n-eat shrimp in creole spices/oil and a side of the ghouda grits. Peel some shrimp, put that on the grits, and then dip a forkful in to the oil. You will be praising little baby Jesus that you read this and tried it. I've never had their version of the shrimp and grits because this is honestly all I can think of. In fact, you can make a meal out of that alone between two people and be pretty satisfied!

Great beer list, too, (I love Abita brews!) and the service is always nice and casual (in a good way).

Special note: There are about 7 tables in the restaurant, so I would choose a not-so-busy time if you don't want to wait. The bar is long though, and usually has seating available. There's also an awesome patio!

I was impressed with Kung Fu Tea.  I've seen several of my Yelp friends check in here recently so I decided to check it out.  I had no idea what to expect, but I have to say that I was surprised how "upscale" the whole experience felt.  The inside looks really nice and there's comfortable leather chairs around the tables and comfortable leather sofas also.  This would be a great place to crack open a laptop and get some work done.  The area where you order has large display panels that list all of the drink options.  The big problem I had was that I had no idea what a lot of the choices were.  When I read "Jelly Wow Milk" it elicited a "Huh?" from me.  Their website isn't any help either.  It just lists the same items with no descriptions.  I ended up going with a passion fruit slush and I really liked it.  I now know that you can select from one of four levels to indicate how much sugar (if any) you want, which I think is great.  I'm looking forward to coming back and trying some of their more exotic flavors.

Pro tips!

Do: Take advantage of the free yelp check-in appetizer.  The edamame hummus was fantastic, even if it did come with a side of cold, greasy, stale wonton chips.

Don't: Expect a great-tasting sushi experience.  I don't know how else to explain what I mean, but their sushi really didn't taste... like sushi. 

The spicy eskimo roll sounded delicious, but just ended up tasting like a ham sandwich. Yes, a ham sandwich.  The spicy tuna roll just kinda tasted like cold rice and sriracha.  The spicy butterfly roll was completely forgettable and tasted almost artificial in flavor.  Not even trying to be funny but this was the weirdest sushi experience I've ever had.   Maybe a case of extreme freezer-burn or just bad fish?  

Definitely skipping next time I'm back in St. Louis 

(Quick disclaimer for those interested - I've lived all over the world and had sushi at hundreds of different places and multiple countries and I've had some of the best sushi ever in Colorado.  Not a ton of fresh fish in the mountains, so I'm used to fish that's been frozen and then thawed and properly cured. Drunken fish does not do these things well)

Dewey's is great for lunch or dinner. The Ellisville Dewey's is my home base, but I went to the Kirkwood Dewey's for lunch today and found them exactly the same. I have tried what feels like everything on the Dewey's menu, so I feel like I could go on and on about all the good choices. 

Tips on Dewey's for first-timers:
-Pizzas are 11" 13" or 17" and can be split half and half. You can sub out one topping for another (say, minus the green peppers and add bacon on the Billy Goat. Hint hint. Try it you'll thank me). The 11" is good for two people, and the 17" is actually more pizza than two elevens and is cheaper. Deal!
-Salads are "side" or "regular" and the regular can easily be split between two (they bring you extra plates).
-Pizzas are red sauce or white sauce, white being olive oil, minced garlic, mozzarella, and fontina cheeses. Both rock.
-They do wine and beer, rotating through a few seasonals. From what I can tell they have Rogue Dead Guy Ale and Guinness on tap year round. The Kung Fu Girl Riesling is delish. 
-Everything is crazy fresh. This is not pizza hut toppings.

Best of the best:
-Candied Walnut and Grape Salad: field greens, candied walnuts, red grapes, gorgonzola, and citrus basil vinaigrette. To die for. I challenge you to find a better salad combination!
-House Salad: field greens, craisins, pine nuts, goat cheese and creamy balsamic vinaigrette. The Shaved Duck does almost the exact same salad for their house.
-Strawberry Macadamia Nut (Summer) and Harvest (Fall), which has figs AND boursin cheese AND applewood smoked bacon (yeah they did that) are both killer.
-Green Lantern: red sauce, mozzarella cheese, mushrooms, goat cheese, artichokes, and pesto. The best pizza I have EVER had. 
-The Caprice, Southwest BBQ, Billy Goat, and Socrates Revenge are my other favorites. 

They do "team service" so you're certain to have ten people clamoring to refill your drinks. The final word is you really can't go wrong with anything (except the Greek salad, which is yuck) so head on over.

I had lunch with Michelle C at Sawatdee a few weeks ago. Like other Yelpers have mentioned before me, the lunch special is awesome. However, I am unsure why the rule is "appetizer or salad, soup and entree" but you cannot get an appetizer, salad and entree. Silly.

I started with the tom yum veggie soup, which was spicy but somehow managed to be "light" in consistency. Tasted very homemade, which was great.

I continued with a spring roll. Good. Basic. I've never had a bad spring roll, have you? 

My entree was pad see iew, my favorite thai noodle dish by far. The actual quality of the noodles was awesome- you could tell they were hand cut. No mushiness, no clumps. The veggies were fresh and the flavor was good, but it was very low key. Nothing popped, nothing sizzled, and what the heck is cauliflower doing in there? Inapprops. 

I would definitely come back to Sawatdee, but if you're looking for bold flavors and lots of spice (like I often am), trek a mile or so south and order from Circles.
Yummy yummy Char Oysters omg cooked with butter and garlic aioli so good! Come here for a 1/2 dz of that and a beer for a snack!

This is me doing the Chicken Tikka Masala dance.... shaka shaka dip dip, stab chicken, insert into naan.... jive across kitchen with mouth full.  

Repeat later, inserting shaka-shaka put leftover tikka in microwave and eat for a second meal!

Also the rice pudding dance comes later, it is similar in style but has a cinnamon-and-cardamom solo section.

Owned and managed by the same people as the solid Sushi Spot in Largo, Osaka is scheduled to open sometime in March.  If it is as good as Sushi Spot, it will be a very nice addition to the western Seminole dining scene.

Wow.  Just wow.  Little Nonna's is so spectacular.  This tiny Italian restaurant packs so much complexity and flavor into every morsel it serves.  

I had the pleasure of dining at Little Nonna's on a Thursday evening.  It was early, but the place was packed solid -- which is probably a common occurrence, since the restaurant is teeny-tiny.  Thankfully, I was able to snag one of the last available first-come-first-serve seats at the back counter, overlooking the kitchen.

The server dropped by to grab my drink order.  I always try to have wine with Italian food, and she recommended an inexpensive yet tasty Pinot Grigio. -- not too sweet, perfect for sipping, and pairs well with most things.

She also told me that the best way for a newbie to experience Little Nonna's is to resist the temptation to fill up on a large pasta dish and, instead, try a sampling of their smaller plates.  So that's what I did.

First course was a plate of wild mushroom arancini (a.k.a. deep-fried risotto balls).  This dish was mind-blowingly delicious.  It's the best risotto I've ever had, and it's probably one of the best Italian dishes *of any kind* I've ever had.  These balls were simultaneously crispy, creamy, savory, sweet -- the total gastronomic package.

Next up was the eggplant parmesan.  This dish is nothing like the heavy, one-note eggplant parmesan served elsewhere, where you can't even identify the eggplant in a sea of breading, cheese, and grease.  Nope -- Nonna makes the eggplant the star, with just enough breading to provide crisp and just enough cheese provide layers of flavor.  This dish let the eggplant shine, and I loved it.

To finish the meal, I had the tiramisu, which was also total perfection.  It was served beautifully, towering high in a large teacup.  The flavors were perfect, and not to sweet either.  I loved the touch of fresh hazelnuts, which gave this tiramisu a contrasting crunchy texture that other tiramisus lack.  

To say I love Little Nonna's is an understatement.  If I lived in the area, I'd be dining here over and over again.  It's the real deal -- check it out for yourself!

I like the atmosphere.  They really took time to decorate the place.  We sat at the booth.  Week day lunch had special plates with rice, soup, and salad.  I had the spicy basil eggplant which I enjoyed.  Someone had the Szechuan chicken which had too much bamboo.  That person didn't like it at all.  Beef broccoli was descent.  The service was great and professional.  It was an enjoyable lunch.

I want to preface this by saying that I ranked it 4/5, but the experience was more like a 3.5/5 or 7/10. It's got a lot of kinks to iron out because the place is new. Right now it's just an insanely expensive average experience. 

This is the new restaurant in the JW, Ice District. Finding this place is difficult, as they have parking but at the moment it's not really complete. I'm here to save the day though, and get you through this maze. You park in the underground parkade off 103 Ave, near Stantec tower. If you blink you will miss this parkade due to construction all around it, so keep your eyes out. After that, go into the parkade, up to the main lobby of the Stantec, and it is directly across the street. Don't try to go in through the patio doors, they keep them locked. Go around the building to the front of the JW and then you will see it. There is a lobby bar, walk past the lobby bar and you are there. I feel the need to explain this because getting here was definitely a bit crazy. But, hey, free parking!

So we get to the hostess stand, get checked in (you need to give your license plate for the parkade), and the restaurant itself is behind the wine wall! The decor is beautiful! We were seated at a nice four-person table, chairs were very comfortable! I just felt very fancy. If you guys know me, you know I like to pretend to be fancy when I'm actually not (lol).

Our server was awesome, when she was there. She was running around like a mad-woman trying to handle all her tables. She did a great job considering the circumstances. It took about a half hour for her to get our wine to us, which is a pretty long time considering that we hadn't even ordered our food before our wine. It was at this point that I knew we were in for a rough 3-3.5 hours. But I get it, it's ironing out the kinks. 

We ordered a Burgundy ($84) and a Gamay Noir - the Gamay was the least expensive ($58), however, I think you're pretty safe in ordering any wine that is on the "cheap" side because the price doesn't really matter. It is very clear that they have spent the time to carefully construct their gorgeous wine menu! When looking through it I could tell that you're basically safe with any wine because of the time and care it takes to create a menu like that. All stunning wines and different varieties. I obviously preferred the Burgundy because I'm a boss, but the Gamay was delicious as well.

I take a big issue with the size of the font on the menu. I mean, come on, why do I need a magnifying glass to read this? You have so much space and should make the font bigger! Even our server was squinting trying to read which items/wines we were trying to order. I totally get wanting to have a nice aesthetic, but this is hurts my eyes. 

We ordered a bunch of menu items to try, the Chargrilled Salmon, the Cauliflower, Onion Rings, Fried Squid, Hamachi Sashimi, mashed potatoes and the Rib Eye. I'm a pescatarian/mostly plant-based, so I did not try the Rib Eye. I was very impressed by the Chargrilled Salmon and the Cauliflower dishes. But I was totally taken aback by how BOMB the mashed potatoes were. I had to laugh because they totally stole the show for me. YUM! I was very pleased with the Salmon and Cauliflower as well. 

For dessert we order this Black Forest Eton Mess Sundae and it was so underwhelming. That was my least favourite part of the meal. It looks like you're about to stuff your face with delicious brownies. But what it actually is, is layers of whipped cream and a tiny bit of ice cream, brownies and cookies and a bunch of maraschino cherries to fill the space. Two big slices of some kind of merengue to make it seem like it isn't just a bowl of whipped cream. For $21, you're better off going home. 

So yeah, kind of an average experience for the first time. I'm definitely going to come back in a few months when they iron out the kinks. I like the space and I want to give it the shot it deserves. You can tell they put a lot of work into it. Right now, however, it needs some work. I wouldn't make it a regular spot until the future. 

I will, however, be back to spend a bunch of $$$ when I recover from this.

My mouth is watering just thinking of this place now! A few friends and I came here while on vacation. It's in an odd location, kind of far from, well where we were staying at least! It was well worth the hike out there though!.  I got the Muffaletta and it was HUGE. I barely was able to eat half of it. I also got the macaroni as a side.  It was a few months ago that we came here, so I don't remember what anybody else had, but I know we all left happy and full!

Meat!
The seats
Are in short
Supply but the 
Sandwiches go a long way towards joy.

I love me some Publix! Their produce always look so fresh and their stores are always kept so clean. Cashiers are really nice and it's a joy to grocery shop when you're shopping at Publix. Oh yeah.. did I mention the free wifi? Aahhhhwesome!

Benihana didn't rock my socks off but it was certainly enjoyable.  A very solid three.  

When we first walked in, they had no record of my reservation (that I had called in on Wednesday for Saturday night), but they were able to accommodate my party of four without a wait.  From beginning to end, I enjoyed the food.  I had the "Land and Sea" hibachi and it came with soup, salad, some appetizer shrimp, and ice cream for dessert.  I felt that the price was reasonable given the amount of food and "the show."  

Our hibachi guy was excellent -- he worked quickly and kept two little kids at a party next to us very entertained and engaged (to the point where we hardly noticed we had kids at our table).  I would have liked if our waitress came back to the table more frequently to check on the drinks -- she forgot water that I asked for and I sat with an empty beer for a good long while before she showed up again to offer another.  They had a decent selection of Japanese beers, which was a definite plus as you don't see that around very often.

As weird as this sounds, I would recommend dressing in layers.  It's cold in there, but it heats up when they start cooking at your table.  Once they shut the stove top off, you're back to fairly chilly while you eat your cold ice cream.  Be prepared if you're sensitive to temperature.

My boyfriend first showed me this place because he goes to Saddleback right next door. Honestly, when he first told me about this place, I was like, pizzas? And burgers? It's going to be the same boring flavors.. but I was proved wrong! The first time I went I ordered a flatbread and the kind owner came by and asked us if we wanted any of the house sauces. By far, these are the best sauces on the planet. NO PLACE can ever make sauces like these. Last night, my boyfriend and I ate a pizza there, the ham was so succulent and fresh while the pizza, although thick, had the right amount of crunch to it! The owner joked around with my boyfriend and I, and honestly the amazing customer service and the pizza made me love this place even more! This is definitely on my top three places to eat!

I was actually surprised with how tasty my meal was! Visiting Reno twice a month for work I've come to enjoy staying at The Peppermill, this however was my first time eating at Oceano. After a 5 minute wait I was seated at the sushi bar and asked if I wanted to do the all you can eat sushi. I'm all about sushi but something about sushi in Reno with the "all you can eat" slogan behind it turned me off. Everyone to the right of me was gobbling up some sushi but I settled for the wood grilled halibut with potatoes and loads of veggies. The meal as I stated in my first sentence was quite tasty, the halibut had a nice wood flavor to it and was seasoned really well. My veggies could have been cooked a bit longer but that's more of a preference than anything else. Overall good service, good menu and I will definitely be back!

I was expecting something amazing when I saw the rating of 4 stars for Nori Thai. It was good, but nothing that blew me away.

The place itself is very small. I almost felt like the couple seated next to use were part of my table. I could easily join in their conversation. Everyone who works there seems friendly enough, though. They seem to know their regulars and serve up smiles and jokes. Or maybe the customers there weren't even regulars, and the servers are really that friendly.

I ordered the massaman curry mild, and the boyfriend ordered tofu pad thai. Two dishes that I feel should be solid enough to make a judgment on a Thai restaurant. The curry was good. I was afraid mild may still be too spicy for me, but it was just right. Really good portion too; just enough where I was able to finish it but not feel too stuffed. I wasn't a fan of the pad thai, though. It was too sweet for my taste, and the noodles seemed overcooked. Too chewy.

If I hadn't been full from our meal and tempura appetizer (which was typical tasting), I would have liked to try one of their desserts, especially the sticky rice with mango. It's something you don't see on every menu.

We stumbled across King of Tandoor almost by accident, and I'm glad we did. The decor is fun, the service was impeccable and the food was very, very tasty. I don't typically wade into the "is this authentic Indian" given that Indian food is highly regional (and I'm not an expert in it), but I do eat a fair bit of Indian food and I'd definitely rank this as some of the better Indian food that's crossed my dinner plate.

Good Indian food in East Philly? What? Yeahh, its true.  This restaurant is right behind a motel (America's best something), so don't blink or you'll miss out.  

I went with a Desi (Indian-American) friend who said this place was great -which it was.  It's a big place, very well decorated, with dimly lit lights and indian music in the background.  The service is very good, waiters very friendly. Since my friend recommeded the place and i'm sure had a lot more experience with indian food than i did - i let him order. We had: 

Masala Paneer (Cheese in Tomato sauce)  - The sauce on this platter was awesome... I'm not a big cheese eater but this plate was soo flavorful. He ordered the spicy which I was like - SPicy? What does spicy mean - because my level of spice tolerance and indian level are very different.  It actually was a tolerable spicy though.
Aloo Gobi (Potatoes and Cauliflower) - Another great amazing dish - the sauce was incredible - the plate all together was very flavorful.. 
Garlic Naan - Mmm..

Also, this was my first time drinking King Fisher beer (lager). It was really good and ice cold!

These two dishes, naan and rice were more than enough food for two people.  Definitely recommended if your in the area or not.   FYI - It's not cheap - it came out to like $50 for two people.

So...I was going to go to lunch with my daughter today but since the side streets in Broad Ripple don't get plowed, I was concerned about getting my car out...and back.  It is a good thing that I work from home :-)

Since I didn't want to venture out...I decided to order chinese food delivered.  For orders of $10+, free delivery - yay!!!

I ordered a quart of the Hot & Sour Soup (very good), a pint of the Egg Drop soup (ok), and the Steamed Chicken & Shrimp with Mixed Vegetables (good but not much shrimp).  

The guy that delivered the food was pleasant and even included a 2011 scroll calendar with my order.

I'm set for the weekend!  Although I am going to venture out of my house tomorrow to do some urban hiking on the towpath :-)

As the name implies, this bar is situated on the 60th floor of the Four Seasons Hotel. Overlooking the city of brotherly love, the view is just magnificent. This should definitely be on your hit list for bars with a view of Philadelphia. The bar offers a delightful menu to accompany a creatively mixed cocktail or wine. Overall, you really go to the sky bar for the ambiance. Enjoy the views!!!

As we walked up to Reef I counted the places doing Sushi within 5 blocks.  I think I counted a total of four, the one in Harrah's, the one serving Thai, the one in Sienna and now Reef.  This seems a little more density than can be sustained.  And quite possibly this will lead to one of these places closing down.  But for now, we have the "Modern Age" of All-You-Can-Eat sushi in Reno. The golden age has passed.  The first strong originators are either closed or way past their prime.  So now, looking forward, what else can we do but wonder...how can it be improved?  How can it be revisited and bring a fresh take on AYCE sushi, something Reno knows more about than probably any other city in North America?

Reef seems to be willing to take up that challenge.  The challenge to bring us the AYCE sushi we know and love, while still giving us a reason to forgo our regular sushi bars and give and them a try.

At the outset you notice new "take" in the theme of the restaurant.  The gentle Hawaiian music playing adds to the visual atmosphere.  Of course being new, everything is clean and sharp and not worn, but it's also very pleasing.  For me, it attains a nice balance between casual and upscale.  They have cloth napkins on one hand, but a soda fountain in view from the bar.  This could easily be a date place and yet still a good place to go when you don't feel like all the pomp and circumstance of a fancy "date night".  They did have two large screen TV's above the bar but they weren't on when we arrived.  Not sure if they plan on having them on all the time or if they just plan on using them during lunch hours.
  
The service was soft opening service.  If anything was slow or a bit "off", it was easily chalked up to the soft opening learning curve.  However everyone was friendly and helpful.  And in all frankness, I've gotten much poorer service at some of the currently established restaurants.  The wait staff was prompt and quick at filling waters, sodas and clearing plates.
  
And now finally we get to the sushi.  The sushi was quality and the variety seemed to reflect all the different places in Reno.  They have taken all the good stuff and put it under one roof.

Mahalo Roll
Mt Fuji Roll
Surf and Turf Roll (my wife's favorite)
Yellowtail Nigiri
Maguro Nigiri
Salmon Nigiri
Spicy Bomb
BBQ Seared Tuna
Donald
Mickey
Crab Handroll
Quail Egg Shooters
Upside Down Shrimp
Spicy Tuna Upside down Shrimp
Crab Cakes
Coconut Shrimp
Potstickers
Mussels
Strawberry Parfait
Tempura Banana with Ice Cream
Tempura Peach with Ice Cream

I'm not gonna review everything, but instead...
Best Mussels in Reno.  Not tough and chewy, but still properly cooked.
Best Desserts offered with an All You Can Eat (the good green tea ice cream is served here)
Non-Soy Sauce based Quail Egg Shooters
Warning: Spicy doesn't seem prominently featured. But I'm sure you can have them spice stuff up.

If they can maintain this level of quality and price and service I don't see them having any problems succeeding.  And IF they do, this very well could take the throne as the "Best in Reno".

The grand opening isn't until Monday 3/25/13.  
They sadly serve Coke products.
They seem to have an extensive Sake menu.
A variety of Tea offerings.
Dinner Price was paid at $25.95 per person.
Lunch is $17.95 per person.
Under 12 AYCE is $9.95.

The Publix on the USF campus is finally open and it is everything we dreamed it would be! This is a full service Publix, complete with deli (PUB SUBS), bakery, and seafood counter. I attended the grand opening today and was very impressed, the store is immaculately clean, there is USF Bulls branding everywhere, there were millions of employees to assist you, and tons of free samples. The first 500 visitors got bags of free samples, and they had plenty of branded promo items like buttons, sunglasses and reusable bags for everyone. The parking lot is pretty big but there is only one way in and out so it will be interesting to see how crowded things get when students get back to campus, it's finals week now and campus has died down quite a bit. I can't wait to shop here on the regular, so convenient!!

July 7, 2017 Friday - 7:30 PM for dessert
4 Adults and a teenager

Atmosphere - 4 stars
Food - 5 stars
Service - 5 stars

Background - Treating my daughter with a special dessert.

Atmosphere - Part of a strip mall they actually have to store fronts.  They have some sit down tables and some long bar style tables you stand at.  They need a few more chairs inside.  It was still too hot to sit outside and eat at a few of their side walk tables.

Dessert - They are known for their ice cream sandwiches.  I am all about snickerdoodles so I was glad to see them.  So I picked the snickerdoodle as my top and bottom cookies.  Now I need to figure out which ice cream will go with the cookies.  Simple and clean to let that cinnamon to come out.  Vanilla of course.  I did not need a "topping", the little something they stick on the side of your ice cream that is visible.  The cookie was solid one the best snickerdoodles I have, which I was surprised by.  Freshness is something they stress there and it pays off.  I think they should suggest some suggested combos for those who can not make their minds up.  Perhaps my daughter's combo of funfetti cookies with bear batter ice cream topped with sprinkles could be the "classic kid sandwich".

Service - Friendly staff.  The concept is simple so they need to execute with perfection.

Future - Desserts like this are always a special treat, so yes but not often.

This place is so irregular I have to give it three stars. Sometimes 2 sometimes 4... the food is a steady 4 but the service you just don't know.

They took away that little trio of spicy sauces but if you ask for it they will bring it to the table. I really like that you can pick from some healthy options as well as go al in on the deep fried and sugary side - all up to you! 

Wine list is good and cocktails are too, they usually have seasonal flavors and wines for a good price worth checking out.

I usually ask for "extra spicy" but it still doesn't come out very hot so if you like the more spicy versions do t be afraid to ask for it, it will not be too much.

I absolutely love this place!  I don't know why we do not come here more often.  When you walk in, it looks like you're walking into someones living room.  The place is tiny so make sure you make a reservation.  We got there at 5:30 on Saturday without a reservation but were told that we had to leave before 7:00 because the table we were at was reserved.  Not a big deal!  They were honest up front.  Take it or leave it!

The restaurant does have a bar but the drinks are so so.  I didn't come for the drinks though.  To start off, the house salad that is served family style is just amazing.  My father in law who's diet consists of steak, bread, and pepsi even eats it.  Don't forget to get the cheese!

I ended up getting the crabcake appetizer that was served with roasted red cabbage and bacon, drizzled with a balsamic dressing.  A++ I didn't think I was going to like the red cabbage, but I can't get it out of my head.  There was this sweetness to it that I can't really explain.  You will have to just try it.  And you can't go wrong with bacon.  The crabcake had nice chunks of lump meat and barely any filler.  One of the best crabcakes I've had in a while.

The others ordered baked penne with meatballs, shrimp scampi, and manicotti.  The table was pretty much silent as everyone dug in.  You definitely get your money's worth.  Everyone had plenty of leftovers for lunch the next day.  Graziano's is definitely on the top of my list when it comes to Italian eateries.  Food was great! Company was great! A nice little step back into time.  We all left happy.

I ventured into Mother's a few hours after arriving in New Orleans last Friday, on my way to the expo for the race I came into town for. I was starving so the ordering system seemed even more confusing than it probably otherwise would have, but as others have stated, wait in line, order, sit, and wait for a server to pick up your receipt. Then trust the process, they will bring you your food. That was my biggest worry, I was so hungry!

Many of the menu items looked delicious but I love breakfast and didn't want to eat fried food before a race so I had an omelet with ham and American cheese. New Orleans people seem to love American cheese for some bizarre reason. It came with grits and a biscuit. Everything was really tasty, and the service was very friendly. They didn't even seem annoyed with me staring longingly at the kitchen waiting for my food! I would definitely come back and try something with debris the next time I'm in town.

Most important thing : CASH ONLY

What's there not to love about a cute icecream joint that's churning out crafted speciality flavors?

My favorite so far has been pop champagne! It tasted like a strawberry something. I couldn't put my finger on it but I know that it was amazing!

I always choose the 6 mini scoops because I like variety. Their milkshakes are the perfect consistency too!

definitely a place you have to bring your out of town guest !

Among the most impressive things St. Louis has going for it are its beautiful parks! And, yes, Forest Park is the jewel and you absolutely cannot miss it if it's your first visit to STL, but Tower Grove is a beautiful park! I was visiting STL with a friend last weekend, and our airbnb was quite close to Tower Grove. So we went over and enjoyed the scenery for a bit before we went out to dinner. It's a great park for a walk or a bike ride or a run or a picnic or just reading your book by the water and watching the geese. A beautiful park!

I'm giving Brio 4 stars only because as a corporate-owned restaurant, they do have certain standards they have to meet 24/7.  I wouldn't go here if I wanted a cozy Friday night.  Granted, the food (Italian, big menu, not quite the scale of Cheesecake's but very adequate) is tastey and if you have any complaints a manager will be at your table in two seconds. Steaks, pork chops, pastas, pizzas... The bar seems to attract the 30 and 40-somethings.  I'd recommend reservations on the weekends.  Good for family events or if you're in the mood for a huge Italian feast, bellini and everything.

This review is for CPK's corporate catering.  We eat basically the same 2 sandwiches at EVERY event my company hosts.  Turkey , Arugula & Brie or Grilled Veggie sandwiches.  Sometimes we will have a few pizzas but since they get cold quickly, the office opts for sandwiches.

We also get the salads - served in a large plastic bowl with dressings (herbal ranch is great!) in bottles on the side.

For a catered meal once in a while it's fine - but to  eat often?  Get's old quick.

BEST SANDWICHES EVER. 

The apparently do a lot of their stuff in house. I came here solely based on recommendation of a friend. Pig mac has stayed on my mind and the muffuletta has changed me. I wish I could have tried more things. Next time, NOLA.

Quetzally is right below Center City in Hawthorne but it remains very much a neighborhood Mexican cafe as opposed to a destination restaurant.  Much of their business is via the takeout or delivery route but there is also a small dining room with a few tables.  I was recommended by a friend to try their chalupas and with good reason - they're good.  I had the homemade chorizo chalupas and after adding hot sauce to provide a nice kick, I enjoyed a nice light meal.
btw - Quetzally means beautiful in the old Aztec language.

We walked in at 5pm. The restaurant was empty, but we were seated only after a few mins, because the staff were still setting up. 

We tried to place order for the $26.95 prime rib dinner that they advertised in the hotel room booklet, but not listed in the menu. I checked with our waiter, a Vietnamese dude named Benam, that it was available 3 times before I place the order. He assured us it is available. Guess what, more than 15 mins later, after we were served the soup, he told us it was not available, and to choose a different entree. It was too late by then for us to leave the restuarant, since we already drank the soup (part of the dinner set). 

 

Fine, we chose different entrees. To be fair, they tasted decent.

We also ordered a mac and cheese after seeing the pic of it on yelp. We got a shock when we were serve KRAFT mac and cheese. When we asked the waiter, Benam, about it, he said that their $8 mac and cheese has always been like that, because it is for kids. Right. When we ask if we can just cancel the order since we didn't touch it yet, he rolled his eyes and brought the dish away after staring at us. I'm not sorry that I refuse to pay $8 for something that cost less than $2 (we were not even serve the entire box. Lol?)

Obviously the dinner turned out really awkward because Benam became the ultimate queen bitch after that. Cleared our dishes loudly after asking rudely if we are done. When it came to choosing dessert, when my husband ask for bread pudding, he sarcastically said oh, are you sure, because I don't think I can trust you now. WTF. 

I was really worried that the staff might spit in our dessert after that. But my husband said that I should have more faith. I am writing the yelp review at the table, while eating my dessert skeptically. Can't wait, because my blood is freaking boiling. I rarely write bad reviews, most of my reviews are 4 or 5 stars, but this 1 star is freaking deserving.

I left tipping Benam, your highness, $8 to thank him for removing the mac and cheese from our orders. If I had thicker skin, I wouldn't have tipped at all.

Edit: husband spoke to the manager and she apologized. She said the mac and cheese we were served belongs to the kids menu, and they mixed it up. Just added a star ( from 1 to 2)  because the manager is super nice about it. See, I'm not that hard to please!!!

A great little gallery, with dog prints.  So of course Sweetie and I had to go.  On a street full of galleries, this was our favorite.  The proprietor was very friendly, there's a good selection and price range, and it's just a fun place to stop in.

Tried buffet at taste of India, good food for reasonable prices, good options. They were like making in small quantities and filling up hot, which I liked the most. Wish we could come back but we are visiting Reno for weekend, so can't.
Will miss for sure!!!

Such an amazing experience!! One of the coolest in our time in town (and there were many)! 

Make sure to sit around the open kitchen. That makes it ten times cooler. The chance to get to see these true artist conduct a symphony of food as you order...can't be beat. An opportunity that won't be soon forgotten by us!! 

Sat for a late brunch. We got the last spots at the "stage". Ordered the sausage bene and the bisque. Both high 10s!! So good. Do it. 

Ordered a killer queen drink and a random next to me saw my love after the first drink and he ordered one. Tops!!

Hm, I wasn't sure what rating to give this place. The food was delicious but the service was terrible, which is why I couldn't bring myself to give it the 5 stars the food may deserve.

My boyfriend and I tried this place out on a Saturday night around 6:45pm since we had a restaurant.com gift certificate. The place was very empty, although it says it's open till past midnight and there was supposedly a WashU party going on later that night.. In any case, we were the only customers in the place for a while and it was a bit awkward at times.

The lady serving us was nice at first, and she reminded us that since we were using the gift certificate, they were giving us $25 of their money for us to enjoy their meal. We smiled politely and checked out the menu.

After she left, a guy (we assumed he was the owner) came over to us and began inquiring about us in the most awkward way imaginable. He stood over us asking what schools we went to, what we studied, and what nationalities we were. The conversation definitely wasn't flowing, especially since when we tried to ask him a question he interrupted us to ask another one.. hm. 

He also then reiterated the fact that since we were using the gift certificate he was covering $25 of our meal. We smiled politely once again, slightly peeved this time...

The items on the menu were so cheap and since there were only 2 of us, it was actually difficult to get our bill to the minimum of $35 in order to use the certificate. For the amount that we got, we were pleasantly surprised at the prices. The appetizers were less than $5, the specials were about $15 and everything else was in between. They could definitely charge more if they wanted to, although I'm glad they don't!

We ended up ordering the samboosa appetizer which I wasn't particularly impressed by (think semi-bland spring roll stuffed with ground beef and a mildly spicy sauce to go with it) and a glass of honey wine which is definitely a kick in the mouth. It kicked me a bit too hard but my boyfriend loved it.

We ordered the goat curry chef's special (a giant plate of goat curry with rice) and my boyfriend enjoyed it thoroughly. I thought it was good but my lamb tibs were better; lamb chunks with onions and hot peppers in a flatbread, similar to the bread we tried in an Ethiopian restaurant (but less sour) with a delicious side salad. 

We definitely enjoyed the meal and were stuffed by the end of it. When the lady came by with the bill, she stood over us and tried to convince us to order more appetizers. We told her we were stuffed and would like the check. She told us to order another appetizer to qualify for the gift certificate. We told her that we had calculated the cost already and we knew it was over $35. 
At that point she reluctantly handed over the bill and rudely said 'well, your total comes to $36, and we're paying for $25 of that, so you should order something else, but I guess that's fine, you want to be cheap, whatever.' 
Then she walked away and stood on the side sulking while we paid. 

I assume restaurants put certificates up on restaurant.com in order to raise awareness of their food and so people will want to try it out and come again regardless of a coupon!
I have never experienced this in any restaurant in my entire life.. although I do realize that it's a cultural difference. Americans are great with customer service, but I have been to many other countries and eaten at many different cuisines with mostly terrible service and delicious food. This was still the worst though.

The food was delicious but I'm not sure I'd want to deal with that service again.

I came to Deacons for a Saturday morning brunch. The vibe is man cave chic with bold fixtures, deep undertones, and nice wood. The menu for brunch was stuffier than I typically prefer such as French style omelettes so I got the burger. Now this burger was the James Beard Competition burger so I had to go for it. It was a prime beef patty with ground shiitake and cremini mushrooms blended in. The patty had a distinct aftertaste that was not pleasant, probably from too many creminis as apparently the burger is 25% mushroom. There was a fresh pesto on the bottom bun and aioli on the top. Halumi cheese and arugula also complimented the burger. The burger was rich and the flavors were competing to be the boldest which meant nobody won. I asked for a tomato to attempt to cut through the richness with some acid and this helped. I ate half of the burger and I never eat half of anything lol but I was on a date and did not want to seem as a complainer. Instead I ate a good amount of my date's burger which was the Deacon's Classic Burger. It was an elevated Big Mac and boy was it juicy and flavorful. I will return to eat the Classic for sure.

With good customer service, a welcoming environment, and beautiful decor, this place was a great choice for a group gathering! The food was good, but I felt like the sour dough that came with my Syrian Breakfast was too toasted, maybe even a little burnt? It made it tough to bite into. Other than that, I was content with my breakfast entree of choice. Something else worth noting, they have some of the BEST coffee I have ever had! I would highly recommend it!

A colleague told me that Root was one of the places that I absolutely must go to while in NO.  I'm glad I listened to him.  The food and the experience were delightful.

We started with a a charcuterie board.  

- The hog's head cheese had a little bite, which was nice
- The liver parfait was rich and had the perfect liver flavor
- The morcilla was smokey, but not too smokey
- The duck prosciutto was a little sweet, which was a nice surprise
- All of the pickled items, especially the tiny oranges, were perfect

For my main, I had the whole fish.  The fish was light and flakey.  Small flakes, which made it a little tough to eat around the bones, but the sweet preparation was excellent and complemented the fish perfectly.

I also was able to try the duck, which had a very light BBQ flavor.  The duck wasn't too fatty, but had just enough to make it nice and tender.  

The service was excellent.  Informative and very friendly, with a light touch.

I'll be back.

The candy kitchen is one of those places that has just always been there for as long as you can remember. This place is a very small hole in the wall that, if you're driving and you blink, you'll miss it. There is very limited parking so be ready to look around if you can't find any in the lot!

The interior of this place is really cool and themed with the copious amounts of old candy, that it'll make you forget you're in 2019. The prices for the candy here are ridiculously reasonable and they even offer bulk candy and candy by the pound.

The ice cream is the best thing about this place though, I got the strawberry oreo ice cream and it was delicious! It was the perfect amount of creamy and for $4 the amount you get is insane! They have many different flavors such as butter pecan and coffee&doughnuts so be ready to have choices!

It is a very small place with MAYBE 7-8 people being able to be inside at one time. Friendly staff and great prices!

I got the stuffed lobster.  It was really good.  But come on, that's not why people come here.  

They come here for the amazing, orgasmic, delicious, not so nutritous, garlicy, cheesy, CHARBROILED OYSTERS!!!!!!!!!  OMG OMG.  They are SO GOOD.  I could make a meal out of them alone, probably.

This review should be a 4* just based on the drinks and their amazing patio alone, but the service tends to get in the way of that 4th star much of the time. 
Service: 
The servers are usually friendly and helpful in figuring out what to order but man once that order is in... crickets.... no server, no service. Empty water and beer glasses and if the food didn't come out  perfect... good luck getting a hold of the server before it's cold. 
Food:
As mentioned above the food needs some attention a lot of the time once it arrives. Ie improper protein cook temps, no sauce, no dressing, wrong side and sometimes "this isn't what I ordered".  When and if the food is corrected it's usually pretty darn good. I don't think I've ever got the same thing twice just because I'm always looking to try something new.
Pricing:
I think for a lot of the menu (which is a good size menu too) the pricing is appropriate but for the salads and burgers it can be a bit high for what you end up with. 
So if these guys would spend a bit more attention to the small details this would easily be a 4 or possibly even a 5 star review.

Yelp reviews on this place made me want to check this out with my lunch buddy.  This cute fast food type of place was located right off Rittenhouse square.  There are a bunch of tables but they were all taken.  The line was out the door.

4 kiosks were available to take your order.  First I thought "how impersonal" then I thought "ohhh my order should be perfect".   It was perfect.  The wait was not very long to order my food or to wait for my custom meal.

I decided to 'Create my Own"  I had egg white noodles with chicken, mushroom, bean sprouts, bell peppers, roasted cashews, cucumbers and lite soy sauce.      They definitely could have used more chicken as I barely saw it in my container.   Tons of noodle.  Although I said lite sauce I still had a bunch of bottom of my container (I wonder if it's light sauce).  It was very tasty.  The portion was huge so I tossed about a third.  There is only so much noodles a girl can eat in one sitting.

My buddy had tofu, brown rice, pepper, broccoli, carrots, pineapple, scallions, cilantro and red coco curry sauce.   She really loved it.  She wants this to be one of our regular lunch spots.  I agree.

Price is reasonable - a bit under $10 for each of us.

The staff was very friendly and they had one person cleaning tables and talking to guests.  

There was plenty of staff working behind the counter/grill.

We will be back.

My favorite part in St. Louis. I went again today and it makes me have butterflies and wanna do flips for summer. The Zoo, The Art Museum, The History Museum, and the Paddleboats... Date HEAVEN! or like today... lonely by myself... ha

Besides the beer and "atmosphere" this place is a no go in my book- at least for wings!
The pros here are:
Had a friendly server, she was "with it." 
The burger sliders appetizer were actually quite tasty. 
Loved the steak fries.
Pretzel bites with cheese were ok- they were cut up pieces of a pretzel and deep fried I could tell.
The cons- the wings are just dreadful. Got smoked and hooters style (fried) and both were about equal to frozen wings. I mean, just bad! 
Obviously parking is a challenge downtown, but we went on an off day and found street parking. It was dead.
Would I go back? Probably not. There are so many other places downtown with better food.

I ordered the chicken tikka masala.  It was better than average but nothing too special.  The chicken was very tender but it tasted a bit fake to me, just a bit too soft as if it was processed somehow.  I have been to at least 50 indian restaurants including 3 weeks in India so I guess I am a bit picky.

Do you like your grilled peppers spicy? The one I had tonight had that heat! 

I tried the Beef, and Barbacos tacos. Both were really good! I'm not sure which I prefer. 
Both the red and green salsas were REALLY GOOD. 

My tacos came with onions and cilantro. The plate had a lil sliced radish, grilled pepper, and a perfect delicious lime wedge. 

CASH ONLY!!! I would have gotten more than 3 tacos, but I only had 5 in cash on me, and am/was much to Ill (due to a gum/tooth infection etc.- not with covid) to try to go get more. 

My dog definitely approved! 

They have tacos, burritos, and a few other items like drinks. 

Stoked to find this place!

We had been ogling their sandwich menu for a really long time in a parking lot, on our phones, before deciding to come here.

From the outside - this place looks like its going to be an upscale establishment that we were under-dressed for. As soon as you walk inside, you will notice that the decor is virtually everything ---- and the kitchen sink... Haaaah.... Get it? No? Ok.

Keonta was our waitress, she was lovely, attentive and laughed at our jokes, stayed on top of the fresh refills, and put our iced teas into to-go cups when we left. 

My fiance got the Pat "Say Jack", which I had been eyeing and I honestly wish I had gotten that... however, instead, something strange hit me when I sat down - I wanted nachos. No, I'm not pregnant, I just suddenly really needed nachos and it said chicken and pepperjack cheese "sauce". Sold. 

I wish I had not gotten the nachos. I had three bites of my fiance's sandwich and had, what I like to call, "Order Envy". I had regret... 

Half of my chips were stale, so stale that they bent and flexed in my mouth while trying to chew - mixed with perfectly fresh crispy chips. I didn't know what I was going to get with each bite until it was too late. The fried jalapenos were delicious on top -- however, the chips, the whole point of the entree, really made it annoying...

We do intend to go back and give this establishment another try - and I will update my review then. 

The people next to us all ordered Monte Cristos and raved about them, perhaps, that is something to consider next time...

Let's start out with some positive points:

1. I liked the movie I saw.
2. Great old theater and the architecture is incredible. 
3. Good location, close to the true city and in a neighborhood that is alive      with activity. Which makes for a fun-filled day or date night. 
4. Well maintained and I love the fact that all the movie poster on display have a St. Louis connection.

Now for the negatives:

1. Stale old popcorn and we were attending the first matinee of the day. 
2. Prices were very high for a matinee show.
3. Young man selling tickets and working concession stand was not friendly. He was also wearing aviator sunglasses inside, I hope it was for a medical reason. If not, it was not cool. I like to have eye contact with the person I am conducting business with. 

I've been spoiled by other art houses for film, but the Tivoli Theatre is a St. Louis tradition. I remember it when it was a single screen, so I will be back to give them another opportunity. One bad experience is not going to keep me away from a St Louis Landmark.
Basic pizza slices. No sit down to speak of. Nice guy. Offered me a free soda with a $1 slice!

Young Bin Kwan is one of many Korean eateries in the Jenkintown area. It's easy to miss the place if you don't know where it is - just remember that they're at Benson Manor on Washington Lane.

The inside is accented with dark woods, and fairly spacious.  Last I was there, it was debatable how much English the servers actually knew, but we were there for BBQ, not conversation! Regardless, service was prompt and helpful.

While their Korean selection of entrees is typical, the expert kitchen preparation is anything but: try the bulgogi! Their banchan is fresh, and the kimchi crunchy. (They also serve sushi, but I found it so-so.)

Young Bin Kwan is good eats, and worth the price of admission.

Just when I thought 2014 couldn't get any better I revisited one of my favorite places to eat in Nashville...and it's in a hotel!

Mason's is the brainchild of genius chef Brandon Frohne. This guy has more ideas than a fancy Ivy League college think tank and his execution would put even the most rabid dictators to shame. Too over the top of a description you say? Try the food at Masons and you will see why there are words to describe the flavors. 

I highly recommend starting with the JARS and the bone marrow beef cheek confit. Then the compressed patty pan and warm goat cheese. The entree is a tough spot to recommend, everything is good. The osso bucco is my favorite right now, but the shrimp and grits is a close second. 

Get all three desserts. Thank me later. You are welcome.
This place is a gem. Crazy good ice cream and absolutely gigantic frozen bananas, retro candy items and every type of fudge you could ask for. You can't go wrong here!

I really like this location.  It's right down the street from my apartment.  It's walkable, but there is a parking lot as well as a parking garage.  Prices are not bad for downtown, and there is a nice selection here of produce, meats, seafood, and dry goods.  We rarely ever have to wait too long to get checked out.  This is our go to grocery spot downtown.

What keeps me coming back? THE SOUP DUMPLINGS. 

It's been said a hundred times but I'll say it again. They are soo yummy. And the cherry on top is the delicious dumpling sauce. I could eat these for days.

I've tried a few other things on the menu such as the beef stew and its all equally mouth-watering.

The best part is the price. I could pig out for hours and still not even break $20 which is so ideal! The service is also pretty fast as well, in my experience even when it is super busy (which it often is) I get served promptly and my food comes out right when it should.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Its worth the wait. Wow. loved it. Gluten Free Friendly. Meat and sausage is awesome. We came in as a group and everyone was stuffed. i think everything was tried and everyone loved it. It is a must stop. YUM. So much history in this place. You can taste it.

Checked this place out on Steve I's Metry bar crawl with the gang. I had heard about it a bunch (probbly from Steve) so was excited to try. The food truck craze always has me craving tacos so how perfect was this. The place itself is.....spartan to say the least. It's an old trailer that is hopefully anchored down in some way. But maybe not. Anyway I decided to try the "lengua" or tongue tacos and a basket of chips and salsa. We brought our selections back to C.Beevers and chowed down. I scarfed mine because they were so good. The chips and salsa were great too. I will def come back and get some grub to go. BTW they sell beer too.

ASB was worth every cent of my $11 Uber ride from Fairmount.

Motivated by their California-centric brew event, our group of ~10 [Yelpers and friends] arrived and settled into a big booth next to the bar. For the next few hours, we managed to order most of the beers on their special list (Hey pretty Almanac! Love you, Ballast Point and Alesmith!) while also getting a taste of their regular food menu.

I went with the pulled pork sandwich. Definitely not my usual meal choice, but theirs was pretty interesting in its own way. As Steph S. put it, the sandwich somehow paralleled a cheesesteak in taste. I liked it!

After eating, some of us went outside for a bit. It was a cool night, their fire pits were ablaze and the bar was decorated colorfully with classic lights. So nice.

Point Breeze isn't a neighborhood I visit all too often, but I'd be happy to return and explore more of ASB's menu and draft choices in the future!

Spectacular pizza! I usually get takeout. 
Pizza here is awesome. Crispy crust. I love the sauce on top with the cheese underneath it. The sauce is tangy and wonderful. Usually get sausage and broccoli rabe. 
It's a tad pricey, but it is great great pizza.

My boyfriend and I were around this area looking for a place to eat. He enjoys meat, and this place had good reviews so we came here to try it out!!
We are so glad we were able to give this place a try. It has a different vibe than any other restaurants I've ever been to. It is in a garage but the owner renovated it to a restaurant (at least that's what I think).
Parking was relatively very easy to find but there are also parking in front of the restaurant. 
Once you step in, there is seating by the "bar" and tables on the side. There is a rack to hang your coats on. On Thursdays, they have a AYCE buffet for $12! And additional $8 for half a rack of ribs. I don't have a big stomach so I usually share a meal with my boyfriend and we get an appetizer on the side. (We had chick-fil-A 2 hours before) so I was even less hungry!
Today, we had the baby back- ribs platter. 
The meat was so tender, it fell off the bones!! It was delicious yummmmy!!
The fries were great, and so was the coleslaw. 
The corn bread was different from any other corn bread I've tried. It seems like there was honey or maple syrup of some sort drizzled on top making it even more delicious.
The staff here is incredibly attentive and nice. Dan was our host and he was very very nice. He was always attentive making sure we were doing good. Additionally, there was a group of men sitting on the table next to us. And I remember someone ordered baby back but to him, it seemed as if it were spare ribs. And another worker(?) or host(?) was seriously the sweetest. He didn't even argue and said the customer is always right. And not even in a rude way. But he was super sweet, took the plate back and brought another plate! From my experience as a customer, no one was ever that sincere. But Dan and the mystery man!!! Deke, if you read this or hear from this, you have yourself an amazing staff.
Generally your average Chinese takeout spot, nothing we ordered was note worthy, nor was it bad

Lactose-intolerant people of Indy, rejoice! BRICS has dairy-free options that will knock your socks off. Although not listed on the menu, I asked the server and they had three options hidden in the back. There was coconut, turtle and a choco-chip cherry option. I liked the sounds of all three, but went for the choco-chip cherry. For something without dairy it was even better than what was in the counter freezer (I know because I snuck in a few bites from my dates waffle bowl).

Had I been able to really indulge in true ice cream, I would have chosen pistachio or the 3X caramel.

The decor echoes the history of the Monon Trail right outside the store's backdoor. The colors are cheerful and the safe is friendly. The entire store, including restroom, was very clean.

We chose to eat inside, because little critters have really taken a liking to me as a snack this summer. Otherwise I would have had my treat on the spacious patio this fine summer evening.

This was my first visit to BRICS and I will be back!

Who isn't a fan of shake shack? I guess vegans, vegetarians, and those that can't eat red meat in excess. Still, I think there could be an option for a few of those guys here! Shake shack is like the cadillac of fast food restaurants - it's quick and carry to your table style, but the food isn't greasy or waiting for you when you walk in the door. Don't get me wrong, this meal is heavy and calorie-filled but it's worth it. I am a fan of the fries - nothing wrong with the crinkle cut - the shack burger and the shroom burger. All great options. I've never had one of the custards or milkshakes because they're too heavy from the looks of it, but they look phenomenal! Love this place!

I love this place. Its much nicer at night though when the darkness covers all the flaws of the area. This is a great place for people who don't know how to skate at all. I've always had a blast here. Its near by the water so the temperatures are significantly lower here. Come prepared, wear layers and it'll serve too purposes. It'll keep you warm and keep you from getting hurt when you fall. 

The lobby has some good hot chocolate if you need a break and want to warm up. They also have games for people who don't want to skate and even Karaoke! 

This is a good place to bring a date or come with a group of people who can't skate. Its fun to watch everyone fall. The pros usually skate in the middle of the rink while newcomers stay to the edges to hold on for dear life. It does get crowded on some theme nights such as Valentines day when the ice is colored red and slow music is playing. Its very romantic if that's what you're looking for. 

Most importantly, its affordable and fun.
Can't wait for the blacken fish its going to rock OMG. We should all go that night to support them
Ice cream is great tasting! Got their milkshake and it was good but next time will get just ice cream scoops.

We read some pretty good reviews of this place, and a friend said the sushi is good, but to be aware that the atmosphere leaves something to be desired. After having dinner there, I'm in agreement that while the food is really good, the service and ambiance are not so great.

When we arrived, there was no one behind the host desk, and when the hostess finally did see us, she almost seemed to wave us off. It took us a while to get a table since they were pretty full.

After finally getting a table, it took a while for someone to come take our order for the all-you-can-eat sushi, and some more time for the food to arrive. Fortunately, they were pretty good about refilling water and such, but I think they're just understaffed. It was a full house, but there were only three servers taking care of all the tables.

Atmosphere-wise, it's not very pretty. The interior looks a bit worn, and they seem to throw things together as needed. Some random pieces of artwork here and there. The bathroom is pretty clean, but just room for one. Fairly reasonable for the size of the restaurant, though.

All of this said, I will say that the food is quite good. The sushi is fresh, and the rolls are tasty. I'm also a fan of their green tea ice cream. Their all-you-can-eat sushi is $21, which is a really good price.

Overall, not bad if you want some good sushi at a good price, but be prepared to wait. And... probably not the best for a first date.

The manager, not the food, was the highlight of my visit, unfortunately for me. The manager greeted us, a group of eight, at the door, and was helpful and friendly the whole time. 

The food spoiled the experience for me: I had their Quarter White with a quarter piece chicken, corn, squash casserole, and corn bread. The service staff did not give me a choice between wing and leg, and for over $8, I expected a better value. Corn bread was barely warm and hard around the edges, but chicken was hot and juicy. 
Here's my main beef: I expected more, judging by all the love from my colleagues and the name recognition, but when all was said and done, I left with a 'this is it??' kind of impression.

Nice ambience and clean shop, I just wish they had proven me wrong in thinking it must be "just another chain restaurant."

I would not consider going back.

We decided to try the chophouse because of the reviews and my husband wanted a good steak.

The building is small, the dining room only has about 10 tables and seating at the bar. They do not take reservations or call aheads. So if it's the weekend be prepared to wait. In warmer weather they do have out door seating too.

Hands down 5 stars on the food. However the hostess was not very friendly, service was just so so and the ladies room was completely trashed. So 4 stars is the best it could get for this visit.

Excellent ribeye steak, tremendous flavor without being overly fatty. Good sear on the outside, but still juicy. No need to even touch the sauce. The sea bass was very good, thick cut by still tender and moist. 

The ingredients were fresh, flavors well paired and quality meal for the price. The house salad and warm bread rolls were wonderful too. 

We left satisfied and were very pleased with the food and experience. I highly recommend dining here when you're in town.

I came here because of the hype. I left here.. unhappy.

I am sure the food is delicious, but when it is not made to order or it is sitting out in warming trays, it can't stay delicious forever.

I am assuming because this place has a usual influx of people, they can make the food move, but the day we went... not the case. 

It looks cafeteria style, but you actually order up by the cashier and sit down to have the food brought to you from behind the cafeteria-style counter.  They will make your drinks at the cashier, but not tell you to come get them (we had no idea).

we also had no idea you had to order at the cashier's until we saw a bunch of other people doing it (mind you, we were starving at this point)

The bread pudding tastes like Paul Deens, the green beans with tomato were delicious - but had been out for awhile  (or at least tasted like it), the shrimp creole was reheated  (NOT delicious)... and the red beans and rice were too salty.

overall, we were unhappy with the atmosphere (the staff was not friendly at all - it was like we should be thankful they stopped their conversation to take our order)

the place was dingy and ... it didn't feel clean to eat there.

How have I not reviewed this place before now?  

We found Piccolo Trattoria one night when I was craving Italian and have been going there for years.  The food is always fresh and tasty, the staff friendly (albeit sometimes slow - but not enough to make me lower my rating). And the cannoli the best I've had in this area!!

We loved it here so much that we decided to have our going away party here recently. This was the only place (of the 5 we called) that could accommodate the 30+ people who would be coming and going and ordering off the menu.  We didn't want to have a set menu, and the staff did awesome taking care of everyone and there were no complaints about service or the food.

If you're in the area I highly recommend stopping in.

Every city needs an old school, 24 hour diner for those about to be hungover and those hoping to recover alike.  St. Louis, Uncle Bill's is your place if your the type who likes to wander from a 3am dive bar to a 24 hour dive diner.

I've been here a few times and love breakfast.  The waitresses are pros, making sure your cup is full of cold water and hot coffee.  Your food will come quickly and your coffee mug will stay full as long as you linger in your booth.

Nothing and nobody is pretentious here.  The food is straight forward classic American fare.  I opt for corn beef hash with biscuits and gravy on the side.  

Now, doesn't your head feel better just reading this?  Time for another cocktail!

Tiny place with great brunch menu. Brunch menu served till 4pm post which dinner menu is served.
Sells freshly baked bread and desserts!! Everything bread was really good. 
Sweet crepes with raspberry jam and berries was good. Would taste even better with Nutella which was an option too. Egg Benedict on sourdough with mashed potatoes was the best I have ever had. It was so flavorful and the bread gave a very good taste. Ended the meal with creme brûlée which again was very fresh and sweetness was perfect to my taste.

So after photos at Sears we swung up here to try this place for lunch. It's normally packed, so we were pleased to find it not too crowded. 

Let's start with what we liked:
Fresh salad bar, great waitress Diane, blueberry lemonade, full sized burgers.

What we didn't like:
Clueless hostess who seats everyone directly next to each other when whole restaurant is empty. Blue Cheese salad dressing that was yellow from sitting out. Totally overcooked mini burgers.

This was a first trip so I'll keep the review to highlights. Ask for Diane, she was great. Refills arrived super promptly of everything, and free refills included the fruit lemonades. The salad bar was great, although the dressings had been sitting out for a while hence the yellow top layer on the blue cheese. Burgers come with unlimited french fries, too.
