This was my first taste from an El Limon restaurant, and I have to say it was very good from atmosphere through loud post almuerzo belching. 

We were the only patrons in the shop when we arrived on Friday afternoon around 2.  There were three women in the store, two sitting at a table in front who quickly stood and took us to a table and distributed menus. The third was in the open kitchen toward the back with a very large ladle stirring something is a mega-gallon pot on the stove. 

The room is decorated a la Mexicana, with bright paint everywhere. Otherwise, the tables/chairs were utilitarian.  The two page menu offered lunch and dinner, with a little space for desert. I appreciated that there were sopas and tortas along with the standard burritos and tacos. 

The refrigeration unit was full of Mexican sodas and homemade huaracha.  We stuck with water and lime, and ordered torta al pastor and tacos pescados. Somewhat surprising that there were no chips and salsa offered gratis for the table, but required a $4 charge. Never saw that in the many other shops I have dined in around the USA, nor even in the homeland. I guess that works for them.

Anyway, the meals were quite good. The tacos were full of lightly fried tilapia, onion, cilantro slung in hot tortillas.  Three were more than enough with sharing, especially with the accompanying rice and beans. The torta was even more engorged with pit fired strips of pork, tomato, cilantro and their own spicy mayonnaise, on a fresh large soft roll.  Delicioso! 

El Limon does a nice balancing act between authentic Mexican fast food and the American palate. They understand their customers are from both worlds. 

If they found a way to provide the chips and salsa in the traditional way, rather than to enhance their bottom line, this local chain would make my short list of favorite casas Mexicanas.

This is the Rite kind of place!

Buy one get one free days are in full swing here!

Arriba!

Need to stock up on hydrogen peroxide or batteries or jelly beans?

This is the Rite Time!

Disclaimer: I do not smoke cigars. (Or anything! Are you reading these, future employers?) BUT, I absolutely love the smell of cigars AND my dad is a huge cigar aficionado, so I always stop in this place when I'm in Nola just to get a whiff and a gift for dear ol' dad. 

As a cigar noob, I basically just walk in and wander aimlessly. Luckily, a knowledgable and kind employee always offers to assist me right away. The staff here is so great. They're smart but not snobby. They really know what they're talking about, and I never feel like I'm being duped. 

The coolest part of this spot is watching them make cigars in-house. The rolling process is absolutely fascinating. It's worth stopping in to watch for a few minutes even if you don't smoke! Just look at the hands of the older men who have been hand rolling cigars their whole lives. Those hands tell a story, and it's fascinating in a lovely way. 

You can find some great gifts for the cigar lover in your life here. Whether you want just an inexpensive cigar to smoke after a night at the bar tonight or if you wanna drop a couple hundo on a swanky gift for a groom-to-be, a new dad, or whatever occasion it is ("Congrats on making it through a Wednesday!"), you can find something for every appreciator of cigars here! It's conveniently located in the heart of the Quarter on Canal, so pop in while you're shopping or bar hopping. Have fun!

Oh Taco Bus! Why must I only crave you in the evening? The evenings that is already dark and no one is around but a few friendly faces? 

You can never go wrong with taco bus. 
Tacos, burritos... Oh and the ceviche! They are all delicious. People go here solely for their tacos but I have to recommend the ceviche. It's definitely scrumptious. It's basically seafood that is slightly cooked with lime. Fresh and made to order.

Joto was my go-to sushi spot when I first moved here almost 20 years ago.  Then, it was just a sushi joint, with sushi done well.  Now a hundred more sushi spots have opened in Tampa, and Joto's now offers Thai food as well as sushi, but whenever I go, it's still just for the sushi.

I have tried a wide variety of sushi and sashimi here, and my favorite item is the sashimi dinner platter.  A large, varied selection of incredibly fresh seafood.  I don't necessarily eat rolls enough to have a favorite roll here, but the dragon roll which came on the Love Boat (sushi and sashimi dinner for two) was really good.

The atmosphere is clean, if dark, and service is very friendly.  A good, solid option if you are in the mood for no-frills sushi.

I tweaked my neck on the plane during my flight to New Orleans...the first thing I did when I got to my hotel was to search nearby massage.  Tao didn't disappoint.  I had a 30min chair massage and the masseuse honed in on the trouble shoulder and went to work.  She was not gentle which is exactly what I wanted.  I have a feeling I'll be back everyday during my conference.  I brought the $5 off coupon from their website and they looked confused by it but accepted it.

This restaurant appeared to be well maintained and clean and was recommended by a  local for the their gumbo.

It was not very hard to get seated and we even got our requested table by the window. 

The room has high ceilings which I have not experienced much since I arrived here in New Orleans.

Our super hospitable server recommended the Garlic Shrimp Pasta and I am glad I took his recommendation because, Oh my popsicles!!!, that was some really good shrimp, pasta and sauce!

The complimentary bread was oh so good and fresh fresh fresh.

The restroom is located in the outdoor courtyard, in the back, and as a warning, it's very small. And old, just like the city itself.

Come for the chicken gumbo, stay for the corn maque choux. I only wish I ordered more of these two dishes. The service was impeccable and the drinks were never empty. I would gladly come back for the ambience and hospitality. Do yourself a favor, sit in the courtyard, and take in the beauty!

OVER.RATED. Wicked long wait for expensive, mediocre food. Only good thing was the bartender! 

I might ruffle some feathers on this one, but I was seriously disappointed by this place. It came highly recommended by 2 people who live locally, so a friend and I decided to try. We got there about 6 on a Wednesday night and the place was packed. The hostess was rude telling us the wait was 45 minutes and then expecting us to leave. I'm willing to wait for good food so I was already turned off by her attitude.

We waited in the waiting area (why aren't these turned into regular tables/booths to get more people serviced?!). We ended up snagging a couple of seats at the bar. The bartender was very helpful with the menu because my friend had a hard time finding something that wasn't fried. She ended up ordering some blackened fish and I got the $9 shrimp po-boy. Her food came out great but mine was another story. 

The sandwich was about 8 inches long with lots of shrimp, two thin slices of tomato, like 1/4 cup of chopped lettuce and maybe 1tbsp of mayo. I shrugged the lack of extras on the sandwich and decided to bite in. The bread was so hard I couldn't bite it! I ended up having to ask for bread that wasn't toasted. When that came, I could see why they toasted it so much: it was so tough, the bread was like jerky! I ended up just eating the shrimp with only some of the bread. And for $9 without even fries? (Those are $2 extra.)

We both got beers too. They came in these goblets that were maybe about a pint size of liquid. The beer was $8! Seriously? Once we got our checks we left to go someone else for drinks. 

Bottom line: stay away if you're looking for good food.

We came in with friends on the opening weekend and had a great time.  All the cocktails, appetizers, pasta dishes, and desserts we ordered were delicious.  We did not have the pizza or meat/fish dishes.

APPS -- Really liked the Oysters Randolfi  -- 3 baked oysters dressed up with fennel, breadcrumbs, and more. ($9)  The fennel really stood out and made this unique,  The house salad ($7) was different looking, using iceberg lettuce as little cups or something.  The Italian dressing really made it shine.  Next was the burrata -- soft mozzarella cheese over cucumber and herbed oil.  This was a nice portion size and perfect for spreading on the complimentary bread. Just remember to mix it all together before you dive in.

PASTAS -- Definitely get the Meatball ($11).  This dish was delicious, well-portioned, and had a spicy kick.  It was served with some house-made noodles.  Not your typical spaghetti, these were thicker, chewier noodles and I really enjoyed them.  They reminded me of the noodles from Corner 17 next door.  I also tried some of the duck confit gnocchi and the salami pasta.  Both of them had great distinctive flavors.  The portion sizes of these two was on the small side, so keep that in mind if you have a large appetite.

DESSERTS -- It is rare for me to order dessert, but the choices were just too appealing to skip.  I tried two. One of them used strawberries, basil, and house-made ricotta.  Every bite (there weren't many) was heaven.  Also really enjoyed another one involving a chocolate torte, cherries, and house-made mascarpone. 

COCKTAILS -- If you're a cocktail nerd, you'll love the offerings here.  Each choice has a complexity-rating of 1-10 shown on the menu.  I thought that was a nice touch.  I got the #37 ($11), a bourbon-ginger liqueur concoction with cherry and smoke-infusion over ice.  It was a nice-sized drink, very well-balanced and actually seemed to pair well with the food.   And at the end, there's a nice little bonus of 2 alcohol-infused cherries to nibble on.  I tried 2 other cocktails and both were outstanding.

Our server was nice and friendly and had a good knowledge of the menu. The place had a cool atmosphere and the use of music was done just right.  Definitely looking forward to coming back and trying out other stuff.

Peacemaker Po Boy - fried oyster and fried shrimp with spiced mayo. 

Charbroiled oysters - fresh off the grill and topped with butter and parm cheese. Served with bread to soak up that butter.

Fried crab claws - mini claws battered and deep fried. Order this and you won't be disappointed. 

Great service and fast - we came on a Monday during lunch.

This cafe is in a decent location downtown but by no means what I would call where the action is at. All the same it fine. Same merchandise you find at any of their other locations except the merchandise will say Nashville on them.

My friend who is an Australian living in the Galapagos came for a quick visit and we met up here. The restaurant is currently going through some renovations, which didn't bother us. Fortunately, we were seated in a booth which made the noise level more bearable.  Although we came at 5:30 PM, there was no mention of a happy hour by any of the staff, which was a shame.

Anyway, she was really intrigued by everything she had read about the vaulted CHEESESTEAK. Had I known that, we probably wouldn't have chosen this place :-)  But they had one on the menu, just as a cheesesteak hoagie. Then she asked, "What's a hoagie?"  Oh jeez. Well, she loved it!  We lied and told her because there was lettuce on top of her meat that it was a healthy choice - hahaha. She ate every bit on her plate, including the giant mound of french fries (aka "chips"). She couldn't believe the size of the plate or the amount of food included.

I opted for the plate of nachos - very tasty, and hit the spot. 

Service was pretty good, although we had to chase down our server for more drinks as we finished ours off pretty quickly.

I'd like to try to come back for burgers.

I have been here many times and had good experiences.  However, my last three interactions were terrible, to the point I vowed never to return.  I've giving two stars only because they have a good selection of items and carry a lot of locally produced goods.

I tried grocery delivery. My food was clearly sitting for a while or in an unrefrigerated van.  My frozen goods were soft and my meat was close to room temperature.  I had checked the box to allow substitutions.  However, the substitutions were just weird. They kept the brands and substituted the flavors.  So pepperocini Kettle Chips were replaced with chile verde Kettle Chips.  Tyson buffalo wings were replaced with Tyson BBQ wings. I called to complain and to their credit, the woman I spoke with gave me a $40 credit on my order. 

I tried curbside pickup.  I ordered two kinds of fish, frozen shrimp, and crab sticks.  I ordered the day before for 7 p.m. pickup.  I received a message in early afternoon that they shopped my items.  However, when I arrived, they said they were out of the fish I ordered.  When I asked why this wasn't conveyed sooner, they had no response, and seemed vaguely amused that I was frustrated. 

Finally, I tried going inside.  It was a Saturday morning, but not too many cars outside.  In theory, their procedures are safe.  But in practice, one employee outside near the entrance wasn't wearing a mask.  Another inside by the registers had his mask pulled down below his nose. They had helpful one-way signage, but no one was enforcing it and shoppers were going where ever they wanted. The checkout lines took longer than they have any previous time I have been there.  Finally, the self checkout lines will not allow you to scan your items until you enter your rewards number.  I couldn't get mine to work, so I couldn't ring up my groceries without assistance.  I was completely frazzled by the time I left. 

It is a shame, they have a great produce selection, as well as cheese and seafood.  But it is not worth the headache.  They used to be so customer centered, but I didn't see much evidence of it lately.

I was browsing around on the net before heading out to my little day trip to Santa Barbara and I came across San Ysidro Ranch. Apparently JFK honeymooned here and it's known to be quite secluded and beautiful. How can I read that and not check it out right??? 

We had a late lunch so we just went to the Plow and Angel for drinks so we can check out the grounds/bar. Plow and Angel itself is very quaint and lovely. The bartendar gave me a few different wines to try and I ended up going with one of their Chardonnay's which I'm not generally fond of drinking. It was pretty good though and strong!!! I was  pretty buzzed before my dessert came out. LOL! Add some sips of beer and tada! Buzzed CJ. haha

Valrhona Chocolate cheesecake is delish!!! Very rich yet subtle if that makes any sense. Orange accents, tangerine sorbet on top, and a little raspberry sauce. MmMmm!!!! 

The one thing I did notice before I left was that they had dessert wines on the dessert menu. I had initially asked for a sweeter wine, preferably a Moscato/Muscat wine but the bartender said they didn't have any. While checking out the dessert menu, they did have Muscat wine!!!! :( I was so sad. 

Everyone was very nice and it was a nice experience. I wish I didn't overhear some racist remarks some patrons said to our bartender but I won't go into that here. Other than the last two points, it was FABULOUS! :)

I'm surprised that I never stopped at the DD over the years.   Nothing special about the fare here.   The service is very polite and they will even ask you how much cream cheese you want on your bagel.   The coffee here was blazing hot and fresh.

There is no drive-thru.   Exiting along the side street (it's on a corner) is challenging as it is a road divided by a small veteran's memorial park.

Delicious local ice cream. Vibe is good. The ice cream is sooo delicious. For a company that's been around for over 30 yrs, their flavor profiles are fresh and new. I'm a sucker for earl grey anything, and their early grey + biscuits was to die for. 

Love craft ice cream. And this was probably it before it ever was.

Time for a city tour of NOLA from the comfort of an air conditioned van.  It was freakin' hot, so I had no issues just riding along.  Some people might prefer more time at some of these sights.  In that case, take a different tour.

This was a nice way to see different parts of the city.  My favorite portions of the tour were the Lower Ninth Ward and the Garden District.  On one hand you had the people most impacted by Katrina and on the other hand you had celebrity homes and grand mansions.  The sad part about the Lower Ninth Ward was seeing people sitting on their front porches just watching these tour buses drive by.  I'd be curious to know if these tour companies do anything for the neighborhoods they are profiting off of.

The least favorite portion of the tour was probably the French Quarter.  I felt the "sights" mentioned were basically the advertisers with the tour company.  For example, it was suggested we eat at Huck Finn's at least three different times during the tour.  They even dropped us off there at the end to catch our afternoon swamp tour.

Please note that you are in the van the entire time except for one stop at a cemetery and a stop at the New Orleans visitors center.  Overall it was informative and introduced me to some new things to check out when I return on a future visit (we were leaving the next day).

We booked two tours (city and swamp) to get a discount.  For my review of the swamp tour, you can search for Cajun Encounters Swamp Tours, LLC in zip code 70461.

I learned about the amazing Nanzhou Hand Drawn Noodle House from Yelp. It just goes to show that Yelp reviews by and large are a great resource.

We tried the hand-drawn and shaved noodles with braised beef and pork. They were great. The broth was favorful, the noodles fresh and tender yet just chewy enough. I think I could eat here daily. 

We (two) ate here, got stuffed and run up a whopping $16 bill.

Definitely not the best sushi I've had, but it fits the sushi needs. The restaurant is quiet, and the service is slow. But they have the fish and the right rolls and hibachi.

I ordered the seaweed salad, summer roll (nix the ponzu), and blue fin fatty tuna sashimi. The seaweed salad was standard. The summer roll was fresh and healthy. The sashimi was absolutely teeny...not worth getting. 

Nothing terrible about this spot, but nothing to rave about either I guess.

Update...

They have added more items to their buffet every day, and its all delicious! 

I work literally down the street. My co-workers talk about this place quite often. Late lunch, starving, wanted something quick and fast. The restaurant is pretty spacious, but the buffet area needs more space. It has good selections, just cramped in a corner. Love that fresh naan is dropped to our table. Everything was delicious! I'm not an Indian food connoisseur so I can't tell you if it's authentic or not. It was just good. And at $10 per person, that's a deal!

Woo! Who would've thought the ramen here would be so good? There was about a 30 min wait at 8pm on a Friday night, which wasn't too bad. They took our number so we just waited at a bar down the block. 

We were really only interested in trying the ramen so we ordered both the miso and brisket bowls. To me, a bowl of ramen is judged by its broth and meat, and both bowls hit home runs in that department. The miso bowl was very rich and flavorful, while the brisket bowl was more spicy with a kick of kimchi. The brisket bowl came with a matzah ball, which I found strange... I didn't care much for it, but it did soak up the broth fairly well. The eggs they put in both bowls were really soft.. like not just runny yolk, but runny erythang.. Only the miso bowl came with the egg; the brisket bowl required an add on ($2 for an egg smh..)

All in all, would definitely come back for ramen fix.
Thought it very good food.  Slow service, so prepare for that but food was very good .  Add onions and mushrooms to your Philly steak... Customer service is not their forte but food is !!

My last visit was disappointing. They used to have selections that appealed a lot more. I tend to want the low fat, sugar free options. They used to have a pecan something that was all these things and super creamy. My last visit, that flavor was gone and a weak raspberry option was icy and not creamy at all. Understand this is subjective, we all have our taste palates and personal preferences so I will go back and see if my next visit is a more positive experience. Last summer, I was a regular, mostly because of this one delicious flavor.

I honestly have never sat at the bar here - this is our place whenever we go to Lambertville/New Hope in the spring/summer/fall for lunch so we can sit outside on the patio.  The sandwiches are always phenomenal, they have a very strong beer selection, and I have always had great service here.
Solid vegetarian options at this great music spot featured on a Bourdain Layover ep.

I will never be back here. Tonight was my second visit to Dim Sum Garden and I'm utterly appalled with the waitstaff and their etiquette. I'm FAR from the "boujee" my waiter needs to tend to my every need type patron...I like little to no attention so I can chit chat with my girlfriends and spend the majority of my time stuffing my face.

We ordered some appetizers, ate said appetizers, and literally had to FLAG down our waiters to order more food. (Waiters in plural because we literally had two but got zero attention). It was like they brought us the food and forgot we existed. We may as well should've been invisible.  This was just the start of my frustration...we placed the order and the majority of the food came out, except for mine and my friend's. My friend's food then came out. Mine didn't. We reminded them about the sweet and sour chicken that we had ordered. Fast forward to 8:30 pm...mind you we sat at 6:30 pm, the sweet and sour chicken comes out. By this time we didn't friggin want it, so my friend says we aren't paying for that chicken. The bill comes, the chicken is on the bill. After much argument, they removed it from the bill and made a point to take the chicken away rather than letting us box it up to take home for the huge inconvenience they caused us. It was actually the most annoying and disrespectful action I've ever experienced from a waiter at dinner. 

If I wrote this review after my first visit, they probably would've gotten a 4 or 5 stars, now however I'm disgusted with this place and will NOT be back. There are dozens of other dim sum spots in Philly...take my advice and go there.

I really want to love El Vez. In typical Steven Starr fashion, the restaurant is dressed to impress, the food is pretty good, and the margaritas are outstanding.

But the service just doesn't cut it, especially given the prices on the menu. I've been here twice now, and both times the servers didn't seem too interested in my table. I shouldn't feel the need to obnoxiously flag someone down for another drink or for a napkin.

At my last visit, we waited forever for the bill. One person wanted a separate check. The server asked if anyone else wanted a separate check, waited all of ten seconds for an answer and then huffed off only to return fifteen minutes later with the bill. 

Let's put this in perspective. I'm paying $13 for guacamole. $13. You can get the same exact amount and quality for less at so many other places, but because it gets served up in a giant stone bowl and because it's El Vez, you get upcharged and everyone worships it. I love me some guac, but I've seriously gotten a tub of made-at-Whole Foods guac for $6, and it's just as good. I mean really, it doesn't exactly require chef-level skill to make and to make well.

So, $13 guac. No happy hour specials. Food that is, in typical Steven Starr fashion, pricey because hey you pay for the ambience. All that for uninterested and barely competent service. 

Eh.

Came in on a Thursday afternoon to a fairly empty restaurant, but I heard how crazy it gets sometimes! (Be sure to make a reservation to be on the safer side!)

The lemon poppy pancakes were the BEST that I've ever had. It was not too sweet but I still didn't have to add any syrup! The lemon flavor was very strong -- definitely satisfied my lemon pancake cravings. The short stack is $8 and the full stack is $11. I was full off getting the short stack with a side of bacon.

Their savory options here are great too. Pretty hefty dishes with a lot of flavor. 

Drinks here are decent. The iced drinks are served in a cute little mason jar that's garnished with some sugar on the rim. Super aesthetic! 

Service was kind, friendly and fairly quick. I'm excited to come back next time!
Good place for a quick in and out of items you may have forgotten or ran out of at the house. It is clean and has good customer service. They are always happy to help find an item.

After a week of fried heavy Louisiana food, I was ready for something else. Well no, not really, I was just too hot and tired to walk to another restaurant. But BOY am I glad I stumbled in here!

Well air conditioned and comfortably decorated, I was greeted by some awesome staff and tasty chips and salsa. By recommendation of my server, I had a watermelon cocktail and the crawfish fajitas. I'm usually not big on crawfish because I haven't mastered shelling those suckers, but when they're all ready shelled? Bring em on!  At $15, yum yum yum.  

I was feel in pretty good after that strong watermelon cocktail, paid my bill, again DONT FORGET TO TIP, and headed back up Esplanade to catch the street car down town.

We decided to stop in for a few cocktails and to grab a bite to eat - rum runners and margaritas $5.50 damn Scott the bartenders are giving away the farm lol thank you sir they were delicious. Yes Virginia it is possible to get a buzz on well liquor - if you're wondering what's to follow well it's a really tragedy - humidity killed the individual packets of salt and pepper since we can't social distance using a real salt shaker someone needs to figure this one out, you can't serve homemade chips without salt.

The atmosphere - even with social distancing is manageable and not bad especially outside on one of the decks, everyone entering the property seems to be wearing a mask - the staff definitely did 100% of the time during our visit. If possible grab a table water side the breeze off the water really stifles the Florida humidity and provides a great unobstructed view.

Staff - very friendly and professional and plentiful even with the limited capacity rules in place everyone seemed to work together. The kitchen seemed to get the food out in a reasonable time and our server was on top of things so no complaints here.

Jack's Chicken Sandwich - We had the southern fried version and it was delicious a real quality chicken sandwich fresh ingredients and well constructed - I'd do this one again and again and again.

House Grouper Sandwich - We chose the blackened version - such a modest name, make no mistake this is deliciousness on a bun. The toasted bun makes it an exceptional choice if you like grouper.

House Chips - our we're served a little cold and I mentioned a number of times lacked seasoning so we thought they were bland - I could see that they have potential but I'd probably pass on the next visit.

Over-all we had a great time and a great meal and hope to return when we are back in the area - Good Job Capt'n Jack's...

Great place for a fancy NOLA treat - come in on a hot day to taste the many flavors of gelato. They are all rich, creamy and unique - really great quality here! Flavors included basil coconut, pistachio, toasted almond and so many more I wanted to try! I imagine in the winter a nice hot chocolate and macaron would be quite nice.

Have you ever been trying to kill a spider and end up trying to light it on fire and soon your entire bedroom is engulfed in flames and all that can cross your mind is "This was a mistake"?  That's how I feel about this place.

Mother's came highly recommended, based off the fact that it was apparently featured on a Travel Channel food show of some sort.  And let me just say...why?

Rant begin:

So I don't mind the line.  The line is not an issue.  Some people may think that a line guarantees quality, but having lived around the LA food scene I can very much guarantee you it does not.  But as lines go, this wasn't a long wait, even if it looks like one.

I don't mind that service was a little weird.  Now no one working here seemed like bad people, but it's a definite culture shock coming from California where service is apparently super friendly and then in NOLA it's just sort of "I'll help you, but I don't have to like it".  Nothing for me to get angry at, just a bit of a shift.  But that's still not the problem.

The problem was the Ferdi Special.  I'm going to be here possibly once in my life, I'm going to go for the Ferdi Special because it's at the top of the menu and it is a specialty of Mother's.  Therefore, this is them saying "This is our best effort, enjoy".  And...

Who in their right mind looked at "Au Jus" and seriously thought "Hey, you know that runny, wet sauce people like to dip roast beef sandwiches into?  Hear me out, let's puddle it onto the bottom of the plate and let the sandwich just sit in it.  Just let it swim in those juices.  Just let that bread soak it all in and disintegrate before your very eyes.  Because that's what sandwiches were made for.  They were made so you can't pick them up."  Like I'm all for open faced but sandwiches are literally made to be eaten with hands what is this?!  It's a mess.  It's a mess of salty meat.  Was it good?  No.  Not even close.  I came in wanting a nice hot meal and I get half of a sandwich and it's not very good.  And just so I'm clear, this wasn't a bit of soggy bread.  This bread was full on paste by the time it got to me.  You CAN'T pick it up, it just crumbles into goop.

And part of me wants to give them the benefit of the doubt and say "Well maybe they have good gumbo or something" but this was the specialty at the top of the menu!  If I went to an actual mother's house and said "Cook me your specialty" and they're all "Okay, let me make you some delicious meatloaf" and the meatloaf comes out and it's made of paper towels and used syringes you don't get a chance to offer me some soup.  You had your shot and squandered it.

I give them two stars because there is still care and hope for this business and obviously someone must like it, and the food wasn't inedible I suppose.  But the Ferdi Special is not the way to go.  Some other reviews might disagree, but they lie.  That's right, I'm calling you out.  You know you're valid opinion?  It's wrong.  You have a wrong opinion.  and your favorite movie isn't very good either.  I'm feeling salty.  It's probably from all the salty meat.

At the marina with a great water view, it's one of the best spots in Dunedin for very reasonably priced eats and drinks.  I met up with a few folks last week at an outside table, it's my very first time going to an establishment to dine "in" since covid started.  Not really into it yet but this place makes it quite comfortable.

Our seating was outside and the service was great!  They handed us one-time use paper menus and they wore masks.

I asked about the stone crabs, although they are always pricey, their prices were a good bit higher than what I'm used to paying in another area in Tampa Bay... so I opted for the Blue Crab stuffed Avocado.  With their kettle chips instead of crackers.  I am not a big chip fan but was told they were awesome.  They were ok, tasted like chips to me.  I'm still not a big chip fan, so next time I'd get the crackers.
The blue crab was pretty good but not ahh-mazing...

There were 5 in our party, they split the bill individually and although a couple of errors, they took the incorrect ones back without issue, fixed them and had them back to us in a jiffy.

I would come back, sit outside and enjoy this place again.

Sam's was my roommates and mine #1 source for pre-class pitchers back in the day. Class at IV theater? Totally convenient to stop here on your way! 
Good basic sanwiches too...you know, if you're into actually eating in IV.

Mediocre food at best and inattentive service. I love Indian food and when done well it always hits the spot. Unfortunately, the dinner here was forgettable and underwhelming. Since I was hungry, I hurriedly selected 3 entrees and all 3 turned out to be disappointing. All 3 dishes were served at the same time in less than 5 minutes which started me thinking that they may all be pre-cooked and just heated up to serve.

The first entree was MASALA DOSA which is a South Indian style crepe made from rice and lentils and stuffed with potatoes and onions. The potatoes were almost rancid which suggested to me that the stuffings were definitely not fresh and prepared awhile ago. So even though the crepe tasted crunchy, the potatoes spoilt the whole dish!

The second entree I guess was an Indian classic MURG (CHICKEN) CURRY which I always use as a barometer to test how good their curry was. The flavor was just ok with chunks of dark meat chicken and nothing else. It was too garlicky for me and certainly failed to impress.
The third entree was a rice plate MURG BIRYANI which was made with Basmati rice with chunks of dark meat chicken, onions, nuts and raisins. The rice tasted like leftover rice and was bland with no kick that one can expect from Indian food. 

Service was sorely lacking. The Indian lady (owner?) was a lady with few words who quickly took my orders and was never to be seen or heard again. Water was never refilled and no one bothered to check on the dinners. I did notice as one yelper previously commented that the help did act like indentured slaves which I thought was quite amusing.

I may give this restaurant another chance but probably not any time soon.

I LOVE Drago's! I first went there for diner last year during my visit for Mardi Gras season last year. I was so sick that year, but the food was still so good. I couldn't wait to go back this year when my tastebuds were working right. And I was not disappointed. 
I ordered the same dish I did last time. I could tell by the texture a year ago the food was really good and could actually slightly taste the corn dish. It pained me to not be able to fully taste such good food. The dish was Drago's Mixed Grill: Half of a Maine lobster, a petit filet, and blackened shrimp with a light Cajun cream sauce, served with corn maque choux and potatoes (from the menu). 
My waiter was Dipen, and he was wonderful. He was so polite and attentive. Made sure I had everything I needed. The service was perfect.
The filet was cooked to a perfect medium-rare, just as I'd requested. The lobster was delicious and delicate. Loved the potatoes and corn--the corn had a bit of a spicy kick to it. It was just a beautiful meal that was perfectly cooked and seasoned. The steak was like butter. I knew I'd missed out due to my illness the year before but didn't realize how much! It was one of the most delectable dinners I had in NOLA. Like I always say, it's hard to get a bad meal in New Orleans.
The dining room is comfortable and had a nice atmosphere. For once, I wasn't asked to sit at the bar because I was dining alone, and I REALLY appreciated that. I had my own little cushy booth. I didn't think the price was bad either. It was pretty much what I'd expect to pay for lobster and steak. 
This restaurant is in a hotel but Drago's is away from the lobby enough to seem like a separate entity. If you want an upscale dinner that tastes amazing, maybe want to treat yourself a bit, make sure you eat here. I certainly will be returning next year when I visit for Mardi Gras 2021. 
I want to try the chargrilled oysters next time. I hate to admit I've never eaten oysters and don't think I could do the raw ones, but I need to step off the ledge next year and try the chargrilled ones.

This was the best meal we've had on this Nawlins visit, we thoroughly enjoyed the crawfish quartet, when our personable waiter told us the soup of the day was crawfish bisque...we joyously changed our order to a quintet.  Fried mudbugs,  crawfish au gratin, crawfish croquettes and fried crawfish tails.  We'll be visiting Deanie's the next time we vacation in Nawlins and there will be a next time 'cause we like to eat great food and this city may be one of the best places on this planet for foodies...we haven't had any average or mediocre meals in this town.

Remedy is an awesome cafe and very popular with Edmontonians. They have lots of comfortable seating and the atmosphere is cozy and welcoming so it's the perfect place to curl up with your laptop if you're needing to get some work done or to meet up with a good friend for a long chat over a delicious beverage. I always get the chai latte when I come and it's one of my favourite chai's ever, it's just as delicious with any of the alternate milks as well. They can also accommodate different dietary needs from vegan, vegetarian, gluten free, dairy free etc...

Bomb Malaysian restaurant in Chinatown.

At an event last nite and needed something to eat afterwards. Got on Yelp and found this gem a few blocks up. Ordered takeout, they were fast, super friendly and we got some people-watching in while we waited. 

I love Singaporean & Malaysian food and we had it often in California, in fact one of our favorite places was called Banana Leaf, so I was interested in seeing how this place stacked up.

Better than the original. And that's saying a lot. 

Indian MeeGoreng had so much flavor, I'm not a big noodle eater, but I finished these the next day for lunch rather than giving it up to my hub for leftovers.

Roti Canai was probably best eaten fresh vs sitting in a bag for a 20min ride home, but it was still pretty good, chewy and crisp at the same time. The sauce was a little thin and could use a bit more kick. 

Hub's Thai Basil chicken, WOW. I mean you hear 'Thai Basil Chicken' and you think, just another filler item on a way-too-long menu, but wow, the flavor off this dish was amazing. The coconut rice was honestly some of the best I've ever had, soft, flakey and packed with flavor. I snuck some of this dish onto my plate and the dog won't be getting leftovers.

Chicken Satay, again another one of those menu items we've all had and they are all vastly forgettable. Not this one. REALLY flavorful...the meat doesn't even need the thick-as-paste peanut sauce (but it's still fun to slather it on), and plentiful sized appetizer. 

Got a Malaysian iced tea to go, packed well, and it was a bit more evaporated milky tasting than I'm used to so wasn't quite a fan there but maybe it's an acquired taste.

Love love loved this place. It seriously kicked N. California's ass on flavor. Surprise.

I would say it is better than Subway but honestly, is that saying much? Truth be told, they are always friendly and clean which are good things in my book. 

Bottom line - It's a reliable spot for straightforward American sandwiches, when the mood strikes you.

It's hard to decide where to go for bubble tea once in Philadelphia's Chinatown because there is literally a place every 10 ft that makes some form of this drink. I chose to go to Mr Wish because of their unique fruit pulp teas. 

I tried a peach tea with pulp at 30% sugar. I don't typically like things that are overly sweet, but I should've gone up a bit with the sugar levels here. The peach bits were very sweet, but contrasted starkly with the rest of the tea. I regret not getting a normal milk tea.

I also got to try the matcha tea with boba. 30% sugar was really nice for the one, even a touch too sweet. It may be cold outside, but order it cold instead of warm!

It wasn't busy when we visited Casa Brazil on a Sunday evening. We did not realize until we arrived that it is BYOB but luckily there is a deli a few doors down that sells beer. The hostess was extremely nice and friendly as well as the other workers that were about. There were two TV screens playing, one was showing a soccer game (the louder of the 2 TVs) and the other side was The Matrix. The seating are small tables of about 4 but can be pushed together for bigger parties, I assume. 

We were offered openers for wine and beer and also served water. The water had to be the biggest complaint since there were particles floating at the top. We later informed them of this but our waters were never replaced, maybe because we were at the end of our meal. The buffet was decent. Really great cheesy lasagna and I loved the beans and their rice. There is also a salad bar. The meat that were out were kinda dry, I would suggest going up for the ones on skewers. If you are going for the meat skewers, I recommend the chicken hearts! They are my favorite. The meats were also nice and juicy, including the chicken. I didn't think they were overseasoned, either. 

I'm not sure how this method of going up to the server to get the meat vs them going to your table works when it is very busy, but it is definitely less stressful than having lots of servers with skewers running to your table when your card is flipped to green. We took some desserts to go, including my favorites tiramisu and tres leches. Both were very good. We will definitely be visiting again. It is very affordable and the service is nice.
limited menu cuz we had a larger group took a little long but the food was good ad the staff was nice had the chicken sandwich kinda plain. most of the group was happy

I wish this was my office. Brew/Ultimo actually makes me jealous of my Point Breeze Pioneer friend Daniel M, who gets to roll out of bed directly into geeked-out coffee, fresh, local fruit and yogurt and Four Worlds baked goods. 

When the weather is fair, the garage doors are hoisted to let the outside in, as the few irritating flies enjoying the scene attest. The vibe here is great -- I always leave positively rejuvenated from the energy and calm beauty of the space as much as my food, be it a Three Springs Fruit Farm peach or a cheddar-herb scone.

Since coffee is not my caffeine of choice, it is nice that the unsweetened iced tea is made with the same care as the pour-over black brew.  It's pleasant not to be regarded as a leper because you don't care for bean juice.

A nice, homey Main Line institution. Nothing special, but there's good service with lots of friendly smiles even when it's busy, a great atmosphere (people of all ages--high school-college students to senior citizens!), and I love the booths and diner vibe. 

The portions are pretty large, so you can definitely share or take some home for later. It's open 24/7 so I think it'd be great for making a pit stop late at night or early in the morning. There is free parking in the lot! 

The omelette I had was alright. I liked the chicken but the avocado wasn't ripe. The potatoes were just right! My friends liked their eggs and one got coffee and split pea soup she enjoyed. 

You take your receipt up to pay at the end. Definitely coming back for the old-fashioned diner vibe and aesthetic for midnight pancakes.
Fantastic service! The food (triple dipper) was actually really good, hot, and fresh (especially considering other Chilis I've frequented). $3.75 for a 22oz XX Amber was a nice surprise as well!

keller plaza is an interesting place.  you can't use debit or credit cards, it hasn't been updated since the early 1830's and it's in the middle of nowhere, BUT two people can see a late-run movie, get two boxes of candy and a bottle of water for $12. That's $2 more than the price of a single ticket back home and you don't need to take out a 2nd mortgage to get popcorn. Definitely check out Keller Plaza if there's something you missed that should be seen on the big screen.

We stopped in here on a Monday evening.  In know I'm in the minority, but I liked the Korean food here when it was Sushi Boat - it wasn't fancy, but it was authentic, and similar to stuff I had growing up; think more like at home cooking than restaurant food.

Changes seem pretty limited - looks like they're not using the old sushi counter, which had one of those conveyor belt boat systems, though it's still just sitting there on one side of the restaurant, taking up probably 20 to 25% of the floor space of the front of the house.  Sushi Boat had a small bar on the left when you came in, though it looked like it was more storage than a bar.  Rolls and Spicy have renovated this area slightly, and turned it into the sushi bar, with a half-dozen bar stools or so.  The rest of the space is the same as before, with maybe ten booths, and a few free standing tables.  

I ordered the seafood soft tofu stew (soondubu chigae), which is one of my favorite Korean dishes, and an order of hamachi since I wanted to try out the sushi.  The GF ordered some rolls.  The a la carte prices seemed dirt cheap for the sushi - nigiri was $2 or $3 for two pieces, and rolls started at $3 for things like a California roll or spicy crab, on up to around $8 for a caterpillar roll.

They had one waitress working the front of the house, and we saw a guy running around, helping out a bit here and there.  We started wondering if they were the only staff working, but we eventually did notice someone wandering around in the back - not sure if they may have had more staff hidden in the kitchen, but I doubt it.  The tables that were cluttered when we came in remained cluttered, as they didn't have the time (or perhaps the organization) to bus the tables.

My tofu stew came out, and I waited for a bit, thinking the sushi would be coming soon.  After a few minutes, the GF told me to go ahead and eat before my food went cold.  During the wait, I had been looking at my food (which came out in a standard little stone bowl), wondering if they had heard that I'd ordered the seafood version of the soondubu chigae, as I was only seeing a few scraps in it - at most Korean restaurants, you'll have some clams, a shrimp or two, and other random seafood, that you might have to pick through a bit - think like a cioppino.  While I found a few pieces of clam meat, it seemed to have come from one of those bags of mixed frozen seafood, and there might have been one, maybe two, tablespoons worth of seafood in the whole thing.  Then I tasted  the broth, which had a promising bright red color to it.  I was surprised that it had almost no flavor whatsoever, and almost no kick what-so-ever.  Bizarre.  Overall, the chigae basically seemed like it had been thrown together in five minutes, with no simmering, no making a good stock/broth ahead of time, etc.

Even more surprising was that while I was eating, the sushi was nowhere to be seen - another group or two came in (in addition to those that had come in previously), and it became obvious that tables were becoming restless - we overhead comments from other tables such as "I think they're having to kill the pig . . . " and muttered complaints as one table that came in later got banchan (Korean "appetizers") before the other table had even ordered.  I heard/saw the waitress comp the Sapporo the table that came in right after us ordered as they were having to wait so long (they didn't have any food, and they'd probably been waiting 20 or 30 minutes).  That seemed like a good gesture, except they didn't comp any other tables as far as I could tell.  As I'm finishing, the waitress comes over and says "Sorry - we've started your sushi now", with an awkward smile on her face and no explanation for the disjointed service.  At this point, it was obvious she had no experience as a waitress, and her limited English skills were such that we didn't press for an explanation.  The fact that the guy we had seen helping out front earlier left the kitchen and was now working behind the sushi bar seems to suggest he may have been trying to run the back of the house all alone.

We ended up getting the rolls and the nigiri to go, and basically got what we paid for - sushi was like what you might get at a grocery store.  GF mentioned that if she didn't have to wait, it could be okay togo, as it's so cheap.

I still want to give this place another shot, as I've heard decent things from people who've gone when no one else is there; not that that's a glowing endorsement, but I definitely crave Korean food occasionally.

As an aside, I have no idea who did their web page, but obviously not someone who's culturally sensitive.  The link to the Japanese menu at http://rollsandspicy.com/reno-nv-japanese-food-and-sushi.htm, reads "Click here to view our Rolls & Spicy Jap Menu".  In additional to the racial slur, the link is broken.

Overall, inexperienced restaurant owners/staff, uber-slow service, mediocre food, but cheap, serviceable sushi

I'm so glad we've stumbled upon this gem! It's been open for 2 days and already has numerous fans! Full of sours, IPAs, stouts, & more! There is something for everyone! Hungry? Check out the food truck outside.

This place is still one of my favorites! 

My friends and I came here for dinner a few sundays ago.

We started out by ordering a plate of dirty fries -- possibly some of the most addictive things on earth!  The last time I had them prior to this visit,  I took them with me on the plane and I made the flight attendant drool with the smell. We were all very hungry and DEVOURED them. I almost stabbed our poor waitress in the hand trying to get the last morsel of dirty fries!

I ordered their version of sheperd's pie. It was a strange combination but definitely grew on me over the meal. My boyfriend got a burger and loved it. Fellow yelper Armita R just got the junior burger but she said it was perfect! It's really impressive when a place can make something super simple really good. 

What I think is wonderful and amazing is the IDK option on the menu. I'm that annoying person that sends the waiter away 3x before the table can order because I can NEVER decide what I want to eat! Amrita R's bf got the IDK and it was fabulous! They were testing out a new menu item and I loved it! 

I can't wait to come back (but I need to exercise some more first)

Padre stopped here on his way home and picked up my beloved tea-smoked duck, along with tea-smoked duck necks.  I didn't even know that they sold them but I got home and there they were!  They were absolutely incredible with the beautiful rosy-pink color and that fantastic smokey flavor.  Plus, they weren't dry at all.  I think that I may have consumed a pound in a single sitting.  They were that addictive.  It definitely reminded me of the foods I used to get while strolling through the small, neighborhood streets in Shanghai.  Love it!

Went here for a Yelp elite event but if I had paid to get in, I would have given it 1 star as it's just not worth it for me.

I've never been very impressed with Busch gardens itself and this visit really just solidified that. However, the event itself was fairly fun. It was a nice Christmasy event, lots of lights to look at, hot cocoa, fake snow (poorly done fake snow may I add) but it did have its highlights. 

Everyone we ran into that worked here was very pleasant and friendly. They have stepped up the beer selection and even offered seasonal choices. All the food we tried was horrid!! The lights were great! Some much better then others, like the blue zone with the lights seemingly dropping from the trees and the colony house interactive lights/music was neat to watch (and made us giggle when we walked out of the colony house to dozens of people staring at us...oh no...it was the lights..but for a brief moment...the fame!)

They "real" statue girl was fun to watch as she surprised the ones who didnt know she was real until she moved during their picture op.

The skating rink and the snow zone were fun, although crowded and very limited on how much time you can spend (3 mins and they herd you out and bring in the nex group) And oh, no throwing snow balls at each other or they toss you out. (WHat! I had a good target on the hubby)

All in all it was a nice Christmas thing to do, really put us in the holiday spirit and made us feel like we were up north in a small town but definitely not worth the priceif you pay full price that is.

I have visited a few times this summer for a Blizzard treat and today was miracle treat day so I visited today. They were out of the flavor I wanted but what I got was yummy. I also ordered a salad which was huge. Ian now very full. It was a good option for an exceedingly hot day, especially since I didn't want to cook. Service was fast and helpful.

When my husband or kids get to pick what kind of take-out to get, they often pick Panda Express. It seems like they have something to please everyone. While this is a typical food-court style Asian restaurant in a stand-alone building, they make everything in small batches so it all is hot and fresh when ordered. They have your typical American style Chinese offerings, and monthly have a new "special" entree.

My favorite thing about Panda Express is their website. Before going to the restaurant you can go online and create your meal and see all of the nutritional information for what you want to order. I love the Panda Bowls, which include rice and one entree. However, you can also get half rice (white or fried rice), half steamed veggies, and one entree. If you choose this option, there are many Panda Bowls that you can create for under 400 calories and it is plenty of food for a filling dinner.

Figuring out exactly what we want to order online and then going through the drive-thru is a great time-saver for our busy family.

my sister picked Marcos on Main for my mom's birthday. she and her family love it. 

i think it is just ok. prices are competitive for an italian place. the food is good but almost never served hot. Warm yes. HOT no! i got their greek pizza and a bit of mom's pasta. the taste of the food is good, but i think it sat a minute because it was not exactly cold but not hot either. 

i go if someone else is paying or the rest of the group decide to go. but not a place i would choose on my own.

if you live in the area, give it a try. it is  not a place that i would go out of the way to eat there.
Strong margaritas  (I suggest the pineapple canela) and flavorful tacos (chicken was amazing)!

Stopped in after driving 7 hours from Atlanta. We were super hungry but not in the mood for fancy schmancy food. I yelped up Tampa Bay Brewing Company because my hubby wanted a Turkey Burger. Located in Ybor City, we were surprised at how empty the place was but we weren't deterred. I ordered an appetizer Shrimp (can't remember the name) but they were fried and then tossed in a spicy and sweet red chili sauce. I wasnt expecting the appetizer portion to be so large but not only was the portion large...so we're the shrimp. Not colossal but pretty big as I was expecting popcorn shrimp for $9.99. I also ordered a side of garlic mashed potatoes and a small side salad. Let me just say that although the shrimps flavor wasn't what I would consider fantastic, they were pretty good, the garlic mashed potatoes were served in a small bowl and kinda reminded me of mashed potatoes from elementary school...really dry looking and tasting. I ate a small amount of the potatoes as I wasnt too crazy about them. My salad was nice. They used really fresh and nice mixed greens instead of iceberg lettuce and the blue cheese dressing tasted kind of home made. My husbands turkey burger looked like one of those white frozen patties style turkey burgers instead of a homemade turkey burger but there were a lot of options to add like blue cheese or bacon etc. he opted to add Smoked Gouda and mushrooms and he seemed to enjoy it in spite of it being a frozen patty. I also ordered their Blond Beer which was mild and light tasting beer. I was told by. The waiter that Tampa Bay Brewing Company is not a chain and so I give them credit for that. The food was okay but at least it was fresh and served quickly. Staff was polite too!

I was in Indianapolis for a Trade Show, after we finished tearing down our booth at the convention center we decided to come and eat here (no wait at the time we went). A colleague of ours had eaten here prior and really raved about the place.  The staff was great the ambiance of the place is very inviting and very open.  We order our starters and drinks, moved on and ordered our meals and the food was outstanding, very delicious and well prepared as well as plentiful.  Definitely will try these guys again the next time I am in town.

This place used to be the best in our area 3/4 years ago. Sad to say I can't say the same now. They do have a pretty good selection of hot food. The sushi however, was questionable. Are used to come here just for the sushi but I honestly had no idea what was in some of the rolls. There were no labels on the sushi buffet so I grabbed what I thought was a spicy tuna roll. I am honestly not quite sure what it was but it tasted sour and tart. The other role I grabbed I thought had salmon on top and when I bit into it I have no idea what it was either. I'm not expecting anything grand but I at least want to identify it because I eat sushi all the time and I like to know what is what. The good thing is: it was $8.54 with tax so you get what you pay for *Kanye Shrug*

3.5

I really hope these guys make it. There's so much heart and (this is most important) I think it's vital that people understand that this isn't a typical Mexican joint that has Americanized its flavors for a palate that is, largely. unfamiliar with the differences in Mexican cuisine (there are 31 states in Mexico; each has its own take on regional cuisine).* So while YMMV, I think it's important to know what El Folklor is and is not before you sit down to try its food.

I came in for take out on a chilly Saturday evening. The dining room was decently busy. I was greeted as soon as I came in (always a nice touch; it doesn't happen all of the time). I told the servers that I wanted a plate to go. They offered me a table, a menu and some water. My first impression: the servers were very nice and hustling very hard to put smiles on everyone's face. After spending a little time going over things, I made my choice: Combo #2. I ordered and my server was quick to point out that the plate came with dishes from three regions and if that was okay. 'Yes' and 'yes.' This may be where some people make a mistake. This isn't (solely) Mexican food. EF takes an approach to Central American cuisine as well (which is different in style and taste profile from most Americanized Mexican food). I ordered and watched the Mexican version of The Jersey Shore (seriously) as I waited for my food. My server came by to apologize for my wait but I told him I'd rather wait for fresh food than have a plate ready as soon as I ordered. Plus, my wait time wasn't too long. Food ready, I hit the road.

I came home to discover a generous amount of food, especially for the price. My #2 Combo came with a Mexican-style chimichanga, a Guatemalan doblada (turnover similar to a pupusa; served with cabbage) and a Salvadoran-style tamale (made from maiz and wrapped in plantain leaves rather than corn husks) -- all chicken. I began with the chimichanga, as it was most familiar to me. It was enjoyable. But, when is fried food bad? I also liked the cheese sauce that came with it. I was impressed with the portion size. Next was the doblada. This was my first time having one, although I've had many pupusas. I really enjoyed it. Again, the portion size was generous and I was happy with the consistency and cooking style of the chicken. Granted, it wasn't the most seasoned of dishes but never having had one before, I don't know if that's typical or not. I saved the tamale for last both because it was fairly large (came in its own container) and I'm not the world's biggest tamale fan. The good news is that I enjoyed the tamale more than I do its Mexican counterpart. The bad news is that I am still not a huge fan of tamales (although I appreciated the flavor profile of the dish).

El Folklor provides the kind of culinary experience one would, typically, have to travel to Nolensville Pike for. I can appreciate the risk the owners took in bringing it to Inglewood. I hope that people take the time to consider and appreciate the differences it offers before complaining that it doesn't serve 'tacos with tomatoes and sour cream.'

*The menu has changed since I first came here in late winter. While I understand from a business point of view the need to change what they offer to meet the expectations of the consumer base, I think it's sad.

The other vietnamese place wasn't open and I remembered seeing this one around, and we were buzzed and haven't had dinner yet.

sadly the lady who took our order didn't know vietnamese! DARN and i actually felt like speaking vietnamese this time, poo. 

I got the pho and was really impressed that it tasted good! broth and everything!

imperial rolls- pretty good, well fried and crunchy. almost like mom made it but probably less healthy....if they can be healthy.....

didn't get our spring rolls, since i said it in vietnamese and she probably missed it SIGH

bf got com thit nuong- pretty good, large portion of meat. 

others got pho, and the bun thit nuong.

not sure if we were drunk but the food really hit the spot....compared to yucky inside reno food, forget the buffet!

As a second Year Essence Festival attendee, the girls and I have been hitting every eatery, tasting as many drinks and strolling up and down as many of these streets in New Orleans as we can... We luckily arrived in town before the crowds and have avoided long lines but unfortunately we were caught in the back of nearly a 100 line crowd of hungry seafood lovers.

Nestled along other restaurants and eateries, Deanies was a ten minute walk from the Royal Sonesta (our hotel) and spoken highly of by the locals and natives. The line moved quickly enough and with the laughter and conversations going on, the hour that passed only felt like minutes. We were seated in a cool, (Thank God ) rather large restaurant and greeted warmly by our waiter.

The table ordered BBQ shrimp, two orders of soft shell crab (amazing) seafood gumbo, stuffed flounder and a shrimp platter.  The BBQ shrimp were delicious but thank God I worked out that morning.  It arrived swimming in BBQ butter and I disliked pulling off the heads and tails.. it was such a tasty but messy meal... so much that the shrimp were slipping out of my fingers from the butter bath... the girls loved their food and the portions were enormous ( I see why obesity is so high .. portions could feed at least 3 people ).. but I digress, and the atmosphere was great for the enormous crowds. I polished off my gumbo and headed to bathroom to remove the now caked butter off my hands.

The bathroom was FILTHY and let me reiterate FILTHY.... I watched poor women reach under stalls for TP and the women's receptacle was overflowing... TP littered the floor and I knew this bathroom hadn't been checked in hours.. I went up front and asked that the restroom be cleaned and was brushed off... I took pictures of the trash and this time asked for a manager... as he swiped through my phone he promptly had an employee (the same one who brushed me off **laughs inside ** ) carry armfuls of TP into the restroom and get to work cleaning..

All in all, outside of dirty bathrooms, the food was banging and my compliments go to the Chef ... 1 Star demotion for the bathroom.. recommended for you Yelpers !

Islandgal29412 ~ Ms. Foodie

We stopped in on a Saturday for lunch and I have to say that the place was buzzing busy.  The service and the demeanor is pretty typical of places like this in Chinatown.  We order the pan fried beef dumplings, the steamed shrimp dumplings, the spring rolls, and the beef over hand stretched noodles.  Everything was good but not excellent, I would say that the pan fried beef dumplings were my favorite.  The beef over noodles was very good as well but I have to be honest in saying that the place next door, Nahn Zhou is much better.  I am glad that we finally went and tried Dim Sum Garden because I have read so much about it but I will probably be sticking to my Nahn Zhou from now on.

We went to this weird Santa Barbara Night Market place during a brief weekend trip between the holidays last month. Matt B. and I were walking along State Street with friends around 3:45 or so and got curious enough about this spot to swing by when it opened at 4:00. It was a pop-up bazaar or something like it in a defunct Macy's, behind a flashy UGG shop that may also have been a pop-up.

It was strange and kind of cool walking through a place that was so clearly a dead Macy's. The space managed to feel a bit deserted even filled up with local vendors. There were some neat booths set up displaying jewelry and clothes and crafty miscellany. A few food and beverage vendors, though nothing particularly tempting. It was interesting to walk through, but there was something a little half-assed about the whole thing.

I assume Santa Barbara Night Market was open at night, but it was definitely a day market when we went, and calling it a night market just struck me as funny and ultra white, given the usual night market connotations (food! crowds! Asians!). Anyway, I guess it's closed now, and whoever owns the building will have to figure out another use for an abandoned Macy's.

Drinks can be hit or okay, but I love their combo of the QQ Milk Tea - boba, grass jelly, and lychee jelly. You definitely can't go wrong with any of the milk teas, and the bobas are chewy. Their puff waffle with filling are okay, a good snack if you're hungry but nothing to write home about. I tried the recent limited edition strawberry drinks with the strawberry boba - definitely not worth it. The strawberry bobas tasted plain, not strawberry-like, and wasn't sweet. Definitely better off with the regular boba

I really like this place the soup had no oil for the pho that I ordered. People say it's blan and flavorless but I like it like this because I can just add my own portion of sriracha and hoisin sauce if I wanted to. Plus healthy life for the win! They give you a lot of noodles and the noodles are actually really good better than some places in San Francisco tbh. Definitely a go to spot if you craving noodle soup in the area!

An adorable Mediterranean cafe, with a personality suited perfectly for Davis Island!

Greeted by the laid back friendly staff, we arrived for late Saturday morning breakfast. But not to worry, they serve breakfast all day! 

The menu is mostly Greek-inspired breakfast entrees, smoothies, and paninis. They tout natural ingredients and locally sourced items when possible. The freshness of their food was wonderful. We started off with giant Americanos which hit the spot. I had the Davis Island Breakfast which included baked bacon, bread, and eggs topped with feta, spinach, and paprika. Wonderful! Loved every bite.

Zigi Cafe is a perfect spot to take in a pleasant Florida morning. Wholesome food and friendly smiles help make this a great "island" breakfast joint.

I came in here on a cold day and the beef brisket noodle soup really hit the spot. I definitely imagine myself coming here on rainy days if I lived in the area. The soup is hot and flavorful. The noodles had a good texture too. This is probably the ultimate comfort food. I wasn't a fan of their scallion pancakes. I felt like it was too greasy, but it still tasted good.

Overall: Contigo is a surprisingly great offering of traditional Latin food worth exploring.

The good: For the most part, the food was above my skeptical expectations for a resort. The lamb appetizer and the chorizo dates were both tender and juicy. The cochinita I had, while on the smaller side, was packed with flavor and fantastic. The meat was well-marinated and the entire ensemble played well together.

The not-so-good: The empanadas were a dud, especially for the price. They weren't filled with much and the taste just wasn't there. Otherwise, the only other thing worth noting is the price - it's a tad much, but it's also in the resort.

Food: 8/10
Service: 8/10
Atmosphere: 8/10

The beach on one side. Mountains on the other. And wine country in between. It's hard to screw this one up, but Cloud Climbers Wine Country Tour really delivers an exceptional experience for any wine enthusiast. Touring vineyards in a small, open-air Jeep is how it's meant to be done. The sights and smells of the Santa Ynez valley, allure of Los Olivos tasting rooms, and rustic charm of Solvang offer a rich backdrop for a day of exploring four locally celebrated wineries. Let your tour guide choose where you go or offer your own insight - the day is yours. Most stops include between five and six tastings tailored to your taste in addition to access to the grounds. Drink in the deep greens of the valley and dazzling views of the Pacific before enjoying a picnic lunch under the California sun to round out your afternoon. The small size of the Jeep keeps your tour private (or semi-private at "worst") so you aren't vying for attention from your guide or begrudgingly dragged to vineyards you aren't interested in. Cloud Climbers service is friendly and accommodating and wholly lacking in any touristy gimmicks that sometimes plague these types of things. Well worth the price for such an enjoyable experience. Even though it's hard to complain after close to 20 wine tastings (ahem), I assure you it's a true "must" whether you're a local or a visitor.

We stopped by for Happy Hour on a Monday night.  I was suprised that the bar wasn't packed like the other nearby restaurants that offer a happy hour.  Their bar is large with plenty of seating.  

Service was good.  The happy hour menu consisted of a handful of small plates as well as a listing of drinks.  We tried the burger, tots, shrimp, and spinach dip.  The tots were good.  Everything else was just ok.

I only just realized Kuma's is a chain, so I don't have any other experience with the brand or nostalgia for the menu. It's loud inside, like loud enough that I can only tolerate it if sitting outside to avoid getting a headache. My burger was tasty, but Indy has lots of tasty burger places. With such good reviews, I think maybe it deserves another chance, but I thought it was pretty average food with average service.

Kinda expensive for ice cream joint but great flavors! Had me at Twix ice cream! Waffle bowls and ice creams are huge. You get to take cute spoons home. The vintage chalk art signs and mural of mermaids really won me over.

I enjoyed sitting at the bar and having a bread pudding sundae for dessert. The bar area was a bit busy, so I didn't like having people crowded around me while I ate though. I would like to try the dinner here as this place has good reviews. The restaurant is a bit narrow though so tables are a bit closer together.

This is my go-to local grocery store. No matter which location I visit, I have always found the store to be clean, organized, and for the most part, well stocked. Sometimes it's hard to find specialty items, such as specific herbs that may or may not be in stock. I like that the stores have recently incorporated a section for locally produced items, such as honey, soup mixes, sauces, and my favourite - Jacek chocolate bars! If you need help finding an item, I find the staff to be helpful and will sometimes even walk you over to the section in question.

Oh El Vez. I'd had a few cocktails here, but never ventured in for dinner until the BF and I had a late show and needed a late dinner. You may be familiar with how I feel about needlessly pimped (and priced) Mexican food (see Alma de Cuba) and all that criticism applies here. Seriously, if you charge $18 for enchiladas, where the hell do you get off charging over $20 just because you've plated them as an assortment, rather than 3-of-a-kind. Bullshit.  The food is okay, but it certainly isn't worth the price. There was time when they did reasonably priced catering, but that time is gone (and their catering manager was always uber-unhelpful anyway). 

I'd give it 2 stars, except that it's so damn conveniently located, has a working photo booth, and I'm head over heals in LOVE with the Mexican Chop Salad with cumin cilantro dressing. Next time, I'm make the bf split the mushroom enchiladas with me, or maybe just the chop salad, and will exit with a smaller bill.

First off, this is actually more a 3.5 review. While I wanted to be able to give it 4, this is just one of those experiences I just can't seem to round up. 

Murrieta's has always been a Mexican restaurant I liked, but rarely visited. I think that's mainly because I used to go to the Sparks location with an old friend, and since he left, I don't really get out that way very much, and the South Reno store just doesn't come to the top of my mind often. For some reason, I always remembered it being kind of sleepy, but when we stopped in last week, this place was hopping. 

What I love about Murrieta's is the variety on their menu. They've got the typical enchiladas, tacos, burritos, and chile rellenos, but as most know, I appreciate those signature dishes that you just aren't going to find on anyone else's menu. Well at Murrieta's, those are the Pambasos. Hard to pronounce but easy to put down, Pambasos are small, light, and pillowy rolls, dipped in a red chile sauce, and crisped on a flat top to trap the flavor and moisture. They're cut to create a pocket, and then stuffed with your choice of meat. I usually get a chorizo, al pastor, and lengua! I love that they offer these meats on their regular menu. 

On this visit, from the minute we walked in to the moment we left, the service was impeccable. Our server knew the menu front and back, was great at making suggestions, and visited at all the right points in the meal. He made sure water glasses were filled, chips remained in steady supply, and that we had everything we needed to enjoy the meal. If rating on his service alone, it would be 5 stars. 

As for what we ordered, when we were seated I could hear and smell fajitas, and had my heart set on them. But as usual, I looked over the menu and made my decision more difficult by eyeing the carnitas. Fortunately Ashley and I decided to share both dishes! 

The carnitas were well seasoned, moist, tender, and slightly crispy from a little bit of time on the flat top. They were some of the tastiest carnitas I've enjoyed in a while, and it's a dish I'd be happy to order again. The fajitas smelled and looked delicious when they arrived, and they were served sizzling on a seriously hot skillet. Unfortunately, something was wrong with the beef though, and it had an off flavor which sort of spread through the dish. The portions on both were ample, and we took home leftovers from both plates, and our server got us extra salsa to take with it. 

I had the leftovers the next day, and while opening the salsa containers I noticed the green salsa had expanded overnight and sort of popped when opened. I thought air must've gotten trapped in it and dipped my first bite in. As soon as it hit my tongue I knew it was spoiled, and I didn't eat it. Kind of weird to encounter the same thing twice here, and I'm hoping it was a total fluke.

This Murrieta's is close to home, and as our usual Mexican spot has been ok lately, I think we'll definitely give it another shot in the future. I know if that beef had been fresher, those would have been the best fajitas I've had in Reno, and just one more reason why Murrieta's is a local favorite.

Great-tasting burgers with lots of different toppings to suit your mood and preferences. My usual is a little bacon burger with lettuce, tomato, raw onions, grilled onions, grilled mushrooms, & green peppers. A little burger is big enough for me, and a regular fills any guy I've eaten Five Guys with.

Their fries aren't that great though, usually kinda soggy and not crisp enough for me. The peanuts are nice to snack on while you wait, random but nice :)

Service is fast and friendly. I've never had to wait long in line to order or at all for a table. Open until 10pm!

Since 1958 International House of Pancakes has been flipping pancakes and serving up smiles.
I can remember when my mom and dad would take us too IHOP.
It was a big deal. Fast forward to today, not much has changed. The menu's are modern, prices a bit more expensive, but the food is constantly good.
IHOP is known for there different variations on pancakes.
They have chocolate, strawberry, blueberry, strawberry cheesecake, English toffee ,tres leches and cupcake pancakes.
If you do not want a flavor, they have there original buttermilk pancakes.
I opted for a omelette and two pancakes.
There are advantages to being over 55, and one is the 55 and older portion of the menu.
For 7.99 I got a cheese omelette and two pancakes. Both were delicious and very filling.
I definitely will be back.

Sure, this place is a bit of a tourist trap located down on the Riverwalk just Southwest of the French Quarter. However, a friend of mine who lives outside of New Orleans recommended it for the grilled oysters, so we went. We ordered the grilled oysters, of course, and also some jumbo Gulf Shrimp stuffed with boudin. The ladder was very good, but honestly the grilled oysters were on freaking point! The place was not crowded either so it wasn't like an arduous task to go into this tourist trap and eat. I say that only to let any yelpers who read this in the future know that you can get in and out relatively quickly and get some of the most delicious oysters of your life.

The bartenders here were fabulous, friendly and gave us good suggestions for places to eat later that evening.

This is one of the best burgers I have ever had. I was in town for the Sugar Bowl and ate here before the game. It was jam packed but the service was still fast and friendly. The fries are killer as are the onion rings  

One tip, there is a "one holer" bathroom for each sex so don't hold out too long on a crowded night. :-)

My husband is the real AYCE Sushi fan, but I have learned to have an appreciation for it, too. Here are my thoughts on this particular spot. 

Pro - The restaurant is in a fun part of town. The vibe is great!

Con - There's no parking lot/garage. We found a free meter (after 6p on a Friday night) about four blocks away. 

Con - The service wasn't great. The friends we went with said it had never been that cruddy before. But on this particular night the servers were hard to flag down and forgot things. It took forever for me to simply get a glass of water because I happened to be up using the bathroom when she took drink orders and I guess I missed my window. Also, with AYCE they need a new system in order to not cluttering the table to heck. Most places I've been, they bring out as much as they can on one huge plate. Here, we ended up with a million small plates and quickly ran out of room. Also, they were very slow to clear which only added to the problem. 

Pro - I really did enjoy the food. I wish there were more appetizer options, but I liked the Fried Dumplings and Stuffed Mushrooms. I also appreciated the vegetarian and cooked Rolls. I felt the selection was unique and not like I'd seen before.

Great place to go to watch the game and have some delicious wings.
