I love the extensive selection of wing sauces. I like menus with a lot of choices and there are definitely choices here. It can be a bit loud here but it is meant to be a sports bar. If you are craving wings and have a game to watch - this is the place to go.

What is there to say about Save A Lot?  It is where I go when I'm broke as a joke and I can't get groceries at Winn Dixie or I'll choke.  I have to drive quite a ways to get over there, but I make it worth the trip by hauling the kids along with me and hitting up the Cici's close by or going roller skating at Airline Skate Center.  But alas, I digress.

This is a good place to come and stock up on staples: canned goods, dry items like canned drinks, noodles, chips, crackers, cereal and stuff, and dairy.  Their produce is pretty ok most of the time, if you don't mind a couple of bruises on your apples.  I bruise easily myself, so I don't mind.  The meat is touch-and-go; it sort of depends on the day as to the quality there, but I usually pick up some ground turkey and maybe a pack of pork chops at least.  The frozen food selection is great, and it is a fantastic place to pick up some bread.  Hell, buy two and stick one loaf in the freezer.  Times are tough.

I can get over a week's worth of groceries here for about $40-$50.  It's no ALDI (don't get me started on that mecca), but, for the price, that'll do, Donkey...that'll do.

My husband and I were in Reno last fall and some friends told us they were also in town and they'd be at a party later in the evening at this hotel.  We weren't far so we walked a few blocks and found ourselves ringing the door bell, trying to find a way in. The neighborhood is horrible and we probably would have stayed at the party later but we didn't want to walk back to the casinos in the dark. Be aware of your surroundings if youre walking by!

Once inside the hotel, we were offered a tour of some of the rooms. Very unique! Several were occupied and we couldn't look at these, but the ones we saw were really fun with great paintings and decorations.

A narrow stairway leads you to a large yard in the back. Lots of large scale art, a few chairs, and a stage. It started to rain as we left - wonder if people piled inside the small lobby or braved it outdoors. It was a cool place to check out before working our way safely back to our own hotel.

Loved my brunch experience here. They have a variety of brunch items to choose from for under $10. I tried the egg, chorizo, bean DIY taco combo. The scrambled eggs with chorizo was perfectly fluffy and paired deliciously with the beans. 

I also ordered the Tinto Santana guac. The mixture of creamy avocado, spiciness and mango sweetness was perfect. It's pricey at $15, but they sure give you a lot! It's about triple the size of what you might get at other places, so definitely worth the price. Also, it's served on a big rock, which is fun to eat off of. Comes with unlimited chips and salsa.

I also like how they specifically list out several virgin cocktails, which is great if it isn't a boozy brunch kind of day. I tried the pomegranate margarita and enjoyed it.

Would definitely recommend this place and come back again!

They know how to poach eggs.

Beware of the sea gulls. If you're not looking, they will swoop in and disrupt your meal.

OMG those **Charbroiled Oysters** doused with divine garlic butter. The French baguette accompanying the oysters is perfect for soaking up all the heavenly juice. 

5 stars.

That is all.

Eat 'em there, take 'em to go, doesn't matter. They're gonna be amazing wherever you choose to enjoy these bad boys.

(If you're curious, the gumbo and salad were also good, but couldn't quite hold a candle to those oysters. Maybe if we use the garlic butter as a salad dressing though... I might be on to something!)

TIP: If you're staying at the Hilton Riverside, you may want to order and go back to your room. It can take up to 25 minutes for the oysters to be ready.

DATE TIP: Yes yes yes!

Nice place to go for a pint.  I usually get the pub sampler when I am with friends, always a solid choice.  This time I got some soup instead and then later the Shepherd's Pie.  I was very impressed, completely filled.  The Guinness is done right and they have some decent Scotch there too.  I love the décor.  When I was in Dublin I loved places like this.  It brings me back to a happy place; the wife and I  visit here a few times a year.  It's always a treat.

Was at the NAMM show last week and checked out Sole Mio for dinner on Friday night. Wow. That's what I can come up with right now as I think back on the deliciousness that was our meal.

First off, their bread is crazy good. I know they say don't fill up on it, but I love carbs and I sort of did. But I don't regret it. Also, try the caprese - it was perfect.

For dinner I did a pre fixe option with a Cesar salad, stuffed salmon with vegetable risotto and for dessert I got the chocolate amaretto cake. How I wish I could have that entire meal right here, right now!

The salad was fantastic - everything seemed from scratch and the dressing was out of this world. The salmon - a huge portion and stuffed with yummy goodness like shrimp and other things. It came on a bed of vegetable risotto and although that was just slightly overcooked, the salmon more than made up for it. The chocolate amaretto cake was decent - good even - but I was missing the amaretto. Just not quite enough kick there.

They've got a GREAT wine list and even though the service was a little slow, our waiter was pretty on top of it and attentive. He knew the menu well and gave some great suggestions. It's the real deal Italian - worth stopping by if you're in Nashville.

I REALLY want to give this place 5 stars. The sandwiches are so finely crafted and the house cured meats are FANTASTIC. However, it is waaayyyyyy too salty :(. It's also a bit pricey but you absolutely get what you pay for.
We ordered a muffaletta with a mix of house cured meats and olive spread. The meats are seriously perfection. Amazingly fresh and so tasty but just way too salty, especially with the olive spread! It was my first time having a muffaletta and I liked the bread, but I didn't love it
The pork belly sandwich is a must try. The pork belly melts in your mouth and is bursting with flavor. If it weren't so salty, it would've been the perfect sandwich. The cucumber slaw was delicious and refreshing but it still couldn't cut through the saltiness of the pork belly and the creaminess of the mayo.

What excellent shakes! I mean the variety and by using frozen custard...there is really no way to recommend Shake Shack any higher.

Service is excellent here, very friendly and talkative with the customer, a rarity these days even with local places.

Did you take a look at that menu? Wow what a selection, and even some treats for dogs too.

I really want to try a burger the next time I come to SS.

The new and improved buffet at the Treasure Chest Casino. New carpet, updated buffet lines. The food has also improved in some areas. Kudos to the Casino for investing in this. We enjoy it almost every time we come here.

While the proximity of this Target to my house is more convenient, the convenience ends there. Everything seems a little bit more expensive and I just finished a trip where they were out of four of the five items on my list. They weren't crazy items, they were normal household items. So many of the shelves were bare.  This is not normal for Target. I asked the cashier if it was normal for them to be out of so many things or if the store has issues getting deliveries and he didn't seem to know what I was talking about.  I now have to go to a different Target and had to take a trip to the grocery store afterwards. So not worth it. Also, while there, the strap on the cart broke forcing me to carry my toddler around or go get a new cart.

Many locals know that Mother's is for tourists....the food is fine & affordable and nothing wrong with it, but it's definitely not worth the long lines that often occur. Got a ham & egg breakfast sandwich. Nothing special about the ham, it was normal and there was a good amount of it. Scrambled eggs nice and fluffy. Biscuit kinda dry so I didn't eat much of it, but then again it's hard to eat a regular biscuit after getting used to the Copeland's and the Popeye's buttermilk biscuits of old (nowadays the Popeye's biscuits aren't nearly as good).

This salon is one of the cleanest along the strip. I can't confirm the licenses of anyone who works there sabotaging is posted besides payment options & proving. #whomp

Regardless of what you get, the prices are the same. I requested the foot/body combo for 50 minutes. Their pricing really doesn't make sense when you do the math from one length of time to the other. The lady explained it was 20 mins on feet & 30 on body. It was pulling teeth when we insisted on 10 mins on feet & 40 minutes on body. 

When they do your foot massage, you are seated in black leather recliner (which should be BrookStone massaging chairs). The chairs are prepped with white towel that they do not change between clients. The foot massage is done by hand and it's decent

You then move to the table for the body massage. There is an open partition but no real privacy as you are out in the open. Due to the body massage station being in the open, you are fully clothed during your massage. Fully clothed and then they cover you with towels so the process is not as deep & effective as you'd like. We got a couple massage & the massages would have been relaxing if the therapists would have kindly shut their traps. They talked in Chinese the entire time. No, not whisper, just chatting it up. We just did our best tuning them out. After the massage is over, they rush you off the table and out the door.

I'm used to a different level of service & skill set so this place only gets 3 stars from me.

Um, so much yes about this place!

I was seriously craving some non-Chipotle type Mexican food on a casual Saturday, and since one of my friends said this was his favorite, a bunch of us decided to try it out. 

Hard to describe the ambiance of this place; it's a peculiar but appealing blend of hole-in-the-wall and fancy. On the one hand, it's pretty small and a bit shabby with tiled walls that resemble the interior of a diner. On the other hand, as my one friend kept insisting, it has wine glasses and candles on the tables so it can kinda qualify as a date spot. Also, the service is excellent, with friendly waiters dressed in all black to add a little more class. 

On top of that, the food is delish, particularly the tacos that my friend got and kindly shared with me. My own "enchiladas de mole" was good, but I'd probably default to their tacos in the future. A memorable dish of the night was one that my other friend ordered, some special dish that was legit ginormous (but also twice the cost of anyone else's dish). I can't even remember what it was called, so I'll just leave it as the mystery menu item, and maybe you can figure it out from the blurred picture I managed to screenshot from the tail-end of my snapvideo! He said it was really good, although he also commented it might be the most expensive dish he's ever ordered at a Mexican place. That's def the anomaly though; everything else there was very reasonably priced and worthwhile imo.

This CVS is clean, neat, organized, bright and well stocked.  They have lots of parking and are very conveniently located on a fantastic little lifestyle center.  
     They are in the same center as my kickboxing studio so I run in here almost every single time I go to my class to pick up a bottle of water.  Checking out is so stressful because it is SO SLOW!  I guess this is not a very busy store because I have never seen more than one employee working the register.  My luck & unfortunate timing always put me behind someone who is picking up pictures or monopolizing the only cashier with limitless questions about where they keep the toothpaste. 
     Eventually when my turn rolls around the cashier wants to have a 20 minute conversation about the CVS card.  I JUST WANT THIS BOTTLE OF WATER!!!!! I am going to be late for kickboxing and they are going to make me do extra burpees!
     Will I be back?  Yes.  Will I continue to be annoyed?  Yes. Will I ever sign up for a CVS card for my $1.58 bottle of water?  No.

Great little sports bar. After driving eight hours from Nashville to Nawlins, I wanted to get out and enjoy the area. From my hotel, I walked down the street and found this place which wasn't as packed as I thought it would be.

The bartenders were pleasant, the drinks were ok, and I spent a about 15 minutes here Berdine heading down the street to find something a little more happening. But it was Christmas Day after all, so that may have been why it wasn't so busy. And I also wanted to check out the area and find some good music/entertainment

One of the most impressive-looking indoor rooftops I've been to!

JG SkyHigh is a fancy restaurant/bar on the 60th floor of the Four Seasons. It's definitely a place to bring someone you're trying impress or celebrate.  Since we came for lunch on a Monday, the restaurant was pretty empty, which was a pleasant surprise. The staff did a good job spacing out the parties that were present. 

I ordered the strawberry Thai basil lemonade for my cocktail, which was good but definitely quite tart (not a bad thing). Our group shared the black truffle pizza (delicious and light) and I chose the salmon for my entree, which was tasty and not too heavy - I loved the corn and the broth served with it. Although the food was good, I think the true wow factor of this restaurant is the ambiance and spectacular views of Philly!

Worth checking out at least once - make sure you dress to impress!

Surprisingly clean and friendly, considering it's in the French Quarter!

Stopped in here during French Quarter fest for a water break. Being out in the hot sun all day can start to drain you after a while. Even though the place was pretty packed, the staff did a good job of keeping up with the crowd and getting people in and out of the door in a timely manner. CVS turned out being a lifesaver during the fest.

This place reminds me of a Buffalo Billiards vibe from the late 90's- happening! Although I'm not 20 anymore and I felt a bit old to be there. Still, this place is cool! Very large with lots of games such as shuffleboard, ping pong, foosball, etc. They have some house made punches, and I really enjoyed my hurricane in a souvenir plastic cup. They have an outdoor back patio which houses the ping pong tables and the left side of the place where the bar is has games and was packed! The right side of the place was more of a sit down restaurant vibe and much smaller. Didn't try food, but they had a ton of beer on draft. Great for a group, will be back!

The food was alright here, what lured me in was the Hell's Kitchen Beef Wellington, the Foie Gras, and the handsome Chef.

The food was alright at best, I've had better Foie Gras. I was VERY disappointed with the Beef Wellington. After watching like 10 years of Hell's Kitchen, is that what it really tasted like? Hope not.

The only thing I found good was the bacon bread from the bread girls who look like they were imported from a small village in the mountains. So pretty.

We had the opportunity to take a photo with the chef. He is so friendly and FLUFFY!

Thanks for the food chef. Hope to see you again.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/roxy-restaurant-and-bar-reno?select=W3ZppqG98ZFVOFqggjMpUg#W3ZppqG98ZFVOFqggjMpUg

It never fails - I throw the suitcase together for a trip - and forget to check everything in my toiletries case - and I am always either missing something or have run out of something!

Thank you for the existence of drug stores!

After getting my coffee - I noticed that Walgreens was just down the strip - so I made a beeline for the place.

Antacids, soft cleaning cloth for eye glasses, a six pack of bottled water (hotel bottled water is soooo expensive), and some other odds and ends and I was good to go!

I was somewhat amused by the cashier - young guy - looked like he was between 18-20. His hair was all over the place - looked like he has just rolled right out of bed and had not combed his hair. You'd think he would look in the mirror before coming to work!

Hmmmm... all the dishes perhaps with the exception of 1-2 had something off about it (and the exceptions are the appetizers). The restaurant ambiance was on point - low lighting, sophisticated decorations. But food-wise... 

==FOOD ORDERED==

1. Pork cracklings $1 (4/5 stars): For $1, this is the best deal of the night. Great snack to go with beer/drinks, the fried pork skin is crunchy, fresh and fattily delicious. 

2. Boudin Balls $4 (3/5 stars): Not bad, but I had better ones at multiple restaurants in New Orleans already.

3. Crispy Oyster & Caviar Taco $8 (3/5 stars);
Ingredients: Louisiana oysters, Cajun caviar & Crystal hot sauce aioli 
I only had a bite of these tacos since it was my friend's order. They tasted OK, nothing stood out but nothing was bad. Average tasting tacos. It is not spicy (the hot sauce is sweet).

4. Dirty Duck & Mirlton Bread Pudding $8 (2/5 stars); 
Ingredients: pulled duck leg confit, foie gras nibbles & jalapeno cornbread with foie gras fondue & bourbon old fashioned duck sauce
Duck is my favorite meat. But I couldn't even really taste the flavor of duck meat here as the entire dish is covered with a weird combination of sauces. Rather than jalepeno, because it wasn't spicy at all (seeds taken out) it tasted more like the duck was wrapped in a large green bell pepper. Everything put together was just too sweet for my liking :(

5. Crispy Confit Pig Ears $7 (2/5 stars);
Ingredients: ghost pepper spiced red bean puree, grilled green onion & Steen's molasses gastrique
Hmmm... so I'm usually used to eating Taiwanese pig ears that are slightly chewy/tendon-y with chili oil drenched on top. When I had it here, the pig ears are dried out almost like dried squid, and don't believe the "ghost pepper spiced red bean puree" description - if there were any hints of ghost pepper I didn't taste it. It's completely 100% unspicy. Not a fan of this dish as it's way too bland.

6. Gumbo $8 (2/5 stars): Ehhhh. So salty!! Holy crap, it was like drinking salt soup. We mentioned the issue with the gumbo with the waitress towards the end of the meal but her response was kind of abrupt - "Oh... I guess I could take those off the bill." No, we'd rather not if you "guess" you'll take it off... that's just awkward.

==ALCOHOLIC DRINKS==
These were good. At least they got the drinks down. Yay.

==PRICING==
Pretty cheaply priced for a higher end restaurant. With everything it came out to $115 pre-tip, for five people. 

==OVERALL==
Sad to say, this is one of the few spots in NOLA that I wouldn't be back for. I had a good time because I was on a fantastic vacation with my friends, but the restaurant itself lacked that wow factor to have me coming back for a next time.

Besides having a serious relationship with chocolate (read my Best Choc. in Town review), I am having an affair with ice cream on the side. I love it and I don't care if it's 100 and sticky or 20 and snowy. I love my ice cream and love finding a good spot to enjoy it.

Enough said about my affair, I came here with a friend after doing some Village shopping and we needed a little pick-me-up for the rest of our afternoon. I was amazed by all the flavors. Some traditional but some that looked really good. I tried a toffee one, can't remember it's name, and decided to go with that. My friend went with the Whistle Stop.

We both ordered ours as a one scoop in a dish. Holy cow! Those were big dishes that I swear it was like 2 scoops or 3 maybe 4?! Say what?! Count me in! I hate going to places that literally give you a tiny scoop in a tiny dish and charge you an arm and a leg. This was great. A good ice cream at a good price is something I can totally handle! So, get your ice cream lovin' self in here and get some ice cream baby!

Finally, after being bookmarked forEVER, I was ready to check out Palace of Asia. The restaurant is connected to a sketchy looking hotel and its even sketchier if you enter the back door. Once inside it transitions into fine dining though. There was a chandelier hanging above with fully plated tables. 

I ordered a large rice and shrimp dish with onions and peppers in a red sauce, which was full of flavor. It was served mild in spice and had generous amounts of shrimp. It didn't 'wow' me but was just standard taste. 

My date had a yogurt based sauce and was accompanied by chicken. His dish was a very large portion. Our naan was potato stuffed but was by far not something I would order again. Even the bread itself was floppy and the potato was mush mash....no flavor. 

The service is where Palace missed the mark the most. Our waiter didn't seem to really care about our visit....he was a little pushy to get us in and out. 

Overall, the meal wasn't bad and the staff clearly, were over working their shift.

This is probably my favorite ice cream joint. The guys are so cool and down to Earth. They always make you feel so welcome. The ice cream taste is unbelievably delicious and there are so many variables. The ever changing menu keeps us coming back for more. It is located in a great neighborhood and the establishment is so clean and pretty. We have been coming g here since it opened and will continue to frequent this establishment
This market had everything we needed, one block away from our hotel. Medicine, food, water, etc.

I saw some people eating here on fb & the food looked pretty good, so I decided to check them out. Now the Yelp reviews said the food was just OK, & my fellow Yelpers were correct! I ordered the shrimp po Boy, the soft shell crab, & the gumbo. The gumbo was DELICIOUS. Soft shell crab was different, it was my 1st time eating it so I don't have anything to compare that too. It was fresh & hot & did have a lil flavor. The poboy wasn't good at all. The shrimp was bland and the sandwhich was lukewarm at best. I was definitely disappointed with the meal. I expected more. 

Service was ok, the guy didn't really wow us. He just got the job done. So that was that. Overall I think New Orleans has better food options. I wouldn't be interested in a round 2 w/them.

This store is close to home and carries the best produce in the area. I can pay my utilities easily and the staff are always so nice and friendly. 

Bonus: they finally fixed the big pothole in the shopping center parking lot.

Hands down, the best meal I had in New Orleans. We were walking down Bourbon Street, and we just happened to turn down Orleans Avenue, where we found this amazing restaurant. 

The setting inside is beautiful and classy, yet very casual at the same time. The servers are very kind and cheerful.

The wines - I had a glass of Weingut Max Ferd Richter Riesling, and a glass of Moscato D'asti dessert wine. Both wines were superb.

Appetizer - I had the New Orleans BBQ'd shrimp that was served with the most delicious, creamy sauce, and French Bread.

For dinner - A nice portion of Filet and a very generous portion of Lobster Tail. The BEST. The Lobster was served with browned butter, that almost tasted like caramel. The Lobster was sweet enough that I didn't even need the butter. The meal also came with very tasty garlic mashed potatoes.

They offer a cheese and wine meal on the patio, and I wanted to come back another day to try that. Unfortunately, I didn't have time to go back. If I ever visit New Orleans again I will definitely be dining here.

We went there on the Thanksgiving day. We called the day before and twice the morning of Thanksgiving and they told us they are all booked and they are not taking any more reservation. We happened to walk by around 11am, went in and asked again and they said the same thing. While looking for a place to eat a couple hours later, we happened to see a line in there. So we went back in again and we were able to get a table in less than 5 min. 

Our server was great super nice. There was some live jazz which was good but  it was very short. The part that I was excited about was the food which sucked. Turkey was dried, ham was dried and the rest of the food was also not tasty. The place was super crowded. Every time we had to stay in line for 20-30min to get food from buffet. I won't go back.

This tiny little joint is just a stumble & a stagger from Colby's Cocktails and puts together some damn tasty Mexican...Now looking at this place from the outside you'd be judging a book by it's cover & honestly this book would look a bit sketch since this place is located in an old house trailer....Inside you got maybe 4-6 tables but hey they can put together some delectable eats! So get over any concerns and get in there and get your grub on....Was told they didn't serve booze but the cooler was stocked with a variety of cervezas...was well pleased to see they carried my favorite, Sol!!

Communication is a bit tricky cause not too much English is spoken or understood here so you gotta get by with pointing but for me the food was totally worth it! In prior reviews (Cantina Laredo, Mia's Tex-Mex, Casa Maria) I've spoken of my love for brisket tacos....This place did a shredded beef taco with the beef soaked in it's own juices that, while not called a brisket taco, was damn tasty and rivaled any of the brisket tacos I've had in the past...

I ordered 3 of those tacos with cilantro, onion and avocado and with the salsa verde poured on top it was a Fiesta for the taste buds!!! I've found my Mexican place in Metry!! The other Yelpers I was with all loved their orders and my mouth is watering for those tacos as I right this review...I'll be back sooner rather than later cause this place is a hidden gem....

It's impossible to eat healthy in New Orleans.  I proved this at Mother's.  I ordered the grilled fish with veggies and grits.  We took a seat in the back and waited for our orders.  My friend said, "You got grilled?  They don't grill anything here.". Good point, turned out she was right.  My friends were pretty much done with their lunches by the time my fish finally came.  The server even said, "mm mm mm, you got grilled???". OK, I get it, lesson learned.

The remarkable thing is that they managed to grill the fish in tons of butter and with the skin on.  The fish seemed to have good flavor, but I wasn't able to separate the skin so that's all I could taste.  I was laughing because even the veggies had ham in them.  I will say that that was the best cabbage I've ever had.  Grits were creamy and good too.

So overall, A-OK.  Next time I'll stick with the fried.  What was I thinking trying to eat healthy anyway?

Nashville Hot Chicken!  Ahhhhh YEAH!  I really liked it a lot. And the slushy boozy cherry lime drink. It was a great quencher.  

As for the chicken, I got "medium" and it was the perfect amount of "hot" for me. When I was younger, I liked things even spicier, but for now this level of heat is just perfect for my taste buds. We can't be having anything *too* bland now. 

Great service and decent ambiance. Nothing special- fairly simple decor, but the food is very satisfying and delicious.

Strolled into Sonny's one night after a happy hour that turned into a night out. In my opinion, this place is honestly underrated for cheesteak in Philly. Granted it was early, but we only waited in line for about 10 minutes. I went for a classic cheesesteak with provolone. Of course, I added some mushrooms and onions. The cheesesteak was great and pretty filling. I also had a few of a friends cheese fries, and the whiz was pretty good (normally I stay away from whiz at all costs). 

Anyways, I definitely recommend Sonny's if you're looking for a pretty good cheesesteak.

I can't believe that I've never written a review for this place!!!
I would eat here EVERY SINGLE NIGHT if I wouldn't suffer the weight gain from it.   I am SERIOUS!  I am a huge ice cream, gelato, custard whatever nut and this is one of my favorites.
I used to come here as a kid, and now my kids grew up coming here.  We get our tree here every year as well and we also love their hotdog food truck.
I will NOT say anything against this landmark, and I'm so glad we have it here in St. Louis so I don't have to drive outta state.

Greasy greasy- that pretty much sums up the panini I had here. The panini was mediocre in size and stuffed with eggplant, broccoli rabe, and provolone. Sounded like a winning combo. The eggplant was slimy (gross). The rabe was bitter (also gross), and the whole sandwich was soft and sort of falling apart. I felt like a picky 5 year old (and I pretty much eat everything) as I took out all the fillings and basically ate the oily bread. Everyone else didn't seem to have the same problem I did so must have been the eggplant, broccoli combo that I picked. 

If you order more than $25 worth of food you get a free pitcher of sangria- sweet! Except that the sangria was really not sangria, but fruit punch with a touch of cheap wine?? I'm not sure what I was drinking, but it definitely wasn't sangria. What do I expect- its free...There's way too many places to get a decent meal in Philly. Panini's is definitely not on that list.....

They make a damned good philly cheese steak. And they get you in and out in record time which I appreciate... But the place is filthy... filthy. Tells you how good it is that we still give it 4-stars...

11/24/17

Wow, I'm pretty damn famous here!!!  So, here's the deal: this restaurant is the very most recommended restaurant throughout New Orleans believe it or not!  We took numerous uber's and taxis, and every single driver told us to come here when asked where to eat.  Every.  Single.  One.  (Second place was Acme Oysters, but who cares about second right?)

So what was it like?  Well, to me, this restaurant was exactly how I picture a popular New Orleans restaurant would look inside and out, but not just any popular restaurant--one packed with locals.  I would say that it was generally about 80% African Americans, and 19% various Caucasians making up the nearly 150-200ish people stuffed into this rather large restaurant.  Oh... and... 2 Asians.  Me.  Her.

So, get this, 3pm on a Fri afternoon, the waiting area overflowed outside, with dozens of families inside waiting for tables.  Yes, 3pm.  I cannot imagine how crazy it would be at normal hours!  Must be pure insanity.

But........... we walked right passed everyone, and as if God wanted us to be happy, two seats were empty at the bar.  Hell yeah, we immediately sat our asses down!  I would say, based on my observations while consuming our meal, that the wait was probably more than hour long.  I do believe that some people that were there when we sat down were still standing there after we left.  So BE PREPARED for some ridiculous waiting if you want tables!

Unfortunately we didn't have enough time to burn through our food adventures from earlier in the day, so we could only eat so much...

1. NOLA Irish Channel Stout (American Stout) $7.50:  This was a GREAT find!  I never thought of Louisiana as a beer-loving state.  More of a Pabst or Miller place I figured, you know, piss in a glass.  But holy cow this NOLA (produced?) beer was a knockout!  Mega rich and with that pure cocoa bean kick.  Like butter and dark chocolate mixed up.  Somewhat similar in architecture to a Guinness but 10x stronger and tastier!  I really gotta try more Louisiana-made beer now.  9/10

2. Half Platter $35.95 "[half as much of] a bounty of fresh shrimp, oysters, catfish, soft shell crabs and crawfish balls, served with french fries"... that's a ton of stuff man... just look at that giant MOUND of fried goodness (really, check out my pics!)...

2a. Soft Shell Crab:  Amazingly, I found some roe inside.  At an American establishment!  I could only find crabs like this at Chinese restaurants.  Totally delicious!  Spicy  Perfectly fried.  10/10

2b. Crawfish Balls:  Well, this was different.  It's soft and mushy in the middle.  Almost like goop.  But it totally works!  Just the most savory, most intense flavor emanating from the center.  Like a ball of really thick yummy stew rolled up and fried.  Love it.  9/10

2c. Catfish:  Their catfish seemed kinda soft strangely.  Not sure why.  But anyway, it has less of that distinct catfish texture than I'd like.  Also, could use more seasoning.  6/10

2d. Oysters:  Yeah, also not my thing.  They cut the oysters up to make smaller pieces.  I would really much more enjoying biting into a huge, plump, fleshy lump.  But otherwise, it's still pretty juicy and flavorful considering that they increased the surface area, exposing more to the frying process.  7/10

2e. French Fries:  Completely unremarkable.  5/10

Oh!.... and....

2f. Coleslaw:  I cannot believe how enamoured I was with their coleslaw, which was actually very typical looking, superficially.  But it was just so fresh, crunchy, tangy and sweet.  The sauce was thick, very unlike the watery stuff in most other coleslaws.  I think they have sliced apples inside.  Might really be the best coleslaw I've had in my life!  10/10

So there you have it... was it the best fried seafood I've had in New Orleans?--honestly, I've had better catfish and some other stuff the last time I came to New Orleans half a decade ago at different restaurants, but overall, the fried foods were consistently excellent.

And of course, you get that local New Orleans vibe!  If you can stand that ridiculous hell of a line, you'll be well rewarded.  Trust me.

5/5

#neworleans #friedseafood #softshellcrab #friedoysters #friedcatfish #crawfishballs

We've visited Pho Quyen off and on over the past couple of years, and it has always been "good"; however, yesterday, we were quite surprised to see dramatic improvements across the board. They went from good to ... outstanding! First, they completely remodeled - understated elegance that work for lunch AND a nice dinner. Second, the food was a level higher: chicken pho melted in your mouth. The curried chicken Bun (salad) was out of this world!!! They have a full bar, wine, etc. and play good background music (classical guitar when we were there) that provides ambiance but is not distracting. We are looking forward to a return visit after the Holidays!

For the record, I cannot eat any of the food from here because of my dairy allergies.  I wanted to write a solid review for them, though, because the employees helped me pick out some amazing treats to bring to a holiday get-together.  They also didn't make me feel like a freak with food allergies; they really listened and treated me like every other customer, which I appreciated.  I was looking for a variety-pack of sorts, but then I was torn about possibly getting sticky buns instead.  I explained that I was headed to a party and the lady recommended I pick out a few of their brownie, cookie, and fruit bars for people to try.  She then proceeded to cube all them and place them neatly in a box so that everyone would be able to get a sample of each.   My coworkers were really impressed with each one (peanut butter blondie, double chocolate brownies, etc.), but they all agreed that the lemon pretzel bar was the winner.  This area of Washington Avenue is a little rough around the edges, but I'm glad that there's an excellent bakery up there that's doing some pretty sweet business.  Next time I have to grab dessert for someone's birthday celebration, I will make my way back here!

We give another star back to the recovering El Vez. With Sean and Stephano heading up the bar crew we have found service drastically improved. While always good to see Tom at the helm, the change in the kitchen is just as impressive as the new life at the bar.

Crab and cactus salsa is once again loaded with fresh ingredients and heaped with crab. Gone are the days of heaping pickled cactus floating in oil. Guacamole was also perfectly prepared, with the roasted sesame seeds bringing a wonderful richness to the large portion of tuna heaped upon avocado bliss.

Oh, how we long for the tuna salsa of old. May the Starr gods hear our plea to have this and the manchego cheese re-added to their pantheon of Salsa. Truly, the tuna, crab, and manchego flight was the best offering we had ever had from these kitchens.

We tried the black bass tacos, and the new presentation is both tasty to palate and eye. The mahi-mahi taco still reigns supreme. 

Keep up the Stellar Starr Service Sean and Stephano, and we hope to see the kitchen bring us those dishes that made you the great flagship of the Starr chain. The day I see those smokin' fajhitas walk the floor again, I'll know you guys are serious about being the best.

My wife, Sarah, loves salad bars. And we saw a Groupon for a buffet lunch, so we thought we'd give it a whirl. And while I don't think I'd spend $24 for this buffet, it's a fun experience for the Groupon price of $14 per person.

And while the salad selections are small compared to most salad bars, but very high quality - romaine and mixed greens, with a small selection of toppings and dressings.

In addition to the salads, there is a soup of the day, cold cuts, rolls, a pasta, sandwiches, and a dessert. (a fantastic bread pudding with melted chocolate).  Service is great - they made Sarah a pasta to order because she is allergic to goat cheese, which the buffet pasta came with).

The food is all very healthy and every single "course" had a vegetarian option. Don't come expecting a carvery or steak. This ain't Bonanza!

I don't know where else you can get a meal for two for $20, but this is my selection! My fiancé and I split the queso with chorizo and a taco salad. Delicious and only slightly over $20. Impressive! Plus, we were full. Juan's never disappoints, and they're usually pretty quick.

Popped in here for a treat after dinner with co-workers.

Adorable! It's an old house, with seating in and out, stools, tables etc.

I went for a teeny tiny scoop of the peanut brittle something or other. OMG - woah. Amazingly creamy and delicious!

And ... not fast. Not fast at all, but that could have been the 12 sundae's that had been ordered prior to our arrival. But really you shouldn't be in too much of a hurry to get some ice cream!

Definitely lots of desert options, ice cream, chocolate, candy and more. I just needed a little scoop but will definitely be back to try some other items!

Next up, the iconic Ted Drewes, a spot I'm actually surprised I did not visit even in my youth given its fame but a location that was perfectly situated in our eating agenda following a nearly 100 degree afternoon at the Missouri Botanical Garden.  Featuring frozen custard in a single flavor - vanilla - with hundreds of possible combinations of mix-ins to formulate your own customized concrete we were fortunate to arrive at an off-hour and after opting for four "Micromini" cups at $1.80 each the selections were packed in a bag with blocks of ice and spoons putting us back in the air conditioned car to enjoy less than 10 minutes after pulling off Route 66.

Soft, smooth, rich, and not overly sweet on its own I will admit that I did not flip the cup over to see just how "concrete" the concoction was, but certainly thicker than standard softserve despite the heat and humidity I've little doubt all but the melted portion would have stayed put.  Skipping the sundaes or options with too many variable and instead going with two fruit options but two choices suggested by the young woman at the counter I personally found the Tedad and Blueberry to both be excellent while the butterscotch was a bit thin and the sour cherry too artificial.  A fun spot and one of those "must visit" landmarks I cannot say I'd go out of my way for Ted Drewes, but I definitely wouldn't drive past it on a cross country trip - particularly in the middle of summer.

Is the older large scale interior 5 stars? No. Is service on par with Bern's? No. But the food is on point and highly unusual. Bursting with flavor.

So for a place that serves up fresh Lao dishes you can't get anywhere else in the area that are sumptuous and vibrant I'm all in. I want to get back and try more ASAP. 

In addition to some wild and interesting Laotian food they also serve sushi. It's a casual and friendly place. So fun to learn about a new cuisine. The decor and culture is also highlighted. And they have cool t-shirts for $12.

They were out of several dishes, but there was lots to try and I need to get back ASAP. Toy took good care of us. Get wowed with Lao adventures at tasty Sokhdii. It's a large place but usually quiet.

Mike and Yoon are wonderful people, had a great time trying and learning different things.  Nice intimate setting, very relaxed and enjoyable.  They make cooking a blast! Learned new techniques that I would've never known without coming here!

We came in on a Saturday night it it was pretty busy but we're able to be seated right away. Our server was very helpful especially after I ordered their beer samplers. He had to smell some of them in order to tell me which one I had ordered. Thought it was funny but knew it was something he had to do. J had ordered the Red Cider Wings and the bomb burger. It did take awhile to get the food, but hey it's Saturday night, they're busy and I have a lot of beer to sample. Let's just enjoy the night. 

I wasn't to crazy about the bomb burger. I'll just stick to your traditional burger. Felt like there was to much pizza dough and stuffs you up very quickly and felt like it absorbed too much of the juices and made it more difficult to eat. I'm not saying it wasn't good. It was damn good. One of those things where you don't mind trying different at least once. 

I would definitely come back, they had very good beers here. Service was amazing.

Well I have been coming here for years and it has always been a must stop for me and my family until this last visit. The prices have been jacked up and then you add in the parking fee across the street it becomes an absolute joke. Let me first say since moving to the South 3 years ago I have learned how to make the delicious muffaletta at home so it's not nearly the treat it used to be. I make it at home and it's so good so the need to drive to NOLA is not necessary unless you are in the area. I picked up my sister from the airport and of course she loves the place so we had to stop in. The price for the sandwich went up around $5 and everything was way marked up since the last time I was here (maybe a year) and at about $15 a plate now, it's just not worth it for me.  If you are a tourist you may want to stop in for lunch because it is a good sandwich and everyone visiting NOLA needs the muffaletta experience. After the $24 parking fee and the $50 lunch tab (3 sandwiches and 3 Cokes) plus a tip well it just became a $80 lunch. Not worth it and honestly I won't be back.

Glad we stopped in. The jazz on Frenchmen street is known for bringing in a less crazed crowd. The atmosphere right away was calmer. The band playing was mesmerizing. The female vocalist had a lovely raspy voice that took you to rustic simpler times.
The drinks were intricate and tasted light. 
My only confusion was that a we (a group of 3) went to the bar and upon seeing no seats- asked for a table (which there were 2) but we were told to go back outside and wait. We waited maybe 5 minutes. They said we would each have to order a plate to get a table. Only one of us was going to eat so they told us to go back to the bar then. We tried making space at the bar and then like twenty minutes later they said we could sit at the tables after all. I guess they had been waiting for more people who would dine and figured it wasn't happening. When a server passed by and we asked for another drink- she abruptly said we would have to order from the bar so my friend made his way to the bar again. It felt like we were bouncing from one end to the next so that interrupted us from enjoying the music at times.

Great burger place, In the Gultch part of Nashville. Popular destination. Very clean and well run. All staff is friendly and accommodating. They have lots of specialty toppings and ways to fix your sandwich. You pick the bread, protein and  side. 
We had a few drinks... a spiked milkshake (not sure when this became popular, daughter likes them) I got a cold one, son had coke. All came out quickly along with our fried pickle appetizer. It was a cup of thinly sliced, tart pickles, lightly floured and season cooked nicely, I little greasy but we gobbled them up quickly. 
We each got a burger, the fineness was not right on the kids burgers so they did a biology, dissection of their hamburgers to trade patties? Which I said we can just send them back, they seemed okay with it, we mentioned to the server because you hope they will look at their process and be better next time. The server promptly got the manager and she was very nice and said she will look into it. Which was fine, again just wanted them to know. 
All good we finish and the bill comes back with no drinks on it, not our intention to get free things, this manage wanted us to have a better experience. Thanks again to the staff and yes we did tip to the full bill ! 
I will be back!

This Ross is located in a little shopping center with other stores such as Bed, bath, and beyond, BJs, Petsmart, Joann's Fabric, and more. This store is really a hit or miss. Sometimes you find something and sometimes you don't. I like to look at the home and kitchen section because they sell things at a decent price. I like coming to this location since it's not too far from my house, but lately the shelves and racks been pretty empty.

First, this restaurant is on restaurant.com so if you are going on a weekday you should go on and get the discount. I really enjoyed the food and service. I had the butternut squash ravioli appetizer and loved it. The server and his assistant were always close by. There are tons of specials offered every night. I lived in this town but only went there once near the end. After trying the food, I realized my mistake. Because it is located on the far end of Farnsworth, people tend to overlook it. If you are in Bordentown, I suggest you walk all the way to the end of the street and give this place a chance!

It's a big ole CVS - like Walgreen's - a known quantity.  You get all the same type of packaged items you'd see at just about any CVS.  Pretty clean and tidy - no major complaints, but not much else to recommend it either.  Haven't had to use it for filling prescriptions - ymmv.

I go to Juan's once a week. Like clockwork. "Oh you went running? Feeling like you might be losing weight? LET'S GO TO JUAN'S AND EAT CHEESE AND GET FAT!!!!"

Everything on the menu is solid. It's predictable Mexican food, no surprises and the weight staff (j/k Staff) is consistently pleasant and accommodating. 

I usually end up with a quesadilla or the fajitas with lots of red and green salsa and queso.

My roommate loooooooves the tacos and can usually be found here on payday going crazy over the margaritas and anything with ground beef.

I don't think they take reservations, but you can usually get a table without waiting very long.

Viva la Juan's~!

(*Cash only!) The soup dumplings were the highlight of my Philly trip. They offer about 4 different kinds - we ordered crabmeat & pork and pork soup dumplings. I really couldn't tell the difference between the two, but both were delicious! 
**FYI, if you don't know how to eat these: bite the top off of the dumplings and pour in your desired sauce (usually vinegar sauce on the table), THEN sip/eat the dumpling all in one bite.

Knocking off one star because of the service and some entrees (not as tasty). Don't get me wrong, they were very quick to get our order.. but they were really rushing us and gave us attitude for not knowing what we wanted yet. 

Be prepared to know what you want to order ASAP, but the food is delicious and super reasonable/cheap prices. Also, stick to the appetizers. We ended up ordering too much food, so I would suggest ordering as you eat. The food comes out quickly so don't worry about sitting around and being hangry. I absolutely would come again.

I was lucky when I came here and was able to get a table for 7 in less than 15 minutes. They don't take reservations but I did see a high-profile looking man cut the line. So maybe you can squeeze your way through if you have connections or look as if you do. 

I tried the fresh oysters as well as the rockerfeller styled chargrilled oysters served with bread. Both were delicious and fresh. I also tried a soft shell crab po-boy that I thought was just ok (the crab was good but the bread was ok and it was bland because there was nothing else in it besides shredded lettuce). The hush puppies and fries were also ok and the fried shrimp was tasty (not too oily, perfectly breaded). The fried crab claws had sweet meat & were really fun to eat. Dinner for two here will cost around $45.

Ate here with a bunch of friends the other day. My only complaint: pricey for diner food. $7 for two eggs and bacon. Although I suppose that's to be expected in this ritzy itzy area. Other than that food was good, and the wait staff was super attentive and really hustled.
In the land of Ted Drews custard, this is a real alternative, its not ice cream, so just get over it and enjoy it for what it is. I like the hot fudge sundays and concretes.

We had a Sunday lunch here and it was ok, nothing great.  Maybe I'm spoiled since I live in Chicagoland, where there are plenty of fabulous restaurants.

We were celebrating an upcoming wedding and they seated us at a round table with a nearby spot to place the gifts on.  That table was almost an afterthought, crammed in the corner, just like us.

The service was ok, but she could have really done more with recommendations and just doing things like taking about plates and glasses faster.  We had a drink spill while the bride to be was trying to open a gift.  There just wasn't enough room.

I had a hard time ordering because they use lots of sauces and I have a dairy allergy.  Yes, it's a pasta place, so you have sauce there, but many of the breakfast entrees are saucy as well.  I ordered a salad which was fine.  The other people in my party ordered breakfast and lunch items.  I didn't hear any raves about it.

Overall I was a bit disappointed here.  My sister picked it out, so it wasn't my choice, but given that it was in the Plaza Frontenac area, I just expected more.

It's always a wait for the most part , but for good reason. The food is fresh, hot and delicious. I have not been disappointed by this restaurant and staff. I recommend not eat all the Cajun potatoes that are free with the meal due to getting full before your entree.

There are so many good Vietnamese spots in Philly but this one is in NJ close to Philly but nearly as good.   I love their bo luc lac, house fried rice and summer rolls.  Parking is easier here too and service is good.

Had a wonderful time brunching on a Saturday morning in the quarter. The interior, especially by the bar, is beautiful. Great atmosphere from the architecture, to the furniture, to the music in the background. The french doors were open to let in the breeze and the sounds from the street. Almost wanted to sit at the sidewalk tables, but too many carriage tours pass by for that, ha! 

That morning they were running a tasting menu for a great price - choose an app / entree / dessert - so my husband went that direction and loved everything! App of fried green tomatoes w/ shrimp, entree of crawfish etoufee, and dessert of bread pudding. He washed it down with the strawberry lemonade, made in house, and also super tasty. I went with an egg sandwich served on a croissant; I added spinach and onions for extra deliciousness. One of the best yet simple breakfast sandwiches I'd had in long time. Washed my meal down with a $15 bottle of Champagne (can't beat that!). The prices were super affordable, and well worth the stop in for a great meal. We'll definitely be back!

My friend's mother is the one who recommended Mother's to us. She told us that this is one of the good places to go to that is open on Sundays. Mother recommending Mother's?!? Tee hee hee! It seemed like an incredibly cute start to what I was hoping to be an amazing food adventure! So off we went.

I had their shrimp creole with a side of collard greens and red beans and rice. I also asked for a cup of jambalaya. The sides were all very tasty, but I am not a fan of the shrimp creole. The shrimps were overcooked and it was just really not very good. 

However, given the fact that my choices for the sides just seem to be a really bad combination, I would have been more forgiving had the staff been nicer. I don't know if it was because I have gotten spoilt by the niceness and hospitality I was shown before this visit, but the staff at Mother's just seemed to be so unhappy to have customers. Nary a "hello" or a smile was to be dispensed by them, it seemed like. 

I think it was Phyllis Diller who said that "A smile is a curve that sets everything straight." And really, I would have taken the blame for the less-than-impressive meal I had if the staff had shown me even the smallest hint of a shadow of a reluctant smile. But as it is, I am just left to say that I would not be going back to this place ever again if I can help it.

Review is only for happy hour, which is 3-6PM.*

Happy hour drink prices are regular priced at other bars/restaurants. At $8 a drink, it didn't feel like a happy hour. But the drinks were good, so I give them that. 

Popcorn catfish - fried catfish bites with some mixed greens underneath, topped off with some gravy. This was good, but not great. 

1 dozen oysters - $9 a dozen. They were fine. 

Oyster shooters - they come out in 6 and are topped off with abita Amber. We absolutely hated these. Lol. But to each their own. 

Wedge salad - served with green goddess dressing. Nothing to write home about. 

Alligator tamales - my friend said it reminded her of chef boyardee ravioli, I didn't try it so I can't confirm. But also said she still enjoyed it. Lol. 

Crawfish pie - the best thing we had. They were sooo good and it's served with grits. The filling came oozing out. Omg. 

Grilled shrimp - can't remember the exact name, but it comes with three. This was really nothing special. 

I had the mango margarita ($5 S/$8 L) - this was good and pretty strong! I really enjoyed it. And a cosmo - it's made with svedka vodka. Actually very tasty. 

Service was great. Adam really helped us out and engaged with our table. It was a fun time. Even when we ordered a little after the 6PM happy hour time, we were still given the happy hour price. Yay!

I found this restaurant on Yelp after planning a COVID-19 safe day trip. The restaurant was very nicely appointed with modern touches including prints of Japanese postcards. They have an outdoor dining area upstairs and downstairs. We enjoyed the monkfish liver, which was expensive but very good at $24. The hostess and staff were very attentive and thoughtful. I highly recommend Oku in Santa Barbara.

After seeing one of my coworker's with the  KFC $5 Fill Up (or as Daym Drops calls it "the $5 Holla") yesterday, I decided to see what the business was:

3 piece chicken (w barbeque sauce): 3.5/5 Now usually I hate circus side show carny food, yeah I called chicken tenders clown food. Lol   But that day, I didn't feel like tackling a piece of chicken with a bone and that was actually a good call on my part.  The tenders were actually the best part of the food part of the meal. Breading was oh so lovely hot, crispy in all the right places and flavorful. The chicken itself was on point; tender to the bite with effortless action on the chew. The barbq sauce was like sweet baby rae's lil cousin ..better than I expected.

Mashed Potatoes and Gravy: 1/5 yeah ok uh Well the good is that it was hot but now the bad: the mashed potatoes had a taste like straight box instant taste. 

Biscusit:0/5 KFC has the worst biscuit in the chicken fast food game. This shouldn't even be called a biscuit but a bread roll lump d lump. I had to mix it with the mashed potatoes. Popeye's come save me!!!

Cookie: 2/5 Nothing to write home about. Tasted like those 3 for $.99 chocolate chip cookies @ Walmart

Strawberry Soda: 5/5: The best was last.....  It was a straight 5 all day!!!

Overall: 3/5 I would get it again but I might see how much extra $ the potatoes wedges would be instead of the mashed potatoes

the best food in new orleans!

we came several times in the few days we stayed in new orleans. we ordered

cochon muffaletta
pastrami
pork belly
cubano
gambino

aboslutely delicious sandwiches that are huge and well priced!

This is one of my friendly neighborhood supermarkets. This Publix is smaller than most and has a smaller selection than other Publix stores. The staff are helpful and I can always count on buying a BOGO item that was not on my grocery list since the BOGO items are always great. There are always ice-cream and coookies on sale. Publix has my heart!

We went on this swamp tour linked with the plantation tour to Laura Plantation and Oak Alley Plantation.  I think my friend simply picked up the brochure in our hotel and went with it.  I'll focus on the swamp tour but we were able to schedule on the same day with no problems and even added a friend who arrived after without problems either.  The bus ride was bumpy, don't sit right over the wheels in the back because every time we hit a bump, I hit my head and I'm only 5'9"!

Once we arrived to the swamp, we were taken on a tour by Bishop, our knowledgeable and friendly guide.  We were loud and rambunctious, but he was great about it.  We went in February and the weather was cold, in the 40-50s during the day so bundle up! Once he speeds the boat up, it is COLD so be warned.  Since it was the winter, we didn't see many alligators as they were hibernating and come up sporadically for air.  I got to see the various animals in the swamp which was cool and learned about the local plant life as well.  I got some great photos which was nice.  Since we missed out on seeing actual alligators in the swamp, we had the opportunity to handle a baby alligator in the gift shop after the tour.  I got to take photos.  

All in all, an enjoyable tour.  I liked that since I was visiting and didn't have a car, they were able to come to pick us up for the tour.  Fortunately I got to sleep during the ride to the swamp.  Just remember to pick your seat carefully so you don't bump your head, dress warm if you go in the winter and enjoy.  Fun guide and fun times! I can't complain!

Ok last year was a crappy year for me medically speaking. I had accidents, illnesses, you name it, and it happened to me. 

When I (actually being sober) fell down my stairs in my house ended up on crutches.

Of course the medical supply store was closed so Pootchie and I drove ALL over Reno to every Wal Mart, Walgreens and CVS at midnight looking for a pair of crutches and THIS CVS was the ONLY store in all of Reno that had crutches for my height! I'm 5'6 which apparently is the most popular height of people who break their legs because they had plenty of crutches for people shorter or taller but none for me.

So this CVS became my favorite place just because it meant I didnt have to hop around like a lunatic.

On one of the walls in the dining room is a quote from, Craig Culver. It says, "People know quality when they taste it." I must agree with him and on my visit today, my ButterBurger tasted no different then a burger I'd get at the Golden Arches. So, today I am taking away a Star on my Yelp rating. 

My guest and I were both craving a ButterBurger and could not believe our disappointment. Seriously, they were no different then the ones we'd get at other fast food chains. Our onion rings didn't seem to be the same either. 

However, the crinkle fries and the Root Beer were still the same quality we remembered. I also, give a shout out to the staff. They were upbeat, cheerful and full of energy. I don't know if they were short staffed, but those working had some pep in their step and were getting things done at a quick pace. 

I'm hoping the drop in burger quality is just a pandemic thing and not the way of the future. I'll be back or I'll stop by another Culver's in the near future to see how things improve. 

When: September 1, 2021
Why: Needed a ButterBurger

I love Chinese food, but I have such hard time finding one that I like, most Chinese restaurant around town are Americanized, where the real Chinese food flavor get mixed with fries and hamburgers in the food court mall. Fustian Asian Bistro got me excited again to have real Chinese food, like I use eat it at my favorite Chinese restaurant in Germany. The fuchsia atmosphere is very pleasant and warm, the server was very friendly answering the many questions I asked about the menu, I ordered the chili chicken soup, it was wonderful! And I also ordered the vegetable spring rolls, they were so good, I place two extra orders to go, for the main meal I ordered chicken with peanut, cashew, chili and cucumber. It was pretty good, but the cucumber was too slippery for an inexperience chopstick user like me. Since I am a big dumpling fan, i ordered the shrimp dumpling, they tasted so good, I know i will be going back soon for more. Overall, I had a real wonderful experience at the Fushia Asian Bistro, I will be going back with a bunch of friend so we can sample more food.

This place seems like a half-assed attempt at an upscale Thai restaurant. 
The food is hit or miss..the waitstaff is miss and miss...The prices do nothing for me.
My girly's Garden soup tasted like it was made from cilantro, cilantro and some cilantro thrown in for good measure.
My Shrimp in a pouch was ok. Nothing special but I didn't hate it.
We shared a hot basil chicken because usually at Thai places, one meal and two appetizers are way more than we need.
Not so much here... The chicken seemed old and the cilantro was over-powering the basil (Love basil, hate cilantro). The waitress took an extra 20 minutes to bring our bill AFTER the plates were cleared...so we sat there at an empty table all that time trying to flag someone down without being too rude. Finally I just help up a hand and yelled. She didn't like that too much but such is life.

And never trust a reviewer that can "promise" you that all reviews that don't match theirs MUST be from people who never ate at a place.
Because seriously...How arrogant is that?

Possibly the best roast beef poboy in the city. Fettuccine alfredo was also on point.  If your limping off bourbon, and looking for some good New Orleans cusine, this is a good spot with 0 wait time.  I promise you will not be disappointed.

I enjoy the massive chicken tenders here. I like all the sauce options also. The food quality is good and I like fun environment here.  It feels like a college hangout.  They have good sides here also.  To be honest though, I don't know if the meals here are much better than Canes but I prefer this place to support local businesses.

This was my first time having Five Guys.  I'm sure I'll be back.  Not often, because it would probably kill me, but I'll be back.

I went with the regular which is actually two patties.  I also chose "all the way" which was everything in black on the menu for toppings.  Off the top of my head, lettuce, tomato, mayo, ketchup, pickles, mustard, grilled onions, grilled mushrooms.  Wow, this was a freakin big burger.  Next time I'll go with the small (one patty)

The burger was pretty good.  I can say that my taste in burgers has definitely been skewed by the fancy burgers I get downtown.  This is a whole 'nother category.  This is like a fast food burger but with really fresh toppings.  Sure they give you two, but it sits pretty damn heavy.  The bun was nothing to speak of.  It was a bit soggy by the time I ate it because it soaked up the stuff that was on my burger.

The fries are great!  When you walk in they have 50lb bag of potatoes on the right hand side and they even have a small chalkboard showing you which farm they are from.  Nice touch, I like that.  When you eat them, they aren't battered, just cooked properly.  Crispy outside, soft inside.  Everything a good fry should be.

So I'll be back.  I'll tone down the burger order and most likely enjoy my experience a bit more.

i've been wanting to try this place since their opening on broadway/kolb. i am always looking for a great pizza!

came here for lunch yesterday with a friend and got there about 15 minutes before they opened. we sat outside on a nice bench in the front. time came and went and it was finally past 11AM. i guess i didn't hear them unlock the door. usually, when you see people waiting outside your establishment, it's common practice to let them know you're open and to come on in.

the hostess sat  us at the booth immediately behind her stand. the interior decor was nice. very modern, comfy seats in the booths.

the menu had a decent selection. there are appetizers, salads, pizzas and "sammies" (sandwhiches) to choose from.

we started with the garlic parmesan wings. they're bone in, which i don't mind but they should consider getting bone out options as well.  the garlic parmesan was good. lots of garlic. a bit greasy, though. they were served with a side of ranch dressing.

also ordered a build your own pizza. basically cheese (added ricotta and garlic). it came out alright. the edges were charred because of the fire oven. i don't mind that either, it adds some good flavor to the pizza. but it really dried out the crust. the toppings i got weren't too tasty, and i felt like they kind of skimped on the cheese. 

service was okay. kind of slow, considering we were the only people in there for the first 20 minutes. i really hate asking for refills on my beverages, but i had to wave the guy over a couple of times. 

may consider this place in the future, but not again anytime soon. there are other places around tucson that have way more to offer.

I have been a fan of the Florida Cane Distillery since their former location off of Falkenburg Road. I was happy to hear that they had moved and were now located in Ybor City. I finally had the chance to stop by today prior to our afternoon Yelp event. 

Since my visit in 2013, FCD has added more flavors and more liquors. In addition to their Vodka, they also sell four different flavors of Moonshine, two flavors of Gin, and two flavors of a Bloody Mary Mix (they had me at bacon). 

I tried so many flavors it was hard to keep track! I tasted the Beach Bum Berry, Weeki Wachee Watermelon, Miami Mango Vodka, and the Okeechobee Cherry. Of the four, the Beach Bum Berry was my favorite.

I also tried two of the Moonshines: the Sunrise and the Sunset. The Sunrise tasted of a fresh baked apple pie, buttery vanilla, with a hot pepper kick. The Sunset was my favorite which tasted of English Toffee with a hint of oranges.

The Bloody Mary Mix was also delicious! There are two flavors available: Chipotle and Bacon. I tasted the Chipotle and it wasn't too spicy for a wimp like me. 

Jessie and Tamara were very personable and attentive during our visit. We were even treated to two amazing cocktails: one made with the Lemon Lime Vodka and Ginger Beer and one made with the Strawberry Vodka and Lemonade. Both cocktails were delicious! Thank you for adding to our Sunday Funday! 

A word to the wise: if you don't drink too often, you may want to eat something before you start your tasting. 

FCD is open Thursday through Sunday and is available for private parties and tastings. Definitely stop by and give Florida Cane Distillery a try!

Marcellas was an unexpected good surprise.  In fact it was unexpected all the way until the first bite I took of my food.  When we first arrived, we noted the server never wore a mask.  That bothered us.  Then while we looked at menus I noticed the prices on mine were $1 more than the prices on my wife's menu.  That bothered us.  We each ordered a chicken burrito, not expecting much of anything. Then...like a switch was flipped, the food arrived.  The burritos were like tortilla wraps that had been pressed in a panini-press.  The chicken was tender white meat, & the accompanying ingredients were fresh & flavorful.  They mixed in avocado, tomato, lettuce, beans, rice, & cilantro.  The server brought out sour cream & a delicious salsa which we topped every bite with.  The flavor combo was equivalent to deliciousness-on-steroids.  Sure, the price of each burrito was the higher price found on my menu.  But the food was so wonderful, everything that bothered us disappeared.  We are excited now to take friends here.  The place is a tiny hole.  The menus are different from each other.  The server doesn't wear a mask.  And there was a language barrier since they speak Spanish & we only speak English.  You know what?  Adversity makes for adventure!  What an awesome experience!

My lunch experience at iNDO yesterday was phenomenal! I am so happy to see yet another great restaurant pop up in the Botanical Heights neighborhood. 

iNDO's lunch service is casual, walk-in counter service as opposed to their dinner service which requires a reservation. Right when you walk in the door for lunch, you'll see a friendly staffer at the counter ready to take your order. If you need a suggestion on what to get, they are happy to share recommendations for your food and drink options. 

I ordered the Tom Yum Pork Skins, the Pork Lettuce Wraps and a canned 1220 Spirits Lemonade and Lavender drink. 

The staffer then gave me a number and said I could sit anywhere I wanted. And they meant it because I sat in what is probably the waiting area for dinner service! I wanted to witness all the counter interactions for lunch. No judgement though! 

The Tom Yum Pork Skins arrived first, and man oh man were they tasty! The tom yum powder sprinkled all over the fried pork skins is so flavorful! And what an incredibly crispy crunch! Dip it in the included Chive Aioli and you've got yourself a savory mouth party! 

After demolishing the pork skins and while waiting for my lunch entree I watched the genuine interactions happening at the counter and bar area. Curious folks stopped by to take a peek at this new Chef Nick Bognar venture. The staff, including Nick, greeted everyone who came in, were happy to talk to people about the restaurant and give them menus to go, and chatted it up with patrons sitting in the bar area. 

When my Pork Lettuce Wrap entree arrived it was gorgeous. Never have I seen a more well-styled lettuce wrap dish in St. Louis. The pork strips were tender with lots of juicy fat for flavor. The real flavorful showstoppers in this dish though are the sauces included. The orange sauce is creamy, savory with a bit of heat while the green sauce starts out sweet and has a spicy finish. 

I can't wait to make a dinner reservation soon to experience iNDO's omakase (I'll leave it up to you) style dinner service. Thanks so much, iNDO!

Everytime i enter Nola I always try to make La Michoacana a must stop. 

Mangonada is a MUST try. Spicy, sweet, salty, mango-y yumminess. It's definitely an acquired taste. 
I would honestly just eat the mango soft serve or whatever it is by itself. 

Mango Fresca .. I didn't like this drink at all.. I asked what was their most popular flavor and mango was recommended. 
I'm not sure if the mango was just old or what but I didn't taste fresh at all..

The soda Float drink was yummy.!

The strawberry in a cup with cream was refreshing! Honestly, so so worth the cost. Loaded with fresh strawberries and cream! I wouldn't drink it though as it's loaded with condensed milk... super sweet!

Elote is always a treat everywhere I go.
I like mine without the tangy Valentino sauce.

This location is slowly winning me over as a regular and it is doing it at good pace. 
I stop here on my way home from work, so I do not need to pass my house and visit the one at Hampton Village. I'm thinking in the future, instead of going to HV from home, I'll head over here to Arsenal. 

I'm still not comfortable with the lay out of this store, but I can learn a new floor plan. 
The vegetable and fruit department is smaller, but the selection seems to be fresher. 
I rarely buy my meat from Schnucks, but the butcher counter here is as good as any other location. I also, like the fact that they periodically offer samples. I have never seen samples being passed out at Hampton Village. 

What truly sets this location above other locations, is that the staff still practices Schnucks old motto, "the friendliest stores in town".  They by far have the best customer service skills of "any" grocery store I have shopped in the Lou. Having this, makes it worth the drive of a couple extra blocks. 

Another side note making it worth to shop, it has some of the best eye candy in town. 
Whatever catches your eye,  you'll see some hottie's in the store.

New Five Guys location. Standard setup. Team behind plexiglass, tables spaced, masks required.  Spotlessly clean.  Encouragingly, the ketchup dispenser, bottles of vinegar and box of peanuts are back out and available for self serve.

Burger delicious as always. Fries scrumptious as always.  Service quick and friendly.  My favorite fast food burger.

Acme Oyster House came highly recommended from almost everyone of my friends, family, and co-workers that I asked about for places to eat in NOLA so I knew it was without question that my friends and I would have some sort of meal here, one way or another! To my dismay, I found out that they didn't take reservations so I just told my friends that we should try to go during off-peak hours, preferably the Monday during our stay since we didn't want to experience the waiting times on Saturday or Sunday.  

After we did a late morning walking tour of the city, we were famished and took a chance in going to Acme to see how the lines were. We were pleasantly surprised when we only saw a dozen or so people waiting in line. Someone was outside going down the line taking names - when they got up to us, they said it would only be about 20 min for 4 people. They asked us if we wanted seats at the bar, a table, or whatever came first. We were pretty hungry so we all agreed that whatever came first was just fine. We were seated in about 15 minutes. 

The menu was not large at all but basically EVERYTHING looked appetizing on it. We ordered a  1/2 dozen of the Raw Oysters and a  1/2 dozen of the Chargrilled Oysters to start off with. We also ordered a round of their Cinnamon Toast Crunch beverage which was Fireball Whiskey and Orchata Cinnamon Cream Rum. The drink was delicious! There was also cinnamon and sugar outlining the glass which really made this drink a dessert more than anything. The Oysters came out after a little bit and the raw ones were huge and so fresh, it was like you were tasting the ocean. The Chargrilled ones were just as mouth-watering. I ordered the Seafood Etouffee and asked for a side of the Fried Crawfish Tails. Up until this point, we hadn't yet had a chance to try Crawfish and since our trip was quickly nearing to an end, I figured even if it was just the fried tails, that we get to experience them. The Etouffee was AMAZING. I had never had this dish before but the flavors were just out of this world. The roux was super buttery and rich. I ate every drop of the dish and used the rice to mop up every last bite. Back in Jersey, I'm already doing Yelp searches on restaurants here that serve Etouffee. They probably won't match up to NOLA's but my taste buds definitely want more!

Even though we were stuffed, we had to try the New Orleans Bread Pudding w/ Whiskey Sauce and we cleaned the plate! It was delish!!

This was probably my favorite place to eat in NOLA! Super causal, delicious food, and even with drinks, our grand total wasn't crazy!! Looking fwd to returning whenever I'm back in NOLA!

This was my favorite Vietnamese place in town!  Unfortunately for it, I think Asian Noodles over in the Costco plaza is much better . . . I'd take back a half star if I could, but they get the benefit of the doubt, and will remain rounded up to 5 stars . . . 

I hadn't had much experience with pho when I moved out to Reno back in 2006, but I've had plenty since then, thanks to the large number of choices here.

Atmosphere isn't anything special.  Just a bunch of tables, packed in pretty close.  No fancy lighting, decorations - just functional.  Pretty crowded during lunch.  They can accommodate pretty large groups as well (tables in the middle can easily sit 8).

Personal favorite is #12, the thin-sliced rare beef, and the spring rolls.  Great broth, and perfect for a cool day or if you're fighting that cold - hot broth, chili peppers, and smoke-free.  Yum!

We came here after our dinner at Van Goghz.  It was a hair above 30 degrees, so not the ideal weather for frozen anything. After some debate, I got the regular Cardinal Sin. I liked the texture a lot better than ice cream and it's a little more solid than frozen yogurt. Chocolate and cherries is a combination that never disappoints. It definitely warrants a return trip the next time I'm in town.

Welcome back to the Treasure Valley the best fast-food Mexican restaurant chain. There were once four locations in Boise alone but they went away. The last location in Nampa, which had been there for decades,  closed two years ago.

Welcome to Meridian. Tacos, Taco Bravos and Potato Oles are back.

Order them with hot red sauce and superhot green. Leave the mild sauce for the kids. This is the first location where I've seen a hot sauce bar. Besides the three sauces mentioned above, they also have a chunky salsa and jalapeno slices.

This is nearly next door to Rocky Mountain High School, so you might plan your visit when the students are in class. Otherwise, you may be waiting in line.

I went back to Dallas Pizza & Steak House yesterday and this time I opted for takeout pizza. Gotta say, probably one of the best pizzas I've had in a long time. They have a few signature pizzas and build your own (obvz), but I went for the Greek Pizza. Olives, onions, fresh tomatoes, green peppers and feta cheese. 

I placed the order then went back 30 mins later to collect it. The lady who served me was lovely! She was super friendly and even gave my daughter a lollipop and a colouring sheet to take home. I told her I recently moved nearby and she gave me a menu to keep, I had no idea they also do deliveries! Great to know. Looking at the menu... it's a lot more than just pizza and steak, there's salads, pastas, donairs and burgers. I haven't veered from steak and pizza as of yet. But happy to know I can get a steak dinner delivered to my door ;)

Back to my pizza.... I got a large for three of us to share and it was enormous. It is more like a deep dish pizza, all those toppings stashed under the delicious cheese! You can't pick any toppings off, which could be an issue for kids or picky eaters. Because the toppings were hidden, my daughter ate it all, including the olives! Even the base sauce was rich and flavourful. I can't fault it. I'll definitely be choosing Dallas over any other pizza place around. 
In fact, I'm eating the leftovers for breakfast right now, and it's still good.
