Very inexpensive, and you get what you pay for. We were pleasantly rejuvenated and I would say it was a decent massage experience overall

Combo 30min body/30min feet - very mediocre body massage; I asked for the firmest pressure possible and it was more of a gentle touch, with minimal attention to key pressure points. Not deep tissue by any stretch of the imagination. 

However, the foot massage portion was AMAZING. Definitely worth your time. Sometimes foot massages focus on weird areas and end up being more uncomfortable than pleasant - however, this was anything but that and my little feetsies were so happy afterwards.

The overall ambiance is nice - no private rooms; however it is very clean, professional, and quiet with peaceful music (same three tracks on repeat), and the price is basically unbeatable. While getting my foot massage, I noted some of the other masseuses really seemed to know what they were doing, so perhaps if you get the right masseuse, the body massage would be better.

This was my first evening in Philadelphia, and our hotel is close to Chinatown (what a lovely surprise)! After exploring many historical sites, our feet were tired and we were ready for dinner. Sakura was awfully packed, so we picked up a take out menu to explore as we walked through Chinatown. Fatigue got the best of us and we returned to Sakura and ordered Edamame, Egg Drop soup, a Spider Roll and General Tso's chicken. We were welcomed with a pot of tea, not a cup, but a pot! The food was delicious, but the service could have been better. Sometimes hungriness blinds me and makes time crawl. Overall, it was a wonderful first real meal in Philly! Looking forward to more this weekend!

This little place was such a hidden gem in its old location on 11th, and what a great upgrade at the new location! 

The Shanghai Steamed Pork Juicy Buns now "pork soup dumplings" are out of this world (and the Crabmeat & Pork and Pork dumplings are delicious too!) The Shredded Pork Ho Fun noodles are also just incredible. And these are just my favorites - I've tried several other buns, dumplings & noodles with friends at Dim Sum and have always been blown away by the flavor. 

I never felt rushed in their old location, and wondered if things would be much slower in their new one. While the place is larger, the service is still pretty quick, and the staff is as friendly as ever. Throw in the fact that it's a BYO and you can't get a more delicious meal for less anywhere else in Chinatown.

After a long day in Longwood Gardens, we passed through West Chester and found the Social on Yelp. It was one of the cheaper, but classier places in town.

Our service was a little choppy at first because of a misunderstanding, but our waitress eventually greeted us and everything went uphill from there! 

Instead of bread, they give you biscuits and butter which was very decadent, so I didn't end up eating too much. 

I ordered the Thai sandwich (sriracha aioli, peanuts, blackened chicken, no teriyaki pig candy which is basically kind of bacon) and it was really good. The peanuts were a little much for me after a while but the flavors were so good, and the chicken had a perfect amount of kick. It came with a huge pile of house chips which were good, but I was stuffed just after eating my sandwich. I also got an Arnold Palmer, which was sweetened only with lemonade, but I found myself not needing any sugar. 

My dad got a burger and my mom got a salad which she ate all of - and she doesn't usually have a big appetite!

If I lived in the area, I'd definitely visit again.

I like the snowballs here, although i find them to be very sweet. The best thing is that they are open late! I prefer the sugar free or the ice cream to the regular snow balls, but there is always a line which says good things!

Really beautiful restaurant . Food and service was great . We had a very nice server . She came right away with the water And then these hot towels to clean our hands a very nice touch .
I ordered the miso soup and it was delicious. Also had the veggie avocado roll . I am learning to like the spicy  wasabi. Hubby had the shrimp roll and he said it was really good 
I now know why wasabi is served with sushi . The reason is some like  it hot but also for the raw fish to kill off parasites.
Would I come back here and eat most definitely yes. Parking is ample . Everyone following COVID plan .

My Beau and I love coming here for the grouper nuggets. They're out favorite.  

We love their fried fish and their sangria. The service is always good too! You can bet I'll be coming back quite frequently as love as I'm with my current guy.

New Orleans is where the voodoo culture came into existence.  It's an underground religious practice that terrified many, including myself.  In hopes of learning more about voodoo, I purchased a ticket for the Haunted History Voodoo Tour which was $25 per person.  You can buy your ticket online OR come to Reverend Zombie's Voodoo Shop. 

As a forewarning, before you purchase, they tell you that this voodoo tour is NOT meant to scare, but to inform.  They hope to disprove that voodoo is NOT as evil as Hollywood portrays it to be--at tour's end they did just that. 

That night, my tour guide was Daphne, an authentic voodoo witch doctor who truly practices voodoo everyday.  (supposedly the ONLY voodoo tour guide that practices)  I felt lucky to have her because she was enthusiastic, hilarious, and knowledgeable about voodoo practices.  While walking the streets of the French Quarter, Daphne told stories that was educational and entertaining.  She taught us the history behind voodoo while showcasing the famous landmarks of Marie Laveau, the mother of Voodoo.  She even showed us some personal artifacts that she uses everyday too!
----
Conclusion: Daphne did an excellent job of piquing my interest for voodoo.  If curious about this culture, I recommend it.  Ask for Daphne as she's one of the better story tellers I've come across.  I just wish they would implement a food/bar crawl with the story telling! Remember to tip your tour guide or else they'll put a spell on you! Jk

Extra Notes:
-CASH ONLY at the Reverend Zombie's Voodoo Shop, but ticket can be purchased online with credit card here:
http://www.neworleans.com/tours/shop/french-quarter-voodoo-tour/
-Arrive 30 minutes before departure time
-Each tour lasts for about 1.5-2 hours
-Tour is only available on Friday-Sunday
-Bring an umbrella and dress in layers
-Wear comfortable shoes
-No restroom breaks

Not to be mistaken for the chain of Capital Grille steakhouses that are out there- this Capitol Grille stands alone . . .with a menu of sustainable food items that are grown on a local farm mere miles from the restaurant.  With a definite southern flair, the food is imaginative and interesting.

Not being a southern girl, myself, some of the things that are on the menu are worth trying . . . .things like okra, hominy, pickled this and that, and cornbread puree . . .none of which is common on menus in other parts of the country.

So imagine my delight in the Carolina flounder dish that I picked which was two small pieces of flounder atop a mix of okra, beans, peas, tomatoes, corn accompanied by some type of light sauce.  Delightful and light.  Good thing it was light for as a side I went with the truffled mac and cheese which was delicious with just the right amount of bread crumbs and cheese.  

Know before you go that portion sizes are not large, rather they are restrained.  So if you are used to getting a huge plate of food this is not going to be the case here.  Also know that the prices are steep as well- my fish entree was $34 with no sides.  Add in a $7 side or two and you are quickly reminded that this is fine dining.

And you gotta love a place that serves Jack Daniels ice cream for dessert.  Yep.  A small scoop, albeit, but it was delicious with just the right amount of flavor.

The ambiance is classy, after all, this is The Hermitage, and the staff is welcoming, informed and well trained to make your evening an unforgettable experience.

Definitely a great choice for before the theater or for a special occasion.  Guess I'm going to have to go back as I never did learn what clabber cream was on the menu.  Ah . .the joys of southern cooking!
This is a great Mexican restaurant in Middle Tennessee and the inside of very pretty. Had them cook some food for a lunch I was doing at one of my doctor's offices and everyone loved the food.

Came here at 3:00 PM on a Monday and the place was packed. Before I even ate the food, I figured that they must be doing something right for it to be so crowded. We sat at the oyster bar since no tables were available. I wanted to be introduced to New Orleans food, so I ordered the New Orleans medley. It had seafood gumbo, jambalaya, red beans and rice, and grilled smoke sausage. It was delicious. And so far, I still have no stomach ache while writing this review which is a positive. A coworker ordered the chargrilled oysters and I was offered several. They were just awesome. The chargrilled oyster was my favorite food there. And it should be, since it is an oyster house! Also had some of my coworker's fried shrimp player which was good. Anything that is fried is usually good. 

The employee at the oyster bar didn't seem to be in the greatest mood, but he may have just been tired cracking open the oysters. Nevertheless, we received our food quickly and our hunger was satisfied. If you want grilled oysters, this is the place to go.

Well, Yelp does it again! We were heading back to the Phoenix area and thought we'd grab a treat before hitting I-10 so of course I consulted yelp to see what my fellow helpers might suggest. We found our way to The Screamery and are oh so glad we did! I had a scoop of the cookie dough and it is definitely amongst the best I've had! Oh so good and the service was friendly and efficient. The place itself was well maintained and clean. The only challenge was finding parking but the quality of the product makes up for that! Good good good stuff!

This sno-ball stand already gets a solid four stars from me based on the fact that they're open till 10 PM most nights. After all, where else can you get a sno-ball from on a Monday night after 8 PM? They're also open year round!! Perfect for people like me who still enjoy sno-balls in 50 degree weather! Lol.

We go here because it's around the corner from my bf's house and there's never a line. There's tons of flavors and toppings to choose from. The staff at the window are a great help with suggesting flavors if you're unsure of what to get. My favorite is their chocolate sno-ball stuffed with swirl ice cream with plenty of condensed milk on top. Messy and sticky but SO GOOD!!!

I grew up being Publix-loyal and continue to be loyal to Publix.  There are 2 within a mile of my house and couldn't be happier.

This particular location has been my location of choice and believe this one's layout and offerings are more than sufficient.

I have even found more recently with higher demand for gluten free products and more healthy options, they have stepped up and stocked some different options in both of these areas.

I order bakery and deli specialties, I request special things from the meat counter, the staff is always very nice and usually very helpful.

I am not a fan of the fish counter, I don't find the fish to be very good...and when I've requested a certain brand of black beans, they've ordered/stocked them and have continued to keep them stocked!  When the Diet Rite white grape flavor was all of a sudden missing from the shelves, I requested to order those and received a call stating that they don't produce it anymore.  Any time you have a question, you will find someone to help.

The store is clean, it is easy to find times to go when it is not crazy busy and again the convenience of where it's located is a huge plus.

The cakes made by Publix are AWESOME and their desserts are really great.  Some of my traditional faves here are the carrot cake bar, the chocolate tres leche (I don't even like tres leche) and the eclairs.  The turnovers (cherry or apple) heated in the toaster over are great too!

Very happy with this store overall and typically don't shop anywhere else.

If you take just one thing from this review, it should be: Go for the "top shelf" Margarita.  It's just $2 more and it's hard-core--no Margie mix.  I saw one of the servers pouring four "top shelf"s together for another table while drinking my humdrum house version.

I learned something that night.  You're going to invest $7 in a weakened cocktail.  Why not spend 28.6 per cent more for, like, a 100 per cent better drink?  If you can't afford $9 for a quality beverage, but you can handle $7 for averageness, better get down to basics and stick with water, which is also good here.

The food is fine for Reno Mexican.  On the Gilbert's (Pico at 26th, Santa Monica) Scale it's a solid 3++-star, divey hangout in a modest Sparks strip mall.  Prices seem a little steep for the 'hood--they parallel Gilbert's--and Macho's surely doesn't have the same monthly nut.

Carnitas wet burrito (enchilada-style) was decent, a 50-50 mix of meat and refried beans, which for me is not enough meat, and enchilada sauce that was bland in light of the eye-opening spiciness of their chilled green and red salsas.

Carnitas taco salad was workmanlike, housed in a freshly fried, fluted flour tortilla shell--unique in that it was pleasant to munch on, and didn't taste stale and/or rancid.  Corn tortilla chips were another bright spot, homemade and not greasy, not warm either, but nevertheless addictive.

Last word: It's called Macho Tequila's.  You didn't venture into the bowels of Sparks to be some flatland-tourister, house-Margarita wimp.  Make the trip worthwhile!

Backwaters is a great seafood restaurant located on Sand Key island, just 1 Island south of Clearwater Beach. I got the Grilled Snapper scallops and shrimp blackened cajun style with a side of fries, garden salad, and lobster bisque soup and everything was pretty tasty. My friend got he rib eye and enjoyed it as well. I'm not a big rib eye fan myself so I really can't comment on the quality of the cut of meat. Service was quick and friendly. We sat at the bar and talked to some tourists visiting from Michigan. There is an on-site parking lot with plenty of parking available shared by other businesses in the plaza. This establishment has a Full liquor and a large variety of seafood. The decor of this place is a bit old school southern touristy, casual, and aquatic with a shark and fish hanging. We had no wait to get seated and the food came out in under 10 minutes which is always a plus! The outside patio offers pretty views of the inter coastal! I look forward to coming back again soon!

Without Whole Foods and Trader Joe's I'd be sunk.
So, Whole Foods - I am be-whole-den to you.

High prices and all - what choice do I have?  My child must have chemical-free, persticide-free, herbicide-free non Genetically Modified organisms on which to feed.

And so I present - An Ode to WHOLE FOODS:

That meat case is impressive!  As are the baked desserts.  The juice bar is a saviour - and sushi never hurts!

O, Whole Foods - how I love thee - though parking really sucks.
A least they'll validate the lot and save me a few bux.

Did you know that if you want some of the best mind-blowing barbecue of your life, then you have to wait at least four hours for it?  I'm sure some of you Indy Yelpers find this to be totally absurd.  Who waits that long for pork?  Yet everyday, people camp out to eat brisket and ribs at Franklin Barbecue in Austin, TX, and everyone will tell you that the wait for 100% worth it.  Your meal smokes the competition.

I connect this situation to Kuma's Corner.  Fact: Kuma's is a top-ranked burger and mac 'n' cheese joint in Chicago and has been for several years. (If you don't believe me, then google it.)  In the 10 years that Kuma's has been around, they have been ravaging your mouth with explosive burgers.  Take the Goatsnake, a monstrous amount of beef topped with herbed goat cheese, corn and poblano relish, lemon vinaigrette, and buttermilk-breaded red onion.  The description alone makes you think, "Damn!  Get into my mouth now!"  Well, just wait until you do shove that dead cow in your mouth.  I won't be too graphic, but it's going to drive you wild.

Based on my experience at Kuma's, the ravaging has trickled over to Indy no doubt, yet have we welcomed this famous, critically-acclaimed shop with open mouths and stomachs?  Not quite.  We over-critique the time it takes for our metal burgers to come out.  What's the rush?  Do you know there's beer to drink?  Is your date going that terrible that you have to take out your frustration on the food being brought out slower than you'd like it to?  Who knows, maybe I'm being a bit of an overprotective mother bear with a place I truly enjoy.  However, I think we as a Yelp Community need to ask ourselves more often: how much weight should we give to the time it takes for our food to come out?  Do we knock 'em three-four stars because of a slow and steady pace? Better yet, should we prioritize service or a kick-ass plate?

With that said, Kuma's: I love you for who you are, not for who certain Yelpers want you to be.

I really like Cafe Roze. The decor, interior space, and food & drinks are all so great. The food, especially. This review is just for the breakfast/brunch menu.

Food - I have never gone wrong with the egg bowl, burger & fries (i love their fries), savory oats, stout waffles, and country ham toast (this sandwich is HUGE and better than any other ham toast I've ever had). Everything is so flavorful, especially the savory bowls. I wish I could make these dishes at home, but I would never get the flavors to be as good, so I will never regret ordering these dishes here. Avocado shake is alright, not a big cup, but if you're craving and willing to pay, sure. I'm also excited to come back and try other sandwiches and the roze bowl too.

Drink - their drink menu is really extensive and I've only had the golden turmeric and black sesame steamers - both lovely. The right milky-ness and not sweet at all. Roze latte is pretty good. Made pretty with the rose petals on top of the drink.

Service - If you don't want to experience slow(er) and less attentive service, I'd recommend coming at off hours. I had one not so great experience, but made up by with a dish on the house. But - I'm also a very patient person, so the mishap didn't bother me that much.

What a great find on vacation! We were looking for fun things to do to escape the heat, and as beer lovers I'm so glad we found Payette! It offers a beautiful, clean indoor space and a spacious outside area. Plus, the beers were great! We each did a flight and then a glass of our favorite! The bartender was awesome and we had a great time.

The 4 Winds Restaurant probably has the bast tacos in Reno. I tried a chorizo, chicken, and carne asada and they were all authentic and delicious. 
$12 got me 3 tacos, 2 beers and had enough left over for the tip jar

It's has a dive bar/restaurant feeling to it. We had the chicken nachos, the blue burger and the famous Mac and cheese. They have a 2 for 1 tall boy all day and they give you a chip you can use anytime next time you come or same day you are in! You don't have to drink everything at once! So your beer won't get hot. And the people next door had the dump truck O' wings and it actually comes on a toy truck!!! It's was funny. I asked the people if I could take a picture and they were nice and let me. This please is awesome! Definitely come check them out!!!

My friend and I are both fond of this creole bar and kitchen, not least for the fish and seafood that features heavily on the menu. Seriously good taste of creole cooking of shrimps, fish and all types of meat. Wings, burgers also feature and as expected, breakfast with waffles, proper biscuits. Our lunch kicked off with Jerk wings and three pieces of different charbroiled chicken breasts (S.O.S), followed by two orders of entrees. Both were very generous in portion. The 4 Horsemen were partitioned by 4 sample dishes ranging from black bean stew, crawfish in creole sauce to shrimp and sausage jambalaya, chicken with garlic prawns in Cajun spices. 

We were surprised by the imagination of the extemporaneous instantiation in the entree IDK, which was loved by my friend, besides, the deviation from our preconceive vision as reminiscent of a beach hut like maritime-themed furnitures or jazz, soul and blues music. The atmosphere was laidback, fun and welcoming, helped along by the emollient nature of the staff. The walls are painted with spring-green and grey paintwork, and in addition to simple blond-wood tables and chairs, the spacious room was decorated by arcade machines and a pool table. Expect, also, games and matches and occasional yelling, providing the soundtrack to the bites and booze.

I was super disappointed in Blake's. I thought it was just like New Mexico Blake's and although they claim it's the same, the food is far different. 
First off the drive through is like waiting and dying a slow death. Granted the food is fresh but waiting 15 minutes with no one in front of you is annoying. 
The bun was very stale and blah. The burger itself had zero seasoning. I got the green chili/cheese burger. How can it have no flavor? Not sure, but it was flavorless. 
I had my hopes so high but unfortunately this place did not live up to the name. 
I'll stick with getting my fix when I'm in New Mexico.

We had Joellas Mac n cheese at Return of the Mac and really liked it.

We must have gotten luck. We were in line less then 10 minutes. Our food came to the table in about 10 minutes. Neither of us liked the craft soda so we both drank sweet tea and I had mine with some lemon aid. Southern. crispy Chicken strips were very tasty crisp outside and juicy and fully cooked. Mac M cheese great. Loved the shoestring fries. For dessert we had the Nutella Poppers. They were also very good. Didn't love the decor or where the drink area was only because you had to get past thru the line of people waiting to place their order. I'm guessing this will be easier as the newness wears off. Great use of what was 96st Steak Burger.

+: SERVICE WAS EXCELLENT!  I have nothing but great things to say about the waitresses and hostess.  No matter if it was our waitress or not- someone was always there to refill your coffee. 

+: The view was..... nice. It was a little industrial (meaning, there were some cranes and old ships obstructing my view), but after the breakfast we were able to have a beautiful stroll along the water front.  

Food was your standard hotel breakfast buffet.  Eggs were moist.. potatoes were stale.. but I enjoyed the yogurt and fruit options too.  Had myself a good bagel w cream cheese.  Nothing else to say about the food.

This is the BEST Chinese food I've had in the New Orleans area.  It's a pain in the butt to drive all the way out to Kenner for Chinese food, but it's so worth it once I'm stuffing my face in their fried chicken wings - which is finger-licking good: crunchy skin, salty and the jalapeno/green onion garnish is perfection! The Westlake soup, imperial chicken and Mongolian beef are also favorites. I think the price is completely reasonable, especially for the quality of the food you're getting. You will not be disappointed!

My husband and I had a great time on the Cajun Encounters Honey Island Swamp Tour!

From the bus pick up in New Orleans to the boat tour within the swamp, the service we experienced was professional and friendly. I was pleasantly surprised by how much information the tour guides had to share with us. I left with a greater knowledge of the area's culture and history which I found very interesting. 

Within the swamp, I was blown away by the natural beauty and thankful that May offered comfortable temperatures. Although wildlife sightings are never guaranteed, we were lucky enough to see several alligators, wild boar, raccoons, and snakes. The tour guide did a great job keeping the experience fun and interactive, even between sightings. 

Considering the transportation, time, and knowledge of the guides, we felt that the price was reasonable. I would recommend this to nature-lovers of all ages. 

I hope to return for a seasonal sunset tour on my next visit to New Orleans!

Went there solely for the oysters and while they were dynamite, I would disagree that they're the best in NOLA. However, they were juicy and plump and beautifully charred. Tons of butter all over the plate which was fantastic for dipping our bread into. 2 dozen oysters and two Sauvignon Blancs and we were out the door for $70 tip and tax included. Not the cheapest but one of the best. So far I think the char grilled oysters at Delmonico are the best we've had.

I liked the decor. It's basically turning into spring outside, and it was warm and sunny where my friend and I sat. 

The Parmesan fries were pretty good. I think I've had better but they were adequate. I had the pulled pork sandwich and I was a little underwhelmed. I ate the majority of it, but it just had some flavors that were missing. I seasoned it a little more myself and it was still pretty lacking.

I had a whiskey cocktail that tasted like straight whiskey. Granted, I'm not a whiskey expert, but part of me feels like they served me whiskey on the rocks. The flavor was all whiskey.

I would give it another try though, maybe ordering a different sandwich and another cocktail.
Excellent Mexican food.  You can never go wrong with this chain!

Some hits, some misses here. 

Dim Sum Garden has the best steamed pork soup buns in Philadelphia that I have tried.  Yes, best in Philadelphia, but not better than the ones in NY.  In NYC, there are several steamed pork soup bun restaurants that would rival Dim Sum Garden.  

Given that the steamed pork soup bun competition in NYC is really good, my expectations are kinda high.  In short the skins for these buns are too thick, the flavor of the broth isn't as complex, and there have been some instances when I felt the meat wasn't ground cleanly.  I will however drop by if I am in the neighborhood and need a steamed pork soup buns fix since they are better than the rest in philly.  Now we have settled that argument, onto the other items on the menu,.....

The steamed chicken dumplings are also good and recommended.  The chicken sticks are also tasty and nicely prepared.  The fried shrimp was fried nicely without an overbearing greasy residue.

The crystal shrimp dumplings wrappers were kinda thick and probably not something I would order again.  The sauce for the pan fried noodles were really bland and saturated with a little too much sauce.  The amount of sauce in the dish basically made the pan fried noodles a soup noodle dish.  Definitely not ideal, and not recommended. 

Overall, I could revisit Dim Sum Garden again.

Let's correct a slight misconception about Chipotle: This is not health food, nor is it light, by any means, despite the marketing hype displayed at all locales touting their "food with integrity" etc etc. This formerly-McDonald's-owned chain serves some mighty tasty grub, and I enjoy it on a fairly regular basis. However, you might want to recalculate your ordering and/or sharing habits.
A standard burrito here, with the tasty pork, rice, black beans, salsa, cheese, sour cream and flour tortilla weighs in at a whopping 1200 calories. That's just shy of your normal daily allowance if you're an average male. Therefore, I almost always split one of these in half and share it or save it for later because half is about a normal meal, calorie-wise. And that's not including chips, which I never get, or any type of sugary drink which I always avoid, as well.
You can have your Taco Bus, Tampa. I will take Chipotle. It tastes better and the quantity is not stingy. These ubiquitous chain restaurants are also very clean, with usually quick service even when there is a line, which is often at mealtimes. I see no differences from one location to another, though parking is tight at Westshore, and there can be a shortage on S. Howard if you go when the nearby bars are peaking.

What's not to love about Lucky's? Hungry? They have a little cafe that sells pizza, sushi and assorted delights. Thirsty? The cafe sells beer by the pint and glasses of wine to sip while you shop. Did I mention the carts even have pint holders for the beer?? Nothing wrong with that my friends!!

Lucky's is a lovely little Whole Foods meets Trader Joes place. Produce looked fresh and included some exotic varieties. There was a nice adult beverage section, great organic and gluten free aisles. The bonus were the bulk food sections. Gorgeous displays of house made granola, dried fruits, baking staples, nuts, candies, pastas etc. There is something quite inviting about the bulk foods section. Very homey and warm!

The deli and prepared foods counter looked amazing, although I didn't try anything from here. My partner in crime and I were pleasantly surprised with this great addition to St. Louis!

When the Girly's parents were in town, we stopped by this little place after our beloved Churro's turned out to be closed.

Each dish was a not-quite-up-to-standard version of the dishes. It was edible but nothing I would ever want to eat again. And I've eaten middle-Eastern food all over the US, the UK and in the middle-East. It just wasn't very GOOD.

Our waitress was nice enough but did not remember any of our orders. It was an empty restaurant and she still wandered off and chatted with someone from the back room for 30 minutes while we waited for drink refills.

I'll stick to Pyeramids ot Monas or Albasha (THANK YOU FOR COMING HERE, ALBASHA!) next time.

This place is an all-around cool spot. The food is good, the atmosphere is urban hip, and the soundtrack playing in the background fulfills all of your classic 90s hip hop throwback needs. I've been here twice and have gotten to-go orders each time. The food is fresh, fast, and flavorful. The first time I came I ordered three tacos with chicken, steak, and pork with chips and queso. Everything was great! I returned a few days ago and asked for the same order, but sadly they were out of chips and queso. It was around 7:30pm on Sunday. That was disappointing, but I ordered the kimchi fried rice instead. It was good as well. The prices aren't bad but being a la carte, things certainly add up and the portions of the menu items are small, so buying multiple things is to be expected.

Before coming here, I had heard about Seoul Taco being great but hadn't been to any of their locations. This being so convenient to where I live in Chesterfield was a welcome surprise. West County needs some flavor and this establishment definitely brings that!

Location is not ideal, but there are some gems at Kermit's Bake Shoppe. Traversed a mile or so to find this shoppe, and immediately indulged in a funfetti cake ice cream sandwich and carrot cake ice cream sandwich. Though the pictures made the funfetti cake sandwich look unreal, I actually enjoyed the carrot cake sandwich more. The flavors were strong but not too strong, and coupled with the ice cream... the whole thing was incredible. 

Really am curious about how the other dessert items taste; there were at least 5-6 other desserts that I was on the verge of purchasing. Everything looked impeccable, and I loved the scope of innovation I saw within the glass casings (homemade poptarts, anyone?)! 

They also do delivery-- perfect for when I'm craving something from Kermit's. +1.

Went there on a friends recommendation and with some trepidation after reading year old reviews here.

On a busy Saturday night, simply put good food, mediocre service. Had to ask for everything even after we (myself and 3 of my wife's friends) told them how ravenous we were.

Reasonable total price as its BYOB, but everything including bread has a price with it. I had the Aloo Tikki as an app.  Potato balls with peas flavored with coriander... very nice. Lamb Korma as an entree, very tender and flavorful. This after munching on naan and puri breads.

Would've rated higher if not for the service, which is a big part of the dining experience for me.

I have been going here for years. I 
have tried numerous things 
on the menu. You can eat in and sit 
at a car port order at the speaker 
and wait for your food come out. I 
believe this is the best way to eat 
here. Sometimes there 
are temp issues at the drive through. 

SUPER CRUNCHY CHICKEN 
STRIP DINNER ~~~~~~~~~~~

There is a medium combo you can get 
with the 5 piece chicken dinner. The 
3 piece comes with just the chicken. I 
love the 5 piece combo meal best but 
if it's lunch time I'll order the 3 piece 
dinner with nothing else. ~~~~~~~~~~

For me, it depends on what I want on 
the day I go. The chicken is nice and 
has a crisp exterior and lean interior 
which makes their chicken meals the 
best. The meal doesn't come with 
country gravy anymore. You have to 
ask what for a sauce. If you're aren't 
familiar ask what sauces they have. 
I always get 2 little plastic containers.

THE CHEESEBURGER WITH KETCHUP ONLY WITH FRENCH FRIES AND A MEDIUM MILKSHAKE ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The burger was heavy in weight. I am not 
a fan of their beef items. The temp 
was off so I didn't eat the rest. The french 
fries were delicious. They had a nice crisp 
exterior with a slight crunch 
and had just the perfect amount of salt. I 
love the soft pillow touch for the exterior. 
I also had a medium peanut butter 
medium milkshake. What I liked about it 
was the consistency. It wasn't too thick 
or too thin. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

SEE YOU SOON!

Good Italian food in an intimate setting.

It's a small place, less than 20 tables.
Decor is reminiscent of an Italian family villa, and the menu reflects a home cooking vibe.  

Without a reservation, we were seated at the chefs bar, overlooking the kitchen.  Our server, Melissa, took great care of us. Friendly, laid back explanation of the menu, assurance on portion sizes. Thank you! Service is quick and it's fun to watch your entree being put together by the kitchen.

I selected a couple of small plates to try, meatballs and broccoli rabe.  Two large meatballs are constructed of beef, veal and pork and stuffed with fontina, cooked perfectly. Not tough, juicy and tender, topped with melted mozzarella. They are flavorfully spiced with a slight kick, just enough to stimulate the taste buds.  They're served atop a dollop of polenta and delicious, sweet plum tomato marinara sauce. 

The broccoli rabe was disappointing.  Sautéed with white beans, garlic, chile and lemon it was very bitter, while I was expecting an earthy, garlic crunch. 

My colleague tried the eggplant parmigiana. Artfully plated in 2 elongated, criss-crossed slices, the eggplant is prepared with basil pesto, topped with marinara sauce and burrata cheese. 

We also tried the wild mushroom arancini.  Golf ball sized balls of wild mushroom risotto are stuffed with mozzarella and deep fried golden brown. These are served with a splash of truffle ailoi.  The arancini were my favorite of the night.... Creamy and savory with a nice crunch in every bite. 

Solid food at this small restaurant. I'd return to try the rest of the menu.

Come here hungry and leave satisfied.  It's just like any other all you can eat sushi place around Reno in terms of quality and price.  We came during lunch on a Sunday of a long weekend.  There wasn't much of a crowd and we were able to sit up at the bar.

Jimmy John's is freakishly...yummy!

I'm a big fan of this franchise. I'm happy that I don't have to wait till I'm in Largo to grab one of their subs! 

You'll notice the sign outside does not say Subway. Meaning they are not Subway, they do things the Jimmy John's way. There may not be a salad bars' worth of veggies for your sub. If that's what you like, you know where to get that! 

My favorite thing about their subs has got to be the bread! Soooo good!! And big! I usually take two days to eat a sub from there. If only they didn't up charge you for cheese... Oh well.

sometimes i'll hear white ppl or non asian ppl talking about chinese buffets and it just cracks me up because it sounds like a lil kid describing christmas like this wondrous epicurean dream of limitless possibilities. the line u hear every time? "THEY HAVE LIKE EVERYTHING.. LIKE LITERALLY EVERYTHING." and so i guess mebe i'm a bit jaded over the years of eating the same chinese buffet simulated over and over again at x y and z restaurant. But.. I guess trends change. The product felt different here at Ichiban. More refined and updated. 

The american food is noticeably better, decent seafood, even sushi that i am willing to eat (usually i dont even want to touch it at chinese buffets), kalbi (korean short ribs), decent kimchi (really bfd to me). Service was nice. Large space with lots of obese ppl so u wont feel that bad about eating 5 pounds of food. 

My brother loves this place and at first i was thinking like oh great.. a chinese buffet. but during the week i was visiting we ended up coming again and i didn't mind. Like 2 pac said, 'its time change the way we eat, its time to change the way we live, and its time to change the way we treat each other.' Relevant? u tell me. a quote is a good way to end things mysteriously anyway..

I had been wanting to try Brio, so I made reservations for Valentines Day.  I decided to do something different and eat at lunch time instead of the usual dinner.  We were seated right away at a little table for two.  We were told they had the tables set up like this for Valentine's Day.  My only problem with that is hubby was across from me instead of beside me.  No hand holding:(
Our server was a sweetie and took very good care of us.  The interior reminded me of the Cheesecake Factory.  Bread basket came quickly and loved the bread (I love bread) I had chicken Marsala and was made with grilled chicken which is different for me and I loved it.  Hubby had the lasagna and said it was very good.  It wasn't very romantic, due to the distance between us and people close by, but it was lunch so it was fine.  Over all, great lunch, great service.  We will definitely go back!
Happy Valentines Day!

Just finished Easter brunch at Brio and it was excellent!  The eggs were light and fluffy.  They give you so much bacon, I couldn't eat it all!  The breakfast potatoes were the best I've ever had!  We had reservations so we didn't have to wait and service was perfect!  We finished our meal with a splurge...it is Easter!  We shared the chocolate molten cake and OMG was it good!  Highly recommend that any time any day! Haha. Another great dining experience at Brio!  Happy Easter!

Good location
Incredibly fair prices
What you see is what you get

Stopped in here on a spring training trip with a buddy, and we spent a decent part of a late afternoon downing some oysters, fried foods, and cold beers.  I didn't think it was particularly special, but the prices were right, the people were friendly, and I had a good time.  As unpretentious a place as they come - I'll go back next time I'm in town.

I was always willing to withdraw cash to get my Creole Creamery fix; however, they now accept cards and I can go swipe my card like Paris Hilton at Juicy Couture circa early 2000s.

They have some of the best flavors ever. I can't get enough of them. I only allow myself to go once in a blue moon, because my sweet tooth gets me in so much trouble.

The staff is so friendly and now during COVID-19 they only allow a handful of people in at a time and there is no indoor dining. I honestly always grabbed my ice cream to go and walked around the neighborhood, such a pretty area.

My go-to is a split small and tbh it's a good amount! If you love queso be a foodie like me and order a waffle cone on the side. Break it up into "chips" and you can thank me later.

Go get yourself some ice cream!

Every year I agonize over an annual birthday dinner destination. Now, I don't "party" so my b-day din is the equvalent to a childhood party where all my friends come and i make favors for them and we all have pizza and cake. except we go to a semi-nice place that I normally wouldn't go to. I sought out a Meditarranean BYOB and on one of my travels home from Trader Joes, I happened upon the tucked away spot, and found the inside beautifully warm. I was met with friendly, helpful servers and a host who took my information and after making a reservation I was confident my party - and my party - would be well off there. 
And we were. And it was. 
My servers: handsome, attentive, and personable. Did I say handsome? Oh, yeah, I did.
I had my first tryst with escargot here - perfectly done jouicy snails in a light as air tomato broth - Med-style, not French - and for an entree had pan-seeared diver scallops that were so meaty and melt in my mouth it was hard to believe. Other guests had the Moussaka, some veg eggplant dish, a halloumi and feta dish, among others, and all were met with raves. 
This restaurant is classified as Middle Eastern - I take issue, only because the menu is more eclectic than Middle Eastern, and contains elements of all the Meditarranean rim, including heavy Italian and North African influences.
This place is a gem, and really does have a menu that can please the most diverse of tastes. The noise level, the ambience - even the comfortable seating was just so perfect. As well as it went over for my shindig, I couldn't help but fantasize about having a quiet date there in the future. 
And more escargot. I have a taste for snails now. Be warned. 
And it was then the voice of Obi Wan came over me and spoke: 
"You have learned well, my young Padawan."

Are you kidding me with how great this place is! Good thing its not closer to where I live because I would be here every week. The food was amazing - highlight was the antipasto and then the spaghetti carbonara (not even the pizza), the service was top notch, and the pricing was better than great! Seriously - why dont they have more of these places around Philly, specifically one across from my apartment (at least I would get exercise walking across the street to burn off that delicious food). Get there now! You won't be disappointed.

Really terrible service; I always feel rushed when I come here by the extremely impatient servers...although I guess that's expected in Chinatown. To be fair, we did stay a while as we kept ordering food and drinking wine (It's a BYO!), but service still could be greatly improved. 

DO order the soup dumplings, shu mai, and really any types of dumplings on the first row of the menu. Our shrimp dumplings was tiny so I would steer away from that, but you really cannot go wrong with the soup dumplings. Their vegetables (garlic stems) are also very, very tasty and authentically cooked, reminding me of what my mother would often cook at home to get me to eat more vegetables. DO NOT order other non-dim sum dishes; they're completely not worth the price or taste. My friend and I ordered only dim-sum items, and was pleasantly surprised at the cheapness of how much food we had eaten (although the soup in the dumplings are composed of liquid fat..but what delicious liquid fat! just order some vegetables to balance it out). 

Warning, they don't take reservations, so steer away from busy nights if you're in a hurry! We waited in a line that extended out of the door for over 20 minutes.

Nice place to get some quick, fresh and tasty food. 

I tried the Spinach and Kale salad. The greens were very fresh and the dressing was light. It was a good portion of salad for the price. The Angus beef, spicy buffalo and blue cheese burger was tasty. The blue cheese was not very overpowering which I liked. The burger was very tasty. We also tried the Beef kabob. This dish comes with some lettuce and red onions on top of fresh flatbread. I think the most memorable part of the meal was how good the bread tasted! It was warm, light and fluffy. There were also three sauces you could put on your flatbread and meat. There is a spicy orange one and a white garlic cream sauce that I thought tasted good on the flatbread. 

They also have a 20% discount with a student ID or you can buy the $15 for $20 on Yelp which makes this place even more worth try! I will definitely come back here when I am in the area and looking for some light, clean food!

Our first visit here for a Saturday lunch verged on 4 stars, or at least some aspects did. The small interior is clean and fairly spartan save for a few colorful paintings. They offer a Yelp checkin offer for free mango lassi( provided you select a dinner entree) which was good. And even offer lunch specials on the weekend. If memory serves vegetarian ones were $6.99, carnivorous ones a buck more. 

But therein lied our first complaint. While providing more than ample plain( ish) basmati, there was less than ample meat and sauce. We did both agree the butter chicken was good, but twice the sauce was needed at least. One other issue is that it cane out instantly, while my choice was about 10 minutes behind. This does not make for an enjoyable date lunch when both parties were already hangry. Also not appreciated was the plastic compartment plate it was served on.  My chicken biryani was very good and a very good portion.... of rice at least. Again the fowl, which was a mix of white and dark meat that had been roasted I believe( with plenty of spices) was lacking. But for the price I would get again. Our order of cheese naan did not live up to expectations and is not worth repeating. 

I would recommend this place for a quick in and out lunch, or for coming with a group and ordering a few dishes to share. The tandoori chicken options are interesting to me, but take over 25 minutes to prepare. Lastly, even though the owner was present and seemed very nice, our server had a bit of an attitude. I think another try is warranted, but based on the few negatives we would probably stick with our old faithful Blue. Let's say 3.66 medium spicy my ass stars

Expensive and charmless. It's cool to watch them make the ice cream, but there was nothing else special about the experience and the taste was nothing extraordinary to warrant such a steep price. 

The amount you get is huge/too much - so I guess that explains the cost, but the flavor was unimpressive, so meh.

I'm all about PizzaRev. You can choose your dough, sauce, and toppings. They even have vegan cheese! I could list all the toppings, but it would take me all day. The same goes for the beer. I LOVE the beer wall. It's easy to read, fun to use, and lets you take your time deciding on what you want to drink. Each tap has a blurb and ABV information. They are also going to get wine on tap. Hooray! 

As a pizza snob, this isn't NY pizza, but it's not supposed to be. Once you know that, you will truly enjoy the experience. PizzaRev is about customization.  

Beyond the food, the staff is incredible. They are incredibly helpful and knowledgeable. One of the staff members told me they are going to start a happy hour deal in the coming weeks or month. It's perfect for anyone who works in the area. It's spacious, clean, and relaxed. Everything you want in a fast casual environment. 

I'm so glad I went for the Yelp event a few weeks ago. It brought me in, which is crazy, I work across the street and watched the build. Now that I've tried it, I can't wait to go back and mix and match my toppings, dough, and sauce.

As we were looking for a place to have dinner in Indy, Dick's was one of the places that popped up.  Unfortunately, it seemed to be pretty packed, and the parking garage had a sign that said $20, so we just passed by and found something else that night.  The next day, though, the weather was decent, so we took a walk over from the NCAA Hall of Champions to try it for lunch.   

This is a national chain that touts "service with sarcasm" but honestly, our waiter was pretty ordinary and didn't really say or do anything funny.  We enjoyed the semi-abusive comments made by some of the other servers while we were there, plus some of the kind of funny remarks on the big paper hats they put on customer heads.  The seating arrangement is crowded, with everyone sitting at long tables beside strangers, if it's crowded.  Prices were a little high and portions were a little small (maybe a dozen fries in my basket - easily the smallest side of fries I can ever remember).  It all tasted pretty good, though, got a decent meal and had a few laughs.

The main reason I love coming here - service, it is always impeccable! Our dining experience tonight did not disappoint. The guys love coming here for the steaks. They serve them on a sizzling hot plate, making them unique from other steakhouses in the area.

To start I had the blueberry lemon drop. It was very good and I could tell it is a popular drink when I saw it on 2 tables around us! We shared 2 Flemings salads for the table, and for my entree I had the Chilean Sea Bass. It was cooked in a southwest broth served with wilted greens and crispy onions. I would highly recommend this to anyone looking to order seafood from here. My favorite side we ordered for the table was a special that night - lobster Mac and cheese!! It was seriously amazing! 

We ended with coffee and desserts. The walnut turtle pie was to die for and they bring you a bowl of homemade whip cream yum!! Can't wait to go back!

Everyone's always creaming their pants over Wegman's, and I just don't get it. 

This supermarket is incredibly crowded, and there isn't really a reason to endure the crowds unless you need:

1. Delicious baked goods
2. Specialty chocolate or health foods
3. A particular piece of produce that your regular store doesn't carry

Even if you find yourself needing one of these things, I would advise you to come here either ass early in the morning or hella late at night so that you can actually maneuver in the aisles and check-out without a 20-minute line.

The staff is nice, though.

The good: Super fun atmosphere. Excellent drink specials. Our server was really nice. Brisket nachos and smoked wings were amazing.

The not so good: Drinks were weak. Fried chicken has super thick breading that falls off leaving bland chicken. 

Summary: Come for the fun atmosphere. Food is good depending on what you order. Forget the fancy cocktail menu.

I've been to Kmart before. I think it was either 2011 or 2012 I had came to this store for the first time. I had bought a comforter. They got "everything" you need here. No complaints, the workers are nice and helpful.

Visiting a take out Chinese shop for an eat-in lunch is always a bit of a gamble.  

You never know what you are going to confront the first time walking in.  Will it be a dive with your shoes sticking to the floor, and the food indigestible?  Or, will the place have a pleasant personality and tone with decent grub given its inherent limitations?  

Very happy to report that China Wok is the later.  

The small space is clean and bright, with the owners/operators equally so.  The menu is adequate for both lunch and dinner, but as I was here in the afternoon for a late lunch, I went with the lunch specials.  Orange Chicken, Fried Rice and a drink (water) for a very reasonable price. 

Yes, it was served in its take out container, but in an interesting way.  It came on a tray with the take out menu opened fully to act like a placemat.  Pleasant alternative to just having the various folding boxes placed in front of me.  Too, the smile that accompanied the service was an unexpected bonus.  Could have used a spoon along with the skinny plastic fork, but why quibble? 

The meal was on the high end for cheap Chinese walk away.  The Chicken was not heavily coated, and it appeared it had not been frozen for long, if at all.  It was soft and pliant without that freezer burn toughness so often present.  The sauce was properly piquant with slices of Orange Peel and Red Szechuan Chili throughout.  The Fried Rice was decent with small chunks of pork and veggies. 

All in all, a surprisingly good meal.  While it would never be confused with fine dining, it was certainly substantial enough without the obvious pitfalls of fast Chinese, that it is worth another visit.

I just wrote a mad long review for this place and accidentally exited my web browser. Sadly, I'm not rewriting all of that.  Instead, I'll sum my long-winded story up by simply saying that this place has been open for a little over a year and we've been eating here since then. Very good pizza (somewhere between gourmet and NY-style with a fire-baked twist), sort of high prices and decent service (staff isn't very polished).

THE CRUST is amazing.

Chopped salads are okay.

Gelato flavors are  not very good.

This used to be THE BEST HIDDEN local spot in the CWE..until the 2 new ladies started and my mom now calls it a red neck bar.

Folks are not as friendly. Frumpy non smiling female bartender and Nicole the Frumpy non happy, non smiling, not personable server.

We rarely hit this spot anymore. 

You can find young professionals, theatre folks, neighbors and business owners, etc. At this spot.

The live theatre is connected to this place.

What I used to love...it used to be like Cheers! Friendly, young female bartender who knew your name even if you hadn't come in for months. The owners are extremely personable  and they have Trivia and wine tasting nights.

They have a members club card...they've opened a sister pizza restaurants in St. Louis also.

It's just not my fave place anymore when you have unhappy, Frumpy staff. Ugh.

Used to be 5+ stars...now, I can only give 2.5 .if that.

I'd seen Paint Nite deals floating around on Living Social and Groupon, so when a friend came to visit from out of down I decided to buy one and sign us up for a Sunday night painting party. When I originally bought the deal from Living Social, it was quickly cancelled, which was a disappointment. However, a few days later I noticed the deal on Groupon, so I bought it again - clearly there are some technical/promotional issues, but thankfully, this time it was on!

We did a Sunday paint nite at Head House Crab & Oyster Co, on 2nd and South. The space was huge and the restaurant and bar were pretty dead on Sunday at 7pm, so I can understand why they'd welcome a crowd of 30 painters - especially when those painters are being encouraged to drink throughout the entire class.  I understand the reciprocal relationship of Paint Nite using the space and encouraging people to buy drinks from the bar, but the pushiness was obvious and got a bit annoying after 2 hours.

As for the class itself, we painted "Fireflies" - an abstract sort of image that is evidently their most popular piece. Although the instructions were vague at time, it was an "Easy" level painting, and so they came out fairly well. Perhaps the most interesting and fun part was to walk around and see how 30 different people could interpret the same scene so many different ways - although I have to admit, it inspired some artist envy!

Overall, the novelty of painting your own masterpiece, while being able to sip drinks, makes for a fun night out, especially if you gather up a group to go. At $50 a person, I wouldn't pay full price, but there seems to be no shortage of half-price deals floating around on the inter webs. Not sure if I'll be a repeat customer, because really, what do you do with a bunch of giant hand painted canvases? Nevertheless, check it out yourself, eager to see more reviews up here!

I'm not typically a fan of meaty oysters but these were amazing. They were fresh and tasty; important factors when you're eating raw seafood. The chargrilled oysters were quite delicious as well. It was pure buttery goodness. I highly recommend this place, as will the line of people waiting outside.

I did the fish po'boy and gumbo for my entree and it's easily some of the best gumbo I've ever had.

A surprise of a hit. Ever since the whole rolling ice cream train hit Philly, I've been a bit skeptical to try new icecream places that looks gimmicky because they're usually overpriced and very mundane in flavor. 

Arctic was not the case, while they were pricey, the quality was worth it. I had pandan ice cream coconut bowl with kiwi, coconut flakes, bananas and sticky rice in a coconut bowl. The sticky rice was main draw here. The rice was sweet and added a very interesting texture. The rice soaked up the ice cream as well as the toppings and busts with flavor when bit into.

I initially thought $8 for a bowl of ice cream was much but it was definitely worth it. The only issue was seatings. The only way to truly appreciate your coconut bowl ice cream was to dine in, there was no point doing take out as presentation was half the dish. Their flavors also switch daily so check back often.

Small but cool spot with very delicious ice cream. Limited but exotic flavors help this place stands out from the rest. Lack of seatings can be annoying but you can always take out. Highly recommended.

ACHTUNG!  *TASTEGASM ALERT!*

SITREP

If there was restaurant-establishment I could hide in my pocket, fly back home with me, and set it up on my street corner, it would be this one.

Jägerhaus is one of those Über-Fantastico Deutschland-traditional establishments that takes food, pastries and dessert making up an knotch.  [Since it closes at 10pm it doesn't quite make it onto my "Munchies For Night Owls" list (to make it on this list, a place must be open at least til Midnight) - and we got there at 9:30pm.  But still, they let us hang out til 10:20pm, so we never felt rushed.

THE SET-UP

My sweet friend and I had just finished a party at Indulge Grill Island and we were working our way back to Hotel Modern, but we decided to take a quick side-trip since we were looking for something to satiate our sweet-tooth.

Now she was from New York City, and how she found this place I don't quite know since this was her first time to New Orleans too, but I am so happy I decided to let her take charge of this night because she was firing on all pistons.

THE TASTE TREATS!

The food here looked amazing.  And I kept telling myself that I would come back earlier in the evening one of the days I was here, but, alas!, that was not to be.  So I am glad I enjoyed this fun moment of tasty sweet fun!  We were definitely feeling the need for ice cream, and so our selections reflected that, and we pulled the trigger on two (2) items that we shared:

*  BLACK FOREST BERRIES - which was a delicious mix of hot blueberries, raspberries with vanilla ice cream, topped with whipped cream and a fudge sauce drizzle; and,

*  APPLE STRUDEL- which was right on par with what I was hoping - a very fluffy apple filled pastry, and we opted to get it with the scoop of French Vanilla ice cream.

DECOR 

The café is very sweet looking, and though German, the décor & style definitely reflects the Czech-Hungarian origins of these owners.  So there is definitely a wonderful, diverse Central European vibe to this awesome place.

THE LOWDOWN

A Fantastic Trans-Altantic Tastegasmatic experience here in New Orleans!

Long wait but worth it! I mean I wouldn't wait more than 45min though.

Waiters are super nice, food portions are HUGE and of course the boiled red potatoes are sooooo gooood! Then again I loooove potatoes in general.

We got this fried seafood platter which came with shrimp, catfish, and oysters on a bed of fries. Wow...so crispy n deeeelish. 

Also got a crawish/shrimp pizza which is more like a small thin crust but it was actually just nice to eat. Seafoody and greasy good pizza. But someone who is picky about pizza may not prefer this. I am not so I welcome you pizza!! 

Those two plates fed three STARVING women. We were completely full and destroyed everythingggggggg

My daughter and parents loved their selections of course.  It has been so long since they have had any ice cream in this ice cream desert we call St. Louis.  Ben  & Jerry's  is a welcome respite from the St. Louis custard obsession.  You can only have so much custard until you break and need some real fresh ice cream!  Just a simple cup of chocolate ice cream was all she needed.

Bobby, where are you? The owner's HOT son. I had a few dates with him that scored me some free ice cream. Raspberry Truffle is AWESOME. YUM. The son was hot too, and rich but .....it just didn't work out.  A++ service and flavors.

One of the newest Publixs in the area and it's GORGEOUS. It looks a lot like the format they're using out in Orlando and it's SO useful. I wish all the stores would look like this.  

The produce is so organized, they have everything SO neat. The wine is right near by too.  This store was busy, but they were the first one to have Toilet Paper that I saw. Color me Impressed. 

The associates were friendly and helpful, we found exactly what we were looking for and were in and out in minutes.  I hope our publix gets a make over to look like this one!

I have to say El Vez used to be one of my favorite Mexican spots in the city. I believe it's seriously declining lately. My past two visits the chips and guac were too salty to eat. No one at my table could get them down. On a previous visit  I ordered the chicken tacos and they were just very ordinary. Normally delicious. My last visit I ordered the Mexican chopped salad with a side of chicken. Salad was pretty good and I really enjoy the avocado dressing they supply but again couldn't eat the $5 chicken side because it was doused in so much salt. -- Also service is meh. Waited for almost 45 minutes for two salads. Plenty of other Mexican spots in the city to branch out too from now on.

This is the original bakery location and it still garners huge lines outside.    The line moves pretty fast though as there are a lot of people working behind the counter.   If you don't already know, the glazed yeast donut is the thing to get here.    They sell so many of them so fast that they don't even bother putting them in the display case.
Really good XLB, actually. Not the best I've had, but impressive. Probably the most soup in a dumpling I've had in a long time.
i shouldn't write this review because it will make the place even MORE crowded, but this place is mind blowingly good.

I had been hearing a ton about this place and was normally deterred due to the 1+ hour wait times I had heard about.

My wife, her friend, and I decided to just suck it up and try it out, knowing that wait times maybe up to an hour or more.

We went on a Monday, hoping that there it wasn't going to be really busy, and we were right!

There were only two groups in the restaurant at the time. I had never been here before, so the bartender/server behind the counter was very helpful. He explained that the menus were on the table, and when we were ready to order to come up to the counter and order. They usually call out names when the orders are ready, but they weren't super busy so they brought out the pizza to us.

The menu is on each table in one of those plastic things that you usually see some sort of happy hour or weird looking ad promoting a club. There's "art" everywhere. Almost every single wall is covered in writing or pictures, some people even managed to make it up to the ceiling. There's a table shuffleboard on a wall and in the back are two dart boards.

We knew we wanted the Chicago style pizza, but didn't know what we wanted on it or the size. We ended up getting a medium with bacon and mushrooms.

Since I heard there were always super long wait times for the food, I timed our order. To my surprise it arrived in 20 mins! Probably because they weren't busy.

Unfortunately, I was quite disappointed in the pizza. The pizza was SUPER cheesy. I really like cheese, but even this was too much. It was like Pizza Hut's stuffed crust pizza, except instead of just the crust being stuffed, the whole pizza was. I felt like there was so much cheese everything else on the pizza was overpowered. I barely tasted any of the bacon, mushroom, or sauce. I basically just tasted a ton of cheese and a little bit of crust.

In my opinion, the Chicago style pizza isn't worth the 1 hour wait, but I would come back to try the normal style pizza.

I have a serious addiction to pretty cafes with pretty desserts and good teas/coffee, so I visited sucre 3 times during my 5 days there.  Ive sampled their vanilla eclair, macarons, marshmallows, gelato, tea, and king cake.  All are excellent, but pricey.  I nearly stopped in my tracks when the bag of marshmallows came out to be over $11!!  The king cake was lightly sweet and moist with cream cheese and cinnamon filling.  Delicious and the only thing that was a good value there at $4 for a big slice.  Despite its price tag, I was a sucker for its prettiness and had desserts for dinner a few nights.

The Capitol Grille quietly makes its case as one of the country's best hotel restaurants. 

The restaurant is located within the gorgeous Hermitage Hotel in downtown Nashville. It's southern business casual versus formal. Jacket isn't necessary, but you don't exactly want to show up after a game of tackle football. Decor is refined, elegant, and comfortable. Service is friendly and straddling between informal and informal. It's fun though. 

You'll have lots of choices of appetizers, entrees, and sides. But it's variety doesn't compromise. It's seasonal. It's local In fact, many (if not all) items come from a nearby farm at Glen Leven. 

Dinner was exceptional. Gulf snapper (with brussel sprouts, celery root puree, crab burre monte) was delicious. The most savory dishes - the braised braised pork cheeks (with corn bread puree, cabbage, soft poached egg) and the venison (with collard greens, heirloom sweet potato, huckleberry shallot jus) - were absolute home-runs, with buttery and tender meats, juicy, bursting with flavor. We sampled several of the sides too. The truffle mac & cheese is truly excellent. The honey-glazed heirloom carrots and brussel sprouts and bacon were delicious too, but played second fiddle to that mac & cheese. Dessert was a dark chocolate with mint. 

Chances are you'll be full, bloated, and incapacitate by meal's end. After you leave the restaurant, take advantage of this state and relax in the lobby of The Hermitage Hotel. You may find staring into the stained glass ceiling therapeutic. 

Note: The Capitol Grille (with an O) is not related to The Capital Grille (with an A), which specializes in steaks, steaks, and more steaks.

No it's not the greatest place to eat in Delco. It's not "clean" whatever that means fir a diner.  So why do I love it?

I like many others in my day enjoyed more than one very cheap 2:30 AM meal here. Call it nostalgia. 

But really, how can you not love a place that keeps their signature breakfast dish under $4 in this tough economy? $3.89 for the Blue Ribbon Special at this time of writing.  And it includes coffee.  No one beats it.

Stopped in after many years today and sat at the counter like the old days. Grabbed a jumbo Jomo burger which wasn't too jumbo. But at $5.69 including fries was certainly a worthy deal. Not the best burger ever but it was good enough. 

That's this place in a nut shell. It's good enough. The prices are what make it worthwhile. 

I don't think the place smelled like stale smoke at all. The whole cleanliness complaint comes from overly picky people. It ain't a country club by any means but there are far worse places in terms of clean.  It's fine.  I think they finally purged that smoke smell. 

And the orange booths are incredibly tacky, and I hope they never get rid of them. It wouldn't be Tom Jones without them.

Frozen custard is delicious! When I first moved to St. Louis Ted Drewes was on my list of places recommended by many locals. I can understand why. This is a touristy spot and even the locals come here and wait in line for their sweet treat! 

I remember my first visit very well. I had no idea how to order or what to order. I was so overwhelmed with the choices. While waiting in line I was reading the menu and asking for tips on what to order;  however, instead of trying to try something different I simply asked for a M&M Concrete; it was that simple. Thank goodness! I was nervous I was going to order incorrectly. 

Now that I have gone back a few times I have tried their Great Pumpkin and I also tried some kind of cherry concrete with dark chocolate. Both were really good, but I'll stick with my traditional M&M concrete since it is simple and sweet. 

If I ever have friends come to town I know I can take them here-I explain that the lines will be long and we just have to be patient. What's really funny is that even in the cold winter months people still wait in line-no way! Not me. I prefer to eat my concretes during the warmer months. 

Ted Drewes, I will come in the spring. Keep up the good work!
I don't know of a better place in Philly to get your bachelorette party penis supplies! What bride doesn't enjoy watching her bridesmaids drink out of penis straws?!

I read a few reviews before going in to try this place out for the first time. Overall, I got an "Italian style chipotle" vibe from the reviews. That being said, I love chipotle haha 

I don't eat meat so I knew going in that they had a veggie option. I went with the vegetarian style Piada. I got most of the veggies (okay, all of them) and the basil pesto. 

It was....okay. Nothing special about it. The interior decor was great, and I really like that! 

Sadly; the actual product fell short for me. It tasted like an overpriced burrito I could have made at home...and had lots of leftovers. I'll save this place for the meat eaters as I didn't get the Italian chipotle vibe that most reviewers mentioned.

Little place that it would be easy to drive by, but some of the best, most authentic Greek food I've eaten. I've been all over Tarpon Springs and back, there's only one other place I like as well.

The guy taking our order seemed a bit scattered but the owners took care to make sure everything was correct. The food was excellent, fresh and hot.  We will definitely go back again.

Tucker's has been around for a long time and it is very popular. They are known for their meat and potatoes menu. The prices are fair and the portions are large. The decor is antique themed, carpet, wallpaper, old photos and lots of wood.  The antique theme is very literal and it translates to old, tired and rundown. The carpet and wallpaper are stained and old and they look  like no one cares about improvement.  The quality of the food is also mediocre, but  portion size and price balances things out.  Overall a good neighborhood gathering place and a place to stuff your face with a lot of meat.  If that's what you are in the mood for and ambience is not an issue, this is your place.

We opted to get their shrimp poboy and it was ok at best. It was lacking in favor. Maybe I just had high expectations for poboys in NOLA. 

Killer Poboys is located inside Erin Rose bar to the back. You need to make your way to the back of the bar. It is limited in sitting and dark and crowded. Plus we saw a cockroach crawling on the table while I was leaning on it. Um maybe that added to my 2 star experience. 

It took forever to get our sandwich too. There was only one person handling the register and making the food. 

If you happened to be drinking at Erin Rose and wanted something to eat it's an ok place to grab food but definitely not worth going out of your way to eat here like us.

Mothers has a serious system, from the moment you walk in the door. Actually you may have to wait outside first, be given s menu and them be instructed to stand along the wall. You order first, then pay, then get your drinks and then will be instructed to a seat. Even though I didn't love what I had here (the creole sauce is a tomato based sauce made peppers & onions), they threw it inside and over the omelette, which looks like it could have been made out of 10 eggs. Huge.
The biscuit came out hot, fresh, and light the highlight of my meal. 
The étouffée  sauce was brown and creamy with a generous amount of crawfish.
The grits were the perfect consistency but completely plain so I threw some butter in them.

We anxiously anticipated returning to this place for oysters and we were not disappointed. We arrived about 6pm on a Friday and the wait was less than 20 minutes. When we left the line had doubled and the wait had to be at least 40 minutes. 

This time we did not mess around: we went right for the charbroiled oysters. We started with a dozen--pure heaven. They are incredibly good. We did not not want it to end. We wanted more so got another 6. I also tried the jambalaya and it was excellent. A bit pricey for the size portion, but very flavorful.  With a pitcher of Abita Amber, life does not get any better. 

We will return! We are compiling a list of our favorites that we have to eat at each time, and between that list and wanting to try new places, we are going to have to extend our stays in New Orleans to more and more time.

Ten of us showed up at Ocean Harbor late Saturday morning for dim sum. Perhaps because it was mid-August, street parking was available on Race Street, so we only had to walk a block to reach this large, bright yellow painted, high ceilinged, dining hall. Had this been a wedding, we would have been the guests of honor, because we were seated up on the stage at the rear of the room. 

Wish I knew the names of everything we sampled, but it came at us so fast and furious, with multiple carts constantly dropping off dishes, that I barely had time to photograph them before they were snapped up by our crew's chopsticks. Regardless, everything was surprisingly good. 

No problem with service, either. The size of our group provided all the incentive necessary to get us plenty of attention.  That most of our party spoke Mandarin probably didn't hurt. 

All we ate and drank came to $100. Great deal for the quantity and quality of food consumed. 

We agreed that coming back again was very likely.

Finally had a chance to go. Read the reviews and was not sure. However, if you go to French Resturant, you get real French Food and compare against. I ordered the mussels. They were very good. When we walked in, it was not that busy, which I expected. When we left it was packed, I did not expect. We had a large party and everyone seemed pretty happy, so no complaints. We will go back and have more than mussels, yet will still have mussels.

Nothing super special about this place. 

The interior is rather plain. It is just one of those places that you go to when you want some Mediterranean food and need a quick bite. 

What I ordered: the falafel salad. The falafel itself was not as flavorful as I would like; however, when I crushed it up and mixed it in with the salad, it was tasty. My boyfriend ordered a classic gyro and it was very good! Not the best I've ever had, but still good. 

Idk if I'll ever come back because there are other Mediterranean places in Stl that I like better, but this place isn't a bad option!

This place was so great. We arrived early and got seated with no wait. Drinks were served quickly, and our service was wonderful throughout. Every small dish we tried was a taste sensation, bruschetta first. It had a unique twist on this classic Italian dish. Next up was the Tempura shrimp, barely battered and sauced with some Japanese mayo and Asian mustard, so delicious I do not have words for it. Fish tacos, small and delightful flavor. Last up, the lamb sliders, so good. One of the best burger type items I have tasted.

Wegmans is my small town oasis.  It's like if Whole Foods and Acme had a baby.  You can find honest to god ANYTHING here.  This is truly one-stop shopping, whether you're vegan, gluten-free, all organic, or couldn't care less.  My mom loves shopping here when she knows I'm coming home.  She can get all her usual stuff, and also grab vegan cheese for me.  The bakery is great, I love their sourdough.  They even have a small bulk section, so I don't have to buy a big bag of expensive nuts when I only need half a cup.  I've found everything from Go Max Go peanut butter cups to Hurraw! lip balm to Pacifica candles here, this place is amazing.

And then there's the prepared foods.  There's so much good stuff!  It's one of the few places I feel cool with grabbing sushi from a supermarket, and they usually have awesome and inventive vegan rolls, like mango and tofu.  The seaweed salad is on point, too, and it's turned my mom into a seaweed believer.  My husband loves the Indian hot bar.  It's not the best, but it's comforting and it hits the spot.

AND THEN there's the beer.  There are crazy laws in Pennsylvania that prevent grocery stores from selling alcohol, but Wegman's craftily put a pub and a beverage store within their store, making the impossible possible.  I can get Einstok and Dogfish Head and Yuengling, AND all of my groceries.  Even in California, I don't usually find Einstok at the grocery store, so this place is truly heaven.

Thanks for making vegan speciality items (and beer) so accessible!

The Pho here was quite delicious.  The Pho broth was well made and very flavorful. The Pho comes in small ($9.95), medium ($10.95) and large ($12.95). I shared a large bowl of Pho and it was more than enough for the two of us. The bowl was huge! Definitely go with the large if you have the option to share with someone. 

I also ordered the summer rolls, which were nicely wrapped in rice paper with fresh ingredients. I liked the accompanying peanut sauce too. 

The interior was clean and spacious. Service was fast and efficient. The food is good, prices are great, and portion sizes are awesome. I would definitely eat here again if in the area.

We recently moved and discovered that one of the garage doors in the new place wouldn't open.

We found Master Garage Door Services on Angie's List and bought a $20 deal to get their evaluation. They came by right on time, took a quick look at the door and told us we needed to replace the springs and rollers. The cost...$250.

We felt that it was a big commitment to make on the spot, so we decided to get a 2nd opinion. The next company that came by immediately observed that someone had used the red rope (so that the door could be used manually) and never put it back. Literally 2 seconds later, they reset it and it worked fine. They didn't even charge us.

We obviously didn't need the spring and roller replacement that Master Garage Door Services recommended. I feel like they either misread the situation completely or tried to upsell us on services we didn't need. Either way, we were none too pleased.

I wasn't sure of what to think with the 3 star reviews, but I can tell you this was a solid 5 on some levels and a solid 4 on others. For example, service was a complete mess and a 3 to 4, but as far as atmosphere, vibe, and food plus drink; it was a 5. 

Between the live music, the Greeks that surrounded this place, belly dancing, live music, ouzo, and poor decisions, we made this night worth it. My sister, cousin, and her boyfriend plus myself were here for 4.5 hours. We drank, ate, and socialized the night away. It almost felt we knew everyone. It was a fun and social environment that engaged everyone despite of where they came from. For the most part, people were wearing masks. I was when I was not eating or drinking.
