I can vouch food was authentic and far from Americanized. I spent 17 days in Greece 3 years ago, and I tore up that country's food scene. It was wonderful to experience something close to the authentic thing here in America. I would've never known that a Greek community existed in Tampa if it weren't from my cousin. It took my sister by surprise as well. She recently relocated her and is still adjusting. Covid times being what it is, my sister is not getting out and exploring very much.

If you want a fun vibe with a chill ambiance of people, this is place to come. You can't go wrong with a bully dance, live musicians, and a singer singing solely in Greek. It was wonderful. 

Come try Mama's when you get a chance. Also, bypass 3 the stars. It exceeds more than just an OK experience.

This place is just ok. All the rolls were pretty good but nothing exceptional. It is very Americanized. I had been once a very long time ago and remembered really liking it but this trip did not blow me away. We are from out of town and would not waste a meal here again but it is decent if you are in the area and looking for a quick sushi fix.

Busy with market. Food for now and later.
This is my favorite location of Cuca's and it's all about the vibe. I feel like I'm in divey taqueria...and I am.

The food is the same from other locations with large portions and some seating on the covered patio. I dig the breakfast burrito con chorizo or the lunch with carnitas. Mmmmm

Parking can be a bear in the back but push your way in and give it a try. If this location is too much for you, the Mesa spot is more laid back with the same great food. Grab a burrito to-go and head for the beach. Breakfast, lunch or even dinner. This food also cures hangovers so salud!

finally got to try Angelo's! i recently heard that this is the new philly favorite cheesesteak and pizza so i had to test it out for myself

1) UPSIDE DOWN PIZZA (w/ extra cheese) 5/5 - this was delicious. fresh or heated up i really enjoyed this. the dough was somehow still light and fluffy even though it's a thick pizza. great sauce 

2) CHEESESTEAK 3.75/5 - i messed up, i got extra american instead of getting their cooper sharp which is their staple. mine didn't have enough cheese to meat ratio but the bread was BOMB. i need to try next time w/ the cooper

3) ITALIAN HOAGIE 5/5 - delicious. AMAZING flavor and great cuts of meat. i really enjoyed this sandwich

all in all, this is a good pizza/sandwich spot. it's not the most convenient since i had to call at 11am and the line was busy for about 20 minutes. it was ready within 40 minutes, cash only and had to go pick it up with my car since i live in north philly (no delivery) but for those that live near by i'm jealous of you!

We had some tasty tacos here today! But, the hit of the visit was their homemade hot sauce! That is some serious hot sauce. It will frizzle your hair and bring on the sweat! Now, back to the tacos...

We tried both Mexican style (cilantro and onion with lime) and American style (cilantro, lettuce, cheese, tomato, onion, and sour cream with lime) and both were flavorful. Both kinds are $2 so you don't need to bring a ton of money. As for the meats, they were out of almost everything so we were left with Al Pastor (good flavor) and beef (much too bland). Apparently, they were busy today!

To order, you go to the lady standing near the food. They make everything and then call your name. You pay later, when you are done, and just tell them what you got. So, there is no fancy numbering system or receipts. Just your honor!

We sat in the gas station/convenience store ambiance and enjoyed our meal. They were actually attentive, clearing away used plates and such and bringing us more hot sauce to melt our skulls. My only complaint, once you get past eating in a convenience store, was we were a little disappointed we couldn't try more meats but perhaps next time.

So I haven't had much mexican food in Philadelphia- mostly just in the suburbs or on road trips from the city. I've had it a few times recently and this place has made me remember how much I love all things Mexican! The tacos were simple but stacked with meat and they came with all of the accompaniments like lime, cucumber, cilantro and spicy, fresh sauces. The enchiladas were very soft and flavorful, and the chicken inside was cooked perfectly. You can tell them make everything as you order but, but the wait wasn't absurdly long, only at the end when getting the check was it a little extra time. On a lazy Sunday, not a huge problem. Order takeout if you're in more of a rush, or just enjoy the process, grab an agua fresca, and wait it out!

Flemings is located in the West End neighborhood near Centennial Park. We come here almost every year to celebrate our anniversary. Always a wonderful experience with outstanding service and phenomenal food! This last dinner, we ordered a bottle of wine, a filet mignon (12 oz) topped with crab oscar style and a side of green beans.  Everything was cooked perfectly! The filet was the perfect temperature of medium, crab meat was sweet like it should be and the green beans al dente! When we left, they gave us a little anniversary gift; it was a small box of 4 truffles and a $25 gift card to come back! We will definitely come back!

Why is when we are  not looking for a place to go with her dog, we find it. We did not have our dog with us this time, and we found this place. They have a beautiful outside area that has a great view of the intercoastal. They have pretty good prices especially if you go around the early part of dinner, but they still had a 12.50 menu that included a side and dessert as well.
I had scallops and my husband had some chicken. The scallops were just okay. His chicken was good but the corn he picked to go with it was strangely a bit spicy. My scallops were a little bit tough. I picked veggies and sweet potatoes to go with it. The sweet potatoes were good with white raisins in it, yup. a bit different. I really wanted a mango daiquiri but they did not have any mango. I will go back here for the nice tropical atmosphere and since I know my dog can come with us here. There is tons of parking too.

This is your typical five guys restaurant peanuts and all. I ordered my phone for pick up and that was probably a good idea since the place was pretty busy on a Saturday night. What I didn't like is when I arrived and I said hi I am so and so and I'm here to pick up my order They yelled my name so everybody in the restaurant could hear and then everybody behind the counter yelled my name again saying hi. I'm not sure if this is a gimmick or they were just being that way but I just want to pick up my food and go. 

The order that I had placed 10 minutes earlier was ready but they already send me off without the milkshake. We of course gave it to me but it just reminded me that you still have to check your order no matter how easy things appear to be going.

The burgers here actually very good and better than the other five guys that I usually end up going to.  I give them four stars for that. Three stars for making your customers feel a little weird or uncomfortable.

Location is good if you are Uptown near the River for any reason. 

Free parking in a lot but be careful for the traffic flow can be worrisome at times.

Nothing special about store or service here. 

I will use this store when I am in need of  something they carry and I am in the area.

I absolutely love noodles. 

So I just had to come here once I heard about Cheu's existence. Reading the reviews and descriptions beforehand, I knew the noodles and food aren't authentic in origin but rather the creations of an excellent chef's culinary imagination. That chef happens to have cooked at one of the best restaurants (Matyson) in the city. Despite my general apprehension of Asian fusion cuisine, I ventured into Cheu's Noodle Bar fearlessly..fueled by my obsession of noodles. 

The inside is really small. Exactly how a noodle bar should be like. There's about 3-4 tables besides the stools. Overall, clean and modern look and yet had a very nice cultural and down to earth feel about it. Great first impression as you walk into the place.

We ordered the following appetizers:

*Black Garlic Wings w/ shishito peppers (4) $ 8: Great tasting garlic flavors on the outside. Had a nice crunch. Although lacked flavors inside. 

*Burger & Pork Belly Buns $7: The buns are fried briefly on the outside. The pork belly was absolutely delicious. It was tender and flavorful. Really melted in your mouth. Exactly how it should be. The bun itself wasn't anything special. 

*Eggplant w/ crispy garlic, herbs, tamarind  $7: I'm not a huge eggplant fan so I can't really comment. Maybe you are and will love this dish!

We ordered the following noodles:

PORK BELLY RAMEN W/ POUCHED EGG, SEA BEANS, GREENS $12: 

THE GOOD: Once again, the pork belly was really good. Definitely the standout of the entire experience. 

THE BAD: The broth wasn't horrible. If you never have authentic ramen before, you might actually think it's delicious. My taste buds are spoiled from the likes of Ippudo and Totto. The broth lacked a certain richness and depth. 

THE UGLY: The ramen was chewier and harder than I liked. Not used to eating ramen with this type of noodles. 

DUCK PHO w/ FOIE GRAS MEATBALLS $13: I don't really understand why this is called Pho because nothing about it taste like Pho. Instead of the traditional rice noodles, Cheu decided to use the exact ramen noodles for the duck "pho" as well...speechless. Aficionados of Pho will be offended. The meatballs were tasty. If you are a fan of pho...be warned! 

Prices are on the heavier side. Service was friendly and accommodating. 

Ultimately- Come here with an open heart about how the food here is conceptionized and prepared and you'll love it more. Read this: Nothing about Cheu is traditional. I genuinely attempted my best to like the noodle bar but years of eating authentic ramen and pho ruined this experience for me.

I wholeheartedly laud owners Ben and Shawn for coming up with this uber cool idea and having the courage to make it a reality. Wish them nothing but success! Will definitely come back one day to see how the food has evolved!

I rarely eat fast food because a: I like supporting local, and b: I prefer eating something that is more healthy.  But for Captain D's, I decided to step out of my boundaries and give them a try.

I have lived on the south side for nearly 20 years and something about this place keeps it going despite the difficulty getting into the parking lot (more later).  It appears to be the only one of this chain in the metro area (according to the website locator).  Yet the ratings stay high while many other fast food places get poor ratings.  So, I stopped in for lunch.

Okay, if you are heading southbound on the divided highway US 31, you can pull right into the lot which has a loop around the building for drive through service.  But even the lot has a large dip for drainage.  However, if you are heading here from the south, you need to turn onto the side street before reaching it and then take a right onto another side street that has sandbox sized potholes by the lot which you have to navigate around.  And getting out of here, you have to head south and turn at the stop light to get headed back to the north.  

So, I took the side street route to get here and found some parking, entering on the highway side.  The place has a clean dining room at the entrance with the order counter on the back left.  The menu is listed overhead and when you are ready, place your order.  I was surprised at how quickly my order came forward form the kitchen in the back.  I hadn't even finished paying yet (they don't make you sign your receipt here even though it says Merchant's Copy....I asked) when my tray arrived with Fish and Fries.

I was given a cup for my beverage to fill at the station to the right.  I also stopped to get some sauces including ketchup and tartar sauce.  Unlike their nearest competitor in the industry, I didn't find malt vinegar anywhere.  I had also been given a wrapped plastic fork at the counter to use.  

I was pleasantly surprised that the fries were really long and still hot and had already been salted.  Very nice!  And the fish (2 pcs) were long and crisped though once cut, the breading sometimes fell off from the steam of the fish.  Again, the fish was good without any "fishy" scent.  That's a good sign!  The plate also came with a couple hush puppies.

Overall, I would say that if you are a fan of this type of meal, the quality is as good as any fast food place I've been.  Now, if they could just do something about the parking lot.

Review #3521

From 5 stars to 2?! What could've happened? One word, greed. I've been coming to this place for about 5 years now. Every time, I have great service and amazing food. It's been about 6 months since I've been to mcdougals and some things have changed. 

1. The large basket used to be $8.99, it's now $10.99. 
2. You can no longer get a cup of water. They now proudly offer you bottled water. Don't get any hot sauce! 
3. The fried chicken sandwich used to be $7.49, it's now $6.99. DEAL, right? Wrong, the sandwich now cost $6.99 but doesn't come with fries. You have to pay $3.09 to add fries. Want a drink with that too? That will be $2.19. 

So the normal meal my boyfriend and I get used to cost about 19 dollars. The same meal now costs 25 dollars (2 dollars more for large basket and 3 bucks for the fries that are now an add on).

Would I eat here again? Yea, but I'm not happy with all the new changes to the menu.

Extremely legit place. I went at 11am on a Monday and it was pretty much all older guys, probably Italian, drinking espressos and hanging out. This is what I want to do when I retire - as soon as possible.

I definitely prefer this place over Jamba Juice any day ! They don't have the super healthy options like Jamba but the prices are for their generous potion is so worth it on a hot hot day ! 
This place is conveniently located in the Santa Barbra outdoor mall so grab a smoothie during the day! 
I got the peach with pineapple sorbet. I LOVE peach and pineapple and this was the best smoothie I have ever had. 
They also have a huge variety of healthy boosts. For FrEe ! I wish there is an LA location !
Very tasty hummus and baba ganoush. The hummus is fresh and the baba ganoush has smoky flavor. The pita bread is made there but it's not typical pita bread, it's more to focaccia bread.

I received a menu in my doorway for a new pizza and steak place about 2 miles from my house so I decided to check it out. The GPS directed me to the address however I was a little lost when I saw this large laundromat. Of course I drive past the laundromat thinking nothing of it. After a block or two I call , low and behold, the pizza and steak place is in the laundromat. This is an ominous sign!


By phone I ordered two cheese steaks for $7 and it comes with French Fries. The order was taken with some difficulty as I had to repeat myself several times in order for the person on the other line to repeat the order as I had given it. On the call I was frustrated however when I arrived at the restaurant I realized she was doubling as the laundromat attendant and taking the orders on the phone for the pizzeria. Too funny. The restaurant as well as the laundromat is extremely clean. But it's new. Based on the location it'll probably change.  The cheesesteaks were extremely sparse lacking meat and cheese, the fries taste like precooked or warmed over fries. Not cold but reheated or under a lamp. Unless my wash machine breaks I can't see coming back!

Mediterranean food is really one of my favorite types of food. I didn't know it until recently, but it is. I was really craving some fresh pita bread and hummus and so I thought about it and decided to try a place nearby. My fiance and I showed up on a Saturday evening and we were both surprised that we were able to be seated so quickly! There were other customers inside, but it was not crazy busy. It was comfortable. 

Our server came over and took our drink orders she also made a few recommendations from the menu. We decided to try the red dip to start and then we continued to look over the menu.  To be honest, I was really thinking about ordering a gyro, but something told me not. I was in a new place and I needed to try a new thing. I surprised myself and ordered the chicken saganaki, the server told me that I would really enjoy it which only made me want it more. 

We enjoyed our dip and the pita while waiting for our meals. By the time our meals came I was feeling ready to try a new dish. It looked delicious and smelled even better. I could not wait to try it. Before digging in though our server offered to bring us some refills which we needed and then she left us to enjoy our meals. One bite later and I was in love. I don't know what saganaki is, but now I know this is going to be my "go to" dish when I come here. The chicken was juicy and the flavors worked so well together. I even has some pita to dip in the sauce which was perfect. 

Yes, I would say this is on my new list of favorite places in STL. If you like Mediterranean food or if you want to try an awesome Mediterranean place you should go visit Apollonia. The food was delicious and the service was friendly and quick.

I received a menu/flier in my mail, and wanted to give it a try. I called to place a carry out order, and my food was ready for pick up in about 15 minutes. The location itself is clean, modern and bright. There is plenty of seating inside. If you are dining in, you go to the counter to place your order, and then you are given a number, and they will bring your food out to you. When I arrived back home, my order was packaged nicely and food was hot a fresh. I sampled from family members the pan fried dumplings (they were ok, not so flavorful), Chicken Pad Thai (again, not flavorful), Japanese Fried Rice (once again, not flavorful), and I ordered the yellow Thai Curry. My dish by far was the best. Wasn't the best yellow curry that I've had in my life, but it was tasty. The third star in my rating is for this dish.

Overall, I would be fine if I never ate here again. Since majority of the items that I tried were not full of flavor, I am not in a hurry to try anything else. Pricing was on the lower end, so I may sample other menu items in the future, for that reason only.

Expensive, yes. But that is the only negative. The people who work here are incredibly nice and helpful. The pre-pared food is a working woman's dream. The Jamba Juice is perfect for breakfast or just to pretend you are in Cali.

HINT: Near their checkout lanes grab a couple tuperware containers full of prepared soups such as Split Pea, Clam Chowder and Parmesean Broccoli. It's like having homemade soup at home or work without all the messy cooking and cleaning!

Kermit's is one of those places that you'll stop in and not only be satisfied with the items made there, you'll also be kind of entertained by the creativity that goes into these baked goods. I somehow keep stopping too early for pizza. But this is a bakery... And a bakery that makes some really good cakes, cookies, tarts, and other items. They also make breakfast pockets that resemble huge pop tarts. The latest wine that I bought was a mushroom and cheese pocket. I've had several types of cookies, cakes, these little fudge brownie pops on a stick, and a huge serving of bread pudding. A quality business that is a good alternative to your everyday bakery.

I need to whip my calculator out one of these days to see if this place does charge a premium.  The produce is great and their butcher is solid.  The deli, get this, doesn't pre-slice their meats.  It makes a difference.  Trust me.  That's how it's done.

Oh yes.  The cheeses: they have a great selection of those as well.  During the day, there are free samples of 2 different cheeses.  Without fail.  It's something I look forward to :P

They even have some Schnucks products that I haven't noticed elsewhere (I'll be on the lookout, though.)  Vacuum packed smoked poultry?  Where did that come from?  Of course, this being in the area it is, there's plenty of Kosher too.

We arrived here early on a Friday evening, so we were one of only a handful of tables at the time. The weather was pleasant and we sat outside on the terrace. The server promptly greeted us and we didn't have to wait long for him to return with our beverages and to take our order. I got the Chicken Biryani and my boyfriend got the Chicken Vindaloo. I absolutely loved the biryani! It was so fragrant and flavorful - delicious and enticing in every way. We were both very happy with our dishes. I also ordered the rasmalai for dessert, which is a sweet dumpling in condensed milk with rose water. It was perfect. It was like a sweet little pillow in my mouth with just the right amount of sweetness. I want to learn how to make this and experiment more with rose water in dishes. Anyway, I look forward to coming here again...I'll make sure it's soon!

This place is such a cool concept. You get to eat and drink while watching small planes and helicopters fly in and out on the grounds around you. 

Service- 2 stars
Food- 4 stars

From the beginning the service was borderline rude. They were a little bit busy so maybe they were stressed but more than one person had an attitude. Being our first time there we were a little confused and no one greeted us for a while, finally the hostess did and she was pretty nice. We were looking at the specials board while we were waiting and a girl got in front of us and started erasing them with out saying a word, it was weird and kind of rude. So we decided to wait at the bar. The bartender was not too friendly either. She seemed annoyed when we asked what vodkas they had, what wines, etc. My bloody mary was delicious though!

Thankfully we got seated pretty quickly. We even got a table outside! It was shaded though so it was a little chilly, but we got up to look at the planes and stand in the sun for a little which was nice. I know we had drinks from the bar but the waiter I guess assumed we didn't need anything else and I was dying for water. He seemed busy as well. Eventually he took care of everything. The next drink I ordered was a mojito. It is on the drink menu however they couldn't make me one because they didn't have any mint. bummer. You can't substitute a salad for the fries, so I just got a salad as well. I'm convinced they accidentally gave me feta instead of goat cheese. Food took a very long time to come out. Again, busy I guess. But it was close to 45 minutes for mostly sandwiches.

Overall I enjoyed the place. Watching the planes is cool, you can even take a helicopter ride! I think I would give it another chance if I was in the area again.

Szechwan Garden has quickly become one of my favorite places to eat in Indy. With a menu so big it requires page numbers, everyone can find something to eat here with little problem. Feeling adventurous? Try the frog dry pot or one of the dishes with intestine in them. Not feeling that? No worries... they have more of the typical Chinese food fare like Kung Pao Chicken, Fried Rice, Lo Mein, etc. too. There's something for everyone on the menu here.

I've been here several times and have experimented a little bit with the menu, but I always get the crispy green beans and fried pot stickers. For my main dishes, I rotate between the Spicy Popcorn Chicken (which is addicting) and I've really started to get into the dry pots - a pan of food over hat that continues to bubble away at the table while you eat. I've had both the tofu and the chicken dry pots and both are delicious with lemongrass and ginger mixed into the broth.

If you haven't been here before, I offer some "newbie" tips to keep in mind:
-If you're a wine snob and only drink specific varieties, stick with water here. They have two kinds of wine: Red and White. That's right.. it's a $9 glass of wine called "Red" or "White" and my guess is that's it's of the boxed variety.

-Everything that I've gotten here has been big enough to share. Most of the tables have a lazy susan built into the middle of it to assist in the family style atmosphere. Just don't forget and place your water on it unless you plan on sharing that too! 

-Because things are meant to be shared, the food comes out when the dish is ready, not when everything is ready. 

-When it's time to start loading up leftovers (which there will almost always be), ask for the plastic containers if you have something soupy or full of liquid.

I really don't get the attraction of Jimmy John's.   Maybe it's because they're the only sandwich shop that delivers.   I, on the other hand, ran into this location to get a sandwich to-go (after picking up some items at the Kroger next door), so I missed out on the whole 'Freaky Fast Sandwiches' experience.

And not just because I didn't have it delivered -- my sandwich took forever for them to make even though I was the only person in the restaurant and was sitting right in front of the pick-up window.   There were 2 guys making sandwiches and 1 finally noticed me and said "Oh, are you still waiting for your sandwich?"    Why YES!

Eventually I got my sandwich and took it home to eat.   I got the #17 which they call The Ultimate Porker (smoked ham and bacon).   It was just 'meh'.    Honestly, I could make a better sandwich at home from the Kroger-brand deli meat.   And the bread?   I thought they were supposed to have this amazing bread for which they proudly offer 'Free Smells'.   Double-meh.   It was cold, hard, and tasteless.

Well, at least I satisfied my curiosity regarding Jimmy John's for the next 10 years at least.

I cannot believe that this was my first visit here.
We are always celebrating birthdays, anniversary and just because we love Mexican food.
This place is so reasonable for dinner with happy hours each day of the week! ( I'm in)

I love great margaritas pair with excellent food!
My husband and I had the pick 4 combination plater! This was so much food that we had to get to go boxes.
On entering this restaurant we were greeted with hello would you like a table or both. 
We selected the both! Our server was happy and friendly!

We all order two margaritas right away! I order one frozen and one on the rocks no salt. ( both of my margaritas was just right for me)

We had a great time eating and drinking margaritas with excellent spicy salsa ($1.00 up charged). I did not care about that because it was  so freakin good. Thank you for providing excellent customer service with excellent food with reasonable pricing. I will return!

Gloria~

I don't know maybe I have gotten too used to Indo-Pak versions of this cuisine but everything here was really bland and mild. We ordered the "sloppy joes" off the appetizer menu and it was really just to sliders buns with minced chicken meat - we added the sauces brought to the table. The meat was spiced ok but was dried out and over cooked. The desserts are over-thought and thus fail to impress. Rasmalai are awesome on their own, please don't turn it into some mockery if a tiramisu. The orange rice pudding was ok but nothing special. The service was terrible and not just for us. This was I think due in large part to the waiters except on being either A. completely new and untrained or B. just really doesn't care.
In the case of our waitress she was clearly untrained. We cringed when she was struggling to explain the food to another table. Now we could hear the whole conversation because this place is rather small so it stands to reason the other two servers heard her struggling as well but opted to just stand by the cash register and stare off into space instead of trying to help her out. I know wait staff works for tips but the best restaurants and kitchens need teamwork and this place clearly did not have it. For the price point and the lack luster food this is most like the only time I will bother dining here.

Super nice people with great skills. 

Completely professional. With my one hour reflexology they also, while my feet were soaking, massages my head, neck, and shoulders. 

The foot massage concluded with hot stones on my soles and then a hot towel rub off. 

Then to my surprise, I was flipped over for a quick back and shoulder massage. They crammed a lot Into an hour and it was 20% off today so was only $40. Well well worth it!!

Best part was they let me bring my dog In, and she sat on the chair with me (on a towel so as to not get hair or dander on the chair) and she supervised while I enjoyed. I think the Masseuse enjoyed her too, he kept smiling at her. All in all a fantastic day. This place is going on must do list whenever I'm in the Tampa area.

Not a big fan of Mexican fare but this has a twist different than the rest! Drinks and a fun atmosphere in the most intriguing side of town make this a no fail visit.  Fall in love with the neighborhood homes by taking a stroll before or after your meal. Everyone in my party enjoyed their meal. I wasn't impressed with the guacamole sadly to say.  My appetizer of fried green tomatoes with grilled shrimp was amazing in portion, idea, and ingredients  but too salty for me.

Outstanding barbecue! I had the pulled pork sandwich and it was delicious! Probably the best one I've ever had. They serve it with a side of their own barbecue sauce, baked beans and cole slaw. The sauce was amazing. It was zesty and smoky, just perfect. The beans were tasty and the cole slaw was delicious! I don't even like cole slaw but I enjoyed this one.

One of my favorite restaurants in New Orleans; amazing Chargrilled Oysters and Warm Whiskey Bread Pudding. If the lines weren't so gosh-darn long, I'd have eaten here everyday. As is, I wish i got up earlier the other day for lunch instead of waiting till 12.30p to venture there. I completely underestimated the place because it was fairly empty @ 12.15p the day before...*sigh*

Chargrilled Oysters- I got half a dozen but wish I had  gotten the order of a Dozen. Parmesean, garlic and butter + baked oysters = Yummy. It wasn't too overpowering with the embellishments, which was A-OK with me since I usually like shellfish simply prepared- the best way to taste Fresh seafood.

Warm Whiskey Bread Pudding- a small order for $4.99. It was so yummy that I really wished that the portion was BIGGER. It was SO good

Peacemaker Po Boy- I got it to go, which was pretty good, but I'm sure it'd have been so much better if i'd had it HOT. Plenty of oysters and shrimps; it was definitely worth the $12 (+$1 when u order it to go)

Seafood Gumbo- I've had better (@ Blues City Diner in Memphis), but it was probably the tastiest Gumbo I had in NOLA ( i had it at several places)

I'll definitely be back on my (hopefully very soon) next visit

Haven't been to Juan's in a while so I thought I will try it again. I got the enchiladas which were ok but nothing like the real thing in California and elsewhere but what can you do. It was good but the fillings were badly overgrilled. Please tell me other than a taco stand where I can find Cali style Mexican food in NOLA. The salsa verde is still good.

Came here to indulge, once again, on their delicious baked ham. There is ALWAYS a line outside to get in here, but luckily we waited to go on a Monday morning, still a line, but our wait was less than 5 minutes. Once inside we were directed to a register to place our order. We ordered the breakfast platter one with their famous baked ham and one with smoked sausage. We were then directed to sit in any available seating in the three dining dining rooms. The food came fairly quickly and consisted of grits, meat,eggs (which you could have fried, scrambled,.etc.), and a homemade biscuit. The ham was the star of the show: flavorful, moist with a great taste. The sausage was okay and not greasy. The biscuits was huge enough to share and was accompanied by blackberry jam. The staff were pleasant. 
All in all the breakfast was okay, but that ham will keep me coming back!

REALLY hit or miss. I have had some great meals here, and then I have had an embarassing moment where I brought my parents here for lunch and we all hated our dishes and couldn't eat them.

Besides that awkward time that I'd like to block out of my memory, I've been brave enough to try the sushi here. This will be reserved for the most desperate sushi cravings! Like if every other sushi place in the world self-combusts and I am not left with any other options. But then I think we'd have bigger fish to fry (pun intended)...

*Review during COVID/outdoor eating only*

A few friends and I visited Pumpkin for the first time in the fall to celebrate a birthday. The outdoor setup is adorable and well decorated, very picturesque! Loved that it was BYOB as well.

Service was excellent, our wait staff was attentive, friendly and knowledgeable. However, I wasn't as impressed with the food that I'd hoped for given the limited reservation availability (we could only get 8:30pm on a Tuesday several weeks in advance) and other glowing reviews. It was tasty and great quality, but just not my favorite - at least not for the pricing. 

I'd love to try again with a different menu, but I'll be knocking some other spots off my bucket list first.

There are some places where the food is so good that you forgive the setting and the horrible service. 

"It's a hole-in-the-wall, the servers are prickly, but the food is worth it."

Not this place.    The food is delicious, the service is excellent, AND the atmosphere is amazing.

If you have the opportunity sit in their awesome patio.   If it's raining or the sun is at a weird angle, they can close the roof or lower a shade.   It's just such pleasant place to be.

And the food does not take a backseat to the environs.   They have authentc birria tacos and posole.    This isn't your father's Mexican food (unless he's from Chihuahua.

I was sadly disappointed w this place this time around. This was our third time here and it was super inconsistent. Little details that I loved were not there like the cute little seahorse and seashell shaped butters. Nope, didn't have it, or our server this time around was too lazy possibly. The guava BBQ roasted chicken my husband liked was gone. They said not enough sales. For BBQ chicken? This time I had the mahi mahi w mango salsa. The fish was over cooked. No wonder it took a while to get our food. Rum runner tasted like watered down rum water, and our server was whatever. Trying to assist us at the last min, rather than when we first get there. This place has a beautiful view, dog friendly outside patio, cheesy quirky fun music, but food quality, and service ehh.

It's one of those restaurants that if you don't set your expectations too high by the reviews, you would feel happier just to explore it. 

Cute restaurant but gets very crowded, loud when it's very busy. We weren't that hungry so we ordered a seafood gumbo and a chicken andouille gumbo just to try. Our server brought us two seafood gumbos and because the service was so slow, we didn't bother to get one of the gumbos changed. 

Flavors and quality are okay. A bit under seasoned. The crawfish was very small and just a little in our cups. The size of bread on side was generous though.

I almost missed out on a great opportunity to dine at Arigato. I was recommended by my inn hostess at Simpsons House and as I looked at all the yelp photos, it looked like they specialized in rolls... Since I prefer sashimi and sushi I was a little hesitant. But since it was a walking distance from our Inn, we went and it was a pleasant surprise. 
We sat at the bar and asked for todays special. Fortunately, they had way better quality uni than SB seafood shellfish company so it made up for the bitter (and puny) uni we had for lunch. We also ordered Shima Aji (it was on a daily special menu) sushi and it just melted in our mouth. Aside from specials, we got the Arigato premium sashimi and it was so good! Our sushi man was professional and very helpful. We loved the vibe, friendly service, fresh wasabi, high quality sashimi and the price! We will definitely come back next time we're in town.

Best hand drawn noodle in philly! This place is my favorite..CASH ONLY.

I usually get the Sliced Beef Noodle Soup or Beef Tendon Noodle Soup. Broth is good and decent amount of noodles/meat. 

Legit place for authentic hand drawn noodles. You probably won't spend more than 10 bucks for your meal.

On my lazy days off when all I want to do is play my video game for most of the day and my stomach starts reminding me that it is almost lunch time, there are only a few places that will deliver in a timely fashion and Jimmy John's is one of them. I have never actually set foot inside this place but I have had many deliveries from this location. I've been satisfied every time with how courteous their drivers are, how quickly they deliver the food, and how tasty their subs are. I always get almost the same thing every time: a turkey tom with extra turkey, add in some onions and peppers. Sometimes I get it on the regular French bread, other with their whole wheat bread.

I love the consistency of this place with their delivery service as well as the food and the online ordering makes everything very convenient!

Yeah I had a lot of fun in Forest park. It is one of the coolest parts of St. Louis!
This is usually one of my favorite stops in St. Louis. The next time I go visit my sister I will have to stop by this place.

Publix has been my go-to grocery store ever since I moved to Florida many years ago. Yeah it can be more expensive than those super-discount chains, but I'll gladly pay the extra money for a very clean store with friendly & helpful associates and a terrific selection of items.

When I was married and used to live in Westchase this was one of the two Publix that I used to visit regularly. She-who-must-never-be-named and I would make our regular pilgrimages to Publix to load up on the staple items for the pantry and freezer, and then stop in during the week for fresh fruits, veggies, and dinner ideas.

This particular Publix is located along Race Track Road and Hillsborough Avenue extended, right before you cross the magical line into Pinellas County. The shopping center is across Race Track from the Oldsmar Flea Market, and it contains a big Lowe's, YouFit Health Club, Cracker Barrel, Publix, and some other retail outlets.

We would either stop at the smaller Publix on Linebaugh Avenue and Countryway Boulevard in the heart of Westchase (better known as the "little" Publix), or this one on Race Track Road known as the "bigger" Publix. Truth be told, this particular Publix is a medium-sized store within their chain (as compared to the big one on Gunn Highway across from Sickles High School).

What I like about this store is that the associates will go out of their way to help you find particular items - even if they are clear across the store. The associates were happy to lead you over to the correct aisle, and then look through the selection of products until you find what you need. They don't view this as an annoyance, but rather as an opportunity to say 'Thanks for shopping here, how can I help you?'.

I've had great experiences at the butcher case, and enjoyed some terrific conversations with the people who will break down one of their packaged items to give you what you need, or even carve it fresh off of a larger cut of meat. One of the butchers would regularly stop and chat with me, and provide cooking tips as he was carving up some special steaks. I was always very appreciative for their excellence in customer service.

Now that I live over in Carrollwood I visit a different set of Publix grocery stores for my regular shopping, but still stop into this store whenever I'm in the Oldsmar / Westchase area and need to pick up a few items.

We capped off our Phoenixville bar crawl at Stable 12. We hadn't intended to stay for more than a drink and then the manfriend heard the word...karoake.

Had I noticed the menu when we were developing our game plan, we would've planned to eat at Stable 12. Not only did the menu sound the best, but the food looked and smelled mouthwatering.

I don't recall what I ordered, something on the lighter side, but I enjoyed it. We ended up staying there for a few hours; catching the end of the football game and staying long enough for manfriend to sing a few rounds of karaoke.

I'm not sure if it's the karaoke, but there seem to be a good number of regulars that come in. When it's warmer out, the size of this place almost triples with their great patio.

They have my favorite cocktail in the world as a happy hour special - The Dark and Stormy. I make it at home all of the time, but I love it even more when it is handed to me for $5 or less!

I have heard great things about the food, so I will have to make another trip soon!

This is my favorite DD! It's on my way to work, and I've been stopping here most mornings for the last year or so. The male cashier who works there is just the most friendly guy and has an incredible memory for your regular order. I've walked in before to find that he already has my drink order ready, just because he recognized my car pulling in. The other workers are very nice and efficient as well, but he stands out. There's also a very sweet, friendly lady (I think her name is Lisa?) who works the drive through register, and she's a joy to see in the morning-- very warm and friendly. Pro tip: walking in is most often quicker than the drive-thru here, so I'll usually park and run in. This is a really great DD!

Really nice new restaurant. They opened December 2019. It's a fun Caribbean inspired restaurant with great food and music. I really liked the guacamole, jerk chicken,  veggie burger, skillet cookie and climate
Change drink. Customer service is really good and it is in a good location on Baronne Street. 

I highly recommend this restaurant! Oh, and happy hour is Monday - Friday 1/2 off drinks.

Not great.  I should have been wary given that there were so few reviews!  I ventured off my route on my way from DC to NY to stop at UMMM.  The place was swarming with high school kids outside.  They were literally the only people on the whole block in what was a pretty dead street.

I walked in and ordered vanilla ice cream with m&ms.  You know when you taste your ice cream and the consistency is like sand?  You can taste the little granules and it almost seems like you need to chew it in order to get it to go down.  Yeah, that's this stuff.  Perhaps the vanilla was old or something, but I won't return to find out if it's a fluke.  

I upped it to two stars because my ice cream yielded me a nice instagram photo with a decent amount of likes.

Bigger is not always better.

Misconduct has recently undergone a large scale renovation and expansion into the neighboring space, and has also undergone a global shift in atmosphere.  What was once a cozy, yet bustling, unique gastro-pub has morphed into yet another mega-bar where you can have a generically "okay" beers and food experience.  It's packed, loud, and rowdy - sometimes complete with fist pumping.

The menu contents are the same, but execution of a lot of the food has been lacking.  The customizable mac & cheese, in particular, has let me down.  I guess it is good for the business that they were profitable enough as a small neighborhood stand-out to morph into an even more profitable scene, but it's not my scene.

WHERE's the beef!?!?!

I'm vegetarian, and even I found myself asking this question because my date and I both ordered thai entrees with pork or shrimp (respectively) and between us, there wasn't enough protein to feed a starving cat. The entrees both tasted wonderful, but  you don't get your money's worth here. Maybe it's because we had a groupon?

We also had a sushi roll as an appetizer. A lot of good specialty rolls. Too many fried ones for our taste though. Still, it had a good amount of fish and wasn't just a lot rice. So may if you come here, stick to the sushi. the sushi boat - it looks awesome! If you're in a group, get The guy rolling them by had looks serious legit. Treats every roll like an art form, according to our waiter.
 
The reason this place gets 3 stars instead of two for the meager entrées was the atmosphere. It was a  wonderful oriental oasis in a typical TPA strip mall. It has an intimate atmosphere with Asian inspired wall treatments and warm lighting. So I would consider returning and just get the sushi.

When my NY family comes to town, they seem to always wanna get Santucci's pizza. 
I shriek at them," What's wrong with you people?! This is not how we were raised!!!" just because I enjoy pointless dramatics and inappropriate outbursts of rage. 

Of course we're born thin crust people, but there's no denyin' that Santooch's, (can I call ya Santooch, Santooch? I already do, Santooch.) square crust, sauce-over-the-cheese pizza is very good eating. The not-too-thick crust always seems to keep its crunch through delivery travel (Well, we're only 7 blocks away...we could walk, I know) and I'm a fan that well-seasoned super-tomatoey Santucci pizza sauce.

Another thing, we recently split the braised short rib sandwich too. Pretty pretty pretty good... The meat is shredded and juicy. It comes on a seeded roll with cremini musrooms and oozy melted fontina. I hit it with a little hot sauce here and there. This 9 dolla sandwich comes with a side of hand-cut fries, and I have to say, I've never had any luck with them. When we've ordered em in the past, these potatoes show up either cold under-cooked, soggy and limp as a noodle, or they're burnt and saltless. Either way, I threaten to hurl them out the window for the pigeons.

'Sides that, you're aces with me, Santooch.

I use to enjoy coming hear to eat. But went hear for Dinner recently. And first thing I could only think of, is why is this place so empty. 

I got seated at a booth, and open up the menu, and my mouth almost dropped, after I seen how high there prices have went up. Yes i understand food is on the rise. But I've never seen prices go up this high no where. This is something I never seen coming especially hear.

I had an amazing shrimp po-boy sandwich here several years ago. And I still talk about it today. The place gets crowded very quickly so go early! The staff is sassy and adds to the ambiance. Make sure you know what you want to order by the time you get to the counter! Or the ladies will have your ass. Well, not really, but I bet they could!

now i know where to go when i want:

- fun specialty cocktails
- bangin hummus
- cute little lamb dumplings
- to get away from center city prices
- to sit outside on a nice evening in g-ho
A solid option late at night.  The food was average, but the prices were a bit much.  Not completely infested with college students surprisingly.

I went to Cheu Noodle Bar with a friend and it was packed, especially for a Tuesday.  It was small, so we were told that the wait time would be 20 minutes and we were seated exactly in 20 minutes.  Everyone there seemed to work together and the restaurant was a well oiled machine.  I don't know if it was because we were seated at the bar, but they made everything so easy.
I really couldn't decide between the Brisket Ramen or the Coconut Curry Noodles.  Then I saw their Ramen Release.  It was the Laksa Tantanmen, so I took a risk and I'm glad I did.  It was so good that they should make it on their main menu.  It was chicken sausage, egg with wide noodles and coconut curry broth.  It was one of those dishes I would be craving long after I ate it.  Now that it is colder, I will be back, especially if they have the Laksa Tantanmen!
If you have a sweet tooth, you must come here while in New Orleans.  I'm fairly sure there was more than one location, but I also had several drinks while in the Quarter.

I can't believe I haven't reviewed this restaurant yet, I've been here 4x now and enjoyed it. I didn't know that this was a sister company to OJ's until i saw the menu.

The one thing I love is the half off bottle of wine day hmmm wine...

We ordered the soft pretzels to start and I got the rocket salad while my sister decided on the jalapeno mac n cheese.

O my the pretzels must be the best I have ever had (besides the one I bake at home). My salad was so good that I order this each time but I always change up the appies.

Servers are a hit and miss, 1 of the 4 days we had a server who was off her game but the food is good so it's forgivable. 

I recommend sitting in the lounge, it's more relaxed and away from families just in case kids are around when you  more than one drink ;).

I was shocked to see the reviews on this golf course! While the course itself is not in the best shape, this is a great place for beginner and intermediate golfers to play and practice. For $16 you can play 9 holes with a cart. If you are a college student, they also offer a student discount. Additionally, they have a decently priced driving range. I love coming to this course!

MASSIVE pizza. A little overpriced (individual toppings can be as much as $3), but pretty good pizza overall. Service is average, but the location is great. Gets very busy on the weekends, so beware. 

Takeout is a great option here if you don't want to wait for a table. The pizza is just the same.

Walking inside everything smells incredible. Like my mouth watered instantly. The donuts are huge and can be split. I chose the one with bacon and maple frosting. Delicious!! Come check this place out!

It's OK.. The restaurant has really cool decor especially if you are  a kid. My son loves watching the trains ride above our heads.   They also give him a paper truck to build. 

We had burgers which were ok. Nothing great.   I was hoping it would be amazing since it was a main menu item. The fries were the shoe string type fries. They have bottomless fries which would normally be good/fun if the fries were amazing.  They were just ok

Kid has chicken tenders.  They were tasty.

The chocolate shake was not made from chocolate ice cream.  It was vanilla ice cream w/ syrup I suppose.   The waitress said she loves chocolate and it would be amazing and we wouldn't taste the different.  We did taste it.

Service was good.

Probably won't be back.

Always a yes. One of my two favorite Italian spots. I'm obsessed with the baked ziti. Holy deliciousness. Is that even a word? Who knows, but worth making up a word. 

Maggiano's is such a majestic/elegant building. I love that's it's up on a hill. Love the lights. Love the signage. Love the different stories. 

Walked in on Father's Day and was able to get a table with no wait; whattttt. 
We pretty much already knew what we wanted upon walking in. 
I love the bread and olive oil dip. Our food came out so quickly; I was super impressed. Food was amazing as expected and hot. We enjoyed it. This time we got dessert; I wanted it all, but got the brownie. Good choice. It was a lot and delicious. 

We got our to go meals, my leftovers and the rest of my dessert. Plenty of food for our money.
Damn you Cold Stone. Why do things that are so bad have to be so good?! Cold Stone is my favorite ice cream place, hands down. There are so many options and their malted shakes are to die for!

The food was good and the service was fast!  My Aunt loved her grilled oysters!  I had crab balls which were so so... the boiled potatoes instead of bread as a starter were spot on!  The portions are HUGE so you are best off splitting a couple things!

The Hurricanes were yummy and my Aunt loved her Martini.  The wine was so so or my palate was just blown which is entirely possible.  

They normally have a LONG line but it was pouring and we got right in!  Last meal in NOLA for this trip... but not the LAST in NOLA... I will be back!

*I forgot my camera, but the next I go in I'll be sure to bring it.*

 Okay, this location of IHOP is definitely the best I've been to. Firstly, the building is huge. There's lots of room and there's not way that they can't service their clientèle. The service was prompt and helpful. The only issue I had was when I asked to substitute (even for an up charge) my eggs for fruit. The server looked hesitant to tell me that, "They won't switch anything for eggs..."

That was okay. The pancakes I had were more than enough anyway. I hardly finished those and let the Mr. have my eggs.

ALSO, they are offering Smucker's sugar free syrup with is my favorite, so that wins me over on a level I can't even begin to explain. Either way, we enjoyed our visit, and with it being pretty inexpensive I'm sure we'll go again.

Welcome Back Gino's! Had my first Gino's burger in over 20 years...very tasty, but to be perfectly honest I can't exactly remember what they tasted like back in the day... 

Had the Bacon Cheeseburger, fries, and a strawberry chocolate shake for about 13 bucks...the price is whats keeping them from 5 stars, just a bit high for fast food. 

The fries are fresh cut, so they are thicker fries...i like mine thinner and crispier, but they are OK. The shake is a shake very similar to McDonald's or Burger King, I don't know there is any real ice cream or milk in it, but it's cold and creamy and is only 3 bucks... 

The burger was good for sure, I will be having another. But its not something like Cheeburger Cheeburger or Charlie's Burgers in Ridley that I would drive 30 minutes for without thinking twice. Still, its nice to have another option available and I do suggest you check it out. 

Obviously, this is a brand spanking new franchise...the staff has very little experience and there are bound to be issues while they are getting their feet wet in the burger business. Someone complained about the soda machines being out of order or the inexperience of the staff. Unfortunately, experience isn't something you can get training for, so this is bound to happen, particularly in the first week of opening...If you can't deal with the learning curve I'd give them a couple weeks to get their act together,(goes for any restaurant) but i had no issues whatsoever going during a busy lunch hour and was very pleased with the food and the service. Only the high prices kept them from 5 stars... 

So be patient, eventually someone will learn how to refill the soda machine promptly and will do it with a smile on their face. 

Gino's parking lot is a bit odd, the entrance and exit are both in the same location...makes more sense to have separate entrances and exits, but i guess they didn't have the option...kids have to be careful going in and out of the building as there isn't much of sidewalk...also note: no drive thru...

Simple food, long wait, overpriced. The best thing about it was that the food was healthy and customizable. That's the key for me but I can't say it was anything special. The wait was terribly long at 6:30 on a Thursday night. The parking was quite tough as we had to park in the Wegman's parking lot then run across the street. But as for the restaurant itself, if you get a salad, you're probably getting something healthy, decently good, and reliable.

Some Covid fun. I like this place a lot especially now that daylight is scarce, they have lights and two story deck for plenty of space between hitting bays.

The gentleman working is so kind and poured my bucket of balls out and was all about helping me move the tee to the left side for my lefty weirdness.

They have a nice pro shop for snacks and beverages  and rest room. 

I'm definitely planning to come here once a week to practice and just enjoy a moment of golf. Big fan!

The staff here really know how to represent the brand. I arrived early at 8:45 am a little before they opened. The store clerk saw me waiting and opened early at 8:50am. This was impressive to me as most associates would wait to exactly 9am and open at 9:01am. To me it's better when an establishment opens early rather than late. Glad to see that they prioritize promptness and customer service. After walking in the store I was immediately welcomed and went to the area with the items I was looking for. The store is well organized and the handbag section is color coordinated. In most ROSS stores, it's difficult to find what you need as you shuffle through the piles of inventory without any idea of what you'll find. The store was bright and clean and impressively the store clerk checked me out immediately after I approached the cashier area. Love this location and the selection they offer, will definitely be back again when I'm in the area.

Why haven't we been here before!  They have been open for 7 months and this is our first visit?!  Really?  Great venue, great service and very good food!  We tried the happy hour menu options of pork belly buns, shishito peppers and pork Gyoza. All so so good. We started our ramen experience with the pork belly ramen to share but it was so good we had the chicken too!  Such a great experience here that goes a long way to having a great food experience. Come here and relax and try some things you might not have had before. You will thank me!

Great food and great service!

The Hawaiian steak is bomb! Bulgogi is a staple, and one of my favorites here. The Basil Chicken was good too, but I'd rather just eat more of the KBBQ beef! 

Excellent, excellent service. I'm not used to having such good service at a KBBQ spot, and I eat KBBQ ALL the time, every week. (Just check my IG if you don't believe me)

The banchan is awesome. I loved the jap chae noodles; the sliced green onion with oil and seasoning is extra flavorful; the kim Chee isn't too overpowering, which I love; and the sprouts are definitely my fav!

My mom loved the seafood pancake. Great flavor, with calamari and shrimp inside.

This place is legit, and I can't wait to return.

Took a day off from work to run some errands and we found ourselves near Bordentown around 1pm. Having been there before we just parked the car and began walking around and came upon the Farnsworth House.

I must say we were pleasantly surprised at he extensive menu, with specials, as well as the 21 beers on tap.

Carol had the Chicken Barcelona along with a salad (Gorgonzola dressing - excellent) which was crisp and fresh. The chicken was stuffed with a spicy sausage and dill mixture and served with a Dijon mustard & tomato cream sauce. A serving of whole grilled asparagus finished off the plate.

I tried the Chicken Bella Bucca with a similar salad. My chicken was stuffed with prosciutto and fresh mozzarella, served over sauteed spinach in a Madeira wine sauce. Carol had a glass of red wine while I tried a Dogfish Head Palo Santo and followed that with a Green Flash IPA.

All, in all, a wonderful meal with a very attentive waiter. Definitely worth a try ...

These were definitely the best beignets we had during our trip to New Orleans. We had beignets in lots of different locations, and these were the lightest and fluffiest. They also have calas, another fried New Orleans treat. Calas are difficult to find so it was great to have the opportunity to try them (though they weren't really our cup of tea).

We also had a bagel sandwich and croissant sandwich which were both solid options. It's a cute little spot with the player piano to provide a bit of ambience. There are only 6-8 tables inside but many more in the courtyard.

With the number of reviews, Mother's Restaurant was a bit disappointing to me.  I went there for breakfast to try out the famous baked ham with grits.  The ham was sweet and tasty, but a little too dried.  The only thing it has going for them, is the Southern charm diner feel.

Wow was this place overrated. With a 4.5 average and almost 500 reviews I expected something spectacular. What I got was an average burger patty with communion wafer of a flatbread bun. The bun was dry and cracked at the fold. I did like the flavor, but the texture completely ruined the bun for me. The meat itself a small patty cooked well but underseasoned. The veggies on the burger were suspect in freshness. I had ordered the cheddar cheeseburger. My two dining companions ordered the bacon cheeseburger and the Texas bbq burger. The Texas bbq guy said it was mediocre. The bacon cheeseburger guy said it was about the same as Carl's Jr. He might have been exaggerating.

The sauces were average at best, especially with all the hole in the wall burger joints that dominate the foodie scene. My dining companion did not care for the viscosity of the sauces, as they were too runny. I did not think the flavors were bold enough. 

The seasoning on the fries was pretty good, but the texture reminded me of kfc potato wedges.

Service was irritating. The cashier did not greet us but instead carried on a long conversation with other employees. The service when we received the food was better but not enough to make me forget the cashier.

Bathroom smelled like mildew and also like urine. 

Not worth a drive out of the way especially with so many other choices.

I've always felt that Cafe De Thai was ahead of it's time.   From the prices I just couldn't afford when I was younger and less interested in a higher end unique experience.   To the modern building with it's oddly satisfying angles and excellent use of natural light beaming onto the industrial surfaces on the interior.  Cafe De Thai has always seemed like someone "transported" it right out of the not so distant future.  But not anymore.  The future is here, and it's much more homey than I expected it to be.  Contrasting the coolness of the metal and concrete lines is a family owned warmth to the service.

Every time I have been we have received the friendliest and most welcoming service.  Our names were remembered just the second time we returned to dine.  We've gone mostly at lunch and at off times to avoid the busier periods.  The food has been good and unique.  My favorite dish by far has been the pho.  For the broth alone it's worth coming here.  Check out my photos of the Pho.  They will tell you all you need to know about that dish.  The meats are all very traditional. Beef balls and such, but the star is the broth.

One of the other things I have loved about Cafe is their unique drink creations that give them their own signature.  Many times alcohol will just be a nice addition to the offerings.  Here they step up the creative game and give you something different to experience off the menu every once in awhile.

Now to get back in for dinner some time soon...

Oh, New Orleans. Your French Quarter always tries to lure us in, but this time we found ourselves charmed by the Marigny. More specifically, the Three Muses called to us, and we are *so* glad that we answered.

This restaurant is the love child of a great jazz club, a bar and a tapas-ish restaurant. But oh does it work ... the ambiance is superb, the service is spot-on and the food. Oh, the food.

Don't be put off by the smallish plates of food. Everything we had was rich and flavorful and filling, and it was easy to make a succulent meal out of two or three dishes.

We'll be back. I promise.
Stopped in again, this time for hot chocolate. Still ever soooooo slow to get the drink. There was only one other couple in the shop and they already had their ice cream before I ordered.

My husband and I came here with his coworkers as a pre dinner drink party. The place was really cool inside. We all stood around the bar, which was a nice setup. The bartenders were amazingly nice and quick to refill drinks, place orders, etc. The guacamole, chips and salsa were good. The margaritas were excellent but strong. I would love to come back if I'm in the area.

A heavy metal burger bar, what more could one need? 
Kuma's Corner is in fountain square across the street from revolution.
It's quite the place, I really like it I've been a few times and have never had a bad experience the burgers are hearty and always have something creative put on them, and are named after a heavy metal band. They also have monthly burger specials as well.
This time around I decided to go because they were carrying a beer from central state, called polyjuice potion and I'm a huge Harry Potter fan, and I couldn't resist going to try it.
I can check that beer off my list, which I'm happy I did! It's a refreshing sour. You shouldn't drink on an empty stomach in the name of responsible adult decisions so i also had the bbq chicken fries and  they were so delicious with savory bbq chicken, onions and cheese. Kuma's never disappoints!

Horrible food and service! Never again! Worst dining experience ever. 

Had a 70+ year old woman waiting on us, which is fine except for the fact that it took 10 minutes for us to be seen. Did not bring us water without us having to request it first. 

Food was horrendous (we're suffering through stomach cramps now). The only blessing was that she understood our request to leave by a certain time and accommodated us. 

Hovered over us when presented with the check. 

Stay away!!!!!!! Was hoodwinked when I saw this place hopping during happy hour - but that's the outside patio area. Who knows - drinks might be decent.

I did not go to Brio for a full sit down meal as I am not a huge fan of chain restaurants.  I went here for happy hour with a bunch of coworkers, and must say it was a fabulous experience.  
The drinks aren't exactly the cheapest in town but for $5 a pop they offer a pretty good selection.  The sangria was very delicious, and the mojitos looked great.  The real hit of the night were the appetizers.  For $3.95 you can choose from a great list of tasty food like ravioli, cheeseburgers, flatbreads, etc. I'd go here every night from 4-7pm if I could.
The service was great, the bar area cozy, the drinks tasty and the food cheap and plentiful.  All in all a solid happy hour experience.

Heaven. Sugar heaven. I decided go big or go home so ordered the gelato po-boy. See picture - amazing! I literally had people staring at it in awe and envy (likely also wondering how a girl like myself was going to eat it all). It's literally three scoops of gelato I'm a yummy sweet bread sammy covered in chocolate. Man it was good! This place had beautiful items to purchase. I'm glad I walked over to sucre as it was worth the diabetes.

It is unusual I am even writing this review, as normally I steer clear of donuts and the like. It's not that I do not like them.., I just do not love them enough to eat them. 

The request for a donut definitely did not come from me, but when my hubby asked me to find him some it became obvious that Long's was the place to be in Indy. Via Yelp we were warned about long lines out the door but we were skeptical. Lines? For a donut? On a Sunday?

No fail and no kidding when we arrived line was out the door, and mind you this was a chilly morning in March. The kind of morning where it is too damn cold to be outside, let alone be outside to wait for anything in line. Luckily, the line seems to move quickly but when you reach the warm inside of the bakery you get hit with a surprise. A snaking line reminiscent of Cedar Point roller coaster queues will have you stand around wondering what even possessed you to come here in the first place. 

On the brightside, if you are the least bit organized you will be ready to go and know exactly what you want when it comes time to place your order. If you are unlucky you will stand in line behind someone like me who gets instantly bugeyed and gummy brained at the idea of ordering anything. 

We opted for a good mix of different types of donuts.. you know, for research purposes. Maple dipped cake, caramel nut yeast, chocolate dipped yeast, powdered yeast, chocolate cake and cinnamon twists were snuggling together in the box amongst a few others which I cannot recall. 

The best by far is the chocolate dipped yeast donut. Light and fluffy with a GREAT chocolate glaze. The glaze is not overly sweet, and contrary to most chocolate dipped donuts out there it has a deep chocolate flavor. So, so good! Another favorite was the caramel nut yeast donut. A gooey and sweet caramel glaze with chopped peanuts gave a wonderful texture to the donut.

I was a little apprehensive about the cinnamon twist as I was not sure what to expect. Cinnamon flavored items are hit or miss for me, as most of the time the cinnamon tastes artificial to me. This however was a great donut/pastry. What made it stand out was the type of sugar used in the coating, it is slightly coarser and therefore creates a good crunch on the outside. 

I will absolutely order the chocolate dipped yeast donuts again, as well as a close second favorite which were the caramel nut yeast donuts. I am not a big fan of their cake donuts, the batter is too bland for my taste and the consistency seems slightly off from your typical cake donut. They are almost too 'light' and not quite cakey enough in my opinion. 

What is really, really odd and confusing is the pricing structure at Long's. Dipped donuts are priced differently than non-dipped, cake donut prices vary also from eachother as well as from yeast donuts. Ordering a true mixed dozen becomes a matter of them ringing up each donut seperately which seems way too complicated. But who am I?

Either way, kudos to Long's! Any business longs (see what I did there!?) for a dedicated following, and judging by the lines, Yelp reviews and the fact that they operate out of two bakeries I think they have accomplished just that.

[CASH ONLY]

It's a build your own meal Mediterranean style. I arrived 11:30 and half hour later more customers came in.

Service was quick. You can have grain, greens or half grain half greens.

Spread: Hummus is the best compared to other options. My second favorite is roasted red pepper. The egg plant has weird taste. I thought it will taste like baba ganoush. It's not even close to it. I asked my spread to be on the side and it was not a lot. It's like a drop not a dollop. That's why I took a star down. Another reason for 4 instead of five stars is because the pita wasn't warm at all. It's an okay pita.

The roasted veggie was perfectly cooked and had balanced flavor. It's still has crunchiness. 

Download the app for points and advanced orders and easy payments.

The container is environmentally friendly. You can buy hummus there. 

The website has nutritional calculator for your customized order.

Being in Reno for the weekend, we just doing think its realistic to always eat at the hotel.  So we SOMETIMES go out to eat at places like Chipotle.  This was like a typical Chipotle establishment.  The only difference would be that the line was located to the left side of the room.  Which was not typical for me.  Everything looks the same as any Chipotle except the line.

When it was my turn to order, they told me they didnt have chicken.  They asked if I could wait or change my order.  They said I would be waiting for 15 minutes.  I decided to wait because I didnt feel like eating beef at the time.  So I WAITED.

They were right.  It was done in 15 minutes. They even serviced me first once the chicken was done.  The only thing that bothered me was that before they told me when the chicken wasnt ready, they already added beans, rice in the tortilla for my burrito.  WHICH is the result when chicken was done...they still used the same tortilla with the beans and rice.  My Tortilla ended up soggy.  Bad bad bad!

Oh well.  Sucks for me right?

If could give no stars I would and I hate giving bad reviews. The 2 armed police at each entrance should have been a clear warning to drive a mile up to the non sketchy schnucks but I digress.  After seeing 2 woman fight over the last sprinkled unfilled long john and witness 3 cops having to break them up I kindly put my doughnuts back not worth getting stabbed. Do yourself a favor and drive to Hampton. Never again!!

Since the 70's, I've been a frequent visitor to New Orleans, flying in to fish the lakes, marsh and bayous south of the City by day, and to hear music, eat and gamble at night. The trips, though fun, can be exhausting, so over time I've found efficiencies in the way I move through my weekend-long debauches.

One such convenience is a stop at Butcher, the Donald Link-owned lunch counter-cum-charcuterie next door to his restaurant, Cochon. 

At the end of a trip, I drop my rental at Hertz, then walk two blocks to Butcher, where I buy something for the plane and something for the house. Thence to Harrah's hotel, the airport and home.

"Something for the plane" has included such delicacies as: 

- Le Pig Mac, which is delicious, and is, as the menu says: "2 all Pork Patties, Special Sauce, Lettuce, Cheese, Pickle, Onion on Sesame Bun"
- Pork Belly with Mint and Cucumber on White, a misleadingly straightforward description of a solid pseudo-souvlaki
- Duck Pastrami Sliders, which I think about when I'm on the plane, flying TO New Orleans.

People complain sometimes that these sandwiches are small. I'll grant that they're not foods built to serve gluttony. Butcher's lunch offerings serve a higher purpose - evocation - and should be savored with calm appreciation. If that requires more patience than the diner can muster, he's well-advised to buy two.

"Something for the house" is often whole breasts of Duck Pastrami. Butcher's team applies a brown sugar and salt brine to the duck, letting it brine for a week, before drying and smoking it at 140 degrees. After the smoke, the breasts hang for 10 days to let them dry.* 

Describing the result is a challenge. "Rich, but not too rich." "Touched with salt, but not distractingly so." "Smoked, but not smoky." "Succulent, if juiceless meat can be called that." 

Perhaps the better way to relate the characteristics of Butcher's Duck Pastrami is to say how I've used it:

I brought two breasts home with me just before Thanksgiving. It was my turn to prepare appetizers for the big meal, so I barbecued oysters over a hickory fire, topping them with parmesan, butter, lemon, parsley, garlic and translucent shavings of Butcher's Duck Pastrami.

The next morning, having duck left in the fridge, I whipped up a Hollandaise and served our houseguests Duck Pastrami Eggs Benedict. 

And finally, on Sunday morning, I diced the remaining duck with Yukon Golds, Red Garnet Yams and a few bits of fried leek (thanks, Tractor Room...) and voila! Duck Hash.

I won't say that Butcher's Duck Pastrami has made me a better cook, but having such a special resource available compels me to think through my plan, so as to do the Butcher team justice.
