This place is located in a busy shopping plaza with a Starbucks but the parking lot is pretty large. The restaurant itself is not too large so come early. They some happy hour food and drink specials. Overall the sushi here is average to slightly above average for its price. I think people come here for the convenience more than anything. Would not go out my way to come back here.

Cute coffee shop alert! They have a good amount of outlets and I'm glad this opened so close to campus. The atmosphere is clean and modern with nice wooden panels along the walls. Note that you do order at the counter where you pick up your order from another part of the counter too.

I ordered the cappuccino, the green tea waffle, and the mushroom sandwich. The cappuccino was decent (maybe a little bit too watered down) but with the waffle was definitely a great pairing.

I would not recommend getting their sandwiches..it's not worth your money. It's pricey and doesn't taste especially good..if you're looking for convenience, sure. 

Overall, Cafe Benne is a good place to get some work done and enjoy a simple cup of coffee. I actually came to catch up with a friend so of course that works too!

Vino Volo at the Philadelphia Airport has an excellent selection of wines and pretty decent food. For snacks, the olives and flavored almonds are an excellent complement to a glass of wine. For dinner, I had the Tuscan Chicken sandwich which consisted of herb roasted chicken served with this red pepper aioli on Ciabatta bread. This was pretty legit for airport food. I will most likely be back next time I am at the Philly Airport.

Tiffin is a pretty good place.

I've had the vegetable samosas, chicken tikka masala, chicken tandoor, vegetables tandoor, and navratan korma.

One of Tiffin's biggest advantages is that they will deliver in places where other delivery drivers avoid.  It seems that you can't live too far north of Market or too west of Broad for them to include you in their radius.

Everything I've had here satisfies on a level comparable to that of other Indian places in town.  While the chicken tikka masala is a little bit more boring than other places(other places will throw in a lot more onions, peppers, sliced tomatoes etc. in the dish), it still did its job(which was to satisfy me and then make me want to take a nap for 2 hours).

The vegetable samosas are not the best, but they are counteracted by a very tasty veggie tandoor dish.  The navratan korma is pretty darn good and will satisfy the vegetarian within you(or physically apart from you).  

This review would have been 3 stars but the great delivery radius bumped them up a notch.

I was driving in the Upper Darby area last week and I came across a small restaurant with a big sign saying "The Falafelhouse". Falafel Is one of my favorite foods and I just had to stop and try this spot out.
There are many different ways of making Falafel,  and this was the most unique way I've ever tried.  Every country or region prepare the Falafel sandwich different and The Falafelhouse's version had all of the traditional ingredients with a twist. The Falafel was freshly made in front of me, fried, smashed on a flour tortilla wrap, then she added fresh veggies,  sauce and spices.  She then rolled it up just like a burrito. The cook said it was the way they made it in the region or Lebanon from where she was born.
It was delicious but I tasted a flavor I had never experienced in any other Falafel sandwich before,  but I just couldn't put my finger on it.  I asked the young lady about the spice that I was tasting and she couldn't tell me anything, apparently the Chef made all the ingredients and she just put them together. If I was going to guess what it was, I think it was cinnamon. 
 To sum it up the food was good the service was okay ( hey family operation where children were the servers), but the only bad thing was that the place was not as clean as I would like it. So the kid that spend all his time on the laptop computer needed To be sentenced to some serious KP duties.

This is a pretty neat little place.  The menu is really creative.  I love the variations of lil noshes and larger entrees.

We had a couple of the house sodas.  The ginger one was crazy strong and I may have had a loud overreaction to it.  I'm sorry about that, but it was seriously like someone squeezed a ginger knob directly on my tongue.  

It takes a lot time, but they did a good job of spacing out the meal and gave us some hot nuts to nibble on.  

Amelia's bread is just wonderful, of course.  The salads were fresh and delicious.

Every single entree that hit our table was a rockstar.  

... and thank you, Bluebeard, for embracing the chicken liver.  It's about goddamn time.

Perks of this location: Target next door and Starbucks in the parking lot, but most important, this location is usually not too crowded so you get in and out very quick. Also, because it usually not too crowded, this location is usually well stocked. 

Publix generally has amazing deli meats and amazing fried chicken. I will also swear by their kitty litter and ginger ale.

This location is a bit older, but it is currently the location I frequent most often for big full out grocery trips. The Dale Mabry location is slightly more convenient, but the crowded parking lot if very frustrating to me.

I love Publix. It is a premier grocery store. I laugh to think about how much Publix stands apart from the Kroger chains I am used to from growing up in Michigan. The best part is that not only does Publix have a great selection of groceries, they also have the best subs around!

My colleagues have not been steering me wrong with Tucson eateries.
Rocco's stuffed pizza was so good.  But heavy.  I couldn't even get through half of my 9 inch pie, and I'm a good pizza eater.  But leftover pizza is a good thing.

The pizza is very, very strong on the garlic, which was delicious while I was eating it, but I didn't enjoy when I had to smell myself later in the evening.

I have it from a reliable source that Rocco's has the best vegan pizza in Tucson.  I didn't verify this, because their vegan pizza had mushrooms on it, which I can't abide.

Returned to shake shack recently and it was better than i remembered. Burger was good, a bit greasy. Shake was delicious. Pretty inexpensive and quick.
Super friendly staff.

Harvest has all the things I look for in a restaurant but after dining here with friends I'm not sure I want to go back.   The farm to table concept is great and the healthy 500 calorie or less meals are good for the waistline.  The beer selection is lacking but not terrible.  This restaurant is focused on wine so I didn't expect them to have a diverse selection.

Our server was attentive and knew the menu well.  After taking our drink orders we ordered the Harvest & Spicy Sausage Flat Breads and the Mussels.  In addition to these apps I ordered a small salad.

Our appetizers & my salad came out quickly.  The Flat Bread's were much larger then I thought they would be and we enjoyed both of them.  Although my salad was simple it was the perfect size and I really enjoyed the dressing.

For dinner we had the fish special and short rib entree's.  Everyone enjoyed their meals.  The portions are small but they need to be to stay under 500 calories.  Since we were not full from dinner some of us tried their dessert cups.  I thought there were a nice finish to the meal and they were only $3-$4 each.

Although the food was good for $100 a couple I left very underwhelmed.  I don't mind spending money on food but it needs to live up to the price.  There are so many good restaurants around these days you can get good food anywhere.  The food needs to be great to stand out and Harvest didn't do that for me.

I wasn't sure if we'd been here before,  until I remembered the good customer service they provided...

  ...and the patience they displayed while we decided what to order! We did order a nice portion of delicious fast food for five
(say THAT five times fast!), and it arrived at our table in a timely manner.  

Social Distancing and cleanliness of the store ruled the day. The drive thru looked to be steady busy, not surprising...this Culver's is worth the wait. 

Recommended!

Burger Theory is just okay in my book.  We were seated immediately and our drink orders were taken. I ordered the farm burger (I think that's what it was called). I was asked about the cook I wanted on both my meat (medium, please) as well as my egg (over-easy).  I also upgraded to onion rings instead of the standard fries. 

When my food arrived, my burger was well-done. The egg was cooked perfectly. I don't like to waste food, so I just ate it. Our server never really did ask how it was anyway.  The onion rings were breaded (I prefer battered) and definitely weren't anything special. That was another bummer. 

Our server was okay. She wasn't very personable, and she didn't seem to be enjoying her job. She kept our drinks full, but that was pretty much the extent of our interaction. 

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this place.  The food and service stunk.

Awesome meeting spaces available here! There are rooms that overlook the Eskimo's field, so if you need to book a meeting room, this place offers a great atmosphere. I organized a meeting for 70 people. It was super easy to book, competitive rates, and there are no restrictions when it comes to bringing in outside food. Some places make you use preferred caterers, but not here. 

Warning though, the rooms can feel like a maze to find, so make sure your guests have great instructions. I rented room 205/206. I suggest renting your own projector screen as they have a smart board that is very small for the size of the room. There is plenty of free parking.

Check out their website for pictures of the rooms.

I have to give this place photo department its props. Best one to go to to have your photo developed and very quick service to. The guy was so awesome.  He took his time with me, made sure he helped me with my photos and tried to get 172 (4×6) and 2 (8×7) in a matter of 15 minutes. He was so awesome and patient with me and I really appreciates good  customer service. Also I paid good price for them as well. Everything worked out find he really saved the day. I have my Walgreen customer reward card as well to collect my points so I'm a happy camper!!

This store reminds me of the old corner grocery store. It even smelLs like that. 
We're visitIng so I stopped in to grab some basic grocery's to start with. Wine, bread, cheese, bananas, flavored water, coffee & filters, etc. They had everything I needed albeit maybe not the brands I was looking for.  It is well organized so it easy to find everything.

It's close to our AirBNB so I know I'll be back.
At the end of my trip I had tried Gumbo, Jambalaya, etoufee, and creole at many places and this place might be the best. Portions were just right.

I wasn't very excited to try a muffuletta but it's just one of those things you have to do when in New Orleans. I'm not a big sandwich eater and I don't like olives or ham (which are the main components of the muffuletta). 

Supposedly, Cochon Butcher beat out the famous Central Grocery for the title of "best muffuletta" so I definitely couldn't miss it. The boyfriend and I arrived on a rainy evening and were the only people in the restaurant. We ordered the muffuletta and their special mac & cheese. I can see why people enjoy the muffuletta here: quality ingredients and perfectly toasted bread. I guess I'm just not a muffuletta fan in general.. The mac & cheese had pancetta and other "fancy" ingredients so I didn't really enjoy it either. I'm a traditionalist and prefer simple mac & cheese -- no truffle oil, lobster, etc. Overall, Cochon Butcher has great meats & cheeses but it's definitely not my style when it comes to dining out.

They said best ham in the world.. I haven't eaten ham everywhere yet..... but it was good.. the sides were ok.. kinda soggy green beans but I think that is the way they were supposed to be just not my style. . EAT A BISCUIT FOR SURE !!

I don't need to think twice about giving Banh Mi So #1 five stars. I haven't been this sure about anything in a long time.

Picture this: After a long trip out of town, I got back to the STL around 9:30pm on a weekday and was starving. No food in the house, grocery store not something I wanted to do, and every place I knew of had already stopped serving food. I scoured my Yelp app and found BMS and called them up to ask them if it was too late to place a to-go order - by this time it was 9:40ish. The kind man who answered the phone told me they actually closed at 9pm but depending on what I wanted, they might be able to make it for me because they still had people there. I read him off what my friend and I were wanting, and he said "okay. Be here in twenty minutes." Can do!

This place was waaaay farther down Grand than I thought it would be. For some reason I pictured it in the middle of all the international places on Grand (Mochi, King & I, Pho Grand, etc.) It was definitely a good two miles or so past there and I felt a little uncomfortable in unfamiliar territory, but that's okay. Parked right outside (literally no one was around) and walked in to a really sweet man waiting there with my food! He was totally relaxed about it and said it was no big deal that they made me the food after hours. So nice and way above and beyond the call of duty.

Quick breakdown of what we ate:
Spring rolls: the sign outside said they were the best in town, and while I don't agree with that, they were very good (just not stuffed the way I like... I was also missing some cilantro.)
Bun Ga Xao (sauteed chicken & onion over vermicelli): tangy and satisfying. Pour that orange sauce they give you all over it. The texture in this one is dynamite. Crunchy, but the noodles underneath are smooth.
Com Chay (vegetarian rice plate): tons of tofu, tons of curry... this one was my favorite.

I cannot WAIT to order more from this place! It's certainly not cheap, but it doesn't break the bank either. Consider Banh Mi So for carryout or dining in when you have the craving for Vietnamese. They're obviously willing to go out of their way for their customers!

Dinner celebrating my friends birthday! By 5:28, they were out of the appetizer special... not good seeing as though they opened at 5pm. Despite all of the hype, I was disappointed by the limited menu. 

Although restaurant week was going on in Philadelphia, I decided to bring a friend to this restaurant for her birthday. We both had the salad verde,  I had the tagliatelli al Limon (which was delicious) while she tried the gnocchi (spinach & Brown butter. While I am not a big gnocchi fan, this was pretty good. We both had the lamb entree. The lamb was good but when ordered and asked for medium well, I was told it could only be prepared one way.. as the chef recommends medium. After being served, the birthday girl was not happy with the redness in her lamb, the waitress so nicely told her they could take it back and cook it more. While I was happy they accommodated my friend, it left me puzzled as to why we were told from the beginning we could not order our meat medium well from the beginning. That encounter left me wondering what the heck was going on. 

Dessert had to be tried for it was her birthday. Once again, we attempted to place an order for a dessert on the menu and we were informed the original dessert we wanted was not available. All and all the experience was ok but I must admit I was a little disappointed.
